HEADLINE: La Difference

BYLINE: By Jim Holt
<BLB>Do the sexes owe their distinguishing traits to culture or biology?; Jim Holt writes about science and philosophy for Lingua Franca and The Wall Street Journal.

 BODY:

THE FIRST SEX
 The Natural Talents of Women
 and How They Are Changing the World.
 By Helen Fisher.
 378 pp. New York:
 Random House. $25.95. 
 Evolution may have given men and women different bodies, but has it given them different minds? We all know from everyday experience that the sexes do not think exactly alike and that they tend to be good at doing different things -- say, reading maps (men) versus reading faces (women). Some social scientists insist that such differences are entirely due to culture. But over the last couple of decades, proponents of evolutionary psychology have been piecing together a case that the mind is naturally sexed. Our male and female forebears faced different evolutionary pressures in their struggle to survive and reproduce on the Pleistocene grasslands, and as a result they have different mental aptitudes and even differently organized brains.
The anthropologist Helen Fisher stands squarely in the evolutionary psychology camp. Nature, she believes, has given men and women distinct talents and brain structures. What is striking about her book "The First Sex" is where she takes this premise.
Whereas Darwin argued that evolution made men the superior sex (since they had to compete by wit and main for those passive reproductive vessels, women), Fisher comes close to making the opposite claim. The female mind surpasses its male counterpart in all sorts of ways, she submits. Women are better than men with language; they are better at contextual, "holistic" thinking and long-term planning; they are better at working cooperatively; they see and hear better, have a keener sense of smell and are more "in touch" with their emotions; they are even "superior performers in bed." All these natural advantages will serve them well in the high-tech economy and culture of the 21st century, Fisher maintains -- which is why "we stand at the doorway of what may become an age of women."
"The First Sex" is an original and often quite enjoyable book, but it must be read with great caution. The quality of Fisher's evidence is uneven, to say the least; it ranges from serious scientific studies to quotations from spokeswomen for professional organizations to articles in New York tabloids. A more serious flaw crops up in Fisher's logic. She freely puts her own speculative interpretations on new scientific findings, lets those interpretations harden into seemingly well-established facts and proceeds to explain these facts by making up a suitable evolutionary story.
Here is an example. The human brain consists of two hemispheres that are somewhat specialized in their functions. Neural scientists have found evidence, as yet quite tentative, that the bridge between the two halves is slightly thicker in women than in men. What does Fisher do with this shaky datum? She leaps to the conclusion that the female brain must be better "connected" or "integrated" than the male brain, and that this enables women to engage in "web thinking," which is superior to the poky "step thinking" of men.
Fisher goes on to explain how web thinking gives women a natural edge in all sorts of contemporary occupations, ranging from planning business strategy to curing illness to solving crimes. Her case would be persuasive if women really were especially gifted at reasoning hypothetically, manipulating contingencies and synthesizing information. But if such an advantage exists, it ought to show up in intelligence testing. And it doesn't. Females do somewhat better on some I.Q. subtests, like verbal fluency and arithmetic calculation. Males do better on others, like quantitative reasoning and spatial relations. When it comes to verbal reasoning and overall cognitive ability there is no detectable difference.
It is a dangerous business trying to draw conclusions about the natural talents of the sexes from the gross anatomy of the male and female brains. Is the female brain really more integrated, as Fisher claims? If so, it would follow that the hemispheres of the male brain are more specialized in their functioning -- and it is such specialization, or lateralization, as brain scientists call it, that distinguishes humans as a species from monkeys and apes.
Happily, "The First Sex" goes well beyond crude brain differences in pursuing its theme. Nature may have made men and women equally good at reasoning, but the sexes do not seem to be equally good at climbing hierarchies of power. Fisher suspects -- quite plausibly -- that this is in part a matter of hormones: "As testosterone and other male hormones contribute to men's drive to reach the top of the business ladder, estrogen most likely contributes to women's drive to take time out to rear their children -- undermining their ability to achieve these high-status jobs." Among the ample evidence she cites for the hormonal hypothesis is a study that found that women who had been subjected to high levels of testosterone in the womb pursued more male-dominated occupations and rose to higher positions.
But if women tend to be less keen than men at clambering up the ladder, they often do a better job when they do end up at the top, especially in politics. Fisher makes a strong argument that an increased female presence in the higher echelons of power will result in better governing. As a nice bit of anecdotal evidence she might have pointed to the Queens of England, who on average have been considerably more distinguished and effective sovereigns than the Kings.
"The First Sex" winds up with a rather rollicking trio of chapters on the "feminization" of sex, romance and marriage. They are stuffed with titillating facts ("Some women can even arouse themselves to orgasm without touching themselves. Only one man in a thousand can achieve an orgasm just by thinking"), and by the end, Fisher's boosterism on behalf of her sex has given way to a vision of equality: "The 21st century may be the first in the modern era to see the sexes work and live as equals -- the way men and women were designed to live."
While as a man I was relieved by the concluding emphasis on parity between the sexes, I wonder whether Fisher isn't still being a little too optimistic. After all, no less a feminist than Lady Violet Bonham Carter admitted that in spite of having devoted her life to the furtherance of women's rights she had come to the conclusion that there were three occupations in which men would always have the edge: hairdressing, dressmaking and cooking.

HEADLINE: I Log On, Therefore I Am

BYLINE: By Geoff Nicholson
<BLB>A first novel about E-mail tackles philosophical conundrums.; Geoff Nicholson's most recent novels are "Bleeding London" and "Flesh Guitar."

 BODY:

THE METAPHYSICAL TOUCH
 By Sylvia Brownrigg.
 390 pp. New York:
 Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $24. 
 THE first problem facing "The Metaphysical Touch" is that in outline it can sound a lot like the movie "You've Got Mail." Two literate, troubled, but essentially decent and likable people meet on the Internet and find that they're granted opportunities for intimacy and self-revelation that the real world denies them. Where Sylvia Brownrigg's first novel diverges -- and, to be fair, it diverges extremely quickly -- is that she's using this premise to conduct a philosophical investigation into the nature of being.
The female half of the couple (and the story is very much hers rather than his) is called Pi, "as in 3.141589, et cetera," we're told, though not until page 377. The male half is called J. D., perhaps as in Salinger, since he's an elusive, absent author whom we never meet except through his writing -- although his actual initials do seem to be J. D.
Pi is a philosophy graduate student. She was writing on "Kant's metaphysics -- on his stark, wisdom-starred vision of what was knowable in the world and what lay beyond the knowable," but lost everything in the 1991 Berkeley-Oakland fire. "Everything" here includes her cat, her books and all the work she'd done on Kant. As she admits, there are people in the world who would dust themselves off and start over again, but she isn't one of them. In fact, she can't even bring herself to step inside a bookshop. So she leaves the disaster and her old life behind, and moves up the coast to Mendocino to stay with the aunt and young cousin of a friend.
A colleague from the university sends her a modem so she can plug into the Net. Initially unconvinced about the joys of cyberspace (like Brownrigg herself, one feels), Pi finds a chat room called "Dickinson 536," as in Emily, and is led to the writing of J. D., who is posting sections of his "Diery," a discursive suicide note that will be completed only if he kills himself.
Pi is hooked and, calling herself Sylvia Plath, enters into a long E-mail relationship with J. D. His E-mails reveal that he's on the road in a rented car, visiting his sister in Baltimore, with California as his final destination. By now he's calling himself Hamlet, for any number of reasons: because he has an absent father; because he's looking for a soul mate, whom he calls his Horatio; and, most obviously, because he spends a lot of time wondering whether to be or not to be.
This E-pistolary exchange makes up about a quarter of the book, and although Brownrigg has very successfully caught that curiously banal, clever-clever, quasi-poetic style that seems to afflict so many inhabitants of cyberspace, I suspect that a lot of readers won't find these communications quite as endearing as the two correspondents do. How many of us would be completely enchanted by E-mails that conclude: "Is there room for this cluttered narrative in your dove-gray computer? I wish I could honor the goodness of your good night with something good of my own. But I hope you'll trust and believe my less poetic warm wishes, sent to you there in the Shangri-La land of your dreaming"?
A romance of sorts develops, but Brownrigg has much bigger things on her mind. We become involved with questions about ontology and epistemology, about absence and presence and where the physical and metaphysical worlds intersect. For one thing, there's the issue of where Pi's thesis was actually located. Was it really in the physical stuff of books, notes and computer disks -- or was it in her head? There are similar questions about J. D. Does he really exist? Is he telling the truth about himself? Is the "Diery" the work of one person or of various hands? Is it anything more than words, words, words? Cyberspace is, after all, a place where narrators can attain new levels of unreliability.
Martha, the friend's young cousin, whose mother has taken Pi into her household, adds to the speculation after Pi begins inventing stories to entertain her. These stories take as their subject a dead cat and dog who exist (if that's the word) as ghosts on the Other Side, yet affect this world by, for instance, making it rain cats and dogs.
Inevitably, everything is ratcheted up somewhat by the fact that we know we're reading a novel, that Brownrigg is the creator of all the texts, all the E-mails, all the philosophical uncertainty. This is done with a merciful lightness of touch.
Precisely as in "You've Got Mail," things come to a head when a meeting is proposed. There's a certain cliffhanger element in all this that deserves not to be spoiled, but suffice it to say that this J. D./Hamlet character turns out to be no Tom Hanks, and that the book's resolution is in itself a philosophical conundrum.
SYLVIA BROWNRIGG'S literary virtues are many. She's witty and smart, and she observes the world with a skeptical though not irredeemably jaundiced eye. Her invocation of Mendocino, "a place of New Age shopping and cosmic seaside revelations," is especially spry.
Her characters are authentic. A very minor one named Xander, who runs a Xerox shop, is beautifully and economically drawn. And if some of the other characters (like Martha, for instance) appear to this reviewer to be insufferable, that's a measure of the extent to which we're free to make up our own minds about them. Brownrigg is also extremely good on her heroine's sex life, which is primarily though not exclusively lesbian. A male reviewer has to be careful here, since the novel mocks men of the "I love lesbianism if you let me watch" school. Suffice it to say that Brownrigg does indeed let us watch, but it never feels voyeuristic.
I think there remains the question of whether this mostly rather domestic narrative can quite bear the philosophical load Brownrigg makes it carry, and there's a good case to be made that the book is about a hundred pages too long. But on balance one accepts the novel's ambitions, which are satisfyingly high and high-minded.
"The Metaphysical Touch" is a serious and intelligently wrought piece of fiction. It is perhaps old-fashioned, or at least unfashionable, in being a novel of ideas, but that is a large part of its appeal and a reason for its success. Meg Ryan won't be starring in the movie version any time soon. 
http://www.nytimes.com

LENGTH: 3490 words

HEADLINE: Instant Company

BYLINE: By Po Bronson; Po Bronson is author of "The Nudist on the Late Shift," a nonfiction book about Silicon Valley.

 BODY:
What were you doing 12 weeks ago?
Twelve weeks ago was Nirav Tolia's last day on a pretty enviable job. He is 27, and in addition to managing the marketing of Yahoo!'s E-commerce properties, he had represented the company on television more than 100 times. Almost nobody leaves Yahoo!, but Nirav Tolia had just heard a really interesting start-up idea from a friend, Naval Ravikant, who had recently left @Home. It took Tolia about one day to decide, and the following morning he resigned. 
 Soon after Tolia's last day at Yahoo! he and Ravikant were joined by one of the highest ranking engineers at Netscape, Ramanathan Guha, who was cooking up an idea very similar to Ravikant's on the back burner of his big brain. By the end of the week, they were five strong. Eleven weeks ago, despite not having a single line of code written or even a paper sketch of the Web site they wanted to build, they got $8 million in seed financing from venture capitalists -- half from Benchmark Capital, which had financed Ebay, and half from August Capital, where Naval Ravikant was camping out as entrepreneur in residence. This gave the start-up what is believed to be one of the highest seed-round valuations ever.
Nine weeks ago, they brought on Lou Montulli and Aleksander Totic, two of the original six founding engineers of Netscape. Eight weeks ago, they moved into a second-floor gabled loft in Mountain View, Calif., and began grinding out 15-hour days, seven days a week -- but of course these guys had done that before.
In a spring when it had started to seem to some Silicon Valley veterans that all the big original ideas were gone, theirs was a lightning rod for talent. The new director of business development, Dion Lim, began to cut deals with other Web sites to import their data feeds. Seven weeks ago, they started hiring category managers. Six weeks ago, it became clear to Guha that enough of the original programming was already done, and he could switch hats from coder to manager. Five weeks ago, their venture capitalist from Benchmark, Bill Gurley, came by the office for his first look-see. He was blown away: "This is, unequivocally, the fastest I have ever seen a start-up move."
Four weeks ago, they began to cut distribution deals; two weeks ago, they settled on their marketing plan, and now, having reached a critical mass of 31 people, they are set to launch their Web site.
In 12 weeks, the amount of time it might take an average person to decide what kind of hedge to plant in the backyard, they built a company from scratch. An instant company, or what is being called in Silicon Valley a "second-generation Web company."
Not so long ago, it seemed incredible that a Web company could be born in a mere two years. But rather than going back to normal, the pace of creation in Silicon Valley now seems to be speeding up even more. Any Web company that starts out today and takes two years to get up and running is likely to be left in the dust.
In first-generation Internet companies, the founder and a few college buddies moved into a garage that they decorated with Nerf guns and green army men. In second-generation Internet companies, the staff coalesces not from friendships but from respect for mutually complementary skill sets. They skip the garage phase, engage two real-estate brokers and make simultaneous bids on three office spaces, hoping one comes through. They move in over the weekend and by Monday have it decorated with Nerf guns and green army men.
In first-generation Internet companies, the staff resigned from monolithic software corporations or took leave of business school or jumped ship on brand-manager positions at Procter & Gamble. Nobody had Internet experience; they learned by making mistakes, of which there were many. The purpose of the Internet was unclear. Now, companies are being formed by staff members who have years of know-how. And they see the Internet, above all, as a place to buy things. Some $301 billion was generated by the Internet economy in 1998, with an annual growth rate over the past four years of 174 percent.
Because of the way high-tech employees are compensated, there are likely to be a great number of second-generation start-ups in the next year. The notorious stock options that add up to so much paper wealth usually take four years to fully vest. For the early movers on the Internet, the four years are coming up. And the golden handcuffs are coming off.
This particular second-generation internet company has managed to recruit top people who were still handcuffed -- what people in the Valley call "the unhirables." Naval Ravikant walked away from what at the time was $4 million worth of unvested @Home stock options. Ramanathan Guha walked away from probably more than $4 million (a figure he is contractually forbidden to confirm) at America Online, which had acquired Netscape. Sabrina Berry's previous employer, CommTouch Software, was planning to go public. Berry walked away from all of her shares in that company. For Lou Montulli to join, he resigned from a hot, well-financed start-up called Geocast Network Systems. At the time Nirav Tolia left Yahoo!, the unvested options he left on the table were worth $10 million.
But, he insisted, it didn't matter to him if it was $20 or $20 million -- he has a dream to pursue.
"People are going to think I'm nuts," said Tolia, rolling his eyes.
"Can we not talk about this anymore?" said Guha. "It's painful to dwell on."
Six weeks ago, the engineering team walked to In-N-Out Burger for lunch. They crossed an overpass above Highway 101 and paused at the rail. "This team has been responsible for many of the key features of Netscape Navigator," Guha said. "These guys can point to any of these cars passing underneath and say: 'That driver has almost certainly used my code. And that driver. And that one.' We want to build something that has that kind of influence. We want to build a site that everyone will use."
So what's the idea that is inspiring so many to jump? Until this week, they've kept everything secret, operating under the code name "Round One." In fact, not even people who come in to interview for a position learn the idea their first day. Several hours of vague conversation seem to be leading up to the grand presentation, but alas, the applicant is sent home with a preliminary offer, setting out salary and options and title -- and no clear sense of what the company will do. If the candidate is sold on the team, then she or he comes back for a second round. Only at the end of that next day does she sit down in front of a whiteboard with Ravikant and Tolia and hear something like this:
As the Web becomes an infinite supply of goods and services, goes the pitch, people crave guidance on what and where to buy. So far, the great number of on-line shopping guides present quantitative, machine-sorted and machine-generated data: comparisons of product prices and specifications. But what consumers need (Ravikant and Tolia contend) is a recommendation that gets beyond that: the advice of someone they trust, someone just like them.
Their solution is a Web site, Epinions.com, which they envision as a sort of Zagat-for-everything, a site consisting entirely of consumer opinions or reviews of anything you can buy. Epinions.com itself will sell nothing at all -- it has no warehouse, no trucks on the back end. The money would come from deals Epinions.com cuts with companies that do sell things: every time an "E-pinion" prompts a reader to click "Buy," the company will earn a tiny commission on the resulting sale.
At the start, the E-pinions on Epinions.com will be culled from existing sources, guiding users through aggregations of expertise from the four corners of the Web. But the key to the whole idea is to make Epinions.com participatory, taking advantage of what I call the Tom Sawyer model. Write and post a short review of any product on Epinions.com, and you can earn a few pennies every time the review is read by another user. By letting readers rate the usefulness of the E-pinions, the most trusted ones will float to the top of every category. As Ebay is a marketplace for products, Epinions.com seeks to be a marketplace for ideas. If it catches on, like Ebay, then everything snowballs, and these hobbyist-reviewers function as sliver-time virtual employees who do all the work for you. "Everybody is an expert at something," they kept repeating around the Epinions.com office; they hope their site will be the place where everyone shares their expertise.
Similar logic has been welling up in the collective unconscious of Silicon Valley, and most E-commerce sites are already adding some form of E-pinion to their Web pages. Productopia, Deja.com, Cnet, Amazon.com -- everyone's hiring editors and bringing back the old-fashioned, well-trusted written word. Of course, sites that both sell goods and review them are subject to criticisms of bias. Epinions.com.com would be the first company to start up doing E-pinions and only E-pinions, hoping to be as Jell-o is to flavored gelatin.
And that's it. Then again, what was Yahoo! at the start but just a Yellow Pages to the Web? The point is that job recruits with demonstrable talent are buying in to give it a go. And they know that in the short and unpredictable history of Internet businesses, success has often come down to getting the details right, fast.
"We don't need any more strategists," says Mike Speiser, a McKinsey consulting alumnus who learned to curtail his own inclination to heady analysis. This was 10 weeks ago.
"We need closers," agrees Nirav Tolia. "We need bulldogs."
"We need engineers who are execution machines," says Guha. "This is not a strategy play. This is an execution play."
First-generation start-ups raise small seed rounds to develop a "proof-of-concept version," at which point the start-up has to go back to dog-and-pony shows, negotiating for more money. Again the second generation is different, faster. Prototypes, demos, alphas -- the language of the hustle -- those words aren't even in the Epinions.com vocabulary. Every minute spent dancing for investors is a minute stolen from the finished product. Ravikant and Tolia's business plan (which consisted of 16 sparse slides) had no financial projections and no budget. They negotiated for $8 million, enough that they wouldn't have to go back for more until well after launch. They had no idea what it would cost to pull together the E-pinions they would need to stock the site, but they budgeted $5 million, just to be safe.
The group's biggest fear was the wrath of prominent venture capitalists who did not get an opportunity for a cut of the deal. A slightly rattled Tolia played me several phone messages left on his answering machine by furious V.C.'s. One of the advantages of combining August Capital and Benchmark is that they occupy the same two-story building. When the terms of the valuation were set with August, Ravikant and Tolia walked upstairs to Bill Gurley's office at Benchmark. Gurley had joined Benchmark only a month before, and Epinions.com would be one of his first big plays for his new employer.
"I need to know if you're in," Tolia said.
Gurley was calm. He recounted some of the internal discussion among the Benchmark partners. One partner, Gurley offered, had scored the idea a 6.5 and the team a 9.5 on a scale of 1 to 10. But he wouldn't tell them details of how the final vote was scored.
"So where does that leave us?" Tolia asked.
"Don't worry, it's done," said Gurley.
"Should I contact your lawyer or something? Draw up term sheets?"
"We don't do term sheets here," Gurley responded, offering his palm. "We do handshakes."
In those first crucial weeks, the Benchmark investment was like having a Hertz Club Gold pass. Every service provider is overbooked in Silicon Valley -- realtors, phone-system installers, furniture suppliers, headhunters. Dropping the Benchmark name was the way to impress vendors without sharing the idea. Everyone wants to do business with what may become the next Ebay, dreaming they'll be rewarded with friends-and-family shares when the time comes.
Of course, they can't do everything. There was that first weekend in their new digs, when the parts for their desks arrived from Home Depot -- 25 solid wood doors, 100 4-by-4 legs and 400 metal braces. Despite this formidable team of engineering talent, in eight hours of off-and-on tinkering they couldn't correctly assemble any desks. Finally they called a carpenter who had done this before, and he started building two desks an hour.
Fortunately, what they don't know about desks, they do know about code. Hiring staff with seasoned Internet experience has allowed Epinions.com to delegate like crazy. "We need to be told what to do but not how to do it," said Luke Knowland, who had done it before at Wired Digital.
"It would take four very bright first-generation engineers a full year to program this site," Guha estimated. "But because we've done it before, we can write most of the code in six weeks."
Everything is faster. Zero drag is optimal. For a while, new applicants would jokingly be asked about their "drag coefficient." Since the office is a full hour's commute from San Francisco, an apartment in the city was a full unit of drag. A spouse? Drag coefficient of one. Kids? A half point per. Then they recognized that such talk, even in jest, could be taken as discriminatory in a hiring situation.
On the business-development side, "I no longer have to waste months evangelizing," says Dion Lim, who has been cutting deals to aggregate opinion material from existing Web sites. A couple of years ago, the process would have been slow and painful. "Now, I just call, and they have a syndication rate scale and a preferred data-feed format," he says.
Meanwhile, Epinions.com has kept up constant reconnaissance on the competitors it will be jockeying with this fall, despite those competitors' best efforts to keep their strategies secret. The Valley has what it calls the "whisper circuit," which is not so much wild gossip as the ability to call in old favors and threaten to pull people's teeth. A lot of whisper-circuit surveillance leaks out the back door of companies through their engineers, who often refuse to lie on principle or are very bad at it when they try.
Through the whisper circuit the company learned that one potential competitor was trying to wiggle out of a partnership so that it could overhaul its product toward something like Epinions.com. The team learned that a top job applicant, on the verge of accepting its offer, had been grilled so hard by another venture capitalist that he cracked and spilled the Epinions.com idea. (The offer was retracted.) Another V.C. was trying to discredit Epinions.com by telling people he'd turned down its deal, which he'd never seen.
And it was on the whisper circuit that the Epinions.com team learned that Amazon.com had started flying writers and editors to Seattle and offering them positions as category editors to cover a wide range of products -- food, video games and so on. The whispering was specific -- that Amazon.com was offering a $65,000 salary, a 10-percent signing bonus and options that could be worth $1 million in four years. (Amazon declines to confirm or deny those details.) The entrance of Amazon.com onto the scene seemed like bad news for Epinions.com. Everyone lost sleep that night.
But their exuberance returned with dawn. "Amazon is supersmart," said Naval, marching out of Benchmark Capital's Sand Hill Road offices with his teammates in tow. "But we're a start-up. We've got focus. Nobody will be able to move as fast as us. I pity the fools!"
"Other than that first night with Amazon, I haven't lost a single hour's sleep over our competition," Nirav Tolia said four weeks ago, when he was only rationing himself four hours a night anyway. "All the sleep I've lost has been over our internal conflicts."
Indeed. By hiring so many bulldogs and execution machines who were all used to being No. 1, Tolia feared the competition between employees would tear the company apart. For the first month, without a product to obsess about, they focused on their responsibilities, and the closest proxy for their responsibilities was their title. That they had given up so much money to be here made them a little testy -- they wanted constant assurance that their career decision wasn't a mistake.
Everyone kept demanding an org chart, preferably with his or her name in a box near the top. In first-generation Web companies, the premise was that no task was beneath you: you did whatever it took to succeed. This wisdom seems not to have been passed down. "How do we go from a team of champions to a championship team?" Tolia kept asking.
Bill Gurley had turned Naval Ravikant on to complexity theory. "Truly alive systems exist only at what is called 'the edge of chaos,"' Ravikant said in one meeting. So though it was causing him to lose hair, he was running the company on the edge of chaos, rallying people to risk making mistakes. "I don't want to be a company that plays it safe." He gave his employees an org chart, and then another one every week. Their titles became vague, more fungible.
Going through the start-up experience usually bonds a team together. There are those occasional "Breakfast Club"-like days when workers' inner lives get revealed to each other. This bedrock of goodwill gets the team through hard times later. Going through it at second-generation speed only allows brief bonding moments. Mike Speiser covered Internet companies as an investment-banking research analyst, but he hadn't worked at one before Epinions.com. A few weeks ago he said: "You know what I miss? I miss those good old days, when we had the run of the place at August Capital, hanging out and brainstorming." Those halcyon days, six weeks earlier.
Nirav Tolia came up with what he thought would be a solution to distract the champions from their fiefdoms. At the all-hands meeting five weeks ago, Tolia announced that he would shave his head if the company met its offical launch date. This is a guy whose E-mail was "the-face@yahoo.com" for a good reason -- a hair is never out of place on his head. "When you're wondering why you're here at 2 in the morning, think about my cue ball," he said.
Everybody howled with laughter. Then Aleksander Totic went over to his computer and pulled up an ancient Web page, from way back in 1994. Digital photographs were posted from the period when the original Netscape engineers shipped Navigator 1.0. There at the top of the page was a picture of Lou Montulli -- who is even more of a sharp dresser than Tolia -- with his head completely shaved. Then everyone really laughed.
"If we're going to be a second-generation Web company, Nirav's going to have to come up with something better," Totic chuckled.
Watching an instant company get built has been slightly disorienting. Silicon Valley is sustained by the myth that you can come here from anywhere with sheer smarts and a firm handshake and make good. Second-generation Internet companies seem to seriously tip the favor to those already here. Four weeks ago on the whisper circuit, Tolia learned that an entrepreneur from Arizona was in town to shop a business plan for a company, called Publicopinion.com, with some of the same basic concepts, like rating reviews. Tolia took the challenge seriously -- Publicopinion.com already had a prototype on line and needed financing to take the next step. But the truth is that if the guy from Arizona is only now trying to get an audience with venture capitalists, he probably doesn't have a chance to catch up.
After Ravikant left @Home, he would still see old colleagues at parties. The comment he heard from them time and time again was: "It's amazing you walked away from all that money. I wish I was brave enough to take the chance."
So why did they walk away from all that money? Take it as a given that they all believe in the commercial viability of the idea, but beyond that, their comments are all over the map. One guy talked blatantly about wanting "plane money," and how you weren't even a player in the Valley with less than $100 million. A few plead that they just want to live the start-up experience, and the money they've earned has bought them the unconditional freedom to pursue that dream.
Now they are at the takeoff point, and their first-generation experience can't help them. The next 12 weeks will be an even greater challenge: the goal now is to turn a brand-new site into a hive, one that has 80 percent of all E-commerce categories covered well in advance of the crucial Christmas buying season. They are blindly gambling that they have the right incentives and the right filtering mechanisms in place. Ready. Fire. Aim.

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
The Caribbean Wonders: Where Are the Tourists?

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
AFTER a slow winter and spring, tourism officials in the Caribbean were hoping for better things for the rest of 1999. The NATO bombing in the Balkans heightened those expectations, on the assumption that many travelers would shun that part of the world and head for the Caribbean.
But Caribbean tourism continues to lag. With the number of tourists to some islands down about 20 percent, hotel occupancy levels are well below those of last year. 
 "Advance bookings for the Caribbean look reasonably good," said Michael Youngman, the executive director of the Caribbean Tourism Organization in New York City, but many tourism officials are somewhat puzzled by the no-shows, especially in view of a strong United States economy and predictions by the Travel Industry Association of America of another record summer travel season.
Some tourism officials in the United States blame rising crime in the region, a series of recent strikes, destruction from Hurricane Georges last fall and increasing competition from resorts in the United States, Mexico and Cuba. Cuba, for example, recently began selling packages combining a vacation on its beaches with a flight to Guatemala to visit Mayan sites and colonial cities.
The Caribbean hotel industry has long blamed the cruise industry for exacerbating the islands' woes, contending that by bringing visitors who stay only a few hours in port, the cruise ships have discouraged longer visits. And during the Caribbean Hotel Association meeting in Nassau, the Bahamas, last month, Ed Malone, the association president, returned to the attack, decrying what he called the islands' aid to the cruise industry.
"We have nothing but admiration for an industry that has succeeded in getting its ships built with subsidies from foreign governments," he said, "sail under flags of convenience and recruit staff from the cheapest, non-unionized labor pools in the world, and then sail the Caribbean in a cruise operator's tax-free heaven. While our governments help keep foreign ship lines afloat, we are sinking on our own shores."
In the past, cruise officials have countered that many cruise passengers later return to the Caribbean on land-based vacations, but this time they mostly ignored the criticism -- perhaps because they have troubles of their own. Cruise fares to the region have been relatively flat this year, averaging less than $100 a day per person including port charges but not air fare. Airlines to the region also cite a slump in passengers and fares.
Financial woes of cruise lines and airlines have long-term implications for tourists. A Carnival Cruise Lines spokesman at the hotel-association conference said that while cruise passengers to the Caribbean have doubled in the last decade, the region's share of the overall cruise business has fallen from about 67 percent in 1989 to slightly more than 50 percent, and so the line will reduce or not add capacity in the region.
A spokesman for American Airlines, the dominant carrier in the Caribbean, said that in part because of lower fares from competitors, its Caribbean profits fell in the first quarter of this year from the comparable period in 1998 and would likely decline further in the second quarter.
But many of those lower fares are still higher, on average, than fares to Cancun, Mexico, or to Europe. In fact, the week of the hotel conference, British Airways and American offered a free round trip to London with each round-trip economy ticket purchased before June 30.
Meanwhile, tourism to Barbados fell 2.5 percent the first quarter of this year, after growing 9.3 percent during the same period last year. Dominican Republic tourism has been battered by lingering effects of Hurricane Georges and a drop in European tourists. And Bermuda, although not in the Caribbean except for purposes of keeping tourism statistics, has also been struggling with sub-par hotel occupancy.
To reverse that, Bermuda is advertising extensively in the United States and Canada. But it got off to a shaky start when a supposed tongue-in-cheek newspaper advertisement suggesting that four days in Bermuda are better than in the Hamptons drew the wrath of Long Island tourism officials. They retaliated with an advertisement saying: "With 1,400 square miles, Long Island's attractions are endless. With 20 square miles, Bermuda's attractions soon end."
Still, some islands appear to have more visitors than last year. Hotel occupancy in Puerto Rico increased 4 percent over the first four months of 1999, compared with the same period in 1998. The Bahamas also seem to be doing better than expected, in large part because of the expansion of the 2,000-room Atlantis Resort and Casino on Paradise Island.
Among the reasons suggested for the Caribbean's slump is that familiarity has bred boredom. And after protests over a gasoline tax led to three days of riots, looting and violence in Jamaica in April, cruise ships and airlines canceled scheduled visits and flights to the island; Jamaican hotels subsequently reported wholesale cancellations.
Caribbean officials acknowledge that some fear remains after a recent series of violent crimes throughout the Caribbean. Although few of the crimes involved tourists (most were drug related), it is hard to dispel the perception of danger, especially when tourists have many other options.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 16; Column 1; Travel Desk

HEADLINE: Where the Trout Jump Onto the Hook

BYLINE: By JAKE MOSHER; JAKE MOSHER, a Montana resident, writes frequently about the outdoors.

 BODY:
THE mountain goats had climbed down the 300-foot rock wall separating Montana from Idaho in the night and now, in the dim light of early morning, they stood at Slagamelt Lake, whiter than the mist rising from the surface. I watched them, three nannies and two kids, until a trout rose between us. When I looked up from the ripples the goats were gone, enveloped in thick fog.
The fish came to my first cast, bending the bamboo rod into a smooth arc and sending a spasm of vibrations up my arm. The three-pound cutthroat, a brightly colored male, fought well. He hung at my feet for several seconds after I released him, then swam for deeper water, the spots on his back blending with the stones on the bottom. 
 I rinsed my hands in the cold water and looked to the east. More than a mile below where I stood in southwest Montana's Bitterroot Range lay the upper Big Hole River Valley. More than 60 miles of river bottom stretched out before me, cut off from the rest of the state by the Bitterroot, Anaconda and Pioneer mountain ranges and interrupted only by canyons of rapids and a handful of frontier-style ranching communities. I had three days to fish, hike and explore this little-visited expanse of Montana back country about 50 miles southwest of Butte last July and already wished for more time.
Slagamelt's outlet, like many of the Big Hole's tributaries, was easy to step across. It tumbled down through a corridor of Engleman spruce trees and granite boulders ranging in size from those of basketballs to small houses. Wherever the water swirled around a fallen tree or bent against the bank, I found aggressive brook trout, sometimes three or four to a pool. The white edging on the brook trouts' fins, the rings of blue haze around their red side spots, and their square orange tails stood in sharp contrast to the rushing whitewater. It was easy fishing and by midmorning, I'd caught and released close to three dozen.
After a few hours, I left the spongy, stream-side moss and hiked through a forest of lodgepole pines and thick-barked Douglas fir. Through a hole in the branches, I watched a golden eagle gliding in circles, slowly moving higher until it became a dark speck against the sky. When I could no longer see it, I leaned forward with my pack and picked up my pace, pushing down from the Bitterroots into the upper Big Hole River Valley.
It was already close to noon, and by the time I reached my truck, the July sun was bearing down and my legs were aching.
Much of the wilderness in the Big Hole Valley comprises Federal Forest Service lands open to the public and bounded by a well-marked network of dirt roads. Most are passable by car, and provide good jumping-off points to mountain lakes like Slagamelt, to scenic meadows and to remote trails traveled far more by deer and elk than by people.
Driving out of the Bitterroot foothills on such a road, I stopped three times to allow small herds of black Angus and white-faced Hereford cows to cross. All over southwest Montana, except for Interstates 90 and 15, cattle have the right of way. They range on Forest Service grazing allotments, moved from pasture to pasture by cowboys.
The entire upper Big Hole Valley is marked by a very precise timber line. Hayfields along the river blend into a rolling prairie of blue-green sage that in turn gives way to Douglas fir and pine. There, the Rocky Mountains seem to shoot straight into the sky.
I rounded a bend and suddenly found myself in the open. Twelve miles ahead, on the eastern edge of the valley, were the heavy forests of the Pioneer Mountains, and to the north the Pintlers in the Anaconda Range, whose jagged, snow-capped peaks looked like giant, prehistoric sharks' teeth. A swath of willows marked the river's path, and the sun was shining off the dozen metal roofs of Jackson. Ready for lunch and a cold glass of water, I was glad to see civilization.
At Rose's Cantina, while my hamburger hissed on the grill, a pair of ranchers discussed the relatively wet June the valley had seen and how, with a bit more rain in August, the perennial threat of drought could be ignored for a season.
An hour later, driving north along the river on Highway 278, through what is known as "the land of 10,000 haystacks," I realized why the ranchers seemed so relieved. For more than a mile on either side of the Big Hole, hay meadows in various stages of cutting spread away from the river, surrounding handsome barns and log cabins, many of which have stood for five generations. Dozens of haystacks, 30-foot cones of loose grass, dotted the landscape, standing exactly where they would when the cows, home from their summer pastures, would tear at their sides in December.
EIGHTEEN miles from Jackson, in the town of Wisdom, I turned west onto Highway 43 and crossed the river. I wanted to visit the Big Hole National Battlefield, where Chief Joseph's Nez Perce Indians, forced out of Idaho and desperately trying to avoid capture by Gen. Oliver O. Howard's troops, held off the soldiers for two days in 1877. As I listened to the taped narrative at the visitor center, hearing of the women and children who were shot down, the soldiers and warriors who fell, it was hard to imagine that this lush creek bottom at the foot of the Pintler Mountains had been the site of such carnage.
I stared at the 12-pounder mountain howitzer employed in the battle, and read the plaque beside it that detailed how its explosive shells operated, and decided I had seen enough. It was getting late in the day, and I didn't want to end it by dwelling on this sore spot of the Big Hole's history. I pointed my truck back toward Wisdom, then northeast, paralleling the river as the valley began to narrow.
Thirty miles from Wisdom, the Big Hole meets the Wise River, and the town by the same name. A handful of outfitters operate out of the one-store community, guiding anglers over some of the most productive trout waters in the west.
Craig Fellin, owner of Big Hole River Outfitters, which includes a group of log guest houses centered around a large main lodge, has been guiding float trips for 16 years. He agreed to guide me on the Big Hole the next day and showed me the cabins, which had hand-hewn beams. Pictures of fish adorned the main lodge, which had a high-ceilinged dining room with views of unbroken wilderness in every direction.
As I had planned before meeting Mr. Fellin, I pitched a tent at a Forest service campground nearby, and I met Mr. Fellin the next morning just as the sun came up. We unloaded his Avon rubber raft on the Wise River, a few hundred yards upstream from its junction with the Big Hole, helped his chocolate Labrador retriever, Kodiak, into the boat, and shoved away from shore.
It was immediately apparent that I was in the hands of a first-rate guide and fisherman, as well a man with a great deal of patience. When my fly fell short of its target, my leader tangled, or I did not cast in time, the most I heard was, "nice try," "here's another spot up ahead," or "good cast."
I hooked my first trout, a small brown, in a backwater where the Wise joins the Big Hole and, since Big Hole River Outfitters operates a strictly catch-and-release business, watched Mr. Fellin let the trout go. We floated down the Big Hole, through rock canyons of rapids, long pools where grass hung over the water and stands of cottonwoods. Over a shore lunch of seafood salad, grilled ginger chicken, banana bread and cherries, our conversation drifted to the places we'd been, those we wished to go, the trout of the day and the trout we had not yet caught.
Through the afternoon, as the water temperature rose toward 70 degrees, the trout grew increasingly sluggish, reluctant to leave the deeper pools for my fly, and I took more time between casts to enjoy the scenery. Floating past the stone abutment of a collapsed bridge, Mr. Fellin explained that a century earlier, a narrow-gauge railway had spanned the Big Hole, its iron tracks providing passage for carts of gold ore mined high in the Pioneers.
He talked of Cowbone Lake in the Bitterroots, named after a hapless rancher who lost his herd through the ice one spring more than 100 years ago, and how legend has it the trout, fed well by beef, grew to immense proportions. As I listened, I reeled in my fly and looked upstream over my shoulder at the snow-capped mountain ranges that seemed to protect this wild and beautiful valley from the rest of the world.
"Why don't you try my rod?" Mr. Fellin suggested as we neared the end of our float. He handed me his Montana-made R. L. Winston, complete with a custom reel seat sporting a colorfully painted brown trout, and pointed to a run between two boulders.
The rainbow trout was on almost as soon as the fly touched down, surging upstream against the current, peeling line from the reel, moving as fast up river as the rapids carried us down. Mr. Fellin nosed the raft into shore, netted the trout, held him for a second for me to admire, then returned him to the Big Hole.
For my final day in the upper Big Hole Valley, Mr. Fellin had arranged for me to accompany a Wise River outfitter, Cliff Page, on a horseback trip into Schultz Lake, 8,500 feet up in the East Pioneers. I met Mr. Page shortly after 8 A.M., and half an hour later, in a Forest Service parking lot on Jacobsen Creek, was introduced to Slick, the 11-year-old gelding that was to carry me over eight miles of trail to Schultz.
For the first time during my stay in the valley, I was leaving my rod behind and traveling light. Schultz sits in a rock bowl at the base of three 10,000-foot peaks, and I was hoping to photograph mountain goats on one of them. Mr. Page slipped Slick's bridle on and asked me to saddle up.
"If the stirrups are too long, your thighs will hurt," he said. "If they're too short, your knees will hurt. But if they're just right, then everything will hurt."
By 10:30, I was well aware that Mr. Page had done a fine job of fitting the stirrups. We rode through meadows dotted with clumps of blue lupines along lower Jacobsen Creek, steep sage hillsides full of the scent of elk and narrow cuts through forests of spruce. A sharp ascent just after noon brought us at last to the blue waters of Schultz Lake.
Mr. Page tied the horses in the shade of a dilapidated cabin he said had belonged to the Schultz family, stressing that they had lived in it year-round for more than a decade near the turn of the century, and this year he had encountered four-and-a-half-foot snow drifts in its yard on June 23. With that thought fueling an if-they-can-do-it-I-can-do-it attitude, I set my sights on the highest peak.
The first hour of climbing was relatively easy. I followed an elk trail up a tongue of timber. Where the trees petered out, boulders, loose gravel and an increased pitch slowed my pace dramatically. The elk trail gave way to mountain goat paths littered with clumps of their winter hair, shed recently for the short alpine summer. Mosquitoes and a hot sun hampered my ascent, but with the story of the Schultz family inspiring me, eventually I crested a ridge a few hundred feet from the summit, where a goat thoroughfare led straight to the top.
Stunted lupines and tiny sprigs of pink fireweed carpeted the summit, lending brilliant color to the gray stone. Less than 50 feet from the top, seven mountain goats stood up from their beds, and I was able to shoot a roll of film before they left.
Above me was a great blue emptiness, and below stretched the upper Big Hole drainage, devoid of any trace of humans. The hay meadows near Jackson were little more than green smudges below the blue forests of the Bitterroots. I closed my eyes and felt once more as if I were floating down the Big Hole, a rod bent double in my hands as a rainbow trout ran hard against the current.
 
Plenty of room for man and beast
 
Getting There
To get to Montana's upper Big Hole River Valley from the east or west, take Interstate 90 to Exit 219, west of Butte, then Interstate 15 south for 16 miles to Exit 121 at Divide. Highway 43, a well-maintained two-lane road, parallels the Big Hole from Divide west to Wisdom, and Highway 278 continues along the river to Jackson.
Much of the country in the Big Hole Valley is National Forest Service land open to the public. The service operates four primitive campgrounds within 10 miles of Wise River, with sites costing $8 a night. To obtain maps, guides to campgrounds, information on scenic drives and fish directories, contact the Wise River ranger station, on Highway 43, Monday through Friday from 8 A.M. to 4:30 P.M., (406) 832-3178.
 
What to Do
Nonresident fishing licenses, available from fly shops or general stores in the area, cost $15 for two days, or $50 for a year. For more information, contact the Montana Fish, Wildlife and Parks Department, (406) 444-2535, or see www.fwp.state.mt.us.
Big Hole River Outfitters, eight miles south of Wise River on Route 73, offers float trips on the Big Hole and horseback trips to mountain lakes. The company has room for 10 guests in three rustic but comfortably furnished cabins that sit a stone's throw from the Wise River. Anglers can take advantage of fishing on three rivers as well as private ponds. The fishing season typically runs from early June through early October, and a six-day, five-night package costs $2,250 a person, double occupancy, including three family-style meals and guide. Information: Frontiers International, Post Office Box 959, Wexford, Pa. 15090-0959; (800) 245-1950.
Troutfitters, two miles west of Wise River on Highway 43, has been floating anglers down the Big Hole for 18 years. Three full-time guides offer day trips for $310 for two people. The fishing is strictly catch and release. Two guesthouses with room for eight are available, $120 a night for two, $160 for four. Reservations: (406) 832-3212.
Big Hole National Battlefield, where Nez Perce Indians battled soldiers for two days in 1877, lies 10 miles west of Wisdom on Highway 43. It has a visitor center, gift shop and two trails to historic spots. In summer, the visitor center is open 8:30 A.M. to 6 P.M. daily. Entrance costs $4 a car or $2 a person; (406) 689-3155.
 
Where to Stay and Eat
The Wise River Club, in the center of Wise River, offers cabins for $45 a night, motel rooms for $30 and an RV park with 12 spaces for $15. Three meals a day are available in their casual restaurant, specializing in local beef, and there is a full bar. Reservations: (406) 832-3258.
Halfway between Wise River and Wisdom, the Sundance Lodge has a eight rooms in the main house and in five small simple cabins with electric heat and bathrooms with showers; some have wood stoves. Room rates start at $69 a night for two people and go to $473 for six nights. Home-cooked meals can be bought in the dining room. Horseback riding is offered for $15 an hour or $75 a day. Reservations should be made early, and a deposit is required; (406) 689-3611.
On Highway 43 in Wisdom, the Nez Perce Motel has eight typical economy-type rooms for $44.20 for a double and $35 for a single. Fishing licenses can be purchased at the motel, and reservations can be made by calling (406) 689-3254.

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 7-11-99;
Land of the Free Market

BYLINE: By Michael Pollan; Michael Pollan is a contributing writer for the magazine. His last article was about his childhood home.

 BODY:
I live just beyond the dilating fringe of the New York metropolitan area, in the kind of place that was called "the country" until a few years ago. That's when the ratio of urban refugees to farmers shifted in a way that made that designation feel self-conscious, so people began calling it "the exurbs," a word formerly used only by urban theorists. The place still looks the same, with lots of forests and fields outlined by old stone walls, but you sense it's been brought under the cultural and economic jurisdiction of Manhattan. How can you tell? The quality of the coffee has suddenly gotten much better.
I quite like living in the exurbs, and while I hope this fine form of civilization -- this late-20th-century cross of countryside and latte -- will last indefinitely, I've always assumed that it won't, that my town will eventually succumb to the ineluctable, almost geologic forces of sprawl. There didn't seem much anyone could do about it, at least nothing that didn't feel selfish or elitist or hypocritical, not to mention perfectly futile. But that was before the Clinton Administration made "quality of life" a fit subject for national politics, and Vice President Gore kicked off his campaign talking, of all things, about sprawl. 
 The sprawl threatening the quality of this particular life is massed somewhere to the south of where I live, and I recently took a drive down Route 7 in search of its current frontier. I had only driven 15 miles, through the cornfields and pastures strung along the Housatonic River, before encountering a new townhouse development just north of New Milford. I recognized it as sprawl because it has one of those sad picturesque names ("Twin Oaks") that memorialize whatever feature of the local landscape has just been obliterated.
As I continued south, the big maples gave way to even bigger signs, the traffic thickened and the franchises began reiterating themselves every five miles or so, the only indication that I'd left one town and entered another. I tried to decide what it meant -- was it ridiculous or significant? -- for a Presidential candidate to declare that the sorry state of this landscape (even this traffic!) was the nation's business. "In too many places across America," Vice President Gore had said in a January speech laying out his Livability Agenda, "the beauty of local vistas has been degraded by decades of ill-planned and ill-coordinated development." The agenda itself was so Clintonian in its modesty (a thimble of money for buying open land, a minor rejiggering of Federal highway spending, some funds to encourage "smart growth") that I initially dismissed it as the urban-planning equivalent of school uniforms.
But the response to Gore's initiative has been so vociferous as to make me think again. The free-market think tanks spewed forth studies arguing that sprawl doesn't really exist or that, if it does, it's exactly what Americans want. George Will detected in the antisprawl movement an echo of 60's disdain for middle-class consumer culture. A high-ranking official of the National Association of Homebuilders issued a threat to any politician who dared get in the industry's way.
As I thought more about it, I realized that George Will may actually be on to something. For by elevating "livability" to a national issue, the Vice President has put a new spin on two legacies of the 60's that the right thought had been safely disposed of a long time ago. One of these is the conviction that "the personal is political." The other is the habit of questioning the wisdom and sovereignty of the free market. Rub these two supposedly discredited ideas together, and you can generate some surprising political heat.
This Administration's quality-of-life issues -- a rubric that embraces everything from family leave and the V-chip to traffic congestion, movie violence and smoking -- are often derided in the media as examples of small-bore, middle-class, "feminized" politics. Yet the very act of injecting such personal matters into national political discourse draws the middle class, unawares, into a conversation about capitalism that is anything but trivial. For implicit in that conversation is the notion that the free market need not have the last word on the state of the American landscape or public health or even popular culture. In a remarkable feat of political jujitsu, Clinton and Gore have taken the right's own emphasis on "values" and turned it into a middle-class critique of consumer capitalism.
Conservatives like to argue that, with sprawl, the free market has given Americans exactly what their spending decisions say they want. And yet many of us -- or maybe I should say some part of most of us -- are dismayed by the landscape and traffic that our own dollars and desires have wrought. That's why it is possible both to deplore the arrival of a new Home Depot in my area and also to shop there.
The right would have you believe that the real me, the only one that finally matters, is the shopping me -- the consumer; the deploring me should be dismissed as a sentimentalist or elitist or hypocrite. Until now, that's been the general view on sprawl, one I've bought into myself. But it overlooks a complicated truth about modern life that conservatives would have us forget. It is that although we are consumers, we are not only consumers, but parents and neighbors and citizens too. The sort of world we bring into being with our dollars does not necessarily match the world we would vote for with our hearts, and one of the things politics is good for is to help us bring those worlds into a more pleasing alignment. What a radical idea.

LENGTH: 648 words

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 7-11-99: Salient Facts: Contaminated Seafood;
Sea Sickness

BYLINE: By Andy Newman 

 BODY:
WAITER, HOW'S THE VIBRIO VULNIFICUS TODAY?
With months containing the letter R on seasonal hiatus, this is the time of year when many wary diners -- especially those with compromised immune systems or livers -- steer clear of raw shellfish and the health hazards that warm weather tends to heighten. The best-known hazard is oysters, which in summer are especially vulnerable to Vibrio vulnificus, a bacterial disease that flourishes in warm waters and kills 10 to 15 liver patients a year. But that's only one of a tankful of marine pathogens. Together they cause well over 100,000 cases of food poisoning annually in the United States (though billions of servings of seafood are safely consumed). And of those, many are a year-round presence.
 
WHAT ELSE MIGHT BE LURKING IN MY PLATEAU DE FRUITS DE MER?
There's Vibrio parahemolyticus, rarely fatal, but "an equal-opportunity gut-wrencher," in the words of George P. Hoskin, a marine biologist with the Food and Drug Administration. The Norwalk virus is a relatively common risk in oysters harvested from sewage-tainted waters. (In January 1997, a Louisiana oysterman who was himself suffering from the virus dumped his sewage into the very waters he was fishing and sickened 432 people in five states.) And amnesiac shellfish poisoning, which is less common, causes short-term memory loss, facial grimace, disorientation and coma.
 
ON SECOND THOUGHT, HOW'S THE FISH?
Don't ask. If members in the scombroid family, like tuna and mackerel, are not kept ice-cold, bacteria can break amino acids down into histamine, causing itching, hives, swelling of the throat or nausea in those who eat them. Reef-dwelling fish, like grouper or barracuda, that have consumed toxic plankton can contain ciguetera, a neurotoxin that can leave diners with years of joint pain, pins and needles or the always-jarring confusion between hot sensations and cold. After that, there are any number of rarer threats like tapeworm larvae, hepatitis and mad-fish disease, which causes fever and shaking.
 
HOW PREVALENT ARE THESE ILLNESSES?
By far the most common is the Norwalk virus, which the F.D.A. blames for about 100,000 of the 113,000 cases of seafood poisoning reported a year. Scombroid poisoning, the next-leading contaminant, hits about 8,000 Americans a year (and in 1997 sickened 26 World Bank employees who ate blue marlin in the company cafeteria), while ciguetera strikes 1,600 people. V. parahemolyticus and Hepatitis A affect about 1,000 people each.
 
HOW CAN YOU SPOT TOXIC SEAFOOD?
You can't, for the most part. The major seafood-borne illnesses don't change the appearance or taste of seafood at all, and seafood that looks, smells or tastes off is not necessarily ambulance bait. Seafood that has been cooked thoroughly is safe from Vibrio and the Norwalk virus (freezing or cooking will kill parasites, too), but heat has no effect on scombroid toxins or ciguetera. Some Gulf oyster suppliers pasteurize their oysters by heating them briefly, which offends purists but dramatically reduces Vibrio. And lemon juice can kill bacteria, but only on those surfaces it touches. Other than that, you take your chances.
 
ISN'T THERE ANY WAY TO BETTER THE ODDS?
Caroline Smith DeWaal, the director of food safety at the Center for Science in the Public Interest in Washington, advises sticking to restaurants or fish stores that know their suppliers and know how the fish has been handled from the time it came out of the water -- as difficult as that sounds. And obviously, seafood is likely to be fresher at places that sell a lot of it.
 
THEN ARE POULTRY AND RED MEAT THE ONLY SAFE BET?
Hardly. "We don't like to get into this contest, quite frankly," Hoskin says, "but on an illnesses-per-pound basis, fish and shellfish are as safe as beef and poultry, and fish are safer than hamburgers." Doughnut, anyone?

HEADLINE: ART / ARCHITECTURE;
Discovering Poetry Even in the Clutter Around the House

BYLINE: By JEFFREY KASTNER; Jeffrey Kastner, a contributing editor of Artnews, writes on cultural topics for The Economist and other publications.

 BODY:
OUR modern lives are replete with stuff, clogged with both the essential and the essentially worthless. Kitchen drawers and bedside tables hide secret ecosystems of hoarded rubber bands, rogue Q-Tips and cryptic plastic widgets whose purpose has long since been forgotten. Left unchecked, these agglomerations grow and spread, becoming small universes unto themselves. For the 30-year-old conceptual artist Sarah Sze, this material profusion presents more than just a housekeeping problem. It's also the rich source for her sprawling found-object installations -- works that celebrate the lyrical potential in clutter, the meaningful relationships that people develop with even the most impersonal trappings of their everyday environments.
Although she has split her time between New York and Berlin in the last year, during the last few months Ms. Sze (pronounced Zee) could be found most days in Brooklyn at her Dumbo studio, preparing for simultaneous high-profile summer exhibitions at Chicago's Museum of Contemporary Art and the Venice Biennale. 
 Looking like a supply depot for an oddball five-and-dime, the artist's small work space serves as a warehouse for the unlikely raw materials she accumulates -- plastic tubing and cotton balls, peanuts, sponges, thread. On a recent visit, it also afforded a glimpse into the extraordinary fate that awaits these ordinary items, as Ms. Sze conducted a tour along the length of a carefully orchestrated cascade of clutter that wound through the middle of the room, a funky landscape of doodads punctuated by plants, lamps and swaying towers of matchsticks, a Plexiglas cube filled with water roiled by an aerator, a length of toilet paper rustling in the breeze of a small fan.
"I'm trying to explore why some things become important to us," says the Boston-born artist, "to take things people are familiar with and invest them with some value and tenderness." If the objects Ms. Sze uses seem unconventional, the way she uses them, she suggests, is not far removed from the traditional formal training in painting and sculpture she received as an undergraduate at Yale. "I think of the whole piece as a canvas," she says, "and the process of building the works as very painterly. It involves a formal understanding of color, movement, edge, composition. It's also painterly in the sense that it's improvisational. You put down a 'mark' and then decide whether or not to keep it, and what's most incidental often turns out to be most exciting."
Ms. Sze's pieces can appear chaotic and ramshackle, but they often entail considerable engineering expertise. At last year's Berlin Biennial, for instance, she devised a system of cantilevers that allowed her to coax a spindly tower of matchsticks and Q-Tips over 20 feet into the air while, near the floor, a complex arrangement of pumps and fans kept several plants watered. And her current piece at the Italian Pavilion in Venice is a delicate arching trail of wires, lamps and toothpicks that swoops from floor to ceiling, a series of camouflaged anchors making it seem to float above viewers' heads like an alien chandelier. "I like the idea of structures that are right at the edge of their capacity to hold together," she says.
Although her Chicago show (which remains on view through Aug. 1) is Ms. Sze's first solo exhibition at an American museum, she has over the last two years become increasingly visible on the international circuit.
Since completing her master's degree at the School of Visual Arts in New York in 1997, she has mounted projects at institutions across Europe, from Greece and Luxembourg to France and Austria. Last summer, at the Institute of Contemporary Arts in London, she filled a gallery with a dizzying array of stuff -- pieces of candy and plastic forks, tea bags, coins, batteries, pasta, straws, pills, pencils -- that climbed up the walls, into the corners and out onto the ceiling.
And over the next few months, Ms. Sze is scheduled to create pieces for a show in Avignon, for the Cartier Foundation in Paris and for her solo debut in New York, planned for September at the Marianne Boesky Gallery in SoHo.
While she continues to build all her pieces improvisationally on location, Ms. Sze's hectic exhibition schedule has led her to begin developing some initial motifs by working on small sections of the constructions before installation begins. Yet even pieces as elaborate as the 15-foot segment she has been fussing over in her studio are completely broken down for shipping and then recreated in often radically different guises in the spaces where they're shown, incorporating local components the artist collects in the given city. Afterward, the works are disassembled and put back in boxes, their constituent parts ready to be used again in another place, and in another way.
"I like the fact that the works are ephemeral and portable," says Ms. Sze as she carefully skirts a tiny colony of pale green Styrofoam chips that marks one boundary of the sprawl, like a pocket of parkland at the edge of a miniature cityscape. "It's a bit like when you move -- you take everything and put it away, and then you take it all out again and reinstall it. It's still all exactly the same stuff, but because it's a different place, it can take on a whole new identity."

HEADLINE: In the Region / New Jersey;
State's Site Standards Upheld, but Debate Continues

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
IN the last decade, builders and municipalities have taken their debate over mandatory statewide residential site-improvement standards from the legislative and regulatory arenas to the courts.
The standards -- governing such matters as street widths, pavement thickness, sidewalks, curbing and sewers -- were challenged by 157 communities and the League of Municipalities, in a suit contending that they infringed on local zoning powers. In May, however, the New Jersey Supreme Court upheld the standards. 
 Before uniform standards were adopted in 1997 -- four years after the state law calling for their creation was passed -- each municipality adopted its own standards, which builders argued drove up construction and housing costs. The goal in unifying the standards, state officials said, was to reduce costs while protecting public health and safety.
"The bad news is that the court did not overturn the standards," said William G. Dressel Jr., executive director of the League of Municipalities. The good news, he added, is that because the court recognized that specific standards could have an adverse affect on local zoning -- and, by extention, the design and character of communities -- a municipality may argue that such a standard is not valid.
Opponents of the state standards are now pursuing a legislative remedy, moving the debate full circle back to the legislature.
The league, which represents most of the state's 566 municipalities as well as homeowner groups, is lobbying for two bills. They would require the Department of Community Affairs, which governs housing and supervises the standards, to amend the regulations to deal only with engineering and construction items, create a range of standards to account for geographical and ecological differences and prohibit intrusion upon local zoning powers and design issues.
Stuart R. Koenig, the lawyer for the league, said the legislation "calls for more flexible standards in the hope of reducing costs." Otherwise "there are sure to be lawsuits" once the housing market turns downward, he said, noting that to many the current regulations "are another bureaucratic process that is rigid and unyielding."
Among the standards opponents of state regulation remained concerned about are those dealing with the widths of roads, the lengths of cul de sacs, the number of required parking spaces and the maintenance of stormwater and retention basins. Charles A. Richmond, assistant commissioner of the Department of Community Affairs, countered that the legislation was unnecessary, adding that the process in place, as the courts found, "deals with those issues, is reasonable and provides predictability and fairness.
"As far as we're concerned the debate is over," he said. "But it will continue because people believe there is an intrusion on home rule, whether or not these standards have a negative or positive impact."
Proponents of the standards say that they are based on widely accepted performance criteria and take into account a town's needs and zoning regulations. They also note that the regulations implementing the standards were devised by an advisory board of state and local officials, planners and engineers that reviews the standards annually and will, if warranted, modify them.
Moreover, proponents of the standards say, the regulations let municipal officials and builders seek a waiver from adhering to any standard shown to jeopardize public health or safety. And they may receive exceptions to do more or less than what the standards require, if the changes are slight and if both sides agree to them, said Mr. Richmond.
Since the 1997 adoption of the regulations, exceptions have been granted to 75 projects, he said, adding, however, that no waivers have been sought or granted.
ONE such project is Heritage Landing, 132 single-family detached homes rising off Whitehead Avenue in South River in Middlesex County. Under the standards the street widths, for example, are 28 feet wide instead of the 30 feet that would have been required, said David Fisher, vice president of land development at Matzel & Mumford of Hazlet, the developer. An exception, he added, also was granted on pavement thickness, going to 5.5 inches over the base surface, rather than the 4.5 required under the standards or the 8 inches the zoning would have allowed.
"We saved a little time because we knew what was expected," Mr. Fisher said. "And we could bring the project to the market sooner, which is important in a competitive market."
Joseph E. Doyle, executive director of New Jersey Planning Officials Inc., contends that there still is no evidence that housing costs are lower as a result of the standards. Rather, he said, taxpayers are contributing to the state's management of the standards.
The problem is not the goal of the original legislation, added Phyllis Matthey, but that in their implementation some of the standards go beyond the intent of the legislation. Ms. Matthey is president of the Coalition of Associations for Political Action, an Edison-based group that represents 90,000 homeowners in condominium, co-op and planned communities and is lobbying for the new legislation.
For instance, said Ms. Matthey, who is a real estate broker, the standards that apply to parking "are unrealistic" for attached-housing communities in the suburbs because they reduce the number of required spaces, which could make such communities "less attractive places to live." The parking issue combined with the narrower streets the standards allow also pose safety risks, she added.
That concerns the New Jersey Fire Prevention and Protection Association, said Robert J. Davidson, the Fire Marshall for South Brunswick and an association member. He noted that the regulations were designed without a fire-safety representative on the advisory board, adding that the association was compiling a report on the standards' impact on safety.
"Not all the standards are bad," Mr. Davidson said, "but some need to be tweaked." As an example, he pointed to the standard allowing parking on both sides of a 30-foot-wide road, which he said hinder the movement of fire and emergency vehicles.
"We already are experiencing problems with planned communities built under the old rules which did not allow parking on both sides of a road," he said. "The new standards exacerbate the problem."
Opponents of the state standards also say that the strong residential market has kept a lid on conflicts over the regulations because developers have been more willing to compromise.
Take for instance Peter Blicher, who heads the state's division of Westrum Pennington L.P in Pennington, a residential developer that has approvals to build 88 homes for buyers age 55 and older off Bunkerhill Road in Lawrenceville. Although Mr. Blicher said the standards "made the process reasonable and predictable," the project has hit a snag.
He said while under the standards the homes, clustered in groups of four, could be served by one sewer line, instead of one line per house, the Lawrenceville-Ewing Sewer Authority is insisting on the latter. Still, he said, he will install the four lines if the state doesn't intervene soon "since I have reservations for 65 of the houses." He said the result could be that $2,000 will be added to the home prices, now in $140,000 to $160,000 range.
Both opponents and proponents of the state standards agree that the standards are not totally being followed and in some cases are being ignored or abused.
"The standards are not doing what was expected and that will become clear when the economy turns sour," said William Dressel, of the League of Municipalities.
Joanne Harkins, director of land use and planning at the New Jersey Builders Association in Plainsboro, disagrees. "Two years is too short a time to say if the standards are accomplishing everything they were expected to achieve, but they are helping."
The standards "are not a silver bullet," but they are gaining acceptance, added Mr. Richmond, of the Department of Community Affairs. "Our concentration is to make people more comfortable with the standards," he said, "so they give us feedback on how to improve them and give the rhetoric a rest."
