HEADLINE: In the Region / Long Island;
As Rents Climb, Co-op Sales and Prices Turn Up

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN
AFTER renting in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, for eight years, Nancy Heiss, who works as a project manager for a Manhattan office furniture company, decided she wanted to buy rather than continue as a tenant.
But with apartments in both Park Slope and Manhattan so expensive, she said, her search brought her to Long Beach, an area where her parents had once lived, and where she has relatives. 

 BODY:
 She found a $120,000 one-bedroom co-op at 600 Shore Road through a local real estate agent, Marilyn Topper, closing on June 16. The 94-unit oceanfront building has an indoor pool. Her apartment has a side view of the ocean and her $600 a month maintenance includes taxes and heat. With mortgage payments, her monthly costs are $1,300, which is $300 less than one-bedroom rentals in Park Slope, she said.
"I had some savings, interest rates were down and I just felt the time was right for me to buy," said the 35-year-old Miss Heiss.
At one time, the Long Island co-op market was almost moribund in some areas, and price increases are still lagging behind those of houses and condominiums.
"The last market to have been lifted up in the suburbs has been the co-op market because buyers feel that condominiums offer them greater flexibility," said Kenneth R. Jacobs, a Manhattan and Yonkers lawyer who is president of the metropolitan area chapter of the Community Associations Institute, a national organization of co-op, condominium and homeowners associations in Alexandria, Va.
Co-op buyers often do not like the idea that boards have so much control, Mr. Jacobs explained.
Owning shares in a cooperative corporation instead of receiving a deed to property is still an alien concept for many suburbanites, said Mark J. Walsh, Consolidated Communities of Long Island, a group representing 75 co-op, condominium and homeowners associations in Suffolk.
"Co-ops have the same pools and amenities as condominiums, the buildings are in good shape, the grounds are nicely kept and they are in good shape financially, but people are still a bit leery of co-ops," he said.
But a turnaround is now being swelled by first-time buyers like Miss Heiss who are tired of pouring money into rent and by older purchasers. For those couples, many of whom are selling their homes at high prices, co-ops offer a way to stay in their communities in a maintenance-free setting that, unlike a rental, has tax advantages.
The revived interest in co-ops began in areas like Great Neck, which has a heavy concentration of apartment houses, but now appears to be affecting sales everywhere as prices of single-family houses and condominiums continue to climb.
"The market started turning around slowly the beginning of the year and it is now really starting to move," said Elaine Nolan, a Hempstead broker, about her area of Mineola and Hempstead.
"Six months ago, we got 3 calls a month for co-op loans; now we are getting 10 to 15 calls," said Richard Shyman, the president of I.M.S. Capital in Melville, a mortgage broker. "Co-ops are viable again and mortgage money is there again."
"Prices are coming back incredibly and we are seeing a lot more action," said Steven J. Greenbaum, director of property management at Mark Greenberg Real Estate in Port Washington, which manages about 40 co-op buildings in Nassau.
FOR a long time, "there was almost no market," said Michael F. Cohen, a Smithtown lawyer who represents 20 co-op complexes in Suffolk. "But the price of co-op apartments is so disproportionate to the cost of homes that people realize they represent a lower-cost alternative and are something they can still afford," he added. "The co-ops I represent have seen sales and prices they have not seen for a number of years."
These observations are echoed by co-op owners. "Nowhere on Long Island is the market comparable to what's happening in Manhattan, but it's definitely picking up after being sluggish for a good number of years," said Michael Herzog, president of the co-op board at the 68-unit Cedarhurst Park in Cedarhurst.
Prices for a one-bedroom apartment in the building have gone up to $85,000 from $60,000 in three years, Mr. Herzog said, and two-bedrooms have risen to $120,000 from $90,000. "We are getting young couples who can't afford a house and who want to own something, and older people selling houses who want to stay in the area," he said.
Raymond J. Ellmer, the co-op board president of the 84-unit Seaview Terrace in Long Beach, said that would-be buyers were calling at the rate of "about five calls a week."
Prices in the building have seen a "tremendous jump" over the last two years, said Mr. Ellmer, a Garden City lawyer. Still, with prices ranging from $80,000 for a studio to $190,000 for a two-bedroom, "the co-ops are reasonably priced for people who have sold a home and want a smaller place and also for young people just starting out," he said. Many young professionals are coming to Long Beach, he added, because of the beach community style of living.
At the Valley Park Estates co-op in Valley Stream, the sponsor, VP Owners in Great Neck, which still owns 130 of the 436 units in the complex, had been renting them out for years because nothing was selling.
Now it has more buyers than empty apartments available, said Jeffrey Bookman, one of the principals. "A year ago, we had no activity," he said. "Now we are selling four to five units a month." With prices for the one- and two-bedroom apartments ranging from $40,000 to $60,000, and monthly rents for the same units ranging from $850 to $1,100, "people realize it's cheaper to own than to rent," Mr. Bookman said, adding he has 20 units under contract.
"The major issue for me was owning something rather than renting," said Lucian Gonzalez, an engineer, recently bought a one-bedroom unit at Valley Park Estates, paying $40,000. With maintenance of a $495, his monthly costs come to only $800, Mr. Gonzalez said. He had been paying $700 a month to rent a studio apartment in Howard Beach, Queens. "I also view my co-op as a steppingstone to eventually purchasing a house," he said.
JOEL GREENBERG, a salesman for a hair products company, and his wife, Diane, who is in real estate sales, moved into the Plaza, a Lawrence co-op, four years ago, after selling a four-bedroom home in North Woodmere. The building is next to a country club with golf and a marina and is a short walk to the train station.
"I lived in a house for 30 years, and I didn't miss the house three minutes," said Mr. Greenberg, now board president at the Plaza, a luxury building with a pool and a doorman where two-bedroom apartments now sell for $250,000 (up, according to Mrs. Greenberg, from $195,000 a year ago).
It is buyers like the Greenbergs who are also fueling the Great Neck market. People are selling large and unwieldy houses to move into a community where amenities, shopping and transportation are all nearby, said Ellen Steinberg-Finkelstein, who specializes in co-op sales at Trylon Realty in Great Neck.
"Years ago, people would sell their houses and rent, but now they want to buy because rentals are too expensive," she added. "My problem is that I don't have enough inventory."
Two of her recent buyers, Doris and Seymour Graylin, came from 34 years of living in a two-family house in Bayside, Queens, moving last week into a two-bedroom co-op in Great Neck, for which they paid $300,000, not counting extensive renovations.
"Never another house," said Mrs. Graylin, 69. Her husband, a retired accountant, is 75. "I don't want to weed the garden anymore or shovel snow," Mrs. Graylin added.
Their new apartment is two blocks from shopping, restaurants and the Long Island Rail Road station "so we won't have to drive so much," she added. "Renting was not an option," she said, "because we wouldn't have any tax benefits."
Prices in Great Neck have been rising, Ms. Steinberg-Finkelstein said. Studios that started at $30,000 two years ago now begin at $55,000. A typical one-bedroom has gone to $175,000 from $142,000, and a two-bedroom to $350,000 from $235,000.
"We are reliving 1985 to 1986 again because, with the decrease in the amount of houses on the market, that leaves co-ops," said Jan Kalman, a real estate agent in Woodmere.
In Roslyn, where small houses start at $250,000 and there is also a shortage of houses for sale, "co-ops are the best alternative if you want to get into a good school district," said Roy Sobel, a local broker. Prices for a one-bedroom start at $60,000, and a two-bedroom recently closed for $79,500, he said.
"Many people can't afford a home, but they want to buy something and so they are buying co-ops," he said.

HEADLINE: Developing an Illinois Suburb, With Principles

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

DATELINE: GRAYSLAKE, Ill.

 BODY:
"COMPACT, transit-oriented development" is how planners say, "a suburb where you can walk to the train station from your house."
A mantra of the anti-sprawl movement, this concept is endorsed by Chicago Metropolis 2020, an influential planning advocacy group headed by George A. Ranney Jr., a lawyer who was formerly president and chief executive of Inland Steel Industries.
Mr. Ranney is not just preaching the concept. He and his wife, Victoria Post Ranney, plan to add a "compact, transit-oriented" town center to Prairie Crossing, their 667-acre development now under construction in this village 40 miles northwest of Chicago. 
 Not only would this town center be an easy walk to a new train station planned on the Metra commuter rail line, it would be laid out on a tight grid of narrow streets, with lots as small as 5,000 square feet. Studio apartments over detached garages would bring an economic mix of residents. And shops, some with dwellings upstairs, would be scaled to neighborhood needs: a bakery, a deli, a general store.
Apostasy, in other words, in the world of conventional suburban subdivisions.
But the five-year-old Prairie Crossing project already breaks so many rules of conventional development that it has drawn national attention far out of proportion to its small size. Of the 317 single-family homes permitted on the site, 133 are now built and 20 more are under construction.
The community is organized around 10 guiding principles -- available for browsing at www.prairiecrossing.com/principles.htm -- including environmental protection, economic and racial diversity, convenient and efficient transportation, energy conservation, esthetic design and "lifelong learning," from child care through courses at a nearby college to informal adult education.
Buyers choose from 12 prototype frame houses that resemble homesteads. With gabled roofs, jaunty pediments, deep porches, clapboard siding, sash windows and white trim against a palette of rustic colors, they exude so much Americana they almost bring an Aaron Copland melody to mind.
"The development," the Chicago Tribune Magazine said in May, "looks like a well-edited version of the Midwest." Nearly 70 percent of the land, 463 acres, is set aside as prairie, pasture, farmland and wetland, with a serpentine lake suitable for swimming, small ponds, a community-supported organic garden and stables for horses.
The tradeoff for this ample communal space is that individual lots are clustered more closely together and are smaller than they would be in a conventional subdivision. However, Mr. Ranney said he is finding that "people care more about access to open lands than having enormous lots."
And Mayor Pat Carey of Grayslake said the village has made use of the concept elsewhere. On one site where zoning was previously limited to one-acre lots, Grayslake will now permit lots as small as the developer cares to build, provided that 50 percent or more of the property is set aside as contiguous open space and that there is no increase in the overall number of houses.
Such an environmentally obliging approach comes at a price: $330,000 for the average house at Prairie Crossing, Mr. Ranney said, or about 20 to 30 percent higher than comparably sized houses in the area. That is good for the business success of the development but has tended to work against the diversity goal.
"WE have done much better than anyone else around here," Mr. Ranney said, "but our hope was that we would have a minority population somewhat larger than we do." It is estimated that 8 percent of the families at Prairie Crossing are African-American, contrasted with 1 percent in the area.
To encourage a greater mix, the Ranneys would sell 25 smaller houses in the town center for $180,000 to $220,000. Buyers on some lots could build 600- to 800-square-foot studio apartments atop their garages for family use or possibly for rent. The Ranneys propose to increase the number of single-family homes to 400, from the maximum of 317 now permitted. The plan is designed by Calthorpe Associates of Berkeley, Calif.
"There's certainly an appeal to the kind of development they're proposing," Mayor Carey said. "If a good deal of people walk across the street to take the train, that balances against the increase in density, in my mind."
However, the Mayor is only one of seven members of the village board, whose approval is required for the new plan. And there is no predicting the outcome of its deliberations later this summer.
Some Prairie Crossing residents wonder whether a town center that draws outsiders may deprive them of the comfort of knowing everyone on the street by sight. They are concerned about the impact on amenities like the little beach along the lake. And there is an unspoken fear that lower-priced houses in one part of the development might depress values elsewhere.
Even broader concerns, felt throughout surrounding Lake County, center on new burdens being placed on already overcrowded schools and roads.
"When we approved the development, we allowed 317 homes," Mayor Carey said. "That's cast in stone at the moment. That's a significant issue. There is a potential for concern about increasing the number of houses in any development at this time."
Donna M. Mack, who moved to Prairie Crossing from Chicago last year, said of the Ranneys' plan: "If anybody can make this work, I think they can. It wasn't what I envisioned and it wasn't what I expected. But I think it can work."
The Ranneys said the extra density is needed in part to offset the expenses they have faced dealing with "outside threats," particularly a nearby landfill. They also pointed out that Prairie Crossing would come nowhere near the 1,600 units approved for the site in 1986.
In 1987, the property was acquired by Gaylord Donnelley, the former president and chairman of R. R. Donnelley & Sons Company, an enormous printing concern founded by his grandfather in 1864. Mr. Donnelley, a conservationist, owned a farm in the 2,000-acre Liberty Prairie Reserve, which adjoins Prairie Crossing. He and other investors founded Prairie Holdings Corporation to develop the site.
After Mr. Donnelley died in 1992, Prairie Holdings was taken over by his nephew, Mr. Ranney, who grew up a half mile away. Donnelley family members are among the largest investors in Prairie Crossing, as are the Ranneys. Mr. Ranney is a partner in the law firm of Mayer, Brown & Platt.
Ms. Ranney is the great-granddaughter of George B. Post, an architect whose works include the New York Stock Exchange, City College campus and the former New York Times building on Park Row. She has edited a volume of the papers of the landscape architect Frederick Law Olmsted.
"I'm surprised and delighted to see that if you lay out guiding principles, the debate tends to be whether you're meeting them," Ms. Ranney said. "People are taking up the cause of Prairie Crossing in ways I would never have guessed five years ago."
Parents are establishing a charter school, publicly financed but independent of local school boards. Although the charter was opposed by the two school districts that serve the area, it was granted on appeal by the state Board of Education. Classes will be held in a pitch-roofed country schoolhouse where farm children were once educated. The earlier school closed in 1958. When the Ranneys learned in 1995 that the owner sought to raze the building, they offered to move it to Prairie Crossing. Come August, it will be home again to 60 youngsters, from kindergarten through second grade.
With "lifelong learning" as a guiding principle, Ms. Ranney said, "We thought we needed to start at the beginning."

HEADLINE: OUT OF ORDER;
There's Something About Garbage

BYLINE: By DAVID BOUCHIER; E-mail address: liorder@nytimes.com

 BODY:
TUESDAY is the high point of my week: garbage collection day, a ritual of cleansing and purification when all the excesses of the past seven days are swept away and out of sight. On a Tuesday morning, everything is potential garbage to me, as I hunt through the house with my all-consuming extra-heavy 30-gallon drawstring trash bag. When the bag is out at the end of the driveway in the big green can (secured with a rubber strap for the amusement of the neighborhood dogs), I feel a solid sense of achievement. As long as I keep putting out the garbage, I postpone the inevitable moment when I become garbage myself.
I like to hear the garbage truck growling in the distance like a hungry dinosaur, getting closer and closer. Sometimes it stops for a while outside our house, as if amazed by the quantity and quality of the offering and digesting it noisily like a hungry man in an all-you-can-eat restaurant. 
 America has the biggest, most impressive garbage trucks in the world and the most garbage -- 200 million tons a year. In some profound sense, garbage is the gross national product, and we produce our share.
It's a bit of a mystery where it all goes. Most of the landfills of Long Island have been turned into recreation areas or golf courses, so I suppose it gets carried off to Oklahoma or somewhere they still have a few square feet of empty space. That would explain why the trucks so often arrive in our neighborhood much later than scheduled, and why the drivers look so tired. The main thing is: the garbage goes away. Those distant landfills work like the Freudian unconscious, where we dump all the things we don't particularly want to remember.
Recycling is a great idea, of course, but it's not as psychologically satisfying as plain garbage. Garbage is about excess and waste. Recycling is about control and responsibility, and it doesn't inspire much enthusiasm first thing in the morning. On the other hand, there is something soothing about the recycling routine. We have a little calendar provided by Riverhead Town, so we can look ahead and see that this Wednesday is mixed recycling day and Dec. 29, right before the millennium, is the day to put out paper. When the future is so uncertain, it's good to know that one's life has some purpose and direction.
In the town of Riverhead where we live, the recycling rules are simple. Bottles, cans and plastic all go into one bright blue container, rather nauseatingly called the Curby Can. I don't envy whoever has the job of sorting out all that stuff. Paper products are bundled together and picked up on alternate weeks. Brookhaven Town, next door, has a long list of forbidden materials, including radioactive waste, explosives and swimming pools, although it's hard to see how even the most dedicated recycler could get a swimming pool into a Curby Can.
In Nassau County, I'm told, residents have an even tougher assignment. They must separate glass, plastic and metal objects, which we throw all together into the same can, and they must carry out a complicated operation on their paper products: newspapers must be separated from magazines, envelopes with and without windows, cardboard, Victorian romantic novels, used train tickets, and so on -- a long list of distinct recycling categories with terrible penalties for the homeowner who gets confused.
Obviously, the more precisely our trash is divided, the more potentially useful it is. In the end we could reach a steady state where everything is recycled right back to being what it was before, and nothing will need to be produced at all.
Recycling is nothing new. The human race has been recycling the same old jokes for thousands of years, along with the same political promises. Television has become the greatest recycling medium of all time, and has not used a new idea since 1946. Some people spend a lifetime recycling their memories of childhood, or weddings or divorces or operations or obscure injuries to their self-esteem.
The planet itself is nothing but a giant recycling mechanism. All our air and water is recycled one way or another, although we don't want to think too hard about that. When we drive we burn gasoline, which is just recycled organic stuff. The used gasoline turns into air pollution, and then into medical fees, and then into the doctor's yacht. In due time the yacht will sink into the mud at the bottom of the sea, the wood will rot away, and in a few million more years the doctor's yacht will turn into oil, which can be pumped up, turned into gasoline and start the whole cycle over again.
Perhaps the whole universe is just a random mechanism for recycling heat and light and stray molecules into random forms like strip malls and Presidential candidates. When these forms have outlived their usefulness, they will be broken down into molecules and reconstituted as something entirely different, and perhaps more useful. This may be the actual secret of the universe. The true answer to the eternal question "What is the meaning of life?" may turn out to be "Recycling."

HEADLINE: The View From/Hartford;
A $22 Million Restoration for Mark Twain House

BYLINE: By STEPHEN L. PURDY 

 BODY:
LIKE the slow evolution of a novel, the Mark Twain House has become a work in progress. The 19-room mansion where Samuel Clemens wrote "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn" is undergoing a $22 million renovation that is expected to return the house to its original condition.
A big part of the renovation was completed in May. The work on the house, which was designed in 1874 by Edward Tuckerman Potter and Alfred H. Thorp, included restoring exterior wood and tile, the patterns of orange and dark blue-grey on the terra cotta brick, and rebuilding the purple slate roofs. 
 The biggest challenge, according to contractors Thomas J. Kronenberger & Sons of Middletown, was the chimneys. With narrowing bases precariously held by corbeling (aesthetic buttresses that projected from inside), they studied the original designs, then applied mortars much stronger than the originals, along with other reinforcements.
"It's detective work," said the curator, Marianne J. Curling, of the detailed process of finding originals and reproductions of all materials, from furniture to textiles and window treatments. "It's really fun, you have that 'Eureka!' moment," she said, laughing, "and then you can reproduce."
' moment," she said, laughing, "and then you can reproduce."
The project is expected to be completed at the same time a documentary on the author by Ken Burns, who created the documentary "The Civil War" in 1990, airs on public television in autumn 2001.
With key research in 1995-96 by the Historic American Buildings Survey and the Society for Preservation of New England Antiquities, plus written documents on Twain and digitally enhanced photographs, contractors and volunteers began the exterior upgrades one year ago.
The drawing room, one of the three interior spaces restored over the last four years, features carefully reproduced salmon-pink wall stenciling and original chairs and settees whose tufted upholstery had been covered by another layer. Ms. Curling explained how digitized photographs helped workers on details for the portieres, the curtains hung over archways, being completed by Elaine Gladstone, a volunteer who has embroidered and beaded them for 18 months.
Such minute examination also helped Ms. Curling reclaim the unusual yellow and pink tones in the master bedroom's woodwork, as well as the grey of the porches and soffits outside, long covered by red.
Among the many survey facts were details on Mrs. Clemens's work with the interior designers, Louis Comfort Tiffany and Associated Artists. "When they hired them, they didn't realize they were hiring the greatest purveyors of the Aesthetic movement," Ms. Curling said.
Tour guides point out that, while the house is Victorian, its daily activity involved a contemporary social parallel -- the professional working at home. With Twain's original study next to his daughters' bedrooms, their activity distracted him and he began his permanent habit of walking to the third floor and working in the billiards room.
Early Twain revivalists chartered The Mark Twain House as a nonprofit organization in 1929. "Not because the house was a great Victorian home," explained Executive Director John Boyer. "It was the birthplace of Tom and Huck."
For roughly the next 30 years, the house hosted a library branch, a one-room museum, and apartments. Interest in its restoration emerged in the 60's, and that interest increased as the home approached its 100th anniversary in 1974.
Ms. Curling suggested that the home's ups and downs were partly in the Clemens spirit of the house as always "a work in progress" anyway. And it's a pragmatic philosophy she uses for its maintenance and progression now.
While displaying a loaned Victorian-style sideboard, in its original but not yet restored dining room spot, she said she hopes the piece will one day be in the museum's permanent collection.
She said the restoration will include chestnut paneling in the kitchen, the dining room's displays of mixed sets of flatware and china, and the carriage house, now used for meetings, will again house carriage and sleigh.
Mr. Boyer said a computerized resource center will be built in the basement for "kids to learn 19th century stenciling so they actually understand it when they visit the house," he said, "and have meaningful interaction with Twain ideas and characters on the Web."
The premier addition will be a 28,000-square-foot education and visitors' center attached to and blending with the carriage house. With galleries, a theater and meeting space for symposiums and lectures, school and storytelling programs, the center will hold the museum's library, including early Twain editions and rare manuscripts.
"It will get things on site that we can't do at the moment," said David Bush, a spokesman for the Twain house.
It's this center and the museum's role in strengthening Hartford, plus its place in the upcoming documentary, that key donors mention when describing why they gave to the capital campaign to renovate the house. Melinda Sullivan, a Hartford-area philanthropist who, with her husband, Dr. Paul Sullivan, donated $1.5 million, said, "You hold your head up a little higher when, asked where Hartford is, you reply, "Did you know that Mark Twain wrote quite a few of his significant works here, had a home designed and built here?' "
While Mrs. Sullivan hopes their donation will spur other people to give, the list of corporate and charitable donors includes the Maximilian E. & Marion O. Hoffman Foundation, the Hartford Foundation for Public Giving, The National Endowments for the Arts and Humanities and The Hartford Financial Services Group.
Administrators of the renovation fund refused to say how much had been contributed.
With four acres next to museum property donated by the city of Hartford, the state Department of Economic and Community Development gave $3 million for parking, exteriors and the visitors' center.
Governor John Rowland even helped raise funds. His wife, Patricia, also a board member of the museum, said, "We've supported Mark Twain House in a variety of ways because we want Connecticut residents to discover, and rediscover, the magnificence in their own backyard."
Mr. Boyer said that although the house's appeal lies in a growing interest in Victorian design and structure, it's based most on the author's wit and clarity.
"He's been called the American Shakespeare, because his works operate simultaneously on so many different levels," he said. "He reaches so many different audiences at the same time."

HEADLINE: AT THE SHORE;
How to Save Wildwood? Make It Even Wilder

BYLINE: By BILL KENT 

 BODY:
Among the many gimmicks that have promised to liven up Wildwood have been a Victorian-themed shopping mall, a comedy club district, a casino and a ski-lift contraption that would carry visitors over the island's burning-hot beach, known locally as the Desert, and drop them within a short walk to the surf. The mall failed; the comedy clubs bombed; the casino was aborted by politicians who favor Atlantic City, and the ski lift is still on the drawing board.
Cut to the summer of 2001. A gigantic crimson crab writhes menacingly atop the just-completed $65 million Wildwood Convention Center. Every 15 minutes, it extends an enormous pincer down to the boardwalk, snatches up a tourist and drops the victim into its steaming maw while delighted family and friends take pictures. 
 "It's a cooked crab," explained Mark Davison, a British-born student of landscape architecture at the University of Pennsylvania, who spent his spring semester studying Wildwood's resort culture. "But here it is, enlarged to a preposterous scale, eating, or appearing to eat, a man. It's just perfect for Wildwood, where everything that's natural is really artificial, and vice versa."
Mr. Davison's crab is among 60 proposals resulting from a three-year study of Wildwood's history, tourist economy and pervasive 1950's building style by three architecture professors and 45 students from Penn, Yale and Kent State Universities. So are a boulevard of sky-high neon-pink flamingos; an avenue of lime-green plastic palm trees; spaceship-shaped lifeguard stations; classical caryatids in polka-dot bikinis; towering video screens showing 1950's situation comedies; a fake Saharan oasis on the beach, and animated signs so huge that they can be read from passing airplanes.
The designs are on display through the summer at the Doo-Wop Preservation League at Pine and Pacific Avenues. Reactions have been "mostly positive," said Mayor Duane Sloan. "We will not have giant crabs on public buildings, as a matter of policy, but as for plastic palm trees, that's the kitschy, over-the-top kind of thing that Wildwood shouldn't be ashamed of."
Jack Morey, an amusement pier owner and hotel developer, has already ordered eight plastic palm trees for a restaurant he is renovating. Mr. Morey initiated the study in 1996 when he gave Steven Izenour, an architecture professor at Penn, a $15,000 grant. The purpose, Mr. Morey said, was to "find out what it is about all of these 50's motels and restaurants and other buildings that we have here that make Wildwood distinctive, and look for ways we can build on that."
With money from the Greater Wildwood Tourism Bureau and the non-profit Doo-Wop Preservation League, the study's most important result "was to legitimize at the academic level Wildwood's architectural heritage," Mr. Morey said. "When most of this stuff was built in the 1950's, it was the new thing across the country. Now, with the retro trends in cars and clothes and music, it's all coming back."
He admitted that some renderings scared people when the study's preliminary suggestions were made public in January. But those who were shocked just didn't understand what Wildwood is all about, said Susan Snyder, a Penn professor and a partner in the Philadelphia architectural firm Company for the Civic Arts, who assisted Mr. Izenour with the study. She explained they were lucky they hadn't torn down their island's streamlined, tropical-hued, aluminum edged, fluorescent-and-neon trimmed-motels, which seemed so dated in the earth-toned 1970's and Victorian-revival 80's.
"There are really two faces of Wildwood," Ms. Snyder said. "Part of the island wants to turn into something more mainstream. They were horrified when we suggested we wanted Wildwood to be more in the doo-wop style because they're aspiring to what they think is a higher taste. From what I've learned about the island's history and tourist economy, these people are dead wrong. The island's economic well-being extends from the boardwalk honky-tonk. It's not enough for Wildwood to be tacky. It has to become wonderfully tacky."
Through August, eight undergraduates studying architecture under Prof. Dan Vieyra of Kent State will be "solving real business problems by renovating motels and restaurants in ways that aren't tasteful or polite," Professor Vieyra said.
"What's attractive about Wildwood is it's the classic corruption of straitjacket modernism driven by mom-and-pop capitalism," he said. "The challenge is to carry this tune and make it even louder."
Such strategies, with or without giant crabs, stand a better chance of improving Wildwood's dwindling tourist base than attempts to copy successful resort cities like Cape May, Mr. Izenour said. A partner in the Philadelphia firm Venturi, Scott Brown & Associates, and a co-author, with Robert Venturi, of the 1971 post-modernist manifesto "Learning From Las Vegas," Mr. Izenour used to vacation in Wildwood with his family and developed a taste for the island that he believes others can still acquire.
"What we're saying with this study is that Wildwood is 95 percent O.K. as it is -- just don't ruin it," he said. "Cape May was created along a very, very tight plan, and it's nice, it's cute, it's tasteful, but it doesn't have that kind of unplanned, pie-in-the-face fun that Wildwood has always had. The way to solve Wildwood's tourism problems is to encourage a crazy, wacky, non-conforming atmosphere where people can get the feeling that anything can happen. The worst thing that could happen to Wildwood would be to impose any kind of rigorous outside order on it."

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY;
Insignia Group's Expanding Universe

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
IT would be hard to argue that Andrew L. Farkas, the chairman and chief executive of Insignia Financial Group, is afraid of change.
Starting the company in 1990, he built it into one of the largest owners and managers of residential properties in the country. Then, in 1996, he acquired the Edward S. Gordon Company, one of the largest commercial real estate services companies in the New York region, and used it as the base for building a nationwide and international network of commercial offices. Two years later he got out of the apartment management business outside of the New York area to concentrate on developing the commercial side of the business. 
 Most recently he spent $65 million to acquire Douglas Elliman, which has a network of offices in upscale New York suburbs and is the largest residential brokerage in Manhattan. With Douglas Elliman and Edward S. Gordon as its keystones, Insignia has announced plans to link commercial and residential operations in an effort to become a powerful real estate services presence in key corporate-headquarters cities around the globe.
"The strategy for operating the business is to become dominant in industry segments," said Mr. Farkas, who is not yet 40 years old, during an interview in his newly decorated office at 200 Park Avenue. "That's why Douglas Elliman was such a special opportunity. It enabled us to become dominant in the No. 1 market in the world."
The move of his corporate headquarters to the former Pan Am building represents something of a homecoming for Mr. Farkas, who is a native New Yorker. He built the residential management business in Greenville, S.C., because of the lower costs in that region, but shifted to New York when he disposed of that business last year.
Mr. Farkas is a son of the chairman of the former Alexander's department store chain, Robin L. Farkas, who now sits on Insignia's board.
The company's growth notwithstanding, Insignia's stock price has remained stuck in the $10 to $12 a share range in recent weeks at a time when the overall market has been soaring and after trading as high as $15.50 earlier this year. Analysts say that publicly traded real estate service companies as a group are out of favor on Wall Street for reasons that range from the inherently cyclical nature of the real estate business to a skepticism that combining dissimilar service operations will increase earnings and cash flow.
"The street either doesn't understand his strategy or it doesn't believe the parts fit together in a strategic sense," said Will Marks of Bank of America Securities. Mr. Marks also noted that Insignia has the shortest track record of its publicly traded peers, at nine years, compared to 30 to 90 years for companies such as CB Richard Ellis, Jones Lang LaSalle, Grubb & Ellis and Trammell Crow and their predecessors.
"What Insignia is trying to do has not been done at this level before," said David Harris, an analyst with Lehman Brothers. This, he said, is a problem for investors because they do not have any similar companies with which to compare Insignia's financial performance.
In an effort to create additional demand for the stock, Insignia's board authorized the repurchase of $10 million in stock in October. Last week, the company announced that $7.5 million had been spent and authorized an additional $10 million repurchase plan.
Mr. Farkas said he expects to acquire other residential brokerage companies in cities where Insignia already has commercial operations and to add services, such as providing mortgages to buyers of residential properties. Today, the company's network is composed of 49 offices in 25 states and includes 13 commercial-services companies purchased since the Gordon acquisition.
Insignia/ESG is the biggest commercial real estate services operation in the New York metropolitan area, having closed 19 of the 50 largest New York City leasing transactions last year. Nationally, it completed deals for 100 million square feet of commercial property and arranged for $3.5 billion in sales and financing in 1998.
Mr. Farkas is already established in Britain, Germany and Italy, and he said he is looking to acquire existing commercial and residential companies in other locations in Europe and Asia or start new companies where suitable acquisitions cannot be completed. "Our sights are set on major financial capitals of Europe, Asia, Canada, Latin America and elsewhere," he declared in Insignia's most recent annual report.
The point of all of this is to build a one-stop-shopping real estate company for big corporations and the people who manage them. "We want to be part of every New Yorker's personal and corporate real estate needs," he said in an interview earlier this month. "The same executives who retain us for commercial space are the ones who use Douglas Elliman to buy and sell their own co-ops and condos." And since Insignia Residential Group manages 60,000 co-op and condominium apartments in the metropolitan area, many of those living in the units are already accustomed to writing monthly checks to Insignia.
Many industry executives, however, question whether the synergies Mr. Farkas claims are made possible by combining commercial and residential operations really exist.
Julien J. Studley, chairman of the commercial brokerage company bearing his name, which specializes in representing tenants, said real estate services companies are hard to manage when they grow quickly, and called Mr. Farkas's plans "a very challenging task." Mr. Studley has maintained that real estate service companies are difficult to manage when they grow quickly.
Bruce Mosler, an executive vice president of Cushman & Wakefield, one of Insignia's major rivals on the commercial side, said that "there is not much synergy between residential and commercial because they are such different businesses."
"A lot of people are skeptical that the combination will add to their market share," Mr. Mosler said.
HE said the model for such an effort was the firm of Coldwell Banker, which added residential brokerage to its existing commercial brokerage in 1937. The company was acquired by Sears, Roebuck & Company in 1981 and Sears decided to sell the commercial-brokerage operations eight years later to a company now known as CB Richard Ellis.
"You have to question how successful it was, because Sears decided to break it up," Mr. Mosler said.
Mr. Farkas contests the analogy. "Coldwell Banker was different," he said. "It was a single brand and a single management doing both commercial and residential."
Edward S. Gordon and Douglas Elliman are different brands and different businesses that were successful independently and are now linked only by a common ownership, Mr. Farkas said. "They have completely separate systems and management and never the twain shall meet," he said. "The two businesses grew up separately and achieved dominance, and they just happened to have done it in the same market."
The importance of the brand was also emphasized by Alan Rogers, the chief executive of Douglas Elliman, who continued in his position after the company was sold to to Insignia. Douglas Elliman has more than 780 brokers, supported by a corporate staff of 100 in 15 offices. Last year it completed more than 4,100 transactions with a total value of $1.8 billion. The experience since the acquisition was announced at the end of May, he said, appears to indicate there is cross-pollination between the commercial and residential sides.
"We are keeping the Douglas Elliman name," he said. "It is a great brand that has traditionally been upscale. But more recently we have been making an effort to be all things to all people, with a cradle to grave philosophy."
He said the approach was to try to connect with young people when they first move to the city and to stay with them as they advance professionally and economically. "They will probably rent for a few years and then buy something for $400,000 or $500,000," he said. "They will probably upgrade once or twice before they finally get a big apartment to raise their family."
He said it is still not clear how the relationship with the commercial side of the company will work out in the long term, but he added: "I've been staggered over the last few weeks about the contacts we have gotten from ESG. We get calls saying, 'I've got this client, can you help him, can you help this friend?' There could be a huge opportunity."
Stephen B. Siegel, president of Insignia Financial Group, said the corporate relocations arranged by the commercial side of the business have implications for employees who will need housing. "If people are to be transferring into the tristate area we can present an analysis to management about the market and whether there is a need for incentives," he said. "We can present an entire package."
The other residential property owned by Insignia is Realty One, a Cleveland-based brokerage company specializing in single-family-home sales. Although it is the biggest such company in Ohio, and thus meets the goal of market dominance, it seems to stick out in Insignia's mix of commercial brokerage and investment operations.
Mr. Farkas said one attraction was that Realty One was advanced technically and had a mortgage banking operation, First Ohio Mortgage, that will almost certainly be added in some form to Douglas Elliman. The ability to provide mortgage loans without having to involve third-party lenders aids the brokerage business by helping to complete transactions and generates income by charging fees for the services. Like most such operations, First Ohio groups the mortgages in pools and sells them to investors.
The purchase of Realty One two years ago was intended to be the first step in an effort to consolidate the highly fragmented home brokerage business, Mr. Farkas said.
"We got Realty One in 1997 at a time when there seemed to be an opportunity to consolidate the industry into a big national franchise," he said. But after the acquisition, the price of companies in that business increased beyond what Insignia was willing to pay.
"When the pricing moved away from us we pulled in our horns and spent the last 24 months learning the business," he said. Since then, he said, the price of brokerage firms has declined, so Insignia is shopping again, with the Douglas Elliman acquisition the first addition to the grocery cart.
The price of companies like Realty One or Douglas Elliman is usually described by dividing the price by the annual income of the acquired company to produce what is known as a multiple. "We paid a lower multiple for Douglas Elliman than for Realty One," Mr. Farkas said, "so pursuing consolidation in major markets makes sense again."
Mr. Farkas, who worked on Wall Street early in his career, described Insignia as the equivalent of an opportunity fund, seeking undervalued investments and selling operations at opportune times to lock in profits.
This, he said, explains why he got into the apartment management business early in the 1990's and got out of it last year, with the exception of New York area operations.
IN the early 1990's, Insignia made investments in multifamily housing at prices the most recent annual report describes as "materially accretive to our shareholders" -- that is, cheap. The strategy then, as it continues to be, was to consolidate a fragmented industry. But by 1997 the consolidation was largely complete, with no big residential management companies left to buy. "We took the business as far as we could given our capital structure" as a taxpaying corporation, he said. "Then we looked for a company with different costs of capital -- a real estate investment trust -- to merge with."
The result was a deal with a company named AIMCO that transferred all of Insignia's residential properties and 8,000 management employees to the REIT, which does not have to pay Federal taxes as long as it distributes 95 percent of its earnings as dividends.
Insignia shareholders received AIMCO stock equivalent to 20 percent of the company in return for Insignia's residential properties and now receive dividends that Insignia, as a growth company, did not pay.
Mr. Farkas describes the deal as a good one for his company, which transferred operations accounting for about 50 percent of its business in terms of cash flow for a price -- $910 million -- that was equal to 95 percent of the company's total capitalization. AIMCO shareholders have benefited as well, since the price of the company's shares have risen from the mid-$30's to about $43 a share.
That left the restructured Insignia with three operating units, commercial real estate services, residential management in the New York area and a capital investment operation known as Insignia Financial Services.
The investment group now provides only about 2 percent of the parent company's income -- compared to 72 percent from commercial services and 26 percent from residential -- but Mr. Farkas said he expects it to be the fastest growing.
He said the commercial deals that Insignia/ESG handles provide information on potentially attractive investments.
"They provide a pipeline of investment opportunities that we can evaluate and deploy our capital alongside our customers in existing properties and in development projects," he said. For example, the company said it has invested $22 million of equity capital in 22 existing properties with a total value of $700 million and has put $18 million into five development projects with a total value of $107 million.
He said Financial Services is also raising funds on Wall Street for investments that will not show on the company's balance sheet and is participating in CS First Boston's $500 million Praedium Fund for International Real Estate. The unit is also marketing securities for property owners who prefer using public markets to other forms of financing. "We want to be an opportunistic player, like Blackstone, Blackacre and Apollo," he said, mentioning three investment groups.
Like consolidation, growth is something of a mantra for Mr. Farkas, whose largely intact management group has made over 50 acquisitions since 1990. He said the key to healthy growth is to maintain financial discipline to avoid overpaying for companies, and devise financial terms that keep previous owners hard at work. "We are not an exit strategy," he said.
Since its inception in 1990 as a real estate investment fund with $5 million in capital, Mr. Farkas said, Insignia has increased market capitalization to over $1 billion. Total revenues of the company have risen from $122 million in 1996 to $507 million in 1998, with revenues of $636 million projected for this year.
Insignia has said that the standard measure of economic performance, net income, is not appropriate for a real estate company because its merger and acquisition activity generates a lot of charges that do not actually cost the company cash.
MR. FARKAS and others in the industry prefer to measure financial performance using what is called EBITDA, earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, which they say approximates the actual cash generated by the business. By this measure, Insignia's profits have grown from $15 million in 1996 to $53 million last year.
While Insignia was expanding domestically, the company was also expanding overseas, particularly in Britain, where it bought two venerable brokerage companies and combined them into an entity called Richard Ellis St. Quintin.
(There were two companies named Richard Ellis, one based in Britain and one in the rest of Europe. An American company then called CB Commercial bought the continental Richard Ellis and promptly added it to its corporate name, becoming CB Richard Ellis. Believing the Richard Ellis brand name has considerable value in Britain, Insignia has retained it, despite the potential for confusion.)
In addition to geographic expansion, Insignia plans to begin relying heavily on technology and the Internet to improve the efficiency of marketing and transactions. Mr. Farkas declined to elaborate in detail on the techniques the company plans to start using later this year, but he playfully opened an E-mail on his desktop computer that included a movable 360-degree picture of a building lobby. And company documents note that Realty One has an automated system for preapproving mortgages.
His goal, Mr. Farkas said, is to be a customer's only real estate company. "We are not interested in one-time relationship with customers," he said. "We want to work with them and be there for them whenever they think of real estate."

HEADLINE: Hamptons' Roads Call For Changes and Concern

 BODY:
It is so distressing to me to hear the Town of Southampton speak of the traffic conditions without one mention of the dangers of Montauk Highway and County Road 39.
The town's No. 1 priority is that the residents and visitors don't get bothered by the increasing traffic, which in effect could deter them from coming to the Hamptons and possibly threaten the town's economy. 
 In 1996 there were at least five road-related deaths and in 1997 there were at least three. I use "at least" to mean only those deaths that I have heard of.
There is a heavy flow of traffic in a well-populated residential and commercial area and all the town cares about is how to increase that flow of traffic and make it move smoothly.
How about the dangers and deaths on these roads? Can cars or people cross one of these roads without putting their lives in danger? Are there a significant amount of stop lights to control speed limits? Are there any pedestrian crossings at intersections?
The answer to all those questions is no. And widening the road or any other road "improvement" that the town does will only increase the chances of more deaths.
Has the town even considered the personal safety of its residents and visitors or do they care only about their pay raise next year?
 
LIZA BOOCKVAR
New York

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
AntitrustIn the Slow Lane

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
THE outcome of the Government's suit against Microsoft, filed 14 months ago, is still far from certain, and the endgame may be two or three years away, after appeals that may well reach the Supreme Court.
But one byproduct is already evident: a policy debate over whether the current system of antitrust enforcement, dating back to John D. Rockefeller and the railway barons, is up to the challenge of policing corporate behavior in a modern, high-technology economy. 
 The issue is speed, the stakes are high and the debate is often highly politicized. In June, Dick Armey, the House majority leader, issued his statement of principles for Government's role in an economy increasingly powered by silicon, software and the Internet. Called "An E-Contract with High-Tech America," it warned against "allowing antitrust law to become an excuse for bureaucratic interference with innovation and competition."
In a scarcely veiled reference to the Microsoft case, it criticized Federal agencies that "use heavy-handed tactics to target specific companies." And it said "the pace of innovation is so quick" that market power -- with which antitrust law concerns itself -- is often fleeting. Mr. Armey's staff says no new antitrust bill is now planned but calls the E-Contract a "starting point."
To be sure, the Armey document can be seen as a predictable gesture from a conservative Republican leader, especially as an election year looms and Microsoft is becoming a more active campaign contributor. But you don't have to side with Bill Gates to see legitimate concerns about whether the Government's antitrust police and the courts can keep up with such fast-moving industries.
A Justice Department advisory committee of executives, academics and lawyers raised that issue in a meeting last month. Committee members said the discussion was not about Microsoft, but rather about the best antitrust policies in an environment of rapid technological obsolescence. Among the options pondered were new guidelines for the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission and "clearer, cleaner definitions" of forbidden behavior in new legislation.
The goal is up-to-date ground rules for powerful companies like Microsoft and Intel, which settled its own antitrust dispute with the F.T.C. earlier this year. "Policy-making has to be streamlined so it can operate on something closer to Internet time, as these industries do," said David B. Yoffie, a professor at Harvard Business School and a committee member.
The rapid pace of change in the software industry will not much affect the verdict on the legality of Microsoft's business practices. But when cases drag on as Microsoft's has, the speed issue weighs heavily on the remedies prosecutors seek. No ruling on Microsoft is expected from the Federal District Court in Washington before the end of the year, 18 months after the suit was filed. Again, you needn't be a Microsoft ally to notice how much has changed since the case began: Microsoft's main corporate "victim" in the case, Netscape Communications, has been acquired by America Online, and its former chief executive, James L. Barksdale, is now a venture capitalist and enthusiastic backer of George W. Bush, who, if elected President, might see antitrust policy somewhat differently than the Clinton Administration has.
THE speed issue figures prominently in the chess game of settlement discussions between Microsoft and the Government. Joel I. Klein, head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, will say only that the settlement equation is "time versus risk." A settlement would rein in Microsoft sooner than a verdict would, Mr. Klein said, but the negotiated terms might leave Microsoft enough leeway to abuse its market power.
By judicial standards, the Microsoft case has moved with surprising speed: "a remarkable achievement," according to Andrew I. Gavil, a law professor at Howard University, writing in Antitrust magazine, an American Bar Association journal. Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, Mr. Gavil said, has used innovative tactics -- from requiring all direct testimony in writing to limiting the number of witnesses -- to speed the proceedings along and avoid the "prolonged trench warfare" that has plagued major cases like the Government's suit against I.B.M., which was dropped in 1982, after 13 years.
But even the most expeditious courts are too slow in many eyes, part of the reason so many antitrust cases are settled. "It may be fast compared with the I.B.M. case, but it's not fast enough, and that's a problem," said Carl Shapiro, an economist at the University of California at Berkeley and a former senior Justice Department official. "A lot of things do change in 18 months."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
In Wine Country, Can White or Red Ever Be Green?

BYLINE: By ALAN KRAUSS 

DATELINE: ST. HELENA, Calif.

 BODY:
FARMERS and vintners in California's Napa Valley have long exploited the region's combination of soil, climate and topography to make wines that can compete with those of the great Bordeaux estates. Shrewd marketing and a robust economy have given premium Napa wines a romance and prestige that help lift sales of wine produced throughout the state.
Napa winemaking has proven so successful, in fact, that there is very little land left on the valley floor to plant new vines. To expand output, the wineries are planting on the surrounding hillsides, arousing a backlash driven by environmental concerns ranging from water pollution caused by soil erosion and pesticides to the destruction of oak trees and wildlife habitat. 
 Pushed by environmentalists, the Napa County Board of Supervisors has already enacted regulations aimed at curbing hillside vineyards, and the board's five elected members are being pressed by constituents to make the rules even more restrictive.
Winemakers say hillsides are not only the last available land for Napa vineyards but also the best land for producing world-class wine grapes -- though the most expensive to develop. At the very least, they say, the new rules would drive development costs even higher. Planting a new hillside vineyard costs $35,000 to $40,000 an acre, on top of the price of the land.
"We need to conserve habitat," said Chris Malan, a county mental health counselor who leads Concerned Citizens for Napa Hillsides, a small but politically vocal environmental group. "We need to protect our tree canopy. We need to not construct infrastructure in the hillsides that causes flooding."
Napa County's landmark 1991 hillside ordinance permits farming on slopes with grades as steep as 22.5 degrees, or 50 percent, meaning the land rises one foot for every two horizontal feet. Ms. Malan wants the county to tighten that limit to 30 percent. Better still, she said, would be a moratorium on all new vineyard development. "This is a very small county," she said. "We have to reach the limit at some point."
Because of Napa's national reputation, the fight has attracted attention from environmental groups across the country. They say they will not hesitate to intervene if measures to clean up the Napa River and protect wildlife seem inadequate.
"If it's just a matter of saying, 'We're going to do some study and crack down on future development,' then that won't solve the problem," said Bruce Hamilton, conservation director for the Sierra Club. "California, using Federal standards, classified the Napa River as impaired in 1987. If the state fails to act, then the Federal Government could step in.
"And if neither acts," he added, "then a private group like the Sierra Club could," by going to court.
Winemakers say county figures show that soil erosion has declined by more than two-thirds since 1991. "Many of us think the current ordinance is pretty damn good and the problem is enforcing it," said Dennis Groth, president of Groth Vineyards in Oakville.
The wine growers cautiously embraced recommendations by a county task force that recently evaluated Napa's hillside ordinance. The task force, whose members included winemakers and environmentalists as well as engineers and government officials, rejected proposals like a moratorium on new vineyards and extending the rules to cover replanting of existing vineyards grandfathered under the 1991 law. Instead, it called for further study.
Compliance with the law is largely voluntary; enforcement is limited to responding to the public's complaints, according to county officials. The number of vineyards that break the rules, while thought to be small, is not known.
Still, the problems that have come to light have been damaging for the winemakers. "When somebody violates the law, the finger points at all of us," said Thomas Shelton, chief executive of Joseph Phelps Vineyards and president of the Napa Vintners Association. "Enforcement of existing regulations is something we can all agree on."
Some in Napa say that planting hillsides does not make economic sense anyway.
"The issue is not growth; the issue is profit," said Volker Eisele, a vintner and grape grower with 60 acres who is also an environmental activist. "When land values and business values climb to such astronomical heights, there is a lot at stake." For what it now costs to develop hillside vineyards, he said, "to make such a venture pay, you're looking at a $60 to $80 bottle price, and I have trouble believing that you can project that kind of price into the future."
Mr. Eisele said the Napa industry should grow by increasing quality, not quantity.
For Stuart Smith, whose 30-acre Smith-Madrone Vineyards and Winery lies nearly 1,000 feet above St. Helena in the Mayacamas Range, growth is very much an issue. Mr. Smith, who is seeking county permission to convert six and a half more acres into vineyards, says modern agricultural techniques can minimize soil erosion and habitat loss. And no one should underestimate nature's resilience, he said.
He pointed to a faded redwood stake, one of many he has found on his property, that supported a grapevine more than a century ago. The tall pine trees and scrub that now surround it are evidence of the forest's regenerative vitality, he said.
"The forest wants to take back the vineyards," Mr. Smith said. "It's a constant battle for us to keep the forest at bay."

HEADLINE: With This Trip Abroad, I Thee Wed

BYLINE: By MONIQUE P. YAZIGI 

DATELINE: SINTRA, Portugal

 BODY:
IT started with a bullfight and ended with a lot of investment bankers and fashion designers skinny-dipping in the hotel pool.
In between, statuesque women wrapped in pashmina shawls teetered in Manolo Blahniks on the cobblestone streets of this scenic coastal city built by Portuguese kings and queens for their summer palaces. 
 There were ponies with hydrangeas woven into their manes, flamenco dancing, a series of all-night parties and bottles of Chateau Lafite brought by members of the Rothschild family from their own vineyards.
Those were some of the highlights when John Josephson, 37, an investment banker, and Carolina Zapf, 30, a porcelain-skinned dress designer, invited 220 of their nearest and dearest to cross the Atlantic Ocean to their wedding, a five-day fandango over the Fourth of July weekend.
The couple, both New Yorkers, have no family in Portugal, nor have they ever lived there; they simply wanted an unusual and exotic location, and in this day of casual jet travel -- not to mention a galloping economy -- the extravagance of going to Europe for a long-weekend wedding did not seem far-fetched. A number of guests, including the bridegroom, who specializes in movie-industry deals, were traveling directly from Portugal to Sun Valley, Idaho, for the annual conference of media and entertainment chieftains given by Allen & Company, the investment firm.
"Who wants to go to another wedding at the Pierre?" said Mr. Josephson, whose mother, Arlette Brisson, wore a James Galanos gown, a gift from the designer, to the ceremony, and changed three times during the 12-hour reception. Mr. Josephson, in a morning coat, got a kick out of showing off the pockets in the tails, where he stashed his gloves.
Mr. Josephson and Ms. Zapf are not alone in marrying abroad. This is the summer of the European wedding for certain New Yorkers willing to pay a minimum of $100,000 for a multi-day splurge for hundreds of guests. At a chateau near Paris over the Memorial Day weekend, Nathalie Gerschel, a special events coordinator at Christie's, wed Edward Kaplan, an executive at Showtime Networks, before 400 friends, including members of Manhattan's junior social set like Whitney Fairchild, Sloan Lindemann and Rob Speyer.
In June, Jamie Saslow, a former retail sales consultant, and David Mitchell, an investment banker, were married in the Spanish Synagogue in the historic Jewish Ghetto in Venice with 160 guests, who were transported by private vaporettos and water taxis to nine events in four days, requiring two party planners from Milan.
And also over Fourth of July weekend, Cynthia Kaufman, who used to work in sales at Donna Karan, and Henry Gabay, an investment banker, were married before 350 in Istanbul, Turkey.
Jill Swid, an editor at Mirabella magazine, who was invited to both the Istanbul wedding and the one in Portugal, had the difficult task of choosing between them. "Cynthia is one of my closest friends," she said. That sealed her decision to go to Istanbul, where festivities began at an open-air nightclub on Wednesday, continued with sightseeing on Friday and peaked at the Saturday ceremony in a restored Ottoman palace overlooking the Bosporus.
"I haven't figured out why there is the European wedding craze," Ms. Swid said, "but there is. Europeans say, 'Our weddings last for days.' But there can be three-day weddings in New York or Southampton. The difference is you're on holiday, I guess."
Others are more confident in offering reasons for the trend. "A lot of this has to do with the economy," said Polly Onet, the event planner, who did the 1996 wedding of David and Julia Koch in Southampton, N.Y., and last year organized a wedding for New Yorkers in Dublin. "I think people in high society get very bored. In order to challenge them and make things very special and spectacular, it takes bringing them to a completely new environment in order to blow their minds. You want to make them feel like it's special, rather than just another wedding at the Colony Club."
Many of those marrying or receiving invitations, which invariably are accompanied by pages of travel instructions, belong to the loosely interlocking worlds of charity parties, investment banking and fashion.
"A lot of these people are on the same wedding circuit," noted Alexandra Kotur, a senior editor at Vogue, who has been to three weddings of New Yorkers this summer in Europe. The grandest joined Valesca Dost and Mathias Guerrand-Hermes, an heir to the French fashion house, who lives in New York. The wedding started with more than 450 guests on May 12 in Paris and ended five days later in Marrakech, Morocco, with guests transported by two private jets.
Alexandra Lind, a young fashion designer, went to the Kaufman-Gabay wedding in Istanbul, the Gerschel-Kaplan wedding in Paris (she designed the blue satin dresses for the bridesmaids), and plans to attend a wedding over Labor Day weekend for Victoria Scaravilli, a real estate agent on the Upper East Side, and Owen Colligan, an investment banker, in Capri, Italy.
Mr. Colligan and Ms. Scaravilli were themselves at the Portugal wedding. "When I told my family we were getting married in Capri, they thought we were nuts," Mr. Colligan said, as he ate a slice of wedding cake at 1:30 A.M. in the Palacio de Seteais, an 18th-century palace-turned-hotel, where many of the guests stayed and the reception was held. "And Princess Di over there," he said, gesturing to his fiancee, who was wrapped in pink pashmina, "wants 12 bridesmaids. So, I had to find 12 ushers who will go with me."
Katrina Pavlos, a guest in Portugal, who has been invited to four European weddings this summer, cried out, "Please, stop, I can't afford it!"
"I feel like I have to go to all of them," said Ms. Pavlos, 26, a filmmaker, as she sipped Champagne. "They're your friends. But I'm broke by now."
Ms. Onet estimated that the weddings cost the hosts, who often fly in their own bands and a minister or rabbi to officiate, anywhere from $100,000 to several million. This contrasts with a wedding at the Pierre Hotel in New York, which for 200 can run about $125,000 and up, including flowers, photographers, tips and taxes, said Arthur Backal, the director of catering at the hotel.
Guests invited to the Portugal wedding, who paid their own air fare and lodging, said they spent from $2,500 to $4,000, not including a gift, numerous clothing changes (during the wedding reception alone, many of the women changed several times, moving from cocktail dresses to ball gowns) and, in some cases, the expense of a nanny brought from home.
Ms. Onet said that clearly, there is an element of one-upmanship in the weddings. "By having an extremely over-the-top, lavish event abroad, people want to impress, make a statement and outshine the last party," she said.
The 1990's jet-set wedding may have been sparked for the current generation by the well-publicized foreign ceremonies of two daughters of the billionaire Robert Miller. In 1993, Pia Miller married Christopher Getty in Bali, where Balinese carried the couple on thrones. Three years later, Marie-Chantal Miller married Crown Prince Pavlos of Greece in England before 1,100 guests; Valentino designed 27 couture dresses for the bridal party, and Barry Diller flew in the wedding cake on his private plane.
Darcy Miller, the weddings editor for Martha Stewart Weddings magazine (and not one of those Miller sisters), said, "Since the magazine started in 1995, we've seen so many more destination weddings, which is going somewhere for your wedding where you do not live and no one else lives."
Some couples marry abroad, Ms. Miller said, as a way of paring down the guest list without bruising feelings. They expect the travel expense will deter all but their closest (and most affluent) friends. But they quickly find out, she said, that people love to travel. More than 70 percent of the invitees showed up for the Josephson-Zapf wedding, some of whom didn't commit until the last minute.
"I turn my head and a new person I didn't know was coming arrives," Ms. Zapf said the day before the ceremony, wearing navy jodhpurs and a white shirt on the terrace of her hotel. She shrugged. "I don't know who else is going to show up."
"I'm not going to think about it," she said, and went off horseback riding to relax.
"Being abroad, it creates an automatic buzz about the wedding itself," said Michelle Halpern, 28, who works in film publicity for Peggy Siegal and attended the Istanbul wedding.
Of course it does. The partying never stops. David Schulhof, 28, a lawyer at Miramax Films, who attended the Gerschel-Kaplan wedding, said that on the first night there was a cocktail party on a bateau-mouche on the Seine.
"In the evening we raged at different nightclubs," he said. "We went to Les Bains Douches, Bar Fly and Le Cabaret."
Even though Mr. Guerrand-Hermes, whose family is French, could claim he was simply returning home to be married outside Paris in mid-May, and thus his wedding was not such an extravagance, the event was the most lavish this season to which New Yorkers were invited in droves.
On the first night, guests were instructed to wear stiletto heels and slicked-back hair to a flamenco-themed party. The wedding the next day took place on an Hermes estate in Chantilly, where a New England-style church had been constructed for the ceremony. Then, guests were flown by private planes to Marrakech. Over the next three days, there were a party in the gardens of Yves Saint Laurent's home, and polo on camelback.
"Everyone felt like a pasha, it was from another era," said Kristina Stewart, the editor in chief of Quest magazine, who attended. On the second-to-last night, she said she told the bridegroom, "If you want to outdo yourself you're going to have to come up with a Kelly bag for every guest and a virgin sacrifice tomorrow night." There were no Kelly bags, but guests were sent home with a custom-made Hermes scarf.
By contrast, the Josephson-Zapf fete in Sintra was more modest -- though only relatively. There was a high quotient of Internet entrepreneurs, including Jon Diamond, the chairman of CDNow, the on-line music retailer, and David Wetherell, the chairman of the venture capital company CMGI, which just before he flew in had paid $2.03 billion for control of the Web search engine Alta Vista. The front-desk manager of the converted castle where many guests stayed received daily piles of faxes in advance with all sorts of special requests, including one for a T1 high-speed data line. (He had no idea what it was.)
Yet, what celebrants repeatedly praised as the charm of a multi-day wedding in Portugal was the way busy, competitive people let down their guard. The social angling familiar to many from weekends in the Hamptons was largely absent. "If you take people out of their element, it works," Mr. Josephson said.
Gordon R. Pennington, a marketing strategist, surveyed the guests dancing in a moonlighted garden the night before the wedding and said: "Half these people wouldn't talk to each other if they were sitting in the Hamptons. When you take them out of the country, in a place they've never been to, it takes their edge off."
At 2:30 A.M. the following night, Bradley Lander's eyes were barely open, but he was unwilling to call it quits. "When are you going to be playing in Sintra again?" he said, and got up to dance, missing a few steps, with a scantily clad woman who tossed her lime-green shawl in the grass to join him.
Earlier, at cocktails, another man had said, "It's chic to say you went to Portugal for the weekend." Moments before he was joined by his date, whom he had escorted from New York, he added, "It's a great way to impress a girl and take her on a test drive at the same time."

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.;
A Second Look at Second-Quarter Forecasts

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
EXPECTATIONS are pretty high as the second-quarter earnings season gets into full swing this week, with reports scheduled from Intel, Apple Computer, International Paper, Merrill Lynch, Pfizer, Whirlpool, Weyerhaeuser and others.
Wall Street analysts who make forecasts for the 500 companies in the Standard & Poor's stock index are predicting the first double-digit growth in quarterly corporate earnings since the end of 1997. I.B.E.S. International, which tracks earnings, is forecasting 10 percent overall growth, based on its compilation of analysts' predictions, while the First Call Corporation, the other leading compiler of earnings, predicts 11.2 percent. 
 Adding to the optimism is the gentleness of the pre-announcement season, often a rocky run-up when many companies warn investors of profit disappointments to come. There have been 270 negative announcements so far, according to First Call; that total is no worse than normal. The only "blockbuster announcement," said Chuck Hill, the director of research at First Call, was Compaq Computer's warning in June that it expected a second-quarter loss of as much as 15 cents a share.
In addition, the number of downward revisions of analysts' earnings estimates, which commonly occur before the beginning of a reporting season, has been smaller than normal for the second quarter. The current First Call forecast of 11.2 percent earnings growth, compared with the second quarter last year, is down from 13.9 percent six months ago. That is a much smaller cut than in the first quarter of this year, when the initial 14.3 percent forecast was slashed to 5.7 percent. A trim of four percentage points is the norm, Mr. Hill said.
And companies that have already reported earnings, including General Electric, Yahoo and Alcoa, have provided good news.
All of this has led Mr. Hill to suggest that by the time all the second-quarter reports are in, the actual jump in earnings, compared with the second quarter of 1998, will be closer to 15 percent.
The strength of the numbers is reassuring in a period when interest rates could move higher. The Federal Reserve, which has already raised rates once, could raise them again later this summer.
The good earnings prospects (analysts think that the third and fourth quarters will be even stronger) also help investors live with the fact that prices are high for many stocks, by historical standards. According to I.B.E.S, stocks have been too pricey for 29 consecutive weeks, the longest overvaluation streak since before the 1987 crash.
But remember that a lot of the punch in the earnings numbers is not from a new surge in growth, but from a rebound from setbacks -- or even sharp losses -- in 1998.
For example, General Motors, according to I.B.E.S. estimates, will show a surge in operating earnings in the second quarter, to $2.55 a share, compared with 54 cents a share in the corresponding period last year. (Operating earnings are adjusted to remove the impact of write-offs and other one-time items and are therefore different from reported earnings.)
But the G.M. gain represents mostly a rebound from sales lost during a strike that crippled production last year. Before cutting estimates because of the strike, analysts expected G.M. to earn $2.27 a share in last year's second quarter. Without G.M.'s sharp expected gain, the overall I.B.E.S. second-quarter growth forecast would drop to 8.6 percent from 10 percent, according to Joseph Abbott, United States research manager.
Intel is also expected to rebound, to operating earnings of 54 cents a share, from 33 cents in the period a year earlier, when chip prices were being cut. Without Intel and G.M., the I.B.E.S. growth forecast would be cut to 8 percent.
Easy quarterly comparisons also help in the next two quarters. G.M. is expected to surge again. And with oil prices 47 percent above the average for the last two quarters of 1998, energy sector profits, according to First Call, should jump 39 percent in the third quarter and 77 percent in the fourth.
Banks and brokerage firms also ought to do well in the third quarter, compared with the disastrous results during the financial turmoil that followed the Russian ruble devaluation and bond default last August.
So don't get too excited about the return to double-digit profit increases.
