HEADLINE: A Son Rises In Texas;
Ross Perot Jr., the Builder, Puts His Stamp on Dallas

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
WHEN it comes to dynasties, Gov. George W. Bush has said that his father's idea of the perfect son was Al Gore. Ross Perot's idea of the perfect son is Ross Perot Jr.
Lest Ross Jr. have any doubts about what was expected of him, his father wrote it all down. At his college graduation, Ross Sr. presented him with "Everything I Know About Business," a treatise that later filled 62 pages in the elder Perot's autobiography. "Avoid undertaking new projects on a grand scale," it advised -- at least until after completing some low-risk trials. 
 Two decades later, Ross Jr. has become the leading real estate developer in a state where builders can wield more power than governors or mayors. And now he is bending some of his father's rules as he sets out to transform a swath of downtown Dallas the size of about 19 Manhattan blocks into office buildings, apartments, shopping concourses and a sports arena that, he boasts, will give this city its own Times Square.
"I'd better go back and read the guidelines," the younger Mr. Perot said with his usual purposeful frown, sitting in an office down the hall from his father's, both of them behind locked and guarded doors. "You're going to get me in trouble."
Not to worry. Though he is in a different trade than his father, who built a fortune with one computer services company and has now gone public with another, Mr. Perot has proved himself his father's son in recognizing government as the businessman's best patron.
As his father built his first company, Electronic Data Systems, on winning government contracts, the son has built his real estate empire on winning all manner of government support.
His latest project has been based on persuading Dallas voters -- usually stingy with public money -- that they should pay $125 million of the $230 million cost for his basketball team's new arena, the anchor for a billion-dollar-plus real estate development.
It has taken Donald Trump 24 years to finish two buildings on the site of Manhattan's West Side rail yards, a tract of about the same size. In Dallas, Mr. Perot had the dirt flying just two years after he bought the Dallas Mavericks of the National Basketball Association in 1996 and a year after his initial downtown investments.
Touring the site in his black Chevrolet Suburban, his top aides filling its three benches, Mr. Perot bounced over curbs, across abandoned railroad tracks and past derelict grain elevators, avidly describing everything he plans -- down to pasting corporate logos on the overpasses.
"There are some neat naming opportunities on the bridges," he told his assistants. "Tastefully done."
MR. PEROT has the ready ability to turn his dreams into steel, concrete and glass. In a business usually run on other people's money, he uses large amounts of his own, gathered from earlier real estate investments that he made with his father.
His successes have had a deeply personal benefit. Even four or five years ago, questions about how much his father's money and connections had contributed to his own progress drew pinched responses. His father was only an investor, Mr. Perot would say, while full, legal, decision-making authority rested with him.
Now, with less to prove, Mr. Perot can warmly describe childhood weekends spent looking over real estate with his father. Or, for all the unwanted attention of being a Perot, the considerable benefits that the name carries. "The key thing is certainly you can go see people," he said. "They'll take your phone calls."
Congenital determination, as well as money, may allow Mr. Perot to bring the ailing center of this city a revival that has been beyond the abilities of anyone else. To buy the Mavericks, he had to muscle aside Thomas O. Hicks, Dallas's own leveraged-buyout king. Even though Mr. Hicks said he could build an arena for a city investment of just $40 million or $50 million, Mr. Perot persuaded civic leaders to allot about three times as much. Mr. Hicks and Mr. Perot became partners in the project, although Mr. Perot remained the developer.
His headstrong ways have decisively shaped his image. No other Texas builder is so eagerly courted or publicly reviled. To those who have opposed the arena or his other vast projects, he is a ruthless privateer intent on raiding the public's purse.
Early last year in Dallas, Mr. Perot and Mr. Hicks spent $2 million to gain voter approval of arena subsidies. An opposition group calling itself "It's a Bad Deal" spent just $75,000 but came within 1,700 votes of winning. The group's members continue to shadow Mr. Perot. "This guy is the biggest welfare baby the public has ever seen," Sharon Boyd, the group's leader and a former member of the Dallas Planning Commission, said months after the vote. "What has he ever done without public assistance? His daddy built his own company with public assistance."
Mr. Perot responds that the jobs and tax revenues produced by his projects far exceed any public costs. And, as he coolly told other developers last fall at the annual meeting of the Urban Land Institute here, braving opposition is his duty.
"Half of this business is politics," he said, in a measured corporate monotone that contrasts with his father's buzz-saw twang. "As real estate developers, it's our job to go in there and get beat up."
His father, back at Perot Systems after two Presidential campaigns, remains a walking editorial cartoon, a rambunctious runt with a tomahawk profile. The son, at 5 feet 11 inches, has conventional broad-shouldered good looks -- as perfectly pressed, meticulously slicked back and emotionally composed as if he had rumbled loose from a marble monument to Texas deal-makers.
The older Mr. Perot argues that a Texas habit -- calling the father "Big" and the son "Little" when they share a given name -- shouldn't apply to him and his son. "He's Big Ross and I'm Old Ross, and there's no better place to live than in your son's shadow," he says.
In politics, however, the younger Mr. Perot, apart from favoring free trade, stays out of his father's way. Recalling the uproar over his 1992 donation to President Bush's re-election campaign before his father joined the race, he has refused to back Governor Bush's Presidential campaign until his father's plans are clear. "I've learned my lessons," Mr. Perot said. "I'm staying on the sidelines for Dad." (Dad, while saying he prefers business to politics, won't rule out another race.)
At 40, Big Ross is less exciting than his father but also less excitable -- a reflection of the influence of his mother, Margot, family friends say. As the oldest of five children and the only son, one friend said, "Ross Jr. was trained for, conditioned for being in the public eye."
It was not your normal childhood. His father, an Annapolis graduate, surrounded his son with military heroes, former prisoners of war and astronauts. The son distinguished himself as an Air Force fighter pilot and later as the lead pilot on the first helicopter trip around the world. Such training is the best business school, the elder Mr. Perot contends, saying, "When you're flying a fighter, you don't have time for committee meetings."
He needs no prompting to tell how he offered his son, then about 14 years old, 75 cents for each bush he would plant along the road in front of the old E.D.S. headquarters in Dallas. Just inches into the ground, Ross Jr. struck rock. Rejecting his father's offer to adjust the price, Ross went at the task with a pickax. Now, his father says, "Anytime he buys a piece of real estate, he checks to see where the rock is."
And how did he rebel? Anything like George W. Bush's wild living in earlier days? The younger Mr. Perot throws back his head and laughs with rare abandon. "It wasn't really part of the program in the Perot family," he says. "Rebellion was not an option."
Instead, friends say, he was driven to make his own mark, to give the lie to anyone who dared say that all his advantages were inherited.
Still, he assumed that he would work for his father. He started out as a land man, leasing drilling rights for his father's oil company. He planned to become an E.D.S. salesman, but in 1984 his father sold the company to General Motors. He decided to turn his family's real estate holdings into the basis of a business, the Hillwood Development Corporation.
With his father's help, he began buying thousands of acres north of Fort Worth, counting on the city's continuing sprawl to turn ranches and farms dotted with post oaks and mesquite into subdivisions and shopping malls. The city, anticipating added tax revenue and jobs, was happy to annex his land and provide services.
Though the collapse of the Texas economy in the late 1980's dashed the Perots' initial plans, they still had the cash to buy thousands of additional acres from desperate sellers. But Ross Jr.'s new plan -- to build an air cargo hub to be called Alliance Airport -- required help from government at all levels. After a tour in the Hillwood helicopter, Jim Wright of Fort Worth, then the Speaker of the House and a prime beneficiary of the Perots' campaign donations, pushed a bill through Congress for a far larger project than the Federal Aviation Administration had recommended. Federal, state and local governments provided more than $200 million in cash and tax breaks.
Local real estate experts estimate that after some early reversals, Mr. Perot has gained hundreds of millions of dollars turning his Fort Worth property into the Southwest's largest hub for cargo shipments. "Alliance was Ross's E.D.S.," said Tom Luce, a Dallas lawyer and political adviser for father and son.
Mr. Perot raised his bet on the area when he bought the 2,500-acre Circle T Ranch in 1993 for less than $20 million from a desperate, bankrupt Nelson Bunker Hunt, who had once insisted that he wouldn't part with it even for $200 million. Mr. Perot, then 34, talked of building a whole new city there, with thousands of office workers, golfers, shoppers and residents.
But the ranch was in Westlake, a hamlet of 250 affluent residents who had moved to the country to escape traffic and crowds.
For Mr. Perot, though, not even lines on a map are unalterable. And so the Westlake aldermen ousted a mayor antagonistic to him and then gave up two-thirds of the town's property, including the Circle T. In a special Saturday meeting, the Fort Worth City Council, eager for development, declared the land Fort Worth's. Amid ensuing lawsuits, it was unclear just who was the Westlake Mayor and which city or town could claim the Circle T.
AT the same time, Mr. Perot was turning back to Dallas. Pointing out his office window in North Dallas at the office park where his father had built E.D.S. and then, in the early 1980's, tried to expand, Mr. Perot delivered a short sermon. "The neighborhood groups did not want Dad to fill out the campus," he said, and the city sided with the neighbors. "That's when Dad left Dallas."
Left -- and started an exodus, to the northern suburb of Plano. The elder Mr. Perot bought land that accommodated several newcomers, starting with E.D.S. "Then another Dallas company, Frito-Lay, then Fina, then Dr Pepper moved to Plano," Ross Jr. said.
By the mid-1990's, Dallas's leaders presided over one of the nation's deadest downtowns -- so dead that even Dallas Mayor Ron Kirk, gazing out his own office window, couldn't resist saying, "You go on a tour of downtown and its attractions now, and you ask, 'What can we do with the other 45 minutes of the hour?' "
Decades earlier, Mr. Perot's father had said he would never run for public office or buy a sports team. But Ross Jr. figured that if an airport could cause the value of the surrounding land to soar, why not an arena?
In early 1996, he bought a 67 percent stake in the Mavericks for $125 million, bluntly declaring that he was in the game for the real estate, not love of the sport. "A lot of people look at a basketball team as an anchor tenant for an arena," he said in announcing the purchase. "I look at an arena as the anchor tenant for a much larger program."
But first, he wanted to persuade the city to pay up and the state to let the city raise its taxes for that purpose. The Texas Legislature, by approving a measure letting Dallas raise its car rental and hotel taxes, allowed backers to say that the cost would fall only on city visitors.
When the city then balked at Mr. Perot's demand that it pay more than half of the arena costs, he took to the air in his company's Bell L-3 helicopter. He carried one suburban mayor after another to view possible arena sites in their towns. He encouraged television helicopters to follow, giving their pilots his radio frequency so that if cameramen missed a shot, he could swoop in again.
"It was just like an Air Force mission," he said.
Mayor Kirk, pressured earlier to avoid giveaways, was now under pressure to make a deal. "Either way, the voters were going to scream at you," he recalled. "But you didn't want to be a mayor that let a team walk away from a city that still hasn't gotten over losing the Cowboys 25 years ago." He agreed for the city to pay $125 million and the team owners just $105 million. In January 1998, voters just barely approved the deal.
To guide his development plans, Mr. Perot visited 25 cities from Shanghai to Berlin and consulted with Edward P. Bass, the Bass brother who led his family in reviving Fort Worth's downtown. Setting his usual high-pressure deadline, Mr. Perot gave five architecture firms only four weeks to submit designs, though most competitions take months.
At the deadline, the architects, gathered at a downtown business club, all had tales of working every day and many nights. When Mr. Perot told Ricardo Legorreta, Mexico's best-known architect, that the competition was great fun, Mr. Legorreta grinned and answered, "More fun for you than it is for us."
Mr. Perot's chose David M. Schwarz of Washington and Fort Worth over Helmut Jahn and other international stars. Mr. Schwarz, whose nostalgic designs have made him royal architect to the Bass family, proposed an updated brick-and-glass version of a college field house. Mr. Perot says the final design, to be revealed as soon as this week, will be substantially different.
The arena will be called the American Airlines Center, with the airline's $190 million payment over 30 years going to the team owners, not to the city. Mr. Perot has dubbed his whole project Victory, a name he announced at a news conference where a film and brochure compared his ambitions to those of Churchill, among others. His design requirements include a victory balcony where athletes can wave their trophies to crowds below.
The balcony is far more likely to accommodate Mr. Hicks's hockey team, the Dallas Stars, which won the Stanley Cup last month, than Mr. Perot's Mavericks, with a record of 19 wins and 31 losses in this year's shortened season. Mr. Perot points out that his team (20-62 the year before) is improving.
Mr. Perot and Mr. Hicks are on the verge of extending their partnership to the full Victory development, with Mr. Hicks saying that he plans to buy a 50 percent interest.
IN Fort Worth, meanwhile, Mr. Perot's plans for the Circle T have come up against officials weary of his muscular tactics. Fidelity Investments wanted to build a 300-acre office park for 2,700 employees but posed one condition: settlement of the feud with Westlake, so the company would know what municipality it would be in. With Westlake having become more receptive, Mr. Perot asked Fort Worth to kindly drop all the Circle T claims he had once encouraged, arguing that the city would still benefit from development in a neighboring town.
At that, Fort Worth's leaders reached their limits. They demanded that Mr. Perot repay the city's legal fees and provide other compensation. After the city blithely let some Perot-imposed deadlines pass, Mr. Perot agreed to build a job training center and buy water supplies from Fort Worth for 30 years.
Dallas, too, expects him to do more than build his brick-and-mortar fortune. A grateful Mayor Kirk has challenged him to take as much responsibility for his city as the Basses of Fort Worth have taken for theirs. "Ross Perot, with his wealth and experience and family," he said, "can do things for Dallas that nobody else can do."

Government connections have, at times, been crucial to Mr. Perot's success, as they were for his father's original business, Electronic Data Systems.

"TEXAS-SIZED DEVELOPMENTS . . ."
American Airlines Center: Taxpayers are picking up $125 million of the $230 million cost of this new downtown arena for the N.B.A.'s Dallas Mavericks, which Mr. Perot also owns, and the N.H.L.'s Dallas Stars. The arena will be the anchor for a retail and office complex valued at more than $1 billion that Mr. Perot calls Victory.
 
Circle T Ranch: Hillwood bought this 2,500-acre ranch on the outskirts of Fort Worth for less than $20 million in 1993 and plans to turn it into a residential, hotel, office and retail complex with three golf courses. Mr. Perot provoked a border dispute over what city controlled the land.
 
Alliance Airport: The largest cargo hub in the Southwest, it was helped along with more than $200 million in cash and tax breaks from Federal, state and local governments. Seventy companies have industrial facilities at this Fort Worth airport.
(Photograph by Mark Graham for The New York Times)(pg. 12)

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3065 words

HEADLINE: Jumping Off the Bandwidth Wagon

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
IN a dingy warren of cables and wires on Manhattan's Upper East Side, phone calls are starting to look a lot like pork bellies.
There, in his cramped office above the Pulse Night Club, Alex Mashinsky, 33, has created an electronic trading floor for telephone service that resembles nothing so much as the international market for traditional commodities. 
 Communications carriers from around the world, including giants like AT&T and Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, link to the Web site for Mr. Mashinsky's company, Arbinet Communications, to trade unused long-distance telephone minutes from New York to every corner of the globe. On Friday, a minute to Israel sold for as little as 8.4 cents, a minute to Hong Kong as little as 4.6 cents.
Although it is tempting to hold up Arbinet as a creator of a new communications landscape, in fact it is only a stark symptom of a much larger shift in the electronic world: While consumers and regulators focus on the communications bottleneck in the so-called last mile of wire to homes and businesses, long-distance communications capacity -- or "bandwidth," a hot buzzword of the Information Moment -- is fast becoming a commodity.
Deregulation, rapid advances in optical technology and generous capital markets have combined to create an explosion in communications supply -- a supply that exceeds even the surging demands in communications unleashed by the Internet. Accordingly, long-distance prices are falling sharply. On Friday, AT&T sold its biggest business customers a minute of telephone time to Israel for 35.4 cents, less than a third of the cost three years ago, and a minute to Hong Kong for 27.2 cents, down 57 percent. The big gap between the retail marketplace and spot markets like Arbinet's cannot last for long.
More significantly, for the companies and investors alike, margins in some parts of the communications business are following suit, as long-distance bandwidth for both telephone and data services turns from scarce to plentiful.
The shift is driving many of the strategy reversals and multibillion-dollar deals that have become almost commonplace in the industry. It explains AT&T's burst into the cable television business and the continuing, soap-opera-like bidding war between Qwest Communications International and Global Crossing for the Frontier Corporation and U S West.
At the same time, the fierce competition in the long-distance arena only highlights its relative absence in local markets. That, in turn, reinforces the almost overarching value of local communications networks -- and is prompting some investors to rethink their portfolios for the digital future.
 
A New Profit Formula
The changes in the long-distance industry are undermining what is perhaps the fundamental rule of telecommunications economics -- that margins stick to assets.
After AT&T began to face significant competition about two decades ago, it became clear that long-term profits in the business stemmed largely from controlling physical assets like fiber optic lines, copper wires and communications switches. For years, the cost of running a network was a big part, perhaps a third or more, of running a communications business. A major component of making money was keeping the continuing network costs low, and the main way to do so was to own the network.
That is one reason Sprint emerged from a venture of the Southern Pacific Railroad, which could use its railroad rights-of-way to lay fiber-optic lines. It also explains MCI's original name, Microwave Communications Inc.; by using microwave links it had developed, MCI could provide long-distance services for less than AT&T. (MCI eventually built its own fiber optic network, to help the company compete more broadly.)
Most of the hundreds of other new long-distance companies that emerged after the 1984 breakup of AT&T, however, leased communications capacity from others, and few have had consistent profits and growth.
Drawing from that experience, new companies like Qwest, Level 3 Communications, Global Crossing, IXC Communications and the communications units of the Williams Companies and Enron, two energy giants, have been founded -- and financed -- on the logic that owning physical assets was essential. Each of the companies is building a new fiber optic long-distance network, some in the United States and some globally. Combined, the first three have raised or borrowed more than $10 billion over the last three years, mainly to build their new networks. At the same time, new optical technologies have been expanding the capacity of existing networks by factors of 16 and 32, with a potential of 160.
To grasp just how much bandwidth is being created, consider this: According to Telegeography Inc., a research firm in Washington, in 1997 the world's public telephone networks carried 81.8 billion minutes, or 155,632 years, worth of international phone calls. The newest optical systems can transmit the digital equivalent of all of those calls over a single fiber in about 11 days.
Hence the new carriers' predicament: Their investments are alleviating the very scarcity that made their original business plans so attractive.
The problem is not that a glut of bandwidth has been created. It is clear that new, bandwidth-hungry services will fill all of the available communications pipes. However, the big profits in the industry are migrating away from raw bandwidth and toward the applications that use it.
An early sign of how prices would turn volatile as bandwidth supply played leapfrog with demand was in the market for T-3 Internet lines, which can carry 45 million bits of digital information a second.
When they first became widely available in 1995, the lines sometimes cost less than $20,000 a month; buyers included corporate customers and Internet service providers. But as the use of the Internet exploded, demand outpaced supply, and prices shot as high as $70,000 a month in early 1996.
Since then, however, prices have fallen consistently, by about 10 percent a year, as new and existing carriers have built up their networks. T-3 lines now cost about $50,000 a month, and many in the industry expect the trend to continue or even accelerate.
"People have been thinking about bandwidth from a Malthusian standpoint: 'How do I ration this?' " said Daniel Smith, chief executive of Sycamore Networks, a communications equipment company, whose previous business, Cascade Communications, another equipment maker, was bought by Ascend Communications in 1997 for $3.7 billion. "And now we're saying, 'How do we think about this from a standpoint of plenty?' "
Many of the nation's communications carriers have come up with an answer: They need to evolve up the digital food chain -- from mere bandwidth suppliers to providers of advanced services -- to maintain their profit margins in the future. They are scrambling to acquire direct links to homes and offices -- not for the assets per se, but because in the next century, margins in the communications business will stick to services and customers.
"If anything, the cost of communications is falling faster than the cost of computing, so assume unlimited bandwidth," said Howard Anderson, managing director of the Yankee Group, a technology consulting firm in Boston. In that case, he said, "you are either the application service innovator, or you're dead meat."
 
Moving to Plan B
The shift has shred business plans across the industry and helped fuel the paroxysm of takeovers reshaping the communications landscape.
AT&T provides a classic example. Many strategic subcurrents have been at work behind AT&T's $90 billion leap into the cable TV business, from a need to protect its long-distance base to the simple desire to shake the company out of a torpor. But at the root has been a quest for sustainable profits, and the brain trust at AT&T's headquarters in Basking Ridge, N.J., decided that such profits were not to be found merely in the long-distance business.
Having a long-distance network is "a necessary, but not sufficient, condition to succeed in the future," said Frank Ianna, president of AT&T's network unit. Instead, AT&T concluded that it again needed to connect directly to its customers. "That's where there's the least amount of competition," he explained, referring to local markets, "and that's where you have the ability to differentiate from your competition."
AT&T is betting that owning cable lines directly into customers' homes will allow it to deliver interactive television, high-speed Internet services and local phone service -- all products that should support higher margins than its core long-distance service.
MCI Worldcom, the No. 2 long-distance provider, after AT&T, has almost the same philosophy, but with a focus on serving business customers. It, too, sees its future in services and applications, not simply bandwidth. And it also wants to own the direct link to the customer.
"Our story is very different from offering raw capacity," said John W. Sidgmore, vice chairman of MCI Worldcom.
In Worldcom's evolution from communications nobody to industry titan over the last decade, the company's deal to acquire MFS Communications in 1996 looks at least as important strategically as its acquisition of MCI last year. The MFS deal gave Worldcom not only direct, local fiber optic links to business customers, but also the Uunet Internet operation run by Mr. Sidgmore. Uunet, coupled with MCI's corporate data communications operation, is now driving MCI Worldcom's growth, by developing the advanced data applications, like intranets, demanded by big business customers and delivering them worldwide.
Since MCI and Worldcom announced their merger in the fall of 1997, telephone service revenue has dropped from 68 to 61 percent of the combined company's overall sales, while Internet and corporate data services have grown from 22 percent to 30 percent. In the first quarter of 1999, telephone service revenue increased only 7 percent over the comparable 1998 period, while data services sales grew 30 percent and Internet revenue 60 percent.
At Qwest, the shift in focus toward the top of the food chain has happened in fast-forward, and some investors have found it unsettling.
When the company first offered shares to the public in 1997, it was seen on Wall Street as a bandwidth play. Investors expected Qwest to concentrate on using the latest technology to build a long-distance network with more, and cheaper, capacity than those of companies like AT&T or MCI, letting the upstart take market share away from slower, less-advanced competitors.
Over the last year, though, Qwest has repositioned itself as -- surprise! -- a provider of advanced communications services for end users. This year alone, Qwest has announced partnerships with companies including KPMG, BellSouth, Siebel Systems, SAP America, Hewlett-Packard, Oracle and Automatic Data Processing's Brokerage Services unit to develop high-margin applications like software for sales forces, aimed at various market segments//cut for space.
And now, Qwest is making an unsolicited run at acquiring Frontier, a long-distance company that also owns Globalcenter, one of the biggest Web-hosting concerns, and U S West, the regional Bell company based in Denver. U S West is the slowest-growing Bell, but it still has millions of customers, whom Qwest needs for the new services it is developing.
Qwest is trying to wrench Frontier and U S West from the grasp of another erstwhile bandwidth play, Global Crossing. While both Qwest and Global Crossing have made cases for why their deals make sense, their sudden transformations have left some investors scratching their heads.
"It's created confusion," said Eric Strumingher, an analyst at Paine Webber. "Qwest and Global Crossing have represented themselves as growth companies, as nimble companies based on modern technology and that had the most flexibility. Now they're attempting to combine with a company that was not representing itself like that, and is in fact not like that. That is the big source of the indigestion."
 
Divergent Philosophies
To James Q. Crowe, perhaps the most prominent executive still carrying the flag for the pure bandwidth strategy, this is all tantamount to heresy.
Mr. Crowe is chief executive of Level 3, which is building a national fiber optic communications network based on Internet systems and the latest optical technology. Mr. Crowe says he has no intention of selling advanced services to consumers. He says that through shrewd investments, he can sustain a technical advantage over his competitors. That, in turn, would let Level 3 sustain a cost advantage, enabling the company to persist as a wholesaler of long-distance bandwidth.
"I think I can drop prices faster than anyone else can keep up with and have margins that are sustainable," Mr. Crowe said. "If you can get a six- or nine-month technical advantage over your competition, you can have a long, long, long life."
The stock market has hardly abandoned Mr. Crowe's world view -- shares of Level 3 are up 56 percent this year -- but others in the industry say he is ignoring the commoditization of bandwidth at considerable peril.
"I respect Jim and I've worked with Jim, but I think he's absolutely, completely dead wrong," Mr. Sidgmore said. "It really is black and white. The fact of the matter is that if you just stand back and think about it, Jim is not going to invent any new technology. It's coming from Lucent or Cisco. And do you think they're going to give anyone an exclusive? If you wanted to give someone an exclusive, it would be the company that could buy the most product; it would be MCI Worldcom or AT&T."
But Level 3 is different from those companies -- if not from Qwest or Global Crossing, in their original guises -- because it has no existing customer or revenue base to protect. That, Mr. Crowe says, will keep his company more focused.
"History tells us that when you get bigger and bigger and more and more vertically integrated, you break businesses apart," Mr. Crowe said. "That's like starting a computer company in 1980 and saying the model is I.B.M."
Indeed, some communications experts think that consumers will suffer as carriers seek vertical integration.
"As someone on the buying end of it, rather than the selling end of it, I'd like the companies that provide bandwidth to do a really good job of that rather than do what the local telcos have done, which is bring services into their networks," said Robert M. Metcalfe, one of the founders of the 3Com Corporation. Mr. Metcalfe, now an industry consultant, contends that the Bell companies, which dominate local communications, have done a poor job of making advanced services available to consumers, even as they try to fend off competition.
For investors, it may not really matter who is right. Even some people who own or recommend the stocks of companies like Level 3 acknowledge that the pure bandwidth strategy may not endure for the long term -- but add that many such companies will probably be acquired in the next few years anyway, perhaps as foreign carriers expand into the United States.
Still, some professional investors are shifting their focus to the remaining points of scarcity in the communications business -- local assets and expertise in advanced services, especially on the Internet. That is why Michael J. Mahoney, director of telecommunications investment at Dresdner RCM Global Investors, likes MCI Worldcom but is also becoming more bullish about local communications companies.
"We have a decent position on the local side," he said, "and if anything, we're steadily growing in our affection for the local side." Mr. Mahoney particularly likes GTE, which is trying to merge with Bell Atlantic, and SBC, which appears close to completing its deal to buy Ameritech.
Mr. Mashinsky of Arbinet, the communications exchange in Manhattan, watches the new world of long-distance evolve every day on his computer screen. To him, the shift is clear. The future is not in electronic pork bellies; it is in the fiber optic equivalent of processed meats.
"Over the last three years, $402 billion was invested in telecom worldwide, and a lot of that went into infrastructure," he said. But many companies "have not been able to fill up their networks, because there are too many people building networks.
"So a lot of these guys are refocusing," Mr. Mashinsky added, "and saying that if we want to retain our margins, we have to get a hold of some customers and add some value."
 
Changes Down the Food Chain
 
IF long-distance phone service is becoming a commodity and bandwidth is being traded at the wholesale level for pennies a minute, some everyday telephone users may be wondering why their phone bills are becoming more complicated and sometimes going up.
The answer is as unfortunate for the relatively unwired as it is welcome for the long-distance industry: You have to spend in order to save.
The falling cost of long-distance capacity is, in fact, leading to drastically lower per-minute rates. Some small carriers, like the IDT Corporation, offer flat rates as low as 8 cents a minute for calls at any time to anywhere in the country.
But many consumers who want the psychological comfort and gold-plated service of a big-name carrier are now facing monthly minimum charges. AT&T, for instance, recently began charging its basic rate customers -- those who do not sign up for a special calling plan -- a $3 monthly minimum. MCI Worldcom also charges many of its basic rate customers a monthly minimum of up to $5. The carriers justify the charges by explaining that they were incurring more costs in billing and tracking low-volume customers than they were taking in as per-minute fees.
Regulatory changes have made bills even more complex. Long-distance bills include a monthly charge of about $1 to cover the cost of offering local service in poor and rural communities, as well as a flat fee of at least $1 to cover the cost of linking long-distance and local networks.
Consumers were paying for these things before, but as part of higher per-minute rates. With the Telecommunications Act of 1996, those fees are now flat and explicit, while per-minute rates have declined. SETH SCHIESEL

SECTION: Section 3; Page 6; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Measuring TheForce Of the Euro

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: ROME

 BODY:
SIX months into the euro era, some of the assumptions about how European stock markets would behave once the single currency arrived are looking shaky.
One theory, for instance, had it that the euro would shift market volatility to industry sectors and away from individual national markets. Indexes would be moved more by, say, European auto sales figures than by a political crisis in Italy or France. Some people even predicted the end of single-country mutual funds, as Europe transformed itself into a market like the United States, where investors watch chemicals, automobiles or electronics, and not necessarily the Northeast or the Midwest. 
 Indeed, European stock markets appeared headed in that direction, with announcements of planned mergers involving exchanges in Frankfurt, London, Paris, Milan and elsewhere.
But in the euro's first half-year, it has not worked out quite that way, at least yet. Borders still count along with sectors in investment decisions, and national stock markets have been casting up widely differing returns. While France, Germany and Finland made big gains in the last six months, Belgium and Portugal have slumped, and Spain and Italy have been somewhat listless.
Part of the explanation is that the euro's arrival has sent huge amounts of capital across national borders as currency hurdles have fallen.
Whereas a German asset manager like Commerzbank previously had more than half its funds in German stocks, that fraction has now dropped to one-third, said Nils Stoerling, chief investment officer at the bank's asset management arm in Frankfurt. The pattern has repeated itself across the Continent, pushing up some markets and hurting others as institutions redeploy their money.
In Spain, about 70 percent of fresh capital is going into Europe-wide investments, and only 30 percent into Spanish shares, said Eduardo Suarez, head of asset management at Santander Gestion de Activos in Madrid. A result: The Madrid stock index fell from a high in January before gaining ground again this month. "The appetite for euro equities is outstanding," he said.
The shift is not only geographical. Money is also flowing from the stocks of small companies -- those with a market value of $300 million to $1.5 billion -- into large-capitalization European corporations that are the elite of European business. "It is something we saw from about a year ago," said Felix Lanters, head of European equity investment at ABN Amro Asset Management in Amsterdam. "And it is one reason why the big caps are outperforming the market. There is interest in top names."
Commerzbank, Mr. Stoerling said, used to follow the old DAX 100-stock index of German companies. Now, its asset managers have assembled a 270-stock index, he said, with almost two-thirds of the companies spread across Euroland, as the euro nations are called, plus Switzerland and Britain, which have not adopted the currency.
As had been expected, many European asset managers are also reorganizing their research, shifting it from individual European countries to industry sectors or a blend of the two. "We started looking at sectors six years ago," said David Duncan, of Global Asset Management in London.
But, he said, his firm still casts "generally, a final glance" at geography, "to make sure you're not 95 percent in Finland, because you've liked the looks of Nokia," the hugely popular Finnish phone company.
Eric Taze-Bernard, chief investment officer in Luxembourg at Paribas Asset Management, said many institutional investors now combine sector and regional analysis. Their reluctance to jettison regional factors, he said, was a result of their rejection of a "false idea about economic convergence."
Rather than forcing European economies to march more closely in step, he said, the euro's imposition of uniform interest rates on differing national economies has served to sharpen cyclical differences. Lower European interest rates may help spur growth in slow economies, like Germany's or Italy's, but can overheat economies that are purring nicely, like Ireland's.
For the moment, many asset managers expect the drive into European large-cap companies to continue. Mr. Suarez of Santander estimated that "only about 30 percent of the reorganization is done," and said it would take one to two more years before capital flows began shifting away from large-cap companies in major economies like Germany and France and toward small-cap companies in markets like Ireland, Belgium and Portugal.
The shifting capital flows, however, are enhanced by a flood of new money that is likely to lift European stocks over all, experts say. J. Paul Horne, an economist at Salomon Smith Barney in London, said European transfers from traditional forms of savings, like bank accounts and life insurance, to stocks and corporate bonds would probably total about $1 trillion in two to three years, buoying European markets.
And the current strength of the dollar against the euro adds to the possible allure of European stocks for American investors. Since it was introduced, the euro has fallen from nearly $1.18 to just below $1.02 on Friday. A rebound in the euro's value would add to European stock market returns in dollars. "The euro, having hit a trough," he said, "adds to the attractiveness of European securities."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Calling All Swat Teams;
This Just In: The Latest Buzz From California

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
IN the two decades since John Belushi bellowed, "Your honey or your wife!" as a corpulent killer bee on "Saturday Night Live," those relentless, aggressive insects have passed out of the realm of schlock movies and sketch comedy and into the daily reality of life in states along the Mexican border, beginning nine years ago in Texas.
This spring, the last corner of Los Angeles County's 4,000 square miles was declared officially colonized by Africanized honey bees, when a swarm was found lurking under the eves of a building in the desolate desert suburb of Palmdale. 
 Science has been powerless to stop the bees' steady northward march from South America, and the sighting of a single swirling swarm in a backyard tree can still prompt a brief mention on the local television news.
But there is nothing like the panic in the streets that Hollywood's mid-1970's imagination predicted.
Maybe Californians have reacted to this latest invader with equanimity because their state has long been home to a rogues' gallery of flying, crawling pestilence. This is, after all, the place "where bowers of flowers bloom in the sun," and that means a motley chorus of pests the world over is always buzzing "California, Here I Come!" and posing new threats to the state's $27 billion-a-year agricultural industry.
There are thrips, tiny juice-sucking insects that prey on avocados, scarring and discoloring the fruit so it looks like a potato. There are olive fruit flies from the Mediterranean, discovered here last fall, the first ever in California and perhaps in all of North America, which leave black olives grayish-white and rotting. There are red imported fire ants from South America, whose mounds grow as big as basketballs and make it hard to move harvesting equipment through orchards.
And now come the Africanized bees, whose ancestors came from South Africa and were released inadvertently from a Brazilian breeding experiment 42 years ago. They have gradually moved north and west, and recently were discovered for the first time east of the Mississippi River, in Jacksonville, Fla.
The bees are no more venomous than their calmer cousins but are considerably more aggressive, capable of delivering 10 times as many stings.
In California, the bees stand poised to colonize the commercial honey-bee hives that are vital to pollinating commercial crops, principally almond groves. Because the Africanized bees are unpredictable and harder to manage, they represent a threat to an important industry.
"Why do we have so many things blooming and growing together here that don't belong together?" asks Robert Page, an entomologist at the University of California at Davis who has helped isolate a gene that may make Africanized bees meaner. "We've been a real cultural mixing bowl forever. Everybody who comes wants to bring their favorite plant. And when they come, they also bring their favorite plant's parasite or disease agent."
In this state, there is seldom a letup.
In 1982 the State Department of Agriculture set up the Pest Detection Emergency Protection division to combat an invasion of the Mediterranean fruit fly, which attacks 250 types of crops.
"We had a long discussion about what we would do when there wasn't an emergency project to keep people busy," Pat Minyard, the division's manager, said ruefully, adding: "We've never had that situation. There is an extraordinary range of problems."
Alan Jennings, director of Pest Management Policy for the Department of Agriculture in Washington, said he knew of no formal ranking of pests by state, but that California and Florida, with their warm climates, long growing seasons and diverse crops, would be together at the top.
"It's not a pest unless it's doing something economically," Mr. Jennings said. "What rises to be a pest is a direct function of what you're growing."
For ordinary citizens, Africanized bees can be a severe annoyance, and there have been a handful of fatalities, including a 72-year-old man who was attacked and killed two years ago in his mobile home in Casa Grande, Ariz.
Noise, like that from lawn mowers or leaf blowers, seems to aggravate the bees. The Africanized variety will chase a human who disturbs it up to a quarter mile, 12 times as far as the European bee, and if you duck under water, it will simply outwait you.
"Right now, everyone should just increase their awareness about it," said Oscar Hidalgo, a spokesman for the State Agriculture Department. "There's not really much that we can do to stop its flow. We live with a lot of pests that can harm you, sting you. Awareness is the key."
By contrast, California works diligently to stop the flow of pests that pose more immediate threats to agriculture, especially the various fruit flies that love backyards and commercial orchards.
At the moment, much of San Diego is under quarantine because of Mexican fruit fly infestations, and big black and white signs dotting the freeways warn residents not to move fruit from trees in their own backyards.
"A lot of times, people don't realize the impact they could have in bringing even a single piece of fruit," Mr. Hidalgo said. "You shouldn't even take it off your property. If you take it a mile, two miles to your office, now that's an infested area, too. But it's something we have to basically use the honor system on."
Last fall, in the Westwood section of Los Angeles, 10 olive fruit flies were found in a residential neighborhood, and about 400 have now been trapped in an effort to gauge the scale of the problem over a 300-square mile area.
Officials say it was the first-ever sighting of this pest in California, though it is widespread in Europe and North Africa. Unlike other fruit flies, it poses a threat only to olives, but California is the nation's sole producer of commercially grown olives, with a 1997 crop valued at nearly $70 million. Most of the growing areas are well north of Los Angeles, but officials are taking no chances.
"Right now," said Mr. Minyard of the state agriculture department, "we're just trapping, trying to wait and see."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Common Causes;
Left and Right Are Crossing Paths

BYLINE: By ETHAN BRONNER 

 BODY:
THE bedfellows get stranger and stranger: Henry J. Hyde, the anti-abortion, right-wing Republican Congressman, joins forces with Barney Frank, the gay, left-wing Democrat, to curb Federal power in property forfeiture: Ron K. Unz, the conservative Republican who helped end bilingual education in California, argues against school vouchers in the pages of The Nation, a leftist magazine; the Clinton Administration fights its longtime allies, the trade unions, over their support of steel import quotas.
Politics has long forged odd alliances but there is clearly something significant happening to the national debate when give-peace-a-chance Vietnam doves morph into Kosovo hawks and the front-runner for each party's Presidential nomination slams the door on traditional party militants to capture the political center when the nomination process has barely begun. 
 Not long ago, when people were described as "on the left" or "on the right," liberal or conservative, Democrat or Republican, their views on a range of issues -- on religion and state, education, war and peace, taxation -- could be inferred. That's no longer the case.
Republicans who tried for years to kill the Department of Education now want to be known as the education party. The Democrats, whose long commitment to fighting poverty was evident last week in President Clinton's tour of the nation's poor areas, have effectively ended welfare. And the White House, sounding like a group of Rockefeller Republicans, says a keystone of foreign policy should be opening the world to American exports and investments.
"All the big issues that used to divide the left and right -- the cold war, inflation, crime, welfare -- have just collapsed as partisan issues," said Francis Fukuyama, a professor of public policy at George Mason University. Professor Fukuyama predicted, in some fashion, the current confusion a decade ago with a much-discussed article in The National Interest magazine titled "The End of History?" in which he argued that liberal democracy and a market-oriented economy were the only viable option for modern societies.
Professor Fukuyama was dismissed by those who noted that history, far from ending, quickly found other conflicts on which to focus: the era of the angry white male in American politics, followed by the Clinton impeachment fight, made reports of the death of ideology and the end of the culture war seem premature.
Moreover, some believe that the big conflicts are far from over, that a vague and dangerous centrism has masked, not solved, them. Republican conservatives, disenchanted by the party's abandonment of the crusade against abortion and other matters they consider pro family, said last month they might start a new party.
"The relativism that is being so widely adopted may be the dominant culture, but there is another culture that is very uncomfortable with it and is resisting it," said Gertrude Himmelfarb, a conservative historian, whose book "One Nation, Two Cultures," is to be published this fall by Knopf. "There are many of us who are still resisting the 60's."
THE traditional left is no less incensed by what it sees as the nation's acquiescence to the Reaganism of the 1980's -- the end of welfare, the growing resegregation of American schools, the wide acceptance of the death penalty and the lack of availability of health care for millions of people.
"There is no question that the failure of Communism has a lot to do with the marginalization of the left," said Katha Pollitt, a columnist for The Nation. "But for me the central value of the left is a commitment to equality, including economic equality, and we have less of that today than we had 20 years ago."
Nonetheless, few in this country or abroad argue much any more with Professor Fukuyama's point about the centrality of markets to modern societies.
Robert Hue, national secretary of the French Communist party, which in the 1970's and 80's maintained a firm Marxist line, said recently: "The Communists are not adversaries of the market. The Communists have broken with the statist vision of things."
The leftist governments in Britain and Germany are further evidence of this change. When the Labor Party leader Tony Blair was elected Prime Minister in Britain, a London tabloid ran a caricature of him dressed in baby clothes as his Conservative predecessor, Margaret Thatcher, cooed, "It's a boy."
In Russia today, Communists are considered conservatives and free-marketers liberals. In Israel, the group that most resembles the founding socialist Zionists, with their frowzy clothes, collectivist vision and unyielding dedication, are the right-wing Jewish settlers in the West Bank.
There is much talk among former leftists here and in Europe of something they call the third way, or what may be seen as capitalism with a conscience. But it is pretty hard to distinguish it from the compassionate conservatism that serves as the rallying cry of Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the Republican Presidential front-runner.
Indeed, while the eclipse of the left has clearly played a major role in the shift, the demise of the right is equally significant. Paul Weyrich, who coined the phrase Moral Majority in the 1970's and was the godfather of what became a substantial political movement, said recently that the effort had ended in failure.
Governor Bush has said he will not require judicial nominees to oppose abortion, which had been a standard Republican position. The evangelist Pat Robertson has acknowledged: "There's no way that we are going to pass a constitutional amendment banning abortion. It's just not going to happen."
A few months ago, when Mr. Weyrich said, "We lost the culture war," he was referring to the fact that most Americans did not view President Clinton's extramarital sex and lies as the basis for impeachment, but he was also casting the issue in larger terms: efforts to expunge 60's-era personal morals had failed.
Alan Wolfe, a professor of political science at Boston College, agrees in some sense with Mr. Weyrich. He spent several years interviewing middle-class Americans for his book "One Nation, After All" (Viking, 1998) and found that most people are far more tolerant of others and other ways of life than is often assumed.
As Professor Wolfe puts his findings now, "The right won the economic war, the left won the cultural war and the center won the political war."
While most analysts agree that the nation seems to be entering an uncharted era of consensual politics, they don't agree on why.
Michael Lind, a senior fellow at the New America Foundation in Washington, has argued in a series of books and articles that what is really going on is that a university-trained professional "overclass" has managed to suppress discussion of class conflicts that are as powerful as ever.
The goal of the new ruling class, Mr. Lind argues, is increased wealth and comfort for itself, and anything that interferes -- curbs on immigration, labor or free trade, which would make it harder to find domestic help and cheap employees and the purchase of products it wants -- is opposed by all members of the class, whether they call themselves Democrats or Republicans, liberals or conservatives. Disagreements over so-called wedge issues, Mr. Lind maintains, are a ruse aimed at making the rest of the nation believe there is debate going on.
Virginia Postrel, editor of Reason magazine, a libertarian monthly, has a different interpretation. In her book "The Future and Its Enemies" (Free Press, 1998), she contends that the old categories of left and right have lost their usefulness because the world has changed.
"A defining question in one era -- whether to nationalize the railroads, give women the vote, outlaw racial segregation or abolish the draft -- may be settled and therefore meaningless in another," she writes. "Nowadays, 'conservatives' may support careers for women, and 'liberals' may back the death penalty."
Ms. Postrel urges abandoning traditional political categories and creating new ones, namely "dynamists" -- those who accept and promote innovation -- and "stasists," who favor a regulated, engineered world. She clearly comes down on the side of the dynamists, arguing that only through unregulated experimentation will society advance materially and intellectually.
With the explosion of information and technological innovation, she argues, central planning bodies are impotent; only freedom, even chaos, will do. By promoting such practices, she says, societies will progress; by squelching them, they will go the way of centrally planned governments.
THIS is not a new idea but has come to a kind of fruition. Half a century ago, the conservative economist Friedrich A. Hayek argued that socialism had no future because in a modern economy the vast majority of information generated is local in character and requires higher and higher degrees of sophistication to grasp. As a result, distant managers or bureaucrats are unlikely to be sufficiently nimble or informed to make good decisions.
Today, it is not only Soviet-style governments that have been forced to undergo change but large corporations like I.B.M., which nearly collapsed and has had to create more entrepreneurial styles of work for its employees.
With such a focus on individual initiative and the accompanying access to vast quantities of information, it is not surprising that broad ideological approaches are losing out to a case-by-case, problem-solving one. Nor is it surprising that with increased exposure to other people and ideas has come increased tolerance and openness to other ways of life.
It is entirely appropriate that Silicon Valley has become one of the country's focal points because its arresting combination of market economics and informal personal and social behavior -- Reaganesque politics of the 1980's and Clintonesque morals of the 60's -- seems to define the nation today. Many had previously thought the two incompatible. The sociologist Daniel Bell once wrote of the inherent contradiction between the Protestant ethic of capitalism and the hedonism it created. And Reagan Republicans tended to think of their goal as reversing the trends of the 60's. Yet many analysts argue today that the Reaganites accomplished their own revolution without really shifting the society as they had hoped; they may have curbed the extremes of the 1960's but much of the rest has been absorbed into mainstream culture.
Mark Lilla, a political philosopher at New York University, wrote in The New York Review of Books in May that the two revolutions are coexisting nicely right now.
"The facts are these," he wrote. "The 60's happened, Reagan happened and for the foreseeable future they will together define our political horizon. As anyone who deals with young people today knows, Americans find no difficulty in reconciling the two in their daily lives. They see no contradiction in holding down day jobs in the unfettered global marketplace -- the Reaganite dream, the left nightmare -- and spending weekends immersed in a moral and cultural universe shaped by the 60's."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 16; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: A Need for Foreign Aid

 BODY:
For a nation of America's wealth, providing aid to alleviate misery in the poorest countries is a worthy cause. But foreign aid is also important to protect American interests. Assistance that helps prevent foreign political conflicts or economic calamities can reduce the need for far more costly future American involvement.
Congress has ignored this rule, and is once again embarked on an effort to slash foreign aid. Such assistance, which pays for everything from military training for American allies to disaster relief, already makes up less than 1 percent of the Federal budget. 
 Spending on aid has dropped by more than 50 percent in inflation-adjusted dollars since 1985. The Senate last month approved a foreign operations appropriation for 2000 that is $800 million less than this year's $13.5 billion total, and $1.9 billion less than President Clinton's request. The House appropriation is expected to be even lower.
The Clinton Administration has justifiably threatened to veto the appropriations bill unless money is added to pay for programs to dismantle nuclear weapons in the former Soviet Union and to support the Wye River peace agreement between Israel and the Palestinians, as well as to restore cuts to dozens of other programs, including the Peace Corps. The White House also strongly opposes language in the spending bill that could limit the Administration's options in managing the situation in Kosovo.
Critics often point to past failures. During the cold war aid was doled out to corrupt anti-Communist regimes that did nothing to improve the conditions of the poor. But aid can be effective in relieving poverty if it is used to strengthen civil society and nurture reform. The Clinton Administration has tried to put money into programs that promote democracy-building, community-based economic development and local initiatives on environmental protection and health care.
Roughly half of the current aid budget supports military or security-related objectives, and is likely to stay that way. Israel and Egypt alone now get about 40 percent of the total. A modest share of the budget is spent on refugee and emergency aid. Only about a third of the budget goes to traditional development activities running the gamut from child immunizations to microcredit programs. Development programs with long-term promise tend to suffer the cuts.
Development experts have become smarter about how to use aid to improve economic and social institutions. The World Bank recently reported that an extra $10 billion in aid annually could lift 25 million people out of poverty if the money was directed to countries with sound fiscal policies and a healthy public sector. While more countries are meeting these criteria, total development assistance worldwide from industrialized nations has dropped by one-third since 1991, with Washington leading that decline. The trend is tragic given how much needs to be done to help the more than one billion people in extreme poverty who live on less than $1 a day. The Clinton Administration's goals for foreign aid are not particularly ambitious. But Congress's effort to trim back the meager funds is a shortsighted national shame.

LENGTH: 1096 words

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Karma and Helms;
A Stick for China, a Carrot for Tibet's Lobby

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IT'S not every day that Jesse Helms and the Beastie Boys find themselves comrades in arms.
About the only thing the chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee and the hip-hop group have in common is contempt for China for its treatment of Tibetans. The Beasties hold concerts to support the Dalai Lama. Senator Helms leads the conservative charge against the Clinton Administration's China policy -- coddling dictators to make a buck, he says -- and inveighs against the World Bank, which he and his allies lump together with the United Nations, the International Monetary Fund and other mysterious institutions that often go their own way. 
 This alliance of convenience came together recently in a remarkable face-off between Washington and the World Bank over a development project so small and out of the way that it would usually attract little notice: A $40 million effort to relocate 58,000 of China's poorest farmers -- they make $60 a year -- to more fertile land in Qinghai province in western China. The problem was that they would be moving into territory the Tibetans consider part of their original homeland, even though most maps show it outside Tibet and the Chinese consider it non-Tibetan land. Critics said the bank was aiding China's effort to dilute the minority Tibetan population -- and doing so in the province that was the birthplace of the Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader of Tibet.
And therein lies an unusual tale of Washington lobbying.
In a few weeks the Tibet lobby -- best known for patrons like Richard Gere and Harrison Ford but power-challenged by Washington's usual measures -- mobilized allies on the far left and the far right. In a flash it reversed White House policy, and led the Administration's nominee for Treasury Secretary, Lawrence H. Summers, to announce that the United States would try to block the loan. The World Bank emerged bloodied, and agreed to study the issue anew. It was a feat that the city's highly paid power brokers could only admire.
Usually, only the lobbyists with the deepest pockets and the busiest PAC's get that kind of attention. Silicon Valley, source of all those new-economy campaign contributions, won two tremendous victories recently: limiting damages from suits arising from Year 2000 computer bugs, and convincing the Administration to relax export controls on powerful but widely available computers, including sales to China. After years of wrangling, the House finally passed a financial restructuring bill this month that was so hotly contested by banks and brokerages, and for so many years, that many thought Congress would debate it forever to keep the money flowing in from all sides.
But every once in a while the stars align in a way that smaller and far less wealthy groups can score a big victory. It helps if they show pictures of crushing poverty or tell stories of repression and -- most important -- side with politicians who may have ulterior agendas. The Tibetan crowd did all of that and won at least a partial victory.
"This was a culmination of forces that have been gathering steam for years," said John Kenneth Knaus, who spent four decades at the Central Intelligence Agency helping the Tibetan resistance fight the Chinese and recently recounted that struggle in a book, "Orphans of the Cold War" (Public Affairs, 1999). "They have always been a very cohesive group, and their story has always had a great appeal in Congress. But this time they got further."
CHINA occupied Tibet in 1950, and Tibet's political fortunes have waxed and waned in Washington depending on the prevailing mood toward Beijing. China considers it a province, and screams whenever it believes Washington is meddling in its internal affairs. When the 64-year-old Dalai Lama shows up in Washington, he is handled like a chunk of plutonium, meeting the President in diplomatically staged "drop by" visits, sitting in the offices of lesser officials.
But if ever the Tibet lobbyists had an opportunity, this was the moment. The accusations of Chinese spying at nuclear laboratories in the United States and the anti-American protests after the accidental bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade have left Congressional conservatives looking for a quick, cost-free way to lash out at China. Human rights groups have concluded that the Administration's China policy is one of toothless, token statements.
Onto this battlefield walked the World Bank, whose savvy president, James Wolfensohn, usually sees land mines ahead and saunters around them. But China was pressing for this loan as part of a last series of interest-free deals that end after June 30. The details were rushed. The environmental studies were done once over lightly. "It was not only politically offensive," said Dana Clark, a senior attorney for the Center for International Environmental Law. "It was done in violation of the bank's own policies." Meanwhile China threatened to end its relations with the bank if the loan was denied -- a step that would give the West less control over Beijing's actions.
Quickly the Office of Tibet, which represents the Dalai Lama, and the International Campaign for Tibet were swinging into action. Members of the Senate were lined up to ask about the program at Mr. Summers'sconfirmation hearing. The Treasury, not looking for a fight at a sensitive time, immediately agreed to oppose the plan. So did Germany. World Bank officials were called to a meeting on Capitol Hill and saw the future.
"When you have a coalition of students in California with body piercings saying the same thing as Jesse Helms," one World Bank official said, "you are on a highway to nowhere." On the left and the right, the official said, the message to the bank was simple: "If you do this, we will kill you."
Mr. Wolfensohn tried to travel to the region himself, then sent a team to reconfirm that the resettlement of the farmers would be voluntary, and that children would attend schools reflecting their ethnic backgrounds. "This is the first time most of these children will get a school," he said. China, he added, didn't need the bank's money -- but with it, the West would have a voice in what China does in the region.
IN the end, the World Bank's board approved the loan for the resettlement -- in part because it feared the United States was moving on an isolationist path that would only worsen relations with China. But the Chinese won't get the money until an independent review board within the World Bank looks at the project. The Tibetan lobby vows to be back.

A Chinese antipoverty project would resettle 58,000 farmers from an overcrowded, eroded area in the northeastern corner of Qinghai province to a sparsely populated area 300 miles to the west. Qinghai is part of the Tibetan Plateau, which was historically settled by Tibetan and Mongolian people. Forty percent of the proposed settlers would be ethnic Chinese, along with Hui Muslims and other groups. Critics have attacked the plan as a threat to Tibetan culture. Map of China shows where the farmers live now and where they would move.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
For Better and Worse, Poverty's Poster Child

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

 BODY:
WHEN President Clinton headed to the back roads of Appalachia last week to call attention to those left out of the nation's pageant of prosperity, his visit had a distinctly familiar air. John F. Kennedy, Robert Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson had all made the trip more than 30 years ago.
You can still find many of the poorest Americans living in the shadow of rickety coal tipples in Appalachian hollows, but Mr. Clinton's visit, in fact, had as much to do with change as constancy. Despite the poverty that persists, Appalachia is a very different place with very different economic development needs than it was in the 1960's. 
 What never seems to change is the mythology of the place as the poster child for American poverty, an image that persists, to the region's detriment and benefit, no matter how much times change.
"We're always glad when we get any kind of attention, because the region remains so misunderstood," said Jean Haskell, director of the Center for Appalachian Studies and Services at East Tennessee State University.
"Unfortunately," she said, "what happens a lot of the time is that images are so ingrained, we get, by definition, the same old culture-of-poverty story. It's a very oversimplified view of the region."
Images of Appalachian poverty go back to regional writing of the 19th century. But that image of a place "below the bottom looking up to see the bottom," as one local mayor put it in the 1960's, took on particular resonance during that era, when the ills of Appalachia became a prime spur for the War on Poverty.
Appalachia still remains poorer than the nation as a whole, and in forlorn coal mining communities far off the interstates life can seem every bit as dismal as it did 35 years ago. But, by most measures, Appalachia is becoming less a place apart.
In 1960, 219 of the 406 counties in the region qualified as distressed, meaning they had poverty and unemployment levels 150 percent of the national norm, and per capita income two-thirds or more below the national norm. Today 108 counties are listed as distressed.
In 1960, 31 percent of the people in the region lived in poverty compared to 22 percent nationally. Now the poverty rate is 15 percent, just two points above the national average. Once an educational wasteland, the region now has a high school graduation rate slightly above the national average.
Much of the region has not shared in the current prosperity. But from the manufacturing hub of Tupelo, Miss., to the aerospace center at Huntsville, Ala., to the glutted tourism scene in Gatlinburg and Pigeon Forge, Tenn., or the booming retirement and second-home meccas in Asheville, Cashiers or Highlands, N.C., much of Appalachia is basking in the same economic glow as the rest of the nation.
"The truth of the matter is the region has progressed tremendously in the 34 years since Johnson went there," said Jesse White, the Federal co-chairman of the Appalachian Regional Commission, which was established in 1965 to promote economic development. It is headed each year by a Federal appointee and by a governor of one of the states.
BUT the old images persist, and were probably reinforced by Mr. Clinton's trip, a subject that people in the region view with very mixed feelings.
On the one hand, Appalachia has benefited enormously because of its down-and-out image.
Since 1965, the Appalachian Regional Commission has approved spending $7.4 billion in the region, which covers parts of 13 states. Nearly two thirds of that has gone to build 2,400 of an anticipated 3,000 miles of highway.
On the other hand, it is a short step or two from the image of pervasive poverty to the stereotype of inbred, gap-toothed hillbillies who, needy or not, are not necessarily the most likely targets for corporate recruiters looking for attractive expansion sites.
"You have to call attention to the problems to get the proper kind of focus," said Gov. Cecil H. Underwood of West Virginia, the other commission co-chairman. "But if you overplay it, then it just adds to the morale problems and the loss of hope."
There was both praise for and skepticism about Mr. Clinton's talk of new markets, investment and entrepreneurship.
And a bleak analysis would say that, despite the progress, the region faces enormous new hurdles because its traditional strengths in natural resources do not go as far in an age defined by microchips rather than coal mines.
But both Mr. White and Ms. Haskell said that the trip reflected a contemporary approach to the region's economic development -- more focused on entrepreneurship and long-term investment than on smokestack chasing or anti-poverty programs. In that sense, Mr. White said, maybe the imagery of the region will finally begin to change.
"This was a very different trip than the one L.B.J. took in the 1960's," he said. "If you remember, President Clinton's second stop was to an electronics company started by a man who left the region and then came back and created good-paying jobs. The last thing we wanted was for the bad news of Appalachia to be the only story that came out of this trip."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Appalachia has long been emblematic of intractable poverty. By 1990, antipoverty programs had done little for Harlan County, Ky. Randy Daniels, then an unemployed laborer, called it "the sorriest place around." (Alan S. Weiner for The New York Times)
 
Chart/Map: "Shrinking Appalachia"
In the 1960's, Congress defined the Appalachian region as counties that shared these traits: inaccessibility by interstate highways, low productivity, heavy reliance on too few industries and marginal agriculture. In 1960, 219 of those counties were distressed economically, which meant that the poverty and unemployment rates were at least 150 percent higher than the national average, and per capita income was at least 67 percent lower than the national average. Today, 108 counties in the Appalachian region are considered distressed. Maps of the Eastern United States shows distressed counties in 1960 and in 1999. (Source: Appalachian Regional Commission)

HEADLINE: In America;
If Not Now, When?

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
Bill Clinton's mood was upbeat. The appearance with Gov. Gray Davis and Magic Johnson at the high school in Watts had gone well. Now he adjusted his long legs in the back seat of the limousine and began answering questions about his effort to draw private investors to some of the poorest regions of America.
The President contends that there are "new markets" to be tapped, and therefore "money to be made," in such chronically distressed areas as Appalachia, the Mississippi Delta, the vast Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in South Dakota and inner-city neighborhoods like Watts. 
 "This is not like either the Great Society of the 60's or the great neglect of the 80's," said Mr. Clinton. "This is about getting good jobs into the inner cities and rural areas by building an economic infrastructure that is part of the private economy."
Mr. Clinton will send legislation to Congress this week that calls for $1.6 billion in Federal tax credits and loan guarantees that are designed to stimulate $15 billion in private investments over five years.
There are skeptics, especially among those who think Mr. Clinton should have done more for the poor during his first six years in office. Without question, he should have. And this is a modest effort at a time when the nation could afford a much grander assault on poverty.
But Mr. Clinton's proposal is, at least, a start. And if even this modest effort fails to win approval at a time when the nation is experiencing its greatest prosperity ever, it would mean that we truly care nothing at all about the poor among us.
Congressional approval is not a lock. With the nation enjoying a spectacular budget surplus, the Republican Party is looking lustily at another big tax cut. It is not much interested in initiatives that might bring struggling Americans into the economic mainstream.
The President scoffed at the G.O.P. tax-cut plans, saying, "If you pay for their tax cut and their defense proposals, it would restore the deficit and dramatically cut our investments in the areas of education and health care and the environment."
He said, "It would be a terrible mistake to walk away from our education obligations, and it would be, I think, very dumb to restore the deficit if we can avoid it."
Then a grin crossed his face. "You know," he said, "the Republicans have made a lot of money out of our economic policy. That's one of the reasons they can afford to finance their campaigns so generously. They've done well."
Without mentioning George W. Bush by name, the President said it was as if the Republicans had decided, "O.K., you've made us a lot of money. Now we want to be in power again, and change the economic policy."
His grin broadened. "Keep in mind," he said, "I'm for a tax cut, too. I just think it ought to be affordable."
Mr. Clinton's visit to Los Angeles came at the end of a four-day tour of impoverished regions across the nation. In some cases he visited people experiencing gruesome levels of distress, including a woman at the Pine Ridge Reservation who lived with 28 others in a five-bedroom dwelling.
These are the glory days of our prosperity. If now is not the right time to offer help to those who are really hurting, to Americans who live in shacks and caves, and with barely enough food to survive, then when?
At the end of the interview with Mr. Clinton, I asked if he and the First Lady are committed to living in New York even if she loses her bid for the Senate.
He referred to a conversation they had in 1993, when he said to Mrs. Clinton, "Ever since you came to Arkansas in 1973, we've lived where my work dictated, and where I wanted to live."
He said he told her that at the end of his Presidency he would have to spend a lot of time in Arkansas establishing his Presidential library and center. "But I said, 'I will live wherever else you want to live.' And she had told me years ago that she wanted to go to New York. And I said, 'That's fine with me. I love New York. I'll be happy to live there.
"So I'm going to divide my time between New York and Arkansas, no matter what happens."
