HEADLINE: East Harlem Mall

 BODY:

To the Editor:
East Harlem will pay a heavy price if a plan to build a $150 million shopping center in the community is allowed to go forward (news article, July 6). 
 Schools and homes exist on the property of the site. And because the site is above the last exit on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, all of the traffic heading to it will have to use local streets. Thousands of schoolchildren walk to schools, day care centers and after-school programs within a five-block radius of the site.
East Harlem's children and elderly residents already suffer disproportionately from asthma and respiratory infections.
The project will start by destroying a dozen long-established local businesses and 144 jobs. There ought to be some things that money can't buy, and among them are the heart and soul of a community.
 
IRENE SMITH
New York, July 7, 1999

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Life Styles of the Rich and Felonious;
Steal a Bundle. Get Out of Town. Now Try to Call It Home.

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
THE duffel bag full of diamonds makes for a great plot twist, no doubt about it. Also the "to do" list that began, "Launder money." All in all, the tale of Martin R. Frankel is already making a most satisfying addition to the lore of that most modern of outlaws, the fugitive financier.
There have been a surprising number of them in the last three decades, with Robert Vesco being perhaps the most notorious. And their stories serve as a reminder that even millions of dollars of loot cannot buy happiness, at least when you're on the lam. A good safe haven is hard to find. 
 Mr. Frankel was a reclusive stock trader who operated from Greenwich, Conn., where secretive money managers are thick on the ground. But last year, while John Meriwether and the crew at Long-Term Capital Management were legitimately losing billions of dollars through complex trades and threatening the foundations of the world financial system, prosecutors say Mr. Frankel was engaged in a rather different economic activity: looting insurance companies.
Mr. Frankel disappeared in early May, shortly before firefighters in Greenwich were called to one of his estates to douse a smoldering filing cabinet. Investigators found, among other things, the "to do" list, as well as astrological charts created to help answer the question, "Should I leave?"
The stars must have been auspicious; Mr. Frankel has disappeared, along with millions (perhaps billions) of dollars, according to prosecutors and court documents. A diamond dealer has confirmed that he sold Mr. Frankel $10 million worth of stones, and that associates of the financier packed them up in two suitcases and a duffel bag.
Mr. Frankel is believed to be hiding in Europe now, but only after having looked into countries elsewhere that have been safe havens for other financial fraudsters.
One was Brazil, where Ronald Biggs has become something of a tourist attraction. Mr. Biggs helped pull off Britain's Great Train Robbery in 1963, and escaped from prison in 1965; he surfaced in South America in 1970, and has since managed to fend off all efforts to extradite him (Brazil's excuse was that Mr. Biggs had fathered a son there who would be hurt if his father was sent back to face the music).
Another spot Mr. Frankel studied, according to documents he left behind, was Israel, which grants citizenship to almost any Jew who chooses to immigrate (the gangster Meyer Lansky was an exception).
But Israeli citizenship did not help Eddie Antar, also known as Crazy Eddie, whose chain of electronics stores collapsed in 1989. He disappeared shortly thereafter, and prosecutors and lawyers for the company's shareholders discovered that Mr. Antar had spirited millions of dollars to Switzerland, Lichtenstein, England, Canada and Israel.
MR. ANTAR may indeed have been a little nuts; the United States Marshals got on to him after he demanded that the Swiss police help him get access to a frozen bank account. He had apparently been living the high life on several continents under several names but was based in Israel, where he was arrested in 1992; he was sent back to the United States, where he ultimately pleaded guilty to racketeering.
Switzerland may be the best haven of all, depending on what you are charged with. Tax evasion is not cause for extradition there, which is why Marc Rich is flourishing in the Alpine town of Zug. A commodities trader accused of tax cheating, he fled to Switzerland in 1984, and until 1994 ran an extremely successful trading operation.
For foreign-born swindlers, the United States appears to be a popular destination. The Irish Times recently reported on the case of Finbarr Ross, whose financial empire collapsed in 1984 owing investors millions of pounds. He was arrested last year in Oklahoma, where he had become an ordained minister at the Light of Christ Church in the small town of Talequah.
Caribbean islands may seem alluring, but they do not always work out. In the 1980's, J. David Dominelli convinced San Diego's high society that he was a crackerjack currency trader who would make them millions. He wasn't and he didn't.
When his scheme collapsed, he fled to Montserrat, a British colony where he had set up a bank. Maybe he shouldn't have held that news conference; in any event, he was booted out and sent back to Miami, where he was arrested. He was sentenced to 20 years for fraud and tax evasion.
Keeping a low profile can be hard for truly proficient fraudsters. David J. Friedland, a one-time New Jersey state senator, faked his death by staging a scuba-diving accident in the Bahamas in 1985. Soon he was indicted for stealing $20 million from a union pension fund.
Two years later, he turned up in the Maldive Islands in the Indian Ocean, which is pretty much as far from everything as a fugitive can get. But his flashy style and success as a businessman (he had a chain of scuba shops) had attracted too much attention, Federal marshals said after they arrested him in 1987. They added that he had posed for a photo used on a tourism postcard, which may not have been a great move, stealth-wise.
But when it comes to fugitive financiers, nobody beats Mr. Vesco, who could have been dreamed up by Graham Greene (or Ian Fleming). To avoid charges that he had stolen more than $200 million from a European mutual fund, Mr. Vesco fled in 1972 to Costa Rica, which at the time was a haven for the legally challenged.
Buying influence seems to have been part of his modus operandi; in addition to contributing to Costa Rican officials, he made an illegal $200,000 campaign contribution to Richard Nixon. He was also indicted in the United States in 1989 on charges of organizing drug smuggling.
One problem with buying governments, however, is that they do not always stay bought. In the late 1970's, Mr. Vesco was forced to move to the Bahamas, and then, in the 1980's, to Cuba. He appeared to live under the protection of Fidel Castro, and maintained the usual trappings of a successful financial fugitive: houses, cars, planes, yachts and flunkies.
But three years ago, Cuba charged Mr. Vesco with fraud in connection with a company that was supposed to be developing a cure for cancer. He was convicted and, when last heard of, was serving a 13-year sentence in a Cuban prison.
It is not clear exactly what ran out, Mr. Vesco's money or his luck (or Mr. Castro's patience). But at least it narrows the search for the latest fugitive financier: Mr. Frankel probably has no plans to move to Havana.

HEADLINE: DATABANK: July 5-July 9;
Even the Heat Didn't Slow the Markets

BYLINE: By MICKEY MEECE 

 BODY:
With little to complain about except triple-digit temperatures, American investors wiped their brows and sent the stock market into new territory.
 In a holiday-shortened week, the Nasdaq broke out with the biggest gains, nearly 2 percent, while the Dow Jones industrials climbed 0.5 percent and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose about 1 percent. 
 There's not much wrong with the world, Michelle Clayman, chief investment officer of New Amsterdam Partners, told Bloomberg News. Inflation, even though people are nervous about it, is still under wraps. Earnings are coming in better than people expected.
 Even though a host of companies are expected to report generally positive second-quarter earnings this week, some analysts question whether the recent run-up can continue.
 People have already priced strong earnings into the market, Peter Anderson, chief investment officer at American Express Financial Advisors, told The Associated Press.
 Even so, analysts say key economic data to be released this week will show low inflation, which always seems to unleash investor enthusiasm. MICKEY MEECE

HEADLINE: OUTDOORS;
Sea Protected Areas Are Source of Debate

BYLINE: By Paul Molyneaux 

 BODY:
Konstantino Papoulidis lives to fish.
"I enjoy selling vegetables and meeting my customers," he said, standing behind his produce counter in Marathon, Fla. "But at the end of the day I close the doors, get in my boat, and go fishing. I obey the rules and catch enough to feed my family and friends. I'm not political, but if anybody gets in the way of my fishing, they're going to hear from me." 
 Papoulidis is one of 5 million recreational and 16,000 commercial fishermen in Florida, all demanding a fair share of the ocean's resources. To guarantee a future for fisheries however, many scientists say as much as 40 percent of the world's marine ecosystems need protection. That means closing or restricting many traditional fishing areas and creating, what are becoming known globally as Marine Protected Areas.
The National Research Council, an independent arm of the National Academy of Science, is in the middle of a government-financed, two-year study of the protected areas. The council's committee of 21 international experts is conducting a series of five public forums around the United States coastlines.
In April, members met in Islamorada, Fla., to gather information for their report on the feasibility of protected areas in the United States. The meeting, held 30 miles northeast of Marathon, surrounded by the 3,674-square-mile Florida Keys National Marine Sanctuary, featured fishermen and scientists in the vanguard of designing marine reserves, a more restrictive step beyond existing marine sanctuaries in protecting ocean habitat and resources.
"Everything else has failed," the chairman, Eduarde Houde, said of past policies that have focused on species-specific management. "Marine Protected Areas are the last resort for fisheries management."
The committee is reviewing data collected from sanctuaries and areas currently closed by regulation. According to scientists at Islamorada, protected areas represent a new paradigm in fisheries management: one that works. A national fisheries service scientist, Jim Bohnsack, pointed out the results of closing almost a third of George's Bank off the Maine coast in 1994, creating a de facto protected areas. "Only four years later," he said, "haddock had increased to the point that the trip limit was raised from 500 pounds per day to 2,000 pounds per day."
Some scientists and environmental organizations favor moving ahead with large closings immediately. But Graeme Kelleher, a committee member and a former vice chairman of the World Conservation Union's commission on protected areas, reminded participants, "The success of M.P.A.'s depends on cooperation and support from the fishing community." Kelleher's experience in the South Pacific has shown "that if we close half the reef, we get twice the fish. After a while fishermen start becoming advocates, but they have to be involved in the process from the very start."
The advent of ecosystem management has brought more voices to the table. Scientists, ecotourists, and the public at large are claiming a stake in an area that was once the sole domain of fishermen. In Florida, a region leading the way in protected areas, fishermen, regulators, the tourism industry and conservationists have forged a fragile compromise on a 185-square-mile "no take" marine reserve in the Gulf of Mexico near the Dry Tortugas. They hope it will protect spawning aggregations of important species of snapper and grouper, and increase the overall fish population throughout the Keys.
Elsewhere, fishermen have been less agreeable to closed areas. In New England, inshore regulatory closings have led to angry meetings between regulators and user groups left with no place to fish. Even in Florida, fishermen pressured Gov. Jeb Bush to drop Felicia Coleman from the Gulf of Mexico Fisheries Management Council because of her advocacy of a 500-square-mile closed area off Tampa.
Florida's recreational anglers support conservation but are leery of no-take zones. Islamorada's John Brownlee, a senior editor of Salt Water Sportsman magazine, sees M.P.A.'s, "as a tool, but not a panacea for all the problems in fisheries today. We need to move slowly.
"Recreational fishing is mostly catch and release now, and has a $6 billion economic impact in this state," he said. "You don't want to just start shutting that down. We need to look at traditional management tools. In Florida, for instance, we haven't even tried quotas for the commercial snapper/grouper fishermen."
Vito Calomo, a longtime New England trawlerman and now executive director of the Gloucester Fisheries Commission, agreed that traditional measures should be given a chance before "we draw lines all over the ocean." Calomo testified at the committee's first meeting in Washington. He acknowledged that fish need safe havens, but suggested a different way of creating them. "I told them we need to go back to gear restrictions," he said. "If fishermen didn't have the gear to tow over rockpiles, they wouldn't go there and those would be your marine reserves."
Dr. Les Watling, a scientist at the University of Maine, who recently helped create maps identifying 26 percent of the seabed in the Gulf of Maine and George's Bank as priority areas for protection, responded to Calomo. "If I thought the fishing industry was serious about matching gear to habitat," he said, "I would be the first to join them. Yet there are fishermen who insist in going in those critical areas with rockhopper gear and flattening them out."
Peter Gladding, a Key West commercial fisherman, tried to strike a tone of compromise. "These fish belong to everyone," he said. "As commercial fishermen, we have the first responsibility to protect them." But he believes, "There's no such thing as nonconsumptive use. Catch-and-release fishing has a mortality rate of 5-10 percent. Every time a snorkeler touches a bit of coral it dies. That's not nonconsumptive."
And Calomo is concerned that large protected areas and other regulations will favor recreational fishermen and more highly capitalized, increasingly mobile commercial operations and cause the disappearance of small inshore owner-operators, the last large group of independent food producers in this country. For consumers, that will mean a loss of access to the freshest fish.
Every region has its own particular problems to resolve in creating a regulatory strategy. Both Brownlee and Gladding, are part of the working group designing the 185-square-mile protected area near Florida's Dry Tortugas. "I like M.P.A.'s," said Gladding. "But I don't trust the Government. We've heard 20-2020: 20 percent of all our fishing grounds closed by the year 2020. This is only the tip of the iceberg."
But everyone agrees that something needs to be done. "There's too many fishermen chasing too few fish," said Brownlee. "If we're going to accomplish anything, everybody's got to come to the table ready to gore their own ox."
Everyone, including Konstantino Papoulidis.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
New Park Doesn't Insure Success

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
The Cleveland Indians set the standard. Beginning this Thursday with the Seattle Mariners, a growing group of teams will try to achieve it: move into new park, sell it out every game, finish first every year.
"The Indians are one of the great success stories of the 90's," Gerry Hunsicker, general manager of the Houston Astros, said. "They are the exception rather than the rule. There have been other new parks that have emerged in the last few years and nobody has come close to duplicating what the Indians have done. So doing that would be somewhat of a stretch." 
 The new park has been only one ingredient in the Indians' remarkable turnaround, a team well on its way to its fifth consecutive division championship after it had endured seven successive losing seasons and 13 of 14 before moving into Jacobs Field in 1994.
"It's not only the new park that created their success," Hunsicker said, "but a lot of other things beginning with the structure of the organization and what they've been able to accomplish within the organization. A new ball park doesn't guarantee anything. It still comes back to the people running the organization and the team you're able to put on the field."
The Astros are one of four teams that will move into new parks next season. They will leave the Astrodome for the Ballpark at Union Station. The San Francisco Giants will exit 3Com Park, nee Candlestick, for Pacific Bell Park. In Milwaukee, the Brewers will abandon County Stadium for Miller Park. The Detroit Tigers will forsake 88-year-old Tiger Stadium for Comerica Park.
The Mariners will ignite the mass migration this Thursday when they play the San Diego Padres at brand spanking new Safeco Field.
The question all of these teams have to ponder is this: Are they in the position they wanted to be for their move; that is, are they prepared to try to capitalize on their new parks the way the Indians did? The answers vary.
The Astros and the Giants, who have held first or second place all season, are in better shape than the Mariners, the Tigers and the Brewers. The Mariners, on the other hand, have some elements, namely Ken Griffey Jr. and Alex Rodriguez, that the Tigers and the Brewers don't have. But will they have them for long? "We've received a commitment from ownership to do what we can to extend their contracts beyond 2000," said Chuck Armstrong, the club's president. "Ownership has assured us the resources are there to try to retain them."
The future of Griffey and Rodriguez, who could become free agents after the 2000 season, recently became a hot topic of discussion in Seattle when they were linked, fairly or not, to a dispute between the Mariners and the Public Facilities District, the agency that oversaw construction of the $517 million park, over payment of $100 million by which the cost exceeded the budget.
The Mariners, who have not resembled contenders all season, conceivably could still challenge Texas for the American League West title, but they would have to discover some pitching to do it.
"I don't think it matters what our position is this season," Woodward said. "The fact that we're moving into the stadium should put us in a very nice situation in this market. It gives us half a season to experience the stadium and see if it's more hitter friendly or pitcher friendly."
Armstrong said he would like to see the Mariners become more fan friendly. "We'd like to improve, possibly on the trade front, and hopefully win the A.L. West again," he said. "We hope moving into Safeco Field will give us a boost."
The executive was talking about a playing boost. On the economic side, he estimated that revenue could rise by about $9 million or $10 million beyond what it would have been at the Kingdome for the remaining 42 home games. Other new parks, he said, have created an additional $18 million to $25 million a year. Woodward cautioned that no one should be fooled by the advantages of a new park.
"A new stadium won't make a small-market club a big-market club," he said. "The Mariners won't become the Yankees. But it will enhance your present position."
The Tigers and the Brewers are in the shakiest positions as they approach their new parks, because they haven't progressed as rapidly as they had expected.
Asked if the Tigers were ready to take their run at the Indians' standard, Randy Smith, their general manager, said: "If you had asked this question in April, I'd have said we're right where we want to be. But guys who have been productive for us in the past haven't been productive. We still feel we have a lot of talent on this club, but we need a star or a face guy that elevates everyone around him. That's our goal between now and next season."
The Tigers, who fired their pitching coach Friday, are certainly not on track to finish close to .500 or a game or two over, which is what Smith said he had expected. They are, in fact, playing at a rate that would give them a record only a victory or two better than last season's 65-97. Yet Smith said, "I think we're a lot closer to winning than being the club our record indicates."
Then he showed how closely he has studied the Indians' development. "They were 76-86 before they moved into Jacobs Field," he said. "We have a chance to approach that or do better even though we haven't played well."
But returning to reality, Smith acknowledged that the Indians' feat "may be a once-in-a-lifetime thing."
Sal Bando knows how Smith feels. As general manager of the Brewers, he has presided over disappointment, too. "The ideal situation would be to be more competitive than we are at the present time," Bando said. "The worst scenario would be that we'd be in the middle of the pack, then add some pieces to be competitive in our first year in the new stadium."
But, noting the process the Brewers began in 1994, he added: "You've got to be right on in your predictions of when your guys are going to mature. We may be one year behind or two years behind, but right now we aren't where we thought we'd be."
Like his counterparts, Bando is envious of the Indians' success but said: "One thing you don't have now that you did then was the ability to take Joe Carter and his million-dollar contract and trade him and get prospects. Today you can't trade your $8 million player and do that."
The Indians traded Carter nearly 10 years ago, a year before he could become a free agent, for Sandy Alomar Jr. and Carlos Baerga, who grew into part of the nucleus that took Jacobs Field by storm.
Like the Tigers, the Brewers plan to increase their payroll for next season, but Bando was wary about how he would be able to go about it.
"The question is who will be out there and can we get him," he said. "If we want him, others will, too, and will we be able to spend what others will?"
The Giants, solid contenders for the third successive season, don't have the problems the Brewers and the Tigers have.
"We've more or less accomplished our goal of being the best team, the best organization we can be going into the new park," General Manager Brian Sabean said. "If you can accomplish that, the new park will enhance things. The new park won't make us a better team or organization. You have to do that with people first. I think we've succeeded in doing that."
Now, Sabean said, the Giants look forward to maintaining their position and the increased revenue the new park will bring.
The Astros, who are working on their third consecutive division championship, have a similar outlook.
"We started our plan a couple years early," Hunsicker, their general manager, said. "We've allowed our payroll to increase rather significantly in anticipation of moving into the new park. We had a solid nucleus we wanted to try to keep in place going in there. I'm pleased with what we have."
 
Lots of Losses at the Break
When Steve Trachsel pitches for the Chicago Cubs tonight, he will be in a position to suffer his 13th loss. The last pitcher who reached the All-Star Game break with at least 13 losses, Elias Sports Bureau research reveals, was Bill Wegman of the Milwaukee Brewers, who suffered his 14th loss in 1993 in the team's 81st game July 6 and didn't start again that season. He spent more than two months on the disabled list with a strained forearm and a stomach disorder. Fourteen losses in 81 games can do that.
The last National League pitcher who achieved that ignominious level of 13 losses was Jose DeLeon of Pittsburgh, who had a 2-13 record at the break in 1985. He finished the season with a 2-19 record after spending four weeks in the minor leagues and then, after returning and reaching 19 losses, being relegated to the bullpen.
 
Abundance of Rookie Pitchers
The major leagues, by necessity, are filled with rookie pitchers. Some of them even win a game now and then. Jose Jimenez of St. Louis has become the best known rookie pitcher because he pitched a no-hitter against Arizona and beat Randy Johnson while doing it. Jeff Weaver of Detroit, Odalis Perez of Atlanta, Kris Benson of Pittsburgh and Freddy Garcia and John Halama of Seattle have pitched and won enough for fans to start recognizing their names.
But who among those fans can identify Pat Daneker, Gil Meche, Jeremy Powell, Wade Miller and Mike Fyhrie? They are rookie pitchers who made their first major league starts last week: Daneker for the Chicago White Sox, Powell for Montreal, Miller for Houston and Meche and Fyhrie against each other in a game between Seattle and Anaheim.
 
Dodgers Ready to Deal
The Los Angeles Dodgers, embarrassed beyond belief, are trying to make some moves to shake up their last-place team. The baseball grapevine says they are trying to trade Ismael Valdes, one of their underachieving starting pitchers, and have talked with Detroit about a swap of first basemen, Eric Karros for Tony Clark. . . . The Colorado Rockies, who have unsuccessfully tried to trade Darryl Kile, their disappointing starting pitcher, have apparently decided to expand their efforts in remaking their disappointing team. Dante Bichette and others are available. The team's ownership has discovered that the hiring of Manager Jim Leyland at $2 million a year was not the answer. "They've found out that Don Baylor was not the problem," an executive of another team said, referring to Leyland's predecessor. . . . A rumor surfaced last week that Bud Selig had just completed his first year as commissioner. Try telling that to Sue Selig, his wife. She knows that he has been commissioner for seven years, longer than five of his eight predecessors.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. RENEWS PUSH FOR A BIG TAX CUT, CITING THE SURPLUS

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 10

 BODY:
After nearly two decades in which their desire for big tax cuts was overwhelmed by efforts to eliminate the Federal budget deficit, Republicans in Congress will begin a concerted push in the coming week to pass the largest and most broadly distributed tax reduction since 1981.
They will have to overcome opposition from President Clinton and most Democrats in Congress, as well as indifference among voters, who consistently rank tax cuts below issues like improving education and shoring up Social Security when asked about their priorities. 
 A vote on the emerging Republican proposals in the House Ways and Means Committee on Tuesday or Wednesday -- and a similar vote planned for a week later in the Senate Finance Committee -- will be the opening moves in what could be months of partisan maneuvering. Both the House and the Senate are likely to pass tax bills this summer, setting up a confrontation with Mr. Clinton, who is all but certain to veto anything along the lines of what Republicans are proposing.
Although a compromise is possible, both parties will face tough choices this year on whether to make a deal or fight out the issue on the campaign trail.
In a sign of his party's revived assertiveness on the issue, the chief Republican tax writer in the House, Representative Bill Archer of Texas, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, said today that the centerpiece of his bill would be a measure Democrats thought they had headed off: a reduction of 10 percent in all personal income tax rates.
The change, which would be phased in gradually over 10 years, would cost roughly $400 billion in that period, nearly half the $864 billion in tax cuts that Mr. Archer intends to include in his bill. Among the bill's other features is a reduction of the top tax rate on capital gains, to 15 percent from 20 percent.
The Archer plan, which would bring the current 15 percent tax bracket down to 13.5 percent, the 28 percent bracket to 25.2 percent and the top 39.6 percent bracket to 35.6 percent, is anathema to liberals, who say it favors the wealthy who need a break the least.
But such a reduction is a long-held goal of conservatives, who say it does nothing more than give the biggest tax cuts to those who pay the most taxes.
Mr. Archer's proposal further hardened positions on both sides. White House officials and Congressional Democrats say the growing budget surpluses present an opportunity to prepare for long-term challenges like the aging of the population while paying off the national debt and investing prudently in areas like education and health care. A big tax cut, they said, would not only endanger those objectives, but risk plunging the nation back into a morass of budget deficits.
Republicans say they too are all for improving education and dealing with social issues. But they say there is so much money on the table that the only way to prevent Washington from spending it on ever-expanding entitlements, additional bureaucracy and pork-barrel projects is to send as much of it as possible back to taxpayers, who can use it more productively than the Government.
"The only reason for this surplus is because taxpayers are paying too much, which is why they deserve a refund," Mr. Archer said. "And if we don't cut taxes now and the money stays in Washington, the politicians will surely spend it. Republicans are determined to protect taxpayers who ultimately get stuck with the bills."
The very magnitude of the projected surpluses suggests there is room for compromise. But for now, both sides are gearing up for several months of all-out partisan warfare.
White House officials say Mr. Clinton is not against tax cuts, noting that he has already put down a bid in the form of his proposal for $250 billion in tax breaks over the next decade intended to spur more retirement savings among low- and middle-income families.
They said, however, that he would stick to his strategy of demanding that any tax cuts await the resolution of efforts to shore up Social Security and Medicare, both of which face financial problems as the baby boom generation grows old.
But the White House is now adding another argument to its case. Administration officials said the surplus estimates being relied on by Republicans were predicated on domestic spending being held to levels that were politically unrealistic and that would require deep cuts in everything from law enforcement to Head Start over the next decade.
Moreover, White House officials said, the surplus projections have been exaggerated by a technical factor. The portion of the surplus that both parties agree is up for grabs, the part generated by general tax revenues rather than payroll tax receipts that are nominally earmarked for Social Security, is $996 billion over the next decade, according to the Congressional Budget Office.
But the $996 billion figure assumes that all of the surplus goes to paying down the national debt, thereby reducing interest costs to the Government. To the degree that the money is used for tax cuts or anything else, interest costs will be higher than assumed, reducing the size of the surplus -- by $179 billion over 10 years, according to an estimate by the Administration. That means, in the Administration's view, that an $864 billion tax cut would return the Government to a deficit a decade from now -- a conclusion that Republicans, who use slightly different numbers, dispute.
"The path we've laid out is a balanced allocation of the surplus," said Jacob J. Lew, the director of the White House's Office of Management and Budget, previewing a line of attack that Administration officials plan to use in coming days.
"If you go down the other route and put everything into a tax cut, sucking up all the dollars, it leaves you either with devastating cuts to programs that would be impossible to deliver on because they'd be unacceptable to the American people, or you'd end up with deficits," Mr. Lew said. Having just recovered from the deficits created in part by the Reagan-era tax cuts and the agonizing choices they forced upon the nation, Mr. Lew said, the country should resist going down a tax-cutting road.
The tax-cutting packages presented in pieces over the last few days by Mr. Archer and his counterpart in the Senate, William V. Roth Jr., the Delaware Republican who is chairman of the Finance Committee, are the first moves in what is likely to be months of maneuvering over the nation's priorities as it shifts into an era of fiscal plenty.
Mr. Roth's proposal is slightly smaller than Mr. Archer's, at no more than $792 billion over 10 years, and it specifically leaves room to deal with one of Mr. Clinton's priorities, adding prescription drug coverage to the Medicare system of health insurance for the elderly.
But both versions are chock-a-block with proposals that have been little more than pipe dreams for Republicans in recent years, from eliminating the tax on estates to reversing the quirk in the tax code that penalizes many married couples.
While Republicans expect neither version to make it into law intact, given Mr. Clinton's opposition, they hope that some of the ideas can be included in any compromise.
The outcome of the sparring over taxes will go a long way toward determining how the parties address a variety of related issues, from Social Security and Medicare to breaking a logjam in Congress over next year's spending bills. And with Republicans and Democrats alike torn over whether confrontation or compromise will play better with voters, it will shape their strategies as they head into the 2000 election campaign.
Many members of both parties in the House would prefer fighting it out over fiscal policy on the campaign trail rather than cutting a deal, judging that staking out a clear ideological position will help them as Democrats fight to wrest control of the chamber from Republicans.
"They're trying to solidify Republican support for a bill they can campaign on, based on the fact that they know this bill will be so irresponsible that the President will be forced to veto it," said Representative Charles B. Rangel of Manhattan, the senior Democrat on the Ways and Means Committee.
The situation is more complicated in the Senate. There, moderate Democrats are open to a substantial tax cut, and Republicans are trying to make it easier for them. The plan introduced by Mr. Roth on Friday was built around a middle-class tax cut far more palatable to Democrats than the approach taken by Mr. Archer in the House.
Some Senate Democrats also see an opportunity to neutralize tax cuts as a political issue.
"Democrats have largely captured the education and environmental issues, and have an expanding advantage on guns and abortion," said Senator Robert G. Torricelli, the New Jersey Democrat who co-sponsored a bipartisan $345 billion tax cut proposal this year. "There is no reason for us to lose on the tax issue."
For their part, Republicans believe that failure to press their tax-cutting agenda could accelerate the slide in their electoral fortunes since 1994 by alienating the conservative base that handed them control of Congress. Indeed, tax cuts are almost as much a moral issue for Republicans as an economic issue.
A high tax burden, Mr. Roth said today in delivering the weekly Republican national radio address, "undermines the fundamental values that dictate that you -- the individuals and families who worked to create this economic expansion -- should be able to use this surplus for you and your loved ones."
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Chart: "SNAPSHOT: Republican Tax Proposals"
Congress will take up proposals this week for the biggest tax cut since 1981. The House will be considering a reduction worth $864 billion over 10 years, while the Senate will weigh a proposal worth up to $792 billion over that period. President Clinton wants to hold any tax cut to $250 billion over the decade. Among the main elements being drafted by Republicans:
 
PERSONAL INCOME TAX REDUCTION -- The House will consider a plan to cut income tax rates by 10 percent across the board, meaning that the current 15 percent rate would drop to 13.5 percent while the top rate of 39.6 percent would drop to 35.6 percent. The Senate will look at a narrower proposal that would reduce the bottom rate of 15 percent to 14 percent.
 
SAVINGS AND INVESTMENT INCENTIVES -- The House will consider reducing the top rate on capital gains to 15 percent from 20 percent. The Senate will consider expansions of the Individual Retirement Account and 401(k) retirement savings programs.
 
TAX BREAKS FOR MARRIED COUPLES -- The House and the Senate will include changes to reduce or eliminate the so-called marriage penalty, which leads many couples to pay more than they would if they were single.
 
INHERITANCE TAX -- The House version calls for a phased elimination of the estate and gift tax, called the death tax by Republicans.
 
EDUCATION AND HEALTH CARE -- Both the House and the Senate bills contain provisions addressing social issues through proposals like tax-advantaged savings accounts for tuition, making health insurance more affordable for the self-employed and providing breaks for long-term care insurance.
 
(Source: House Ways and Means Committee; Senate Finance Committee)(pg. 19)

HEADLINE: Albany Lags In Effort to Cut Electricity Use

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER 

 BODY:
At a time when the rising demand for energy has stretched the New York metropolitan region's power system to the limit, the state has quietly scaled back its effort to promote energy conservation. New York was once a leader among states, but its main program to encourage conservation of electricity has been reduced by 75 percent in the last six years, much to the dismay of environmentalists.
Conservationists have challenged the cutbacks by concentrating on environmental concerns. They say it is important to reduce the demand for electricity to curb air pollution, by diminishing the amount of fuel burned in power plants. 
 But after the blackouts last week in Washington Heights, the Lower East Side and other New York City neighborhoods, environmentalists have seized on what they hope will be a powerful new argument in the debate: reducing the demand for electrical power, they say, would reduce stress on an aging electrical distribution system and diminish the risk of future power failures.
Few if any environmentalists would claim that the cutback in the state's energy conservation program caused the failure of "feeder" cables that carry electricity to neighborhoods from local distribution stations, which led to the blackouts. Instead, they say that a reduction in demand for electricity, especially at peak moments like the hottest days of the summer, would ease the strains on the system.
"You can't say that problems with any single feeder line would not occur," said Edward Smeloff the executive director of the Pace Energy Project at the Pace University School of Law. "But statistically more load means more heat, which causes the failures. The argument for conservation in the current setting is to increase the robustness of the distribution system, to increase its reliability."
The system's reliability, already severely tested in the heat wave, faces much larger tests in the future, utility experts say, since the increasing demand for energy in the New York metropolitan area is not being matched by a comparable increase in the system's capacity to generate and deliver it.
The experts say the answer lies in four areas: building power plants to keep up with demand rising 2 to 3 percent a year nationally; adding new transmission lines to bring power into the metropolitan area; upgrading local lines that deliver electricity, and adopting more aggressive energy conservation programs.
The debate over changes by state regulators in the arcane world of energy conservation has gone on for several years with little public notice. That is in part because the regulations are complicated, but it is also because fuel prices are at record lows and electricity rates remain relatively low. Moreover, the benefits of conserving energy are long term, while the cost of investing in more energy-efficient equipment is immediate.
Americans are far removed from the days, in the 1970's, when the Arab oil boycott caused energy prices to skyrocket and conservation to become a way of life, at least for a while. Just as drivers slowly drifted back to larger, gas-guzzling sedans and sport utility vehicles, consumers of electricity have lost much of their passion for energy-efficient appliances and fixtures.
Beginning a decade ago, state utility regulators tried to encourage consumers to reduce their demand for electricity. They created a program requiring power companies to reimburse customers for some of the cost of replacing light fixtures, air-conditioners and other appliances with more energy-efficient models. The cost of the reimbursement was built into the rates that utilities were permitted to charge.
While homeowners and apartment owners could take advantage of the program, it was aimed especially at businesses, owners of office buildings and other commercial customers, where the substitution of modern equipment can cut energy use by as much as 20 to 40 percent.
In the program's peak years, in 1992 and 1993, power companies statewide spent nearly $300 million a year to help subsidize the purchase of energy-efficient appliances and lighting systems. But then the cutbacks began, first under Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and continuing under Gov. George E. Pataki. Last year, utilities spent $66 million for the conservation effort, according to data compiled by the Natural Resources Defense Council.
Other states have spent much more to encourage conservation. Connecticut utilities spent $109 million last year to reimburse customers for buying more efficient equipment, and power companies in New Jersey spent $230 million, according to the Natural Resources Defense Council. In California, utilities spent $415 million last year.
"They have all made a much greater commitment to energy efficiency funding than New York does now," said Larry Shapiro, a staff attorney with the New York Public Interest Research Group. "In New York, the program has been mostly dismantled."
State regulators scaled back the program to help reduce electricity rates and as part of a broad restructuring of the industry: moving away from the traditional system, which gave utilities a monopoly on power distribution, and toward a competitive market in which consumers will be able to choose among electricity providers.
In the new system, the regulators believe, the marketplace will encourage efficiency, with some energy companies trying to attract customers by offering conservation services. The State Public Service Commission, which regulates utilities, believes that "innovative, cost-effective energy services will develop in this new competitive market," said David Flanagan, the commission's spokesman.
But many conservationists are skeptical that energy companies and consumers will spend enough on new equipment to curb the growth in demand for electricity. The competitive pressure to keep rates low will make it difficult to increase spending on conservation, they say.
"This was a short-term discretionary cost that they could cut," Ashok Gupta, an economist at the Natural Resources Defense Council, said of the reductions in conservation spending. "It was a bad decision to get some short-term savings. It's like not plugging up the hole in your gas tank because you don't want to spend the money right now.
"The reason we need to do it is that markets don't do it," Mr. Gupta said. "Developers who build the buildings don't care what the energy bill will be."

HEADLINE: A Shaky Pillar in Harlem;
Black-Owned Carver Bank Seeks Solid Financial Base

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
As a symbol of Harlem's economic revival, almost nothing would seem to beat the Carver Federal Savings Bank building on 125th Street. Four shiny stories of stone and brass and skylights, it is a monument to the bank's five-decade transformation from a struggling storefront into a pillar of its flourishing community -- and the largest African-American financial institution in the country.
But the bright facade is deceiving. In the last few years, Carver has been beset by almost every problem a bank can face, including fire, fraud and deadbeat borrowers. It has annoyed customers, infuriated shareholders and angered some community leaders. And it has lost a lot of money -- $4.5 million in the last fiscal year alone. 
 Now a new president, Deborah C. Wright, 41, must try to bring into the 21st century an institution that she concedes is about 15 years behind the times -- and whose last effort to modernize ended in financial disaster.
And she may not have much time. Kevin Cohee, a rival banker from Boston who has proposed merging his black-owned bank with Carver, plans to run for a seat on the Carver board at the annual meeting later this year.
"There are a lot of folks with very different visions of what this bank should be," Ms. Wright said recently. But, she added, "they are really all pressuring us to the same place" -- profitability.
To many people in Harlem and the other neighborhoods the bank serves, Carver's history -- and its survival as an independent, black-run bank -- mean a lot. "It is a very important institution both in terms of practicality and in terms of its symbolism," said the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d, pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem, who got his home mortgage from Carver.
Whether Carver can recover will have implications far beyond New York. While they are writ large at Carver, the bank's problems are shared by many other minority-owned financial institutions, which tend to be small, conservative operations serving rural or inner-city neighborhoods.
The reluctance of these banks to take risks -- a trait that served them so well during tough times, including the savings and loan crisis of the early 1980's -- has become a handicap in the rapidly changing world of banking. Merely providing a place for people to park their money is no longer enough.
In the 1990's, bank customers expect instant access to their money, which requires expensive investments in technology. Big banks, forced by Federal law to lend money in inner cities, have discovered that they can make money there, and loom as formidable competitors to Carver on its own turf.
The competition is only getting tougher as banks merge or team up with brokerage and insurance concerns. Indeed, Congress has passed legislation meant to remove many of the regulations that have governed banking since the Great Depression, further blurring the line between savings banks like Carver and other financial institutions, like commercial banks and brokerage firms.
This brave new world has been hard for many banks, but minority-owned institutions have particular problems, said William M. Cunningham, president of Creative Investment Research in Washington, a company that monitors minority-owned financial institutions. "They're too small, their costs are too high, and there's not a lot of innovation or vision about using the resources they have."
 
Survival, Not Growth, Has Been the Challenge
That caution can be explained by their history. Born in the days of Jim Crow or in the early years of the civil rights movement, black-owned banks and savings and loans were for decades the only financial institutions serving their communities. They may not have had much competition, but neither did they have many financial resources.
"Growth hasn't always been the issue -- survival has," said Dina Nichelson, president of the American League of Financial Institutions in Washington, a trade association for minority-owned savings and loans. The number of savings institutions run by black, Hispanic or female managers has dwindled, she said, from more than 100 two decades ago to no more than 40 today.
Like many of these banks, Carver has been a prisoner of its past. It opened on 125th Street in 1949 with the backing of the cream of Harlem's black businessmen, as well as clergymen like the Rev. M. Moran Weston of St. Philip's Episcopal Church on 134th Street.
The founders stuck around for decades. Father Weston and Richard T. Greene, the longtime bank president, did not retire from the board until 1997, when both were well into their 80's. When it came time to pick new board members, they favored civic leaders like David N. Dinkins, the former Mayor, over businesspeople or bankers.
Innovators they were not. Carver did not get its first automated teller machine until 1989 -- long after they had become commonplace at other banks -- and its idea of advertising was mailing out a calendar.
Even worse than change, in board members' minds, was risk. Banks make most of their money -- and take most of their risk -- making loans. Carver made almost no loans, except to churches. Instead, like many other minority-owned banks, it simply accepted deposits and invested them in money market funds and mortgage securities, generating consistent but small profits.
The bank's caution only intensified in late 1990, when neighboring Freedom National Bank, then one of the largest black-owned banks in the nation, failed after having expanded too aggressively.
The memory of depositors lined up on 125th Street to try to get their money out of Freedom haunted Carver's board members, said David R. Jones, who joined the board in 1989 and is now its chairman. Mr. Jones, a former city official who is president of New York's oldest family welfare organization, the Community Service Society of New York, has had an account at Carver since he was a child.
In 1992, Carver started having serious problems of its own. A fire destroyed the bank's headquarters, forcing customers to take shuttle buses from Harlem to an office far downtown, in Chelsea, or to use branches as far away as Bedford-Stuyvesant in Brooklyn or St. Albans in Queens.
Meanwhile, Mr. Jones said, regulators began to complain that Carver had too little capital. The bank's board for once decided to do the financially fashionable thing -- sell shares in the bank, which had been owned by its depositors, to the public.
Ms. Wright, now the bank president, recalled being appalled by the news. She worked on Wall Street for three years in the 1980's. "I didn't think they had any idea of the vast difference in what would be expected in terms of reporting, or of the rigor of focus on performance," she said, adding that she visited Father Weston, the bank's chairman, to beg him not to take it public.
 
Plunging Shares And Serious Missteps
But the deal went forward anyway. In 1994, the year Carver went public, it made headlines when its shares plunged instead of soaring like those of most newly public savings and loans, as investors looked askance at its poor profitability and low levels of lending. The bank took a $250,000 charge in November to settle a class-action lawsuit brought by investors who claimed that they had been misled when the bank went public.
Even after raising more than $20 million through the stock sale, the bank was still making very few loans. To this day, Federal regulators rate Carver's community reinvestment activity as only satisfactory, rather than the "outstanding" rating that they give big mainstream banks like Chase, which has three branches on 125th Street.
Some Harlem leaders contend that Carver has not kept up with the changes in the communities it serves, as the middle-class families with Caribbean backgrounds -- like those who founded the bank -- were displaced by immigrants from Africa, the Dominican Republic, Mexico and the West Indies. Carver "did not keep up with changing times, did not go where the people were," said Lloyd A. Williams, president of the Greater Harlem Chamber of Commerce, whose grandparents were charter depositors at the bank.
The bank did start to change under Thomas L. Clark Jr., a former state banking regulator who became president of Carver in 1995. It began to make mortgage loans, and it bought loans originated by other banks. These moves were expensive, but they increased earnings over time.
But there were serious missteps. A new finance official was arrested on Federal charges of defrauding the bank; a resolution of the case is pending. A new computer system faltered and cost millions of dollars to fix. Grand plans to expand in Westchester County never came to fruition.
The worst mistake was a disastrous foray into credit cards, auto loans and other consumer lending. These areas are not intrinsically unprofitable; some banks make big money in them. But Carver lacked the staff, savvy and resources to do so, and an unusually high percentage of its borrowers defaulted on their loans.
The board fired Mr. Clark in January; he is now a senior executive at E. G. Bowman, a black-owned insurance brokerage in Manhattan. Mr. Jones said the board had agreed with Mr. Clark's strategy but not with the way he had carried it out.
Loan losses and computer costs forced Carver to take a $7.8 million charge in the previous fiscal year, which more than wiped out its earnings. It ended its fiscal year on March 31 with a loss of $4.5 million. Shortly thereafter, regulators sharply downgraded the bank's safety and soundness rating, and restricted its ability to make loans.
"This is like a soap opera that compressed everything that would happen to a bank into three or four years," said Mr. Jones, the board chairman.
 
A Leap of Faith, And Dreams of Success
After an extensive search by a recruiting firm, Carver's board decided to hire Ms. Wright as the new president; she took over on June 1. One of her chief assets, Mr. Jones said, was her ability to put together strong teams of people without offering top salaries. She served as the city's Housing Preservation and Development Commissioner before becoming president of the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone in 1996, and she had a good reputation in Harlem and among nonprofit groups.
What she lacks is experience in commercial banking; indeed, she lacks commercial experience of any kind, as Mr. Cohee -- the Boston banker who was once her classmate at Harvard -- likes to point out.
The board "took a leap of faith on me," Ms. Wright said candidly.
She said she hoped to make the bank better at serving people like her, who would like to have accounts there if the services were as good as those at other banks. She would like the bank to advise local businessmen and women, not just on raising money, but on finding successors to run their companies. And she dreams of serving customers who are uneasy about banks but who must increasingly deal with electronic paychecks and benefits and tax refunds.
But she sounds pragmatic: "We can't serve those people if we don't have our act together."
The shareholders, however, may not be willing to wait. The bank's historically poor financial performance has meant that, during the greatest stock market surge in American history, the price of Carver's shares has actually fallen, from $10 in late 1994 to $8.25 as of Friday.
At the last two annual shareholder meetings, more than a quarter of those who voted favored a shareholder's proposal to try to sell the bank. The shareholder, Joseph Sonnenberg, a Manhattan retiree who lives off his investments, said he planned to offer the proposal again this year. The bank, he said, "has to prove a lot and I don't want to wait around that long."
He is not the only one. Martin J. Whitman, one of Wall Street's most seasoned investors, is Carver's biggest shareholder, with almost 10 percent of the shares. "The African-American community needs some way to have a financial institution to call their own," he said. But he added, "Obviously I have no reason to be terribly supportive of the old board or the new C.E.O."
Then there is Mr. Cohee, who owns about 7 percent of Carver's shares and wants to join the board. He said he was not married to the idea of merging Carver with his Boston Bank of Commerce, which is much smaller but far more profitable. But things need to change, he said.
"I have a responsibility as an African-American who runs a community development institution and knows what impact this type of institution has on its community to see that the bank is strong enough to support the dreams and aspirations of its community," he said. "If it isn't in a position to be effective, many people are hurt by that failure."
No one is predicting that the bank will fail; for one thing, Federal regulators now have a mandate to preserve minority-owned institutions. But whether Carver can stay independent and thrive is unclear, especially if the economy turns sour or interest rates rise.
Other minority-owned banks around the country, facing many of the same problems and faced with the need to raise money that Carver had in the early 1990's, are watching the bank carefully, hoping that it will become a successful prototype for the minority-owned bank of the future. "They're sort of paving the way in a lot of areas right now," said Bob Adkins, senior vice president of the Broadway Financial Corporation, which owns a $140 million minority-run savings bank in Los Angeles.
And even those who have sometimes been unhappy with the bank are rooting for it now. "Carver is critical to the growth and development of Harlem, the Harlems of New York City," said Mr. Williams of the Chamber of Commerce. "And if you believe Langston Hughes, as goes Harlem, so goes black and Hispanic America."

HEADLINE: A Khrushchev Is Pledging New Allegiance

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 8

 BODY:
Four decades after his father, Nikita S. Khrushchev, provocatively vowed from the Kremlin, "We will bury you," Sergei N. Khrushchev awaits American citizenship, happily prepared to pledge allegiance to the United States as its newest patriot.
"Sure," said Sergei Khrushchev with a wisp of merriment in his blue eyes that recalled no one so much as his father. 
 "This is a great country and it's an honor to live here," the 64-year-old son of the late Soviet Premier declared this week. "They will tell me what to do.
"I will do everything as they say," he added with a patient smile, speaking of the citizenship ceremony and the universal ways of bureaucracy.
Now a scholar of the cold war whose lectures at Brown University here are driven by eyewitness memories, Mr. Khrushchev had been a rocket and computer scientist in his father's heyday and a firm believer in Communism. But on Monday, in a red-white-and-blue ceremony off Cathedral Square here, Mr. Khrushchev will stand and be sworn with other new Americans, including his wife, Valentina Garlenka, in a most personal postscript to the cold war years of his father.
Nikita S. Khrushchev had barnstormed America with his son at his side at the height of the cold war 40 years ago. "An impression of a great country, but nothing shocking," Sergei Khrushchev said. "More friendly than expected. You smile more than others."
The son, an ardent collector of butterflies, journeyed to such exotic places as Brooklyn in adding to his collection, while the father hammered away -- literally and famously at the United Nations -- at the message that capitalism would some day be defeated by Communism.
"Of course, you use only that expression about 'bury,' " said the son with a smile, talking from a perspective somewhere between Moscow and Washington about how his father had referred to economic, not thermonuclear, burial. But the distinction was often lost in fear and outrage on the American side of the Iron Curtain.
But that was then, and now Sergei Khrushchev can enjoy the liberating aftermath as he edits family journals, lectures and writes about the cold war at the university's Thomas J. Watson Jr. Institute for International Studies. "Time does its inevitable work," he wrote in his own memoir a decade ago before he ever imagined becoming an American.
More playful than solemn about his citizenship decision, he keeps a Soviet spy-satellite photograph of Rhode Island pinned to the wall as a symbol of his double-faceted fate, near a cartoon of a grizzled beggar labeled "Expert on Russia."
Outside his tiny faculty office, in which he was interviewed, a poster offers the image and hopeful prediction of his father that after a person's death "the good things will outweigh the bad." Inside, the son tests that hope in his scholarship about the long and at times frighteningly checkered career of Premier Khrushchev. The son dismisses the question of what his father, celebrated for his barnyard candor, might have said about having an American for a son. "It is impossible to move a political figure from one era to another," the scholar said of the dictator. "We only create such fiction in movies."
He came by his scholarly role accidentally, he explained, when someone was needed to edit his father's dictated memoirs. "Then I was interested in missiles and gyroscopes," he said. "But I decided I would work with the society," he added, summarizing a journey that included his father's daring to denounce the horrific abuses of Stalin, his predecessor, and his father's eventual fall in 1964 as he attempted gradual changes in the Soviet system.
When the liberating era of Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived, Sergei Khrushchev was already more independent-minded in investigating the cold war in detail, and he became fascinated by its "mutual misperceptions." By then, his father had come to be viewed as something of a foreshadowing of Gorbachev.
The son began teaching here in 1991 and last year decided that, with travel to Russia no longer restricted, he would base his life here. "We thought that if you decide to work and live here you have an obligation to be a citizen," he said.
Mr. and Mrs. Khrushchev's three adult sons (and three grandchildren) in Moscow regularly visit.
They have American Dream trappings, living in a house in Cranston.
Lately he is bemused by questions from Americans about whether there is any sense of betrayal in Russia at his change in citizenship. "People over there, really much more than here, they are less under the pressure of old ideology," he said. "They can like America, they can dislike America, but they are not living in the cold war.
"Of course, I heard one of the old apparatchiks call me an 'enemy of the people,' " he added, charmed by the notion.
While his father took long, garrulous walks with his son after his Kremlin work days, he never talked of the raw daily fear of the Stalin terror until after he took power and began denouncing before party leaders the murderous abuses of the masses, Sergei Khrushchev said.
"We were very close," the son said. "He liked to talk and tell these stories. But not everything."
Nina Petrovna, Sergei's mother, who died in 1984, had learned and taught English to her children, so she was able to read her husband's memoir when it was originally published in English. "Now I'm editing my mother's diary," Sergei Khrushchev said. "And she's often saying, 'So many interesting things that my husband never told me.' "
Nikita Khrushchev exemplified the triumphs, sorrows and lethal politics of the Kremlin regime. His first wife died in the harrowing famine of 1921. His son, Leonid, died as a combat pilot in World War II. Sergei was born of the second marriage.
"No 'golden youth' for me," Sergei Khrushchev said, referring to the pampered children of Kremlin leaders. "No playboy. No pocket money. No cars. I went by subway to the university."
He seems particularly proud of these memories as he becomes an American. "Parents warned, 'If you do this or don't do that, you will be like Stalin's son -- the worst example for our family,' " he recalled.
In Moscow, Mr. Khrushchev found that his 15 minutes of infamy was over after his father died in 1971. "They stopped bugging my phone and I told friends I'm not an important person anymore," he said.
"But now my wife's sister tells me the tone of the telephone changes two days before I arrive," he added with a grin at the status of his new life.
Sergei Khrushchev promises that he will worry far more than the average American about the "artificial" and "corrupt" situation in Moscow, where, he says, a stumbling Boris N. Yeltsin recalls the final years of Czar Nicholas 2d before the Bolshevik revolution. "I can't feel I am safe here and not care about all my family and friends there."
More than ever, he stressed, the people need economic hope and progress, an imperative he said his father once angrily conceded beyond Western ears soon after his vow to "bury" capitalism. In facing Soviet military demands for more weaponry, Sergei Khrushchev said, "My father told the generals that, between Communism and capitalism, that system will win that presents the better life to the people."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Biography

HEADLINE: Mideast's Ripe Moment

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, July 10

 BODY:
As Prime Minister Ehud Barak sets off on an ambitious course to forge a comprehensive peace in the Mideast, he heads out into a region of several aging leaders weary of the logjam of Israeli-Arab hostilities.
It would seem that the moment is particularly ripe for successful negotiations, after hopes were dashed, expectations lowered and relations soured during the tenure of Mr. Barak's predecessor, Benjamin Netanyahu. 
 Even President Hafez al-Assad of Syria is making cooing noises in Mr. Barak's direction. Mr. Assad, 69, and the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, also 69, are said to be eager because of their ages and health problems to hammer out deals sooner rather than later.
President Clinton, too, having invested so much time in assisting Middle East peacemaking, is determined to see significant progress during his final year in office.
Whether this confluence of interests translates into the dawn of a new peacemaking era, erupts into violence or fizzles into a new stalemate of intransigence remains to be seen. Many who believe in peace see this as a moment of very positive expectations, but history also teaches that skepticism or wariness is in order.
"This minuet of peace is by no means a foregone conclusion," Abraham H. Foxman, director of the Anti-Defamation League, said this week during one of his frequent trips to the region to see Israeli and Arab leaders.
A highly decorated former general who won a resounding mandate at the polls, Mr. Barak, 57, is certainly diving straight into the maelstrom. He set off on a whirlwind diplomatic tour two days after moving into the Prime Minister's office on Wednesday.
On Friday in Alexandria, he saw President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, who almost effusively endorsed the new Prime Minister as a man of peace. On Sunday afternoon, Mr. Barak is scheduled to hold his first meeting with Mr. Arafat at the Erez checkpoint between Gaza and Israel.
Late Tuesday night, he is supposed to see King Abdullah of Jordan in Aqaba, Jordan. On Wednesday in Jerusalem, he ends his regional meetings by seeing President Suleyman Demirel of Turkey. And on Thursday, he starts a weeklong trip to the United States with a visit to President Clinton at the White House, and then concludes his journey with visits to England and Spain.
From the day he was elected, Mr. Barak has made it clear that he views his most significant mission to be as a warrior-turned-peacemaker, ending, as he often says, "100 years of bloody conflict."
He made it clear by the composition of his coalition that peace, rather than domestic social issues, was his priority. And by the very fact of assembling such a broad coalition -- representing nearly two-thirds of the Parliament -- he communicated that he envisioned making difficult decisions.
"The only reason to put together a coalition that large and unwieldy is so as to be able to absorb blows and defections and still presumably be stable enough to move ahead with territorial concessions," said Joseph Alpher, Mideast director for the American Jewish Committee.
In his inaugural address early last week, Mr. Barak personally addressed Mr. Arafat and Mr. Assad, informing them in a televised address that he wanted to start a new chapter. He spoke a language of empathy rare for an Israeli leader and in stark contrast to the hostility of the last three years.
"I am not only cognizant of the sufferings of my own people," Mr. Barak said, "but I also recognize the sufferings of the Palestinian people."
Mr. Barak has now entered an exploratory phase. A very disciplined strategist, he tends to collect information and review it carefully before devising a plan. No concrete results are expected out of his diplomatic visits, although there could be the announcement in Washington of the scheduling of a meeting with Mr. Assad.
But there are no advance teams and Mr. Barak, who is serving as his own Defense Minister, will not be traveling with a broad entourage of advisers.
"Skepticism could derive from the fact that Barak, who is an unknown quantity, is also very much a one-man show," Mr. Alpher said.
In the next week, Mr. Barak, who says he is seeking to restore trust on all sides, will be feeling out his new peace partners as he tries to compose a plan of action.
"There are expectations of huge progress, but Barak is quite a cautious guy," said Efraim Inbar, a professor at the Begin-Sadat Center for Strategic Studies at Bar-Ilan University. "My theory is that the peace process is very robust. There are great social forces pushing all sides toward minimizing the conflicts. Everyone is tired, and everyone knows he can't realize his dream. The idea of a greater Israel is gone, the idea of a greater Palestine is over, the idea of a pan-Arab nationalism is dead.
"On the other hand, I think everyone is very pragmatic. This liberal notion of trust is pure nonsense. I imagine Barak's aiming for an armed peace at best."
While Mr. Barak has said publicly that he plans to move forward simultaneously on the Palestinian and Syrian tracks, there is a question of pacing. It would be difficult to pursue both at the same time with the same intensity.
Some analysts have predicted that Syria, which represents more of a military threat than the Palestinians, could take priority. Mr. Barak has pledged to withdraw Israeli troops from southern Lebanon within a year and he sees that in the context of a peace agreement with Syria.
"There is a certain neatness to making a deal with Syria that has fascinated several Israeli leaders," said Itamar Rabinovich, president of Tel Aviv University and a former diplomat who headed Israel's delegation to Syria from 1992 to 1995.
"Syria is a state," he continued. "It's always easier to deal with a state than a society or community like the Palestinians. Also, it has an authoritative Government that may be hard to negotiate with, but insures good implementation."
Mr. Rabinovich and other analysts say they believe that Syria has been sending out signals of readiness just as Mr. Barak has indicated that he is prepared to withdraw from most of the Golan Heights in exchange for peace.
"A different type of music is coming out of Damascus," Mr. Rabinovich said. "It is much more inviting, much more positive and much more forthcoming."
Mr. Assad apparently regrets giving up the opportunity to negotiate a peace deal in the early 1990's by taking too hard a line. He held several secret talks with the Israelis during Mr. Netanyahu's Government -- through an intermediary, Ronald Lauder, the American cosmetics businessman. Now he supposedly sees Mr. Barak's Government as a second window of opportunity, and one opening up at a time when Syria's economy is failing and when he is considering passing the reins of authority to his son.
"Syria is partner to the hope of Prime Minister Ehud Barak to put an end to war," the Syrian Foreign Ministry said in a statement last week.
Still, it is unclear how far Mr. Assad is willing to bend. To date, he has been unwilling to make any public gestures to the Israeli people that would send a message of reconciliation. He has been unwilling to open discreet channels of communications that would allow high-level Syrians and Americans, for instance, to take a walk in the woods and establish the parameters of negotiations. And he has been adamant that an Israeli promise to withdraw from the Golan Heights is not something to negotiate but rather the necessary prelude to dialogue.
Nonetheless, while formally Mr. Assad's position remains the same, there have been signs that he is willing to be more flexible. The Syrians have said, for instance, that the redeployment of the Syrian Army is a Syrian decision, which indicates that this is a negotiable subject.
Negotiations with the Palestinians are likely to be far messier and more complex. Mr. Barak committed what the Palestinians consider to be a diplomatic faux pas by waiting weeks after his election to call Mr. Arafat, who is notoriously sensitive and given to such formalities .
Also, Mr. Barak has unnerved the Palestinians by suggesting that they consider delaying the final two phases of the Wye agreement, which was negotiated early last fall in Wye, Md., and suspended late last fall by the Israelis.
Israeli analysts have said that Mr. Barak might pledge future recognition of a Palestinian state in exchange. Mr. Barak acknowledged this strategy publicly for the first time on Friday night. He said, in an Israeli television interview, that he will propose to Mr. Arafat that the two sides defer carrying out the rest of Wye and go straight into expedited final status negotiations and look broadly at all remaining issues.
While the Wye agreement provided interim steps like the return of land and political prisoners, the final status negotiations are supposed to conclude the peace process, resolving the most sensitive issues, like Jerusalem, borders and refugees.
If Mr. Arafat objects, Mr. Barak says he will move quickly on the Wye agreement.
The Palestinians view the idea of postponing the execution of the Wye agreement with great trepidation.
"We absolutely, totally and utterly reject even the idea, or the mere thinking about it, and we urge Mr. Barak not even to suggest if he means and intends to build trust," said Saeb Erekat, the chief Palestinian negotiator.
Mr. Erekat said the Palestinians are impatient and want to see Mr. Barak take quick action. They expect a quick handover of land, a return of Palestinian prisoners and a total change in atmosphere.
"We don't want to wait anymore," he said. "We are tired of waiting."
