HEADLINE: U.N. Poverty Agency Vying With Aid Offices for Cash

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 9

 BODY:
Mark Malloch Brown, the new chief of the United Nations Development Program, had barely moved into his spacious office with its panoramic views of the East River and the United Nations when he got some bad news: Denmark and Germany, mainstays of his agency's $2 billion budget, were slashing their annual contributions.
The German Cabinet, citing its obligation to limit its budget deficit under Europe's single-currency agreement, announced that it was cutting its contribution to the world body's main foreign aid arm by 50 percent, or $25 million. Denmark, too, announced a 23 percent cut to finance a pledge it had made to rebuild Kosovo. 
 Indeed, the Kosovo crisis has intensified the already fierce competition for dollars among relief and development agencies and makes it all the more likely that the search for funds will consume much of Mr. Malloch Brown's tenure.
The decline in contributions, which are voluntary rather than mandatory like United Nations dues, are not limited to Denmark and Germany. America's portion of the budget has been dropping, too.
In a recent issue of the journal Foreign Affairs, James Gustave Speth, an American who headed the agency for six years before Mr. Malloch Brown took over on July 1, called Washington's donations "particularly stingy." While Nordic countries contributed about $16 per capita to the agency, Mr. Speth complained in a recent interview, America's per capita contribution stood at 50 cents.
In announcing his country's reduction, Poul Nielsen, Denmark's Development Minister, who had been Europe's candidate for the job of leading the agency, denied that the cut was what a Danish journalist called a "devious" act of "revenge" for not having won the post.
While Mr. Malloch Brown declined to discuss Denmark's motives in an interview last week, he expressed his "alarm" that a country with such a long history of generous giving to the world's poor would "tax Africa to fund Kosovo." Denmark, he added, underscoring his concern, risked setting "a dangerous trend" that he hoped other donors would not follow.
As for Germany, the new administrator, as the agency's chief is known, vowed to "fight" the Cabinet's decision through friends in the German Government and, if necessary, reverse the planned cuts in Parliament, which is expected to consider the issue this fall.
Mr. Malloch Brown framed the challenge to get more money for his agency as primarily one of marketing. Employing the free-market jargon so fashionable in the development community these days, Mr. Malloch Brown stressed the need to promote his agency's "comparative advantage" in advancing development through "good governance."
Projects that foster democratic, honest, responsible government, the rule of law, competent, unbiased judicial systems and commercial codes, private organizations and partnerships between government agencies and commercial and nonprofit partners made aid dollars go further, he said.
Mr. Malloch Brown, who was previously vice president for external affairs at the World Bank, said he intends to use his communication skills to enhance his agency's reputation and promote its credibility.
While he praised his predecessor, Mr. Speth -- who is now the dean of Yale University's School of Forestry and Environmental Studies -- Mr. Malloch Brown's emphasis on giving the agency a higher profile seemed to imply that Mr. Speth had been less than successful in this regard.
The Development Program has almost 6,000 employees in 130 offices throughout the world and disperses more than $1.9 billion of its $2.2 billion budget to help fight poverty and underdevelopment. Recently, Mr. Malloch Brown gave his far-flung team a pep talk, delivered via audio and video-conferencing. He warned the staff that to continue being a "relevant" player in development, the agency had to "reinvent" itself.
Articulate, energetic and experienced in relief work, the 46-year-old British national was a popular choice among American officials and many relief workers, who felt that Mr. Speth had placed too little emphasis on integrating emergency assistance into long-term development aid.
But the Europeans, increasingly resentful of the United States for failing to pay the $1.6 billion in back dues it owes the United Nations, had campaigned intensively to lead the agency, and Secretary General Kofi Annan's selection of Mr. Malloch Brown, a long-time associate, caused a diplomatic stir.
Mr. Malloch Brown's World Bank background is the source of another concern. Some fear that the bank, which lends $22 billion of development aid a year, may come to dominate the agency's activities.
Mr. Malloch Brown vowed that he would not permit the World Bank to "swamp" his agency. But, he added, it was an "open secret" that he expected to be judged partly "by my relationship with the World Bank." He urged development proponents not to think of the relationship as a rivalry for clout, but rather as an "opportunity for partnership."

HEADLINE: Will Profit Motive Cure Poverty?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your July 7 news article on President Clinton's tour of the country's poorest areas says his fundamental message is that "nothing motivates business like the prospect of profits." These areas may well be poverty- stricken because of the truth of the message. Businesses may have abandoned them because the prospects for profits are dim, even with tax credits and loan guarantees. 
 Corporations are not driven by humanitarian concerns, but President Clinton sounds as if he is. If he truly wants to insure that these communities have decent-paying jobs, why not mandate that new Government offices and such -- for example, the centers that process Government records -- be constructed where unemployment is highest?
 
LESTER GOLDSTEIN
Seattle, July 8, 1999

HEADLINE: Will Profit Motive Cure Poverty?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
President Clinton's pilgrimage to the poorest parts of the United States (news article, July 7) is heartwarming. But in his rush to fight endemic poverty, does he run the risk of causing yet another "rush to the bottom"? What a wonderful chance for businesses to locate where they might not be bothered by such irksome trivialities as decent wages and union contracts. 
 Could Appalachia become this country's own maquiladora area, where the destitute are glad to get any kind of a job at any price? What looks like a bonanza for industry could be another nail in the coffin of organized labor and decent conditions.
 
LARRY SOLWAY
Toronto, July 8, 1999

HEADLINE: Will Profit Motive Cure Poverty?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
It is nice to finally have some policy-oriented discussion about impoverished areas in the United States. Yet the message coming out of President Clinton's "poverty tour" -- that poverty can be alleviated by enticing private investment through tax incentives -- gives me pause (news article, July 7). 
 To hear a Democratic President tell the people of East St. Louis, Ill., that nobody, including the Government, will invest money in impoverished areas "if they think they're going to lose it" shows just how much the Democratic Party has swung to the right.
Will espousing the Wall Street euphemism of "emerging markets" in East St. Louis or eastern Kentucky really address the needs of the people in such places?
What the people in these areas really need are sustainable jobs, living wages and affordable health and child care.
 
RICHARD WELLS
Brooklyn, July 8, 1999

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
In Wine Country, Can White or Red Ever Be Green?

BYLINE: By ALAN KRAUSS

DATELINE: ST. HELENA, Calif.

 BODY:
FARMERS and vintners in California's Napa Valley have long exploited the region's combination of soil, climate and topography to make wines that can compete with those of the great Bordeaux estates. Shrewd marketing and a robust economy have given premium Napa wines a romance and prestige that help lift sales of wine produced throughout the state.
Napa winemaking has proven so successful, in fact, that there is very little land left on the valley floor to plant new vines. To expand output, the wineries are planting on the surrounding hillsides, arousing a backlash driven by environmental concerns ranging from water pollution caused by soil erosion and pesticides to the destruction of oak trees and wildlife habitat. 
 Pushed by environmentalists, the Napa County Board of Supervisors has already enacted regulations aimed at curbing hillside vineyards, and the board's five elected members are being pressed by constituents to make the rules even more restrictive.
Winemakers say hillsides are not only the last available land for Napa vineyards but also the best land for producing world-class wine grapes -- though the most expensive to develop. At the very least, they say, the new rules would drive development costs even higher. Planting a new hillside vineyard costs $35,000 to $40,000 an acre, on top of the price of the land.
"We need to conserve habitat," said Chris Malan, a county mental health counselor who leads Concerned Citizens for Napa Hillsides, a small but politically vocal environmental group. "We need to protect our tree canopy. We need to not construct infrastructure in the hillsides that causes flooding."
Napa County's landmark 1991 hillside ordinance permits farming on slopes with grades as steep as 22.5 degrees, or 50 percent, meaning the land rises one foot for every two horizontal feet. Ms. Malan wants the county to tighten that limit to 30 percent. Better still, she said, would be a moratorium on all new vineyard development. "This is a very small county," she said. "We have to reach the limit at some point."
Because of Napa's national reputation, the fight has attracted attention from environmental groups across the country. They say they will not hesitate to intervene if measures to clean up the Napa River and protect wildlife seem inadequate.
"If it's just a matter of saying, 'We're going to do some study and crack down on future development,' then that won't solve the problem," said Bruce Hamilton, conservation director for the Sierra Club. "California, using Federal standards, classified the Napa River as impaired in 1987. If the state fails to act, then the Federal Government could step in.
"And if neither acts," he added, "then a private group like the Sierra Club could," by going to court.
Winemakers say county figures show that soil erosion has declined by more than two-thirds since 1991. "Many of us think the current ordinance is pretty damn good and the problem is enforcing it," said Dennis Groth, president of Groth Vineyards in Oakville.
The wine growers cautiously embraced recommendations by a county task force that recently evaluated Napa's hillside ordinance. The task force, whose members included winemakers and environmentalists as well as engineers and government officials, rejected proposals like a moratorium on new vineyards and extending the rules to cover replanting of existing vineyards grandfathered under the 1991 law. Instead, it called for further study.
Compliance with the law is largely voluntary; enforcement is limited to responding to the public's complaints, according to county officials. The number of vineyards that break the rules, while thought to be small, is not known.
Still, the problems that have come to light have been damaging for the winemakers. "When somebody violates the law, the finger points at all of us," said Thomas Shelton, chief executive of Joseph Phelps Vineyards and president of the Napa Vintners Association. "Enforcement of existing regulations is something we can all agree on."
Some in Napa say that planting hillsides does not make economic sense anyway.
"The issue is not growth; the issue is profit," said Volker Eisele, a vintner and grape grower with 60 acres who is also an environmental activist. "When land values and business values climb to such astronomical heights, there is a lot at stake." For what it now costs to develop hillside vineyards, he said, "to make such a venture pay, you're looking at a $60 to $80 bottle price, and I have trouble believing that you can project that kind of price into the future."
Mr. Eisele said the Napa industry should grow by increasing quality, not quantity.
For Stuart Smith, whose 30-acre Smith-Madrone Vineyards and Winery lies nearly 1,000 feet above St. Helena in the Mayacamas Range, growth is very much an issue. Mr. Smith, who is seeking county permission to convert six and a half more acres into vineyards, says modern agricultural techniques can minimize soil erosion and habitat loss. And no one should underestimate nature's resilience, he said.
He pointed to a faded redwood stake, one of many he has found on his property, that supported a grapevine more than a century ago. The tall pine trees and scrub that now surround it are evidence of the forest's regenerative vitality, he said.
"The forest wants to take back the vineyards," Mr. Smith said. "It's a constant battle for us to keep the forest at bay."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 25, 1999, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on July 11 about a dispute between winemakers and environmentalists over development of hillside vineyards in Napa County, Calif., misstated the degree equivalent of a slope of 50 percent, the steepest on which farming is permitted by a county land use ordinance. It is 26.6 degrees, not 22.5.

HEADLINE: The Man Who Would Be President

BYLINE: By Michael R. Beschloss; Michael R. Beschloss, author of "Taking Charge," the first volume of a trilogy on Lyndon Johnson's White House tapes, is writing a history of the Lincoln assassination.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
From a Cabinet member's diary on the eve of a Presidential campaign: "The Vice President is becoming more and more truculent. . . . He would interrupt and say to the President, 'Well, didn't I tell you so?' 'You remember I brought that up two or three years ago.' . . . The breach is evidently widening."
The diarist was Harold Ickes, Franklin Roosevelt's Interior Secretary, writing in 1939 about the growing friction between Roosevelt and his Number Two, John Nance Garner of Texas, who had come out against a third term for his boss and was planning to run for President. (Roosevelt observed that his whisky-loving Vice President had "thrown his bottle into the ring.") 
 Now once again there are strains between a President and a Vice President who wants his job. Advisers to Bill Clinton are making it known that he is "angered" and "hurt" by Al Gore's efforts to separate himself from his boss; they say that the relationship has never been so tense. Mr. Clinton, The New York Times reported, was especially irked by Mr. Gore's comments that the President's behavior in the Monica Lewinsky episode was "inexcusable" and that he felt Mr. Clinton had compromised the dignity of the Presidency.
Earlier in American history, most Vice Presidents had no higher ambitions and saw no need to differentiate themselves from the Presidents they served. But in the 60 years between Garner's declaration of independence and Mr. Gore's, every single Vice President has sought the Presidency. Thus the need for modern Vice Presidents to profess stalwart loyalty for their bosses while proclaiming how breathtakingly different they will be when they are Chief Executive.
For Mr. Gore, this stance may prove even more difficult than for some of his predecessors. Mr. Clinton has given him a gift that no other Vice President in this century has enjoyed: a sitting President has endorsed his Number Two at the outset of a contested Presidential nominating process.
President Clinton has ample reason to insure that he is succeeded by someone of his own choosing. Members of Congress and other political leaders are less likely to ignore a second-term President as a powerless lame duck if they face the chance that his chosen heir might be President for an additional eight years, with many of the same people and programs in place, in a position to kick derrieres and take names.
Richard Nixon knew this when he abruptly decided, in the spring of 1971, that his designated heir should be John Connally, a conservative Democrat and former Texas Governor who had served for only several months as Nixon's Treasury Secretary and whom Nixon scarcely knew. Nixon thought Connally would serve as a bridge to conservative Democrats and make the Republicans a majority party. But when Nixon demanded Connally for Vice President after Spiro Agnew resigned in 1973, he was told that the Texan could not be confirmed.
Moreover, an unfriendly successor can make life unhappy for a recently retired President. When Roosevelt defeated Herbert Hoover, he effectively exiled him from Washington and used the power of his bully pulpit to cast Hoover as the enemy of prosperity and fairness. After John F. Kennedy took office from Dwight Eisenhower, one Eisenhower official complained that "virtually everything" that Ike had accomplished had been "brought into question or downgraded."
Despite the obvious benefits, few Presidents have tried to shape their succession. Eisenhower, distrustful of Nixon, tried in 1955 to get him out of the Vice Presidency by offering him a Cabinet post. Nixon refused, and Eisenhower lacked the stomach to force him out. Milton Eisenhower, his brother and confidante, grumpily observed to me in 1983 that "a more sensitive man" would have taken the hint and quit the 1956 ticket: "But he thought this was his chance to be President."
Lyndon Johnson was a textbook case of a commanding President unable to manage the succession. Throughout 1968, Johnson was torn. He allowed that Hubert Humphrey had been a devoted, "A-plus" Vice President. He recoiled from the alternatives -- Robert Kennedy, Eugene McCarthy, George McGovern. But Johnson was furious at Humphrey's private doubts over the Vietnam War and carped that "Hubert cries too much." Although convinced that he had not long to live, he flirted with having Democrats at Chicago "draft" him for another term.
At the same time, Johnson urged New York's Governor, Nelson Rockefeller, a fellow champion of big government and dear friend, to seek the Republican nomination. Had Rockefeller defeated Nixon, Johnson might have stayed neutral during the fall campaign.
Johnson even vacillated over Nixon. Although he knew that Nixon was likely to gut his beloved Great Society, he wondered whether Nixon might be better for the country than Humphrey. At a 30-year reunion of the Johnson Administration at the L.B.J. Ranch in May, Joseph Califano, a close Presidential aide, told me that he still does not know whom Johnson really supported in 1968.
In retrospect, Johnson clearly should have swallowed his reservations about Humphrey and insured the election of a liberal Democrat who would have expanded his programs.
Presidents aren't the only ones with such problems. Tensions between a President and an ambitious Vice President run both ways. In 1960, for example, although Nixon ran as the heir to one of the most popular Americans in history, he responded to Kennedy's critiques of Eisenhower lassitude in military spending and economic growth by showing how he would be a better President than Ike.
Concerned for Eisenhower's health and determined to win the White House on his own, Nixon refused to ask the war hero to traverse the country for him. Wounded, angry, slumping his shoulders in a Nixon impersonation, Ike growled to intimates, "He sure looks like a loser to me!"

In 1979, Walter Mondale, who hoped to succeed Jimmy Carter, privately agonized over his boss's fiscal conservatism and his irritation with labor unions. At least by one account, he considered resigning.
George Bush played the good soldier as Vice President, but Ronald Reagan refused to intervene in the 1988 primaries and endorsed him only after he had locked up the nomination on his own. But that lack of support freed Mr. Bush from any major obligation to his old boss. Thus Mr. Reagan should not have been so startled when Mr. Bush promised a "kinder, gentler America" and went on to systematically uproot many of the Reagan policies and personnel.
History suggests that conflict between the President and the Vice President is inescapable. And as the campaign grinds on, even with so polite a Vice President as Al Gore and a President who understands that extreme measures may be required to get a congenial successor elected, we are likely to see frictions between the two men grow.

HEADLINE: Can Hillary Speak for New York?

 BODY:
Hillary Rodham Clinton seems set on running for the Senate from New York, and many people are asking how well someone who has not lived in the state could represent it. Mrs. Clinton acknowledged the issue last week when she said, "I think I have some real work to do to get out and listen and learn from the people of New York and demonstrate that what I'm for is maybe as important -- if not more important -- than where I'm from." 
 Below, some experts give their views on the question, "Are Hillary Clinton's politics the same as New York State's politics?"
 
Mike Wallace is the co-author of "Gotham: A History of New York City to 1898."
Over the long historical haul, New Yorkers have advocated innovative uses of government to build the economy and promote social justice. Upstaters and downstaters alike supported great infrastructural works like the Erie Canal.
We pioneered making social services -- like public universities and public health programs -- available to all citizens. And we used the state to promote equality and opportunities for all New Yorkers, regardless of race, sex, religion, class or national origin. State politicians who have engaged in such creative statecraft include Alexander Hamilton, De Witt Clinton and Fiorello La Guardia.
Would Hillary Clinton fit this lineage? It's hard to say. Her health plan opted for managed care over single payer. Her New Democrat husband spurned big government and shredded the welfare safety net with no apparent dissent from her. She certainly bears the mantle of Seneca Falls and is likely to champion women's rights.
But will she back bold public works projects like a cross-harbor tunnel or a deep-water port in Brooklyn? Will she help the working poor by fostering unionization, higher minimum wages and new job creation? Will she help rescue our budget-starved and unfairly maligned state and city university systems? Time will tell.
 
C. Virginia Fields is Manhattan Borough President.
Education is, hands down, the number one concern of most New Yorkers I meet. For them, Mrs. Clinton's agenda -- smaller classroom size, universal prekindergarten, rebuilding crowded and decrepit schools -- goes down as smooth as an egg cream on a July afternoon.
And the stops she has chosen for her listening tour -- Catskills crossroads, the industrial Mohawk Valley -- demonstrate she's got the brains and grit to show the Democratic flag in New York State's heartland.
 
Alfonse D'Amato represented New York in the Senate for 18 years.
Hillary Clinton does not represent New York because she is not a New Yorker. She created a health care plan that would have cost New York billions of dollars. She has expressed support for the establishment of a permanent Palestinian state that New York clearly opposes. It does matter where you come from because it shapes what you stand for. New York doesn't need an Illinois-Arkansas-Washington Senator.
 
Geraldine Ferraro, a former Representative from Queens, ran for Vice President in 1984.
I know from my experience in Congress that my allies were not automatically my colleagues from New York. Instead my allies were politicians around the country who were committed to the same values that I was. New York politicians who vote with Dick Armey and Tom DeLay are not voting in New York's interests.
It's also a mistake to assume that a candidate from any one section of New York is ready to represent all of the state. After all, Rudolph Giuliani confused the town of Monroe in Orange County with Monroe County 300 miles north. Yet, it seems as if all he wants to talk about is geography. Too bad he's failing his own test!
 
Robert F. Kennedy Jr. is a lawyer for Riverkeepers, a conservation group.
Most states are small enough that personal relationships still count in political life. New York is big and as diverse as America itself, and so our political currency is ideas. Hillary Clinton has all it takes to enter this marketplace.
New York's size and competitiveness have helped produce the 20th century's defining national leader in each political party, Theodore and Franklin Roosevelt, and a host of nationally influential visionaries -- Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Robert Kennedy, Jacob Javits, Nelson Rockefeller and Mario Cuomo. Each had the common traits that New Yorkers admire and that Mrs. Clinton has in spades: the peculiar mix of toughness, idealism, compassion and intellectual rigor.
In great New York tradition, I expect that Mrs. Clinton will beckon the less affluent toward more participation and responsibility while explaining to wealthier Americans that we can't advance ourselves as a community by leaving our poorer brothers and sisters behind.
 
Joseph L. Bruno is New York State Senate majority leader.
No one really knows for sure what Hillary Clinton's politics are. She has never held elective office, is not from New York and has no connection to the state or its people.
If Mrs. Clinton shares the liberal, tax-and-spend politics of Democrats like Mario Cuomo that drove jobs from our state and left us with multibillion-dollar budget deficits, she will fail to win in New York.
The voters of New York State have a lot to learn about someone who spent her life in Illinois, Arkansas and Washington and suddenly claims to have always loved New York.

Blanche Wiesen Cook is the author of "Eleanor Roosevelt: Volume 2, 1933-1938."
Hillary Clinton would do well to reflect on the ideals of another First Lady who considered a run for New York's Senate. Eleanor Roosevelt was outspoken in her quest for a politics of decency and dignity for all people.
"I could give you 100 percent literacy and I could show you the road to full employment," she said. "Try 1 teacher for every 5 students at a decent salary."
She believed that government had only one purpose: to make things better for all people. This is what New Yorkers want, and this is what Mrs. Clinton says she wants.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY: E-Commerce Report;
As women start to use the Internet more for shopping, the prospects sharply improve for on-line retailers.

BYLINE: By Bob Tedeschi 

 BODY:
WHILE the E-commerce engine has been warming up in recent months, it remains fueled largely by the wallets of affluent men and computer geeks. That fuel, however, is about to receive a powerful additive: X chromosomes.
Women are joining the Internet more quickly than ever, nearly erasing the gender gap among the medium's 92 million users. Perhaps more significant for the Internet economy, though, is the fact that the percentage of World Wide Web shoppers who are women has jumped the last 12 months, to 38 percent from 29 percent, according to a Commercenet/Nielsen Media Research study. Industry executives expect that presence to rise quickly in the next year, bringing with it opportunities in several categories and expanding E-commerce as a whole. 
 "The early part of the E-commerce revolution was a revolution of rich white males," said Katherine Borsecnik, senior vice president for strategic business at America Online. "That's changing. And with 80 to 85 percent of household spending controlled by women, the total retail dollars involved in that change is very high."
Of course, the immediate impact of that change will be felt in traditional female retail strongholds, said Fiona Swerdlow, an analyst with Jupiter Communications, the Internet research firm. Ms. Swerdlow forecasts that categories like apparel, health and beauty and toys will particularly benefit from a growing presence of women shoppers -- meaning sites like those for Gap, Lands' End, Estee Lauder's Clinique, eToys and Toys "R" Us should benefit.
Not only will these categories benefit from first-time buyers, executives said, but they will also reap the fruits of higher spending from more experienced female Internet shoppers. Indeed, according to a survey by NFO Interactive conducted last week, women who shopped on the Internet in the last year said they planned to spend 20 percent more on line in the next year. The survey gathered responses from 880 United States Internet users -- 437 of whom were women -- who said they had bought goods over the Web in the last 12 months.
Travel and apparel are the most favored purchasing categories for female Internet shoppers, according to the survey. Women shoppers responding to the survey said they planned to spend, on average, $965 on travel and $783 on apparel on line, respectively, on those categories in the next year.
The other on-line categories with the greatest growth potential among repeat buyers, according to NFO, include sports and fitness -- on which the women in the survey said they planned to spend an average of 71 percent more in the next 12 months than in the last. Others were food and drink (a projected spending rise of 27 percent), apparel and accessories (24 percent) and home and garden (13 percent).
"I've always said the Internet would take off when women came on line, and it's true," said Marleen McDaniel, chief executive of Women.com, which offers information, shopping and advertising directed toward women. Women.com has catered to what Ms. McDaniel called characteristic shopping behavior among women -- in particular, a propensity to gather a great deal of information before making a purchase. "Women are avid consumers of information, and shopping is their passion," Ms. McDaniel said.
Given that assumption, the site provides "tons of original content," she said, which women can use to make buying decisions. "We'll have an article on echinacea, within the subject of healing herbs," Ms. McDaniel said. "So we'll have a link next to it for colds, and what about echinacea makes it a remedy. Adjacent to that, we'll have an ad for a pharmacy that sells it. Then users can go to the community section of our site and ask a nutritionist, a woman doctor, when to take it. For advertisers, it's fantastic because you're catching a consumer right in flight."
The payoff is apparent in the site's shopping figures, Ms. McDaniel said. According to @Plan, an Internet research firm, 51 percent of Women.com's audience had made purchases on the Internet in the last six months, more than 10 percentage points higher than the average for women on line.
Retailers are also using gender-specific approaches to cash in on perceived differences in shopping behavior. "We do a lot of things to skew toward women," said Steve Hamlin, vice president of iQVC, which is the on-line arm of the Comcast Corporation's QVC home-shopping TV channel and whose clientele is 70 percent female. "Women enjoy the experience of shopping more than men, and are more willing to look at content and browse the site."
For that reason, he said, areas of the site like the jewelry section and the wedding boutique include more editorial content and advisory features than, for instance, the area devoted to sporting goods.
Mr. Hamlin also said that the site had seen a significant rise in computer electronics purchases by women since it began selling prebundled systems. "Women generally feel less confident when making these kinds of purchases," he said, "so they're more comfortable knowing that a certain scanner goes with a certain computer."
Other sites take a more gender-neutral approach. Fingerhut, the Federated Department Stores subsidiary that wholly or partly owns several Web sites, including Andy's Garage and Mountainzone.com, "doesn't spend a lot of time looking at gender," said Andy Johnson, senior vice president for market development, even though 65 percent of Fingerhut's Internet shoppers are women. "We're trying to create processes to serve individual customers as much as they want, no matter their gender."
Ms. Borsecnik, of America Online, takes a similar view. "A vast majority of what we do has nothing to do with gender," she said, noting that roughly 50 percent of the company's shoppers are women. "Our approach is more of a translation of what works off line to the on-line world."
Because some retail categories that tend to attract women have not yet developed fully on line, the gender impact may not be felt immediately, Ms. Borsecnik noted.
"Categories like house and garden hardly register among on-line shoppers, but off line, 25 to 30 percent of all purchases fall into that," she said. By contrast, Ms. Borsecnik said, music CD's account for 13 percent of all purchases made on America Online, while "music has to be less than 2 percent of off-line purchases."
The growth in women shoppers may speed the maturation process for categories like house and garden, as companies rush to market -- once they know the dollars are there. At the same time, Ms. Borsecnik said, many merchants are already setting up shop in hopes that doing so will give a greater number of women reason to log on, ready to spend. "There's still an element," she said, "of 'build it and they will come.' "
The E-Commerce Report appears on alternate Mondays in Business Day, and every Monday in the Technology section of The New York Times on the Web:

 BODY:

Rogers & Wells Approves Merger With London Firm
Lawyers at Rogers & Wells in New York and Clifford Chance in London approved a merger of their firms, the first combination between major British and American law firms.
The firms' partners also agreed to push forward with plans to merge with Germany's third-largest law firm -- a move that would create the largest law firm in the world in terms of both lawyers and revenue, pushing aside two American giants. Page C13. 

Met Life Seen Buying St. Paul Unit
Metropolitan Life, one of the nation's largest life insurance companies, is expected to announce today that it is sharply expanding its auto and home insurance subsidiary by buying a unit of the St. Paul Companies, a leading corporate insurer, for more than $500 million, executives close to the negotiations said. C14.
 
Convention Focuses on Diversity
At a convention in Seattle, more than 5,000 minority journalists -- and hundreds more people who train them, hire them and advertise with their news organizations -- spent days debating what news organizations must do to present a more complete picture of their communities. The main goal of the convention was to underscore the importance of increasing the number of minority journalists in newsrooms, but a survey showed that more than half of minority journalists plan to leave the business in the next five years. Some, like Mary Lou Fulton, have already left, in her case for the on-line world, while others think their career prospects are limited. C11.
 
'Sesame Street' as English Lesson
Berlitz International is joining with the producers of "Sesame Street" to use the internationally known television program in a multimedia project to teach English as a second language to children around the world. C11.
 
More Women Are Shopping on Line
Women are joining the Internet more quickly than ever, nearly erasing the gender gap among the medium's 92 million users. And industry executives expect that presence to rise quickly over the next year. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. C4.
 
Commercekey, an Internet start-up that helps businesses set up shop on the Web, has its own fleet of cargo vessels standing by to deliver merchandise around the world. C4.
 
Sega Gives Game Console a Push
Two months before its new game console is scheduled to go on sale nationwide, Sega Enterprises plans to start making it available for rent this week through about 1,000 Hollywood Video stores, along with a new version of the game "Sonic the Hedgehog." For Sega, much rests on the success of the new console, called the Dreamcast, and on the unusual pump-priming marketing experiment. C4.
 
'Hardball' Moving to MSNBC
MSNBC is canceling John Hockenberry's 10 P.M. talk show to make way for "Hardball with Chris Matthews," which is now on CNBC, the business-news sibling of MSNBC. Mr. Matthews's show, which regularly attracts 400,000 to 500,000 viewers, is expected to bolster prime-time ratings at MSNBC, which is feeling pressure from the Fox News Channel. C11.

HEADLINE: MEDIA;
Big Turnout for Minority Journalists

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER

DATELINE: SEATTLE, July 10

 BODY:
If the gathering here this week had been a medical convention, it would have been billed as a gathering of experts seeking cures for terminal nearsightedness. More than 5,000 minority journalists -- and hundreds more people who train them, hire them, study their work, make their computers and advertise with their news organizations -- spent days debating what news organizations must do to put the world in focus.
The overarching assumption was that major news organizations will have continuing trouble keeping their audiences. "We need to paint a more complete picture of America," was the way that Catalina Camia, the president of Unity: Journalists of Color Inc., put it at the opening session of the group's second-ever national convention, which brought together members of the National Association of Black Journalists, the Asian-American Journalists' Association, the Native American Journalists Association and the National Association of Hispanic Journalists. 
 The event nearly foundered nine months ago when a faction of the black group said that Washington State was not a fit site because it had passed an anti-affirmative action initiative. But after rancorous debate, the groups voted to keep the gathering in Seattle. So for some, the existence of the convention was a victory. But for many, jobs mattered most.
"More people of color in the newsrooms -- that's the bottom-line goal of all of the four organizations," said Sheila Brooks, a member of the National Association of Black Journalists who is chief executive of SAB Productions , a television and video production company. "But it's not going to change unless we pound and pound and pound." The convention included a job fair at which scores of news organizations interviewed minority candidates.
"We've made at least one hire here -- at least," said Leonard Downie Jr., the executive editor of The Washington Post. Rob Dean, the managing editor of The New Mexican in Santa Fe, with a circulation of 25,000, had not filled the job opening he had, but said he talked to about 15 candidates and is taking six resumes home. Telly Hughes, a recent graduate of Illinois State University who, at 21, is looking for an entry-level job in broadcasting, came away with a fistful of business cards and a head filled with advice. "I can't believe these established people take time to talk to me," he said.
But hovering near the surface of this gathering was the knowledge that, five years after Unity had its first convention in Atlanta in 1995, the number of Hispanic, Native American, Asian and black newspaper journalists has risen to only 11.55 percent from 10.49 percent, for a total of 6,365 journalists out of 55,100 in newspaper newsrooms, according to an annual diversity survey of the American Society of Newspaper Editors.
But in local television stations, minorities in the work force dropped to 19 percent in 1998 from 21 percent in 1996, according to the Radio-Television News Directors Association.
The Census Bureau estimates that 28 percent of the country's population belongs to one of those four minority groups; that figure is expected to reach almost 38 percent by 2025.
Still, the stubbornness of the statistics and the sense at the convention that minority journalists are leaving the profession faster than they can be replaced did not dampen the spirits of some for whom the convention was like a family reunion. Organizers were pleased to see network correspondents and the publishers or editors of the country's five largest newspapers who came to recruit, and three Presidential candidates who addressed the group.
The jam-packed schedule featured multiple seminars by day -- sometimes six at a time -- and multiple parties by night -- at least six at a time. Sponsors included companies like Knight Ridder, Apple Computer Inc. and the Adolph Coors Company.
As the convention started, the Freedom Forum, a foundation based n Washington, released a survey showing that more than half of minority journalists plan to leave the business in the next five years even though 60 percent said that they liked their jobs "very much." Figures for nonminority journalists were unavailable.
The apparent paradox in the survey can perhaps be explained by ex-journalists like Mary Lou Fulton and Ron Funabiki. Ms. Fulton, whose mother is Mexican, describes her eight-year journalism career, mostly at The Los Angeles Times, in tones that mix real gratitude with deep dissatisfaction.
"Newspapers often believe that if you have enough different colored noses in a newsroom, that's going to make a better newspaper," said Ms. Fulton, who was by turns a local reporter and the editor of The Los Angeles Times's short-lived City Weekly. "I think having enough noses is essential, but you also have to have different coverage strategies." She praised the newspaper's new Hispanic desk, saying that earlier coverage of minority communities was one dimensional.
But for all that, she said, nothing could have kept her from the lure of the Internet, which she discovered five years ago after she had received a master's degree in public administration. Now 35, "an old woman" in her new world, she is leaving her job as a vice president for editorial operations of Yahoo's Geocities unit and is being interviewed for top jobs at two Internet start-ups, she said.
Mr. Funabiki, 50, who is Japanese-American, spent twice as much time in the business as Ms. Fulton, but reflected the same mix of satisfaction and frustration. At The San Diego Union, he had some choice assignments, including a self-designed beat covering the economics of the Pacific Rim. But Mr. Funabiki said he felt his career prospects were limited.
"I wasn't really angry or upset, but I wasn't satisfied with things, either," he said. In 1990, after 19 years in the business, he accepted an offer to start a new program at San Francisco State University focused on analyzing mainstream journalism. After five years, he moved to the Ford Foundation as a program officer.
Both Mr. Funabiki and Ms. Fulton came back to Unity this week -- Ms. Fulton as a panelist for a session on high-technology with Vice President Al Gore, and Mr. Funabiki to see how Unity used some of the $400,000 in grants Ford has made to it in recent years.
The reality of attrition, however, is making it hard to keep the minority numbers rising. A recent article in American Editor cited studies showing that journalism schools over all are producing about 750 minority print journalists a year -- exactly the number of people who, like Mr. Funabiki and Ms. Fulton, have been lost to attrition.

SECTION: Section E; Page 1; Column 2; The Arts/Cultural Desk

HEADLINE: Books' Hero Wins Young Minds;
An Apprentice Wizard Rules the World (at Least Its Bookstores)

BYLINE: By EDEN ROSS LIPSON 

 BODY:
Hannibal Lecter and Harry Potter are shaping up as the summer's must reads. Harry who?
Hannibal the cannibal is the title character of Thomas Harris's grisly new novel who has appeared in two previous novels and two movies. So his place atop the best-seller lists is predictable. 
 But riding broomstick high, right behind the ghoulish Dr. Lecter, is Harry Potter, an orphan wizard with unruly hair and a lightning scar on his forehead. This unusually adept pupil at Hogwarts School for Witchcraft and Wizardry is the hero of two wildly successful British children's novels by J. R. Rowling.
Last week there were 826,000 copies in print of the first novel, "Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone," and some 915,000 of the second, "Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets," which was published on June 2. At bedtime, at the beach, by the pool, in the back of the car, whole families are reading about the boarding school where the food is delicious and the equipment list includes a wand and cauldron.
The Potter books are an international phenomenon; in two years the first has been published in 115 countries in 25 languages. The headline in the British newspaper The Guardian on Thursday proclaimed, "Hannibal eaten for breakfast by 13-year-old." The article said that 24 hours before publication of the third book, "Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban," with a first printing of 240,000, it had surpassed "Hannibal" on the Amazon.com.uk charts.
The book went on sale 15 minutes after school ended that afternoon to stampedes of children going from schoolyards to stores. Scholastic Press, the American publisher, plans a national release of that book here on Sept. 7, the day after Labor Day. British wholesalers have been reminded of the territorial rights of British publishers and told not to sell "Azkaban" abroad. But as was the case this spring when the second book was available only in Britain, and E-commerce bypassed copyright, many American readers and bookstores have already ordered copies directly or on the Internet.
All winter and spring teachers and librarians marveled at the speed with which children, particularly "reluctant readers," embraced "Sorcerer's Stone." But the biggest surprise, based on anecdotal evidence, may be the books' combined power to bring boys back to reading. Calls to sleep-away camps for children aged 8 to 15 around the United States early this month suggest that roughly a third of the children had already read them.
American girls, for the most part, have always been readers, have loved series and have been receptive to suggestions for the next book. Boys have always found alternatives to reading: think Tom Sawyer. But adult concern for reinforcing boys' reading skills has intensified in recent years as alternative temptations have burgeoned to include Pokemon, Play Station, computer games or the Internet.
"The Hardy Boys" and the baseball novels of John R. Tunis notwithstanding, the last title genuinely popular with boys, as opposed to one foisted on them by adults, was probably "Hatchet," Gary Paulsen's realistic 1987 novel about a boy stranded for 54 days in the Canadian wilderness. The book and its sequels remain popular paperback titles.
Earlier in the 90's boys read the paperback "Goosebumps" series avidly, but, as Clifford Wohl, a former children's bookseller, put it: "You couldn't get them off that dime. You couldn't say, 'Here's another scary book you might like.' No. They only wanted 'Goosebumps.' It was like a fence, and the boys were trapped within the series."
Boarding school books have been a British export since "Tom Brown's Schooldays" and fantasy worlds since J. R. R. Tolkien's "Lord of the Rings." Contemporary writers successfully working with witchcraft and parallel universes include Diana Wynne Jones and Terry Pratchett, who said recently in The Sunday Times of London that the British were major exporters of imaginary worlds.
The great summer read in the United States 25 years ago, in fact the best-selling adult novel for six months, was "Watership Down," by Richard Adams, a dense fantasy about a rabbit civilization. A children's title in England, the novel was considered so sophisticated here that it was published as an adult book. Today it's a paperback popular on middle-school reading lists.
Although they are widely admired, and read, by adults, there has been no confusion about the Potter books. Susan Hirschman, the editor of Greenwillow Books, who bought "Watership Down," says that Ms. Rowling's achievement in the Potter books is: "She never breaks out of her voice. There's no Roald Dahl bark in the prose, no adult asides."
The fantasy is firmly in the British tradition: the wizards live by rules, hovering above England in a setting quite near reality but not part of it and so clearly described that young readers can map it. Hogworts has required classes in charms and potions, name tags on black robes and on pointed hats; the mail is delivered by owls, and Harry stars in the spectacular airborne school sport called Quidditch, riding his Nimbus 2000 broomstick. And of course there are good and evil.
The plot springs from the fact that Harry's parents were murdered by the dark prince Voldemort, generally referred to as "You Know Who." He and his legion disappeared during the years Harry was in the care of his dreadful human relatives, the Dursleys. Voldemort's followers are reappearing in pursuit of Harry, and he lurks somewhere ahead in future books along with the fevers of adolescence.
 
In the Hammock Or at the Beach
Ordinarily, said Bill McMahon, director of Camp Moosilauke, in Orford, N.H., boys tend to "leave reading a little behind" at camp, though they read every night. This summer, he said, "we are seeing them in the hammock at free time and down at the beach with the books." He noted that European campers there had packed their own editions.
The boys' enthusiasm for Harry Potter is spilling over into other books, many booksellers and librarians say. They cite, for example, "Holes" by Louis Sachar (Frances Foster Books/Farrar Straus & Giroux). This adventure story about Stanley Yelnats (admittedly certified in adult eyes because it is the winner of the 1998 National Book Award and the 1999 Newbery Medal) is selling at nearly twice the expected rate, more than 190,000 copies in five months. At Barnes & Noble, said Steven Geck, the children's buyer, other hardcover fiction for middle-grade readers, especially boys, is selling strongly as well.
Word of mouth, not to mention placement in the front of bookstores because of the best-seller status, has made the Potter books a crossover phenomenon. They are now attracting adult readers here pretty much as they did in Britain, where the second book topped the best-seller lists last year.
Sally Lodge of Wellesley, Mass., said: "I've been a mother for almost 18 years, and never in my parenting career have all three of my children read and even fought over the same book. But then my husband started the first book at the same time the 11-year-old was reading it, and he wanted it reserved for him. So he hid it under his pillow. But she found it."
Juliette Smith, a counselor at Camp Kamaji, a girls camp in Cass Lake, Minn., is reading the first book to 8-year-olds, a chapter a night. "They are silent throughout," she said, "and then say, 'Can we read some more?' "
Ms. Rowling said she imagined the character while riding on a train. She planned seven books, one for each year of boarding school, carrying Harry from just before his 11th birthday when he is summoned to Hogwarts, to graduation. Several years later, while she was an unemployed single mother on the dole, she sat in cafes in Edinburgh writing the first novel in longhand while her infant daughter napped beside her.
Arthur A. Levine of Scholastic, an editor with a keen eye for fantasy, bought the American rights to the first novel after reading advance galleys of the British edition. It was a spirited auction, and the price, $105,000, was the highest then paid for a foreign children's novel.
In consultation with the author Mr. Levine changed the title from "Philosopher's Stone" to "Sorcerer's Stone" and made small editing changes that smoothed out differences in British and American speech. He also added rich paper, a cover illustration and decorative chapter illustrations.
 
Selling Tactics, Not Just for Children
Scholastic -- best known to adults for the paperback series "The Animorphs," "Goosebumps," "Baby Sitters Club" and "Fear Street" -- used the marketing strategies and techniques given to promising adult fiction titles. Barbara Marcus, the executive vice president of the book division, said the strategy included sending nearly 2,000 advance copies to so-called "big-mouth" or influential adults and children. Scholastic placed Harry Potter in all its advertisements and in the fall and holiday catalogues, invested in easel displays and posters and brought Ms. Rowling to the United States. Independent booksellers in particular eagerly "hand sold" the book, recommending it to holiday shoppers.
The first printing was 35,000, with a hefty marketing budget of $100,000. Still, Diane Roback, children's editor of Publishers Weekly, which gave "Sorcerer's Stone" a starred review and an interview, says: "Marketing can only go so far because it's directed at adults. It's the incredible word of mouth among kids that has blown this into a phenomenon."
Scholastic planned to bring out "Chamber of Secrets" in September, a year after the first Harry Potter title, but large numbers of books imported from England forced them to move up the date and then to schedule "Azkaban." Appearing in American stores a week ahead of "Hannibal," "Chamber of Secrets" spent a week as No. 1 on the best-seller list in The New York Times.
 
They Finish One And There's Another
Beth Peffer at the Bank Street College Book Store in Manhattan thinks the almost immediate availability of the sequel helped develop reader loyalty. Often there have been long intervals between installments of many of the best loved American children's books.
Using the example of Jean Craighead George's "Julie of the Wolves," she pointed out: "The original kids outgrew it before the sequel came. We sold that to another generation entirely. But here the sequel is being sold to the initial excitement." A new "Ramona" book by Beverly Cleary will be published this fall; the first was published in 1952, the last 15 years ago. Compare that to three Harry Potter books in a year, something that never occurs in adult publishing.
Ms. Rowling, who will do an American book tour in October, is off somewhere finishing the fourth book. In the future the novels will be published simultaneously in all English-speaking countries.
So where, cynical parents sated by "Phantom Menace" merchandise this summer must be wondering, is the movie? Where are the toys? How can this be just a book? Warner Brothers has the film and merchandise rights to the first book, but there will be a lull before American children see their personal image of Harry replaced by a face on a movie screen or have a chance to buy a certified Nimbus 2000 broomstick.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1976 words

HEADLINE: Plenty Of Seats Available

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
For movie theater owners this summer, it is the best of times and the worst of times.
The summer is shaping up as the best ever at the box office, on the strength of hits like "Star Wars," "Austin Powers" and "The Wild, Wild West," with widely anticipated movies like Stanley Kubrick's "Eyes Wide Shut" still ahead. And filmgoers are flocking to sparkling new megaplexes. Such theater complexes typically have more than a dozen big screens, digital sound systems and so-called stadium seating -- armchairs arrayed in tiers to offer each member of the audience an unobstructed view. 
 "I like the new megaplexes," Gloria Dickerson, a children's book distributor, said enthusiastically as she left a screening last Thursday of the Spike Lee film, "Summer of Sam," at the new Loews megaplex on Second Avenue at East 32d Street in Manhattan. "The seats are comfortable. I think they're wonderful."
In short, for film makers and their audiences, going to the movies has seldom been better. So how come the companies that run the theaters are having such a lousy summer?
The four leading publicly held exhibitor companies -- AMC Entertainment, Carmike Theaters, GC Companies and Loews Cineplex Entertainment -- all lost money in their most recently completed fiscal years, and their stocks are sagging. While the extent of the problem varies among these companies, all are finding themselves on the wrong side of two economic forces: a glut of screens, even with record demand for movie tickets, and a costly unplanned obsolescence for hundreds of cinemas.
Though audiences are flocking to the spacious new megaplexes, people are staying away in droves from many of the so-called multiplexes of shoe-box size theaters that have been a mainstay of shopping malls and a staple of the movie industry for decades.
Because the big exhibitors with the financial clout to erect the new megaplexes are also the largest owners of the fading multiplexes, companies like AMC and Loews tend to be bearing the brunt of the forces they themselves have unleashed. And while analysts predict that the strongest exhibitors will survive the industry's transition from shoe boxes to showcases, few expect the recovery to be swift or smooth.
"It will take another two years before the investments pay off," predicted Christopher Dixon, a media analyst at Paine Webber, who has been bearish on the exhibitor stocks for the past two years.
Scrambling to respond to the public's overwhelming preference for megaplexes, the big theater chains are attempting to convert multiplexes to megaplexes wherever they can. Many of the old multiplexes, however, just cannot be revamped -- especially in shopping malls where there may be little flexibility to expand floor plans and raise ceilings for stadium-style layouts, which require at least twice the height as a conventional theater. In such cases exhibitors may seek to sell the theaters, keep marginally productive theaters open while waiting for their leases to expire or simply close the theaters and take write-offs while building new megaplexes elsewhere.
But none of this is happening fast enough to reduce the current glut of movie screens -- 34,160 throughout the United States. That is approximately one for every 8,000 people in the nation, notes Sumner M. Redstone, who is chairman of the entertainment company Viacom Inc. The number of movie tickets sold each year has risen 40 percent since 1988, to a current rate of over 1.4 billion annually. Unfortunately for exhibitors, the number of screens has increased even more so -- by 47 percent during that same period.
Mr. Redstone, who also personally owns the private exhibition company National Amusements, with some 1,300 screens, says that the United States has become "overscreened." That is why, even as National Amusements has joined the megaplex mania in this country, it is also busily building theaters in less glutted markets like Latin America.
For similar reasons, virtually every American movie exhibition company is investing overseas.
But with the United States remaining the core market for exhibitors, theater companies have little choice but to pour money into the type of theaters that American audiences are now demanding.
"Stadium seating is a breakthrough in the industry," Mr. Redstone said. "Where we have built them, we are doubling and tripling our business. For example, in Cincinnati, where we have a 20-screen stadium seating complex, we are doing three to four times as much business as we did a year ago, before we converted the multiplex."
The megaplexing of America is generally agreed to have begun in 1994 when AMC Entertainment, the nation's largest publicly owned theater chain -- or "circuit," in industry parlance -- opened a megaplex in Dallas, called the Grand. Built after extensive interviews with moviegoers, the Grand was immediately successful and yielded a basic formula that has been widely copied since: 14 or more screens, stadium seating, arm rests that hold drinks and can be tilted up to convert individual seats into a cozy love-seat tandem, a digital sound system and a ceiling-to-floor, wall-to-wall screen.
Such luxurious viewing does not come cheap, though. For Loews, which is building megaplexes with as many as 24 screens and more than 3,000 seats, the construction cost is $1 million a screen -- which does not include the cost of buying or leasing the land. That compares with an old multiplex with 8 to 12 screens, perhaps 2,500 seats and a construction cost of about $600,000 a screen. Loews says that 432 of its screens -- or about a quarter of the company's United States total -- are now in megaplexes and that within the next few years the majority of its screens will be in these new supercinemas.
The chairman of Loews, Laurence Ruisi, says that this fast-track construction schedule accounts for his company's poor results for fiscal 1999, which ended in February. Loews reported a net loss of $5.9 million on sales of $851 million. The deficit came despite a positive cash flow -- earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization -- of $144.2 million. And Mr. Ruisi predicted that it might be two more years before the company returned to profitability.
But then, he promises, Loews's business will be better than ever. "The megaplexes are much more profitable for us," Mr. Ruisi said.
Mr. Redstone, too, describes the new-theater boom as a business for long-term players with deep pockets.
"The reward is terrific, but the capital costs are enormous," he said. "In Revere, Mass., we have the largest-grossing National theater in New England. We are tearing it down, and we are spending about $20 million to build a new 20-screen stadium-seat theater."
A theater chain that does not protect its turf with a megaplex risks losing business, Mr. Redstone said, citing research by National Amusements indicating that audiences will bypass a multiplex closer to home to see a film at a megaplex that is farther away.
But it is not always the case that for each new theater complex built another is torn down.
"Everybody is building new screens, and the old screens are not coming off line as quickly as expected," said Marina Jacobson, who follows the movie exhibition business for the investment firm of Bear, Stearns.
Take the case of the new Loews megaplex on Second Avenue at East 32d Street in Manhattan. The company already owned a three-screen multiplex two blocks away on East 34th Street when it broke ground for the megaplex. Last year, Loews sold the 34th Street multiplex to Clearview Cinemas. That came in response to a ruling from the Justice Department's antitrust division that Loews's acquisition of a separate big theater chain, Cineplex Odeon, had given the company too many theaters in Manhattan. As a result of the transfer of the 34th Street property to Clearview, Loews's new megaplex is competing with a multiplex virtually around the corner.
So far, though, it appears to be the Loews megaplex that is drawing the crowds -- and the new releases. While the Loews lineup last week had a full complement of hits and recently released blockbuster hopefuls (including "South Park," "Wild, Wild West," "Big Daddy," "Tarzan," "Austin Powers," "Summer of Sam" and "The General's Daughter") the nearby Clearview multiplex had only three movies, the popularity of which crested weeks ago: "Notting Hill," "Walk on the Moon" and "The Red Violin."
The industry's "overscreening" gives an advantage to distributors, the middlemen who take Hollywood's films and apportion them among the exhibitors. Distributors and exhibitors divide the box-office gross, with the theater owners getting perhaps only 10 percent of the take when a film first opens but keeping an increasing percentage of receipts the longer the film runs.
Using time-honored formulas that vary slightly depending on who has the most leverage, the exhibitors and distributors generally aim for a 50-50 split over the film's entire run. Right now, though, the leverage is clearly with the distributors, which not only have greater leeway than in the past to pick and choose among local theaters but can also dictate tougher terms. Thus 20th Century Fox, a News Corporation subsidiary, has been able to demand a formula that may allow it to keep a 52 percent share of the take from exhibitors with whom it has favored with copies of its blockbuster "Star Wars."
A year ago, Alan Gould, a movie industry analyst for the investment firm of Gerard Klauer Mattison was bullish on the theater-chain companies. Not now, though; he has lowered his earnings estimates for the entire group.
"We simply didn't realize how fast the cash flow from the multiplexes would decay," Mr. Gould said. "It has been a forced cannibalization. Now, if someone plops down a megaplex, it gets the best movies and the best attendance."
For AMC, Loews and the other megaplex builders, the big issue now is getting rid of their aging multiplexes as quickly as feasible. In many cases, long-term leases at shopping malls and other locations means swallowing big write-offs when the older cinemas take early retirement.
And the alternative of selling the complexes no longer seems as easy as it was as recently as a year ago, when several financial players were still gobbling up theaters. Two leveraged buyout firms, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, for example, jointly acquired several chains, now called Regal Cinemas. But they are no longer aggressively buying up properties, and analysts see little hope that other big buyout firms will enter the theater market.
"I think they thought that if they could lead a consolidation in the industry, they would have more clout in negotiating terms of the film studios for movies; but that didn't happen," said a movie studio analyst, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
But this industry melodrama may yet have a happy ending -- at least for the companies with the financing to build megaplexes. To control their own costs, Hollywood studios are trying -- or so they claim -- to cut back on the number of films they produce each year. Fewer movies would give each new release a better chance of getting more screen time, with the longer runs that favor the exhibitors.
If that trend bears out, and as the least profitable multiplexes are gradually phased out, some analysts expect a return to good times for the theater chains. Michael Wolff, who heads the media consulting business at Booz Allen & Hamilton, predicts that running movie theaters will be an attractive business once the rebuilding is finished.
"These are not comparable to other high-growth industries, but they are a reliable, steady cash-flow business," Mr. Wolff said. "I think the megaplexes will become major entertainment centers."

Chart: "Waiting for the Payoff"
Caught in the industry transition from mutliplexes to megaplexes, the four leading publicly held movie theater companies have all lost money recently and the performance of their stocks has been disappointing. HEADLINE: The Big City;
Seeing Con Ed In New Light, With Rivals

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
IT may not be of much comfort at the moment, but there may soon come a time when Consolidated Edison is unable to plunge large sections of New York City into darkness. Even more incredible, Con Ed could become a popular institution.
Well, maybe "popular" is putting it too strongly. New Yorkers' relationship with Con Ed has been so bad for so long that it will probably never fully recover. A public utility makes the perfect public enemy for both conservatives and liberals: an inefficient creation of the government that is also a giant corporation raking in guaranteed profits off a vital public service. What's not to hate? 
 But Con Ed's monopoly, which is the root cause of the public frustration, will not last forever. New York is one of the many states that has slowly begun deregulating the electricity industry so that customers can shop for power from competing companies. And thanks to new technology, the "small is beautiful" approach to energy now appeals to engineers and economists, as well as to environmentalists.
Neighborhoods like Washington Heights and the Lower East Side, which went dark last week, could in the not so distant future have their own power generators and distribution networks that go on working even when Con Edison's fail. It's already possible for an apartment building to generate all its own electricity with natural gas, using a turbine no bigger than a dishwasher.
Ashok Gupta, senior energy economist at the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group in New York, sees the model for the future in the new home of Conde Nast in Times Square. The building generates some of its own electricity from solar panels built into the facade and from fuel cells that run on natural gas.
"Just as with computers and telecommunications," Mr. Gupta said, "the power industry is becoming smaller and modular and closer to the customer. There are a host of technologies that allow people to generate their own electricity. You might see a hospital like Columbia-Presbyterian generate its own power and defray some of the capital costs by providing electricity to its neighbors in Washington Heights."
Today, New York faces the prospect of power shortages because electricity consumption is straining the system's capacity. But it is hardly the sort of crisis that loomed in the 1970's, when oil and natural gas supplies were thought to be vanishing. Back then, it seemed impossible to meet the power demand without building large, costly plants, fueled by coal or uranium, that were anathema to environmentalists.
These days, plants can be any size because of advances in turbine design and the abundance of natural gas, which is cheap and clean. Factories are already using gas turbines to generate their own power, and independent power companies are seeking approval from Albany to build natural gas plants to compete with Con Edison.
FOR now, when businesses and homes buy power from Con Ed's competitors, it is still delivered through Con Ed wires. As long as it maintains its monopoly on power transmission and distribution, customers will be vulnerable to the kind of widespread blackouts that occurred last week when Con Ed cables failed.
But there could eventually be other cables. In some cities, like Cleveland, rival companies already maintain separate grids in the same neighborhoods. It may seem impractical to put more power lines under the streets of New York, but other companies already have wires and pipes underground.
"New electric lines could be built by companies that already have rights of way, like the telephone and cable and gas companies," said Jerry Taylor, the director of natural resource studies at the Cato Institute, which has published reports urging the rapid end of all monopolies in the power industry. "It's very easy to imagine a gas company setting up a microturbine in a neighborhood and running electric wires along its pipes into customers' homes. You might be wired up to two grids and choose your service provider like your long-distance telephone provider."
Like AT&T, Con Edison would remain a dominant presence even without its monopoly, but it would not be so unpopular with consumers or such an easy target for politicians. Lily Tomlin's famous line about the phone company -- "We don't care; we don't have to" -- no longer works for long-distance companies. When AT&T's system fails, there isn't a public outcry for official inquiries and new regulations. Its customers can better vent their anger by taking their money elsewhere.
