HEADLINE: Unlikely Lobbyist Will Lead H.M.O.'s Into Battle

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11

 BODY:
When the Senate takes up legislation on Monday to define patients' rights, Democrats will argue that hundreds of people have been injured or even died because they were denied necessary care by cost-conscious health maintenance organizations.
So it is rather surprising to find that the chief lobbyist for the managed care industry is herself a Democrat, a veteran of the trade union movement and a longtime advocate of universal health insurance. 
 The lobbyist, Karen M. Ignagni, has deflected much of the anger that threatened to overwhelm H.M.O.'s just a year ago. She will lead the industry into battle this week, as the Senate holds four days of impassioned debate on proposals to set comprehensive Federal standards for health insurance plans.
It will be the most extensive debate on any health care issue since President Clinton's plan for universal health insurance died on the Senate floor in the summer of 1994.
As president of the American Association of Health Plans, Ms. Ignagni leads a nimble, quick-witted campaign to outmaneuver the Clinton Administration and Democrats in Congress who want to enact a so-called patients' bill of rights, enforceable by lawsuits against health plans that injure patients by denying them care.
In a city teeming with health care lobbyists, Ms. Ignagni is widely considered one of the most effective. She blends a detailed knowledge of health policy with an intuitive feel for politics.
Since taking charge of the association nearly six years ago, she has built up a large stable of health policy analysts and has retained pollsters and political consultants from both parties to repair the tattered image of H.M.O.'s. She has persuaded members of the association to adopt a voluntary code of conduct, which they use to argue that new laws are unneeded.
Ms. Ignagni (pronounced ig-NAH-nee) puts a humane face on an industry reviled by many consumers. Old friends say they are puzzled by the transition she has made from champion of the working class to defender of big business. She now denounces proposals by Democratic members of Congress who were her allies for more than a decade, when she worked at the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
One Democrat on Capitol Hill said, "Karen went from God's right hand to Satan's left hand." A labor union leader said, "She jumped to the other side." Former allies on the left say she has sold out, abandoned principles, become a turncoat.
"She has become part of the enemy, as far as I'm concerned," said Dr. Sidney M. Wolfe, director of Ralph Nader's Health Research Group.
Representative Greg Ganske, an Iowa Republican who supports many of President Clinton's proposals to regulate H.M.O.'s, said: "Karen has one of the more difficult jobs in Washington, defending an industry that has a public relations record similar to that of the tobacco industry. In private conversations, I sense that she is uncomfortable defending the totally irresponsible behavior of some H.M.O.'s."
Ms. Ignagni sees no contradiction. Even as she works to head off legislation defining patients' rights, she insists that she is motivated by concern for low-income workers. Proposed new Federal standards and requirements, she says, would increase the cost of health insurance and make it unaffordable for many workers and small employers.
Ms. Ignagni's adversaries express grudging respect for her. "I just wish she were on our side," said Gail E. Shearer, a health policy expert at Consumers Union. David H. Nexon, the senior health policy adviser to Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said, "Karen has revitalized an organization that was somewhat moribund and made it a real player on the Washington scene."
Lobbyists for the association have penetrated the innermost chambers of the Health Care Financing Administration, the unit of the Department of Health and Human Services that runs Medicare. The lobbyists often seem to know more about what is happening at the agency than do senior officials of the department.
The association and its business allies have flooded the airwaves and newspapers with advertisements opposing legislation to regulate H.M.O.'s. Through an umbrella group known as the Health Benefits Coalition, they spent $2 million on advertising last year and have already spent more than that this year, with a new burst of advertising planned for this week.
The advertisements attack the main Democratic bill by name, but provide justification -- and political cover -- for senators to vote against any patients' rights legislation.
At 45, Ms. Ignagni is younger, more informal and more direct than most lobbyists who run big trade associations. Her talk is breezy, but it serves a purpose, frequently disarming her opponents.
Most H.M.O.'s are operated by profit-making companies like Aetna, Cigna and Pacificare, but Ms. Ignagni rarely talks about their profits or losses. She prefers to talk about the quality of health care, the concerns of consumers, the work that H.M.O.'s are doing to detect breast cancer and treat asthma.
As consumer groups, labor unions and doctors press Congress for legislation to define patients' rights, the position of the managed-care industry has been continually evolving.
Two years ago Ms. Ignagni said her members saw no need for legislation. Now, she said, they strenuously oppose the main Democratic bill and have not endorsed the Republican bill, although they see it as "less undesirable."
Explaining why she was now willing to consider legislation, Ms. Ignagni said, "If we want to influence the discussion in Congress, we can't oppose everything."
Provisions of the Republican bill allowing patients to appeal the denial of care are "a good starting point for bipartisan discussion," she said. But, she added, "We dislike provisions of the Republican bill that micromanage our activities and dictate the design of health plans."
Ms. Ignagni's presence is a reminder of the history of H.M.O.'s. They have their roots in labor union health plans and in the idealism of the health cooperatives that were formed in the 1940's and 50's to obtain better health care at the lowest possible cost.
For years, the United Automobile Workers, the United Mine Workers and other labor unions had seats on the board of the Group Health Association of America, established in 1959. In 1996, the organization changed its name to the American Association of Health Plans.
Ms. Ignagni has combined policy and politics throughout her career. After graduating from Providence College in Rhode Island in 1975, she worked as a research analyst at the Social Security Administration, analyzing data on health spending.
She moved to the Committee for National Health Insurance, formed by Walter Reuther of the auto workers' union, and then worked for Senate Democrats before taking a job at the A.F.L.-C.I.O., where she held senior staff positions from 1982 to 1993.
Ms. Ignagni did not seek her current job; she was recruited by an executive search firm. She received a salary of $300,000 last year, plus a $100,000 bonus for her performance.
When the House passed a Republican bill to regulate H.M.O.'s last summer, Ms. Ignagni complained that "the debate has been defined by politicians, pollsters and Hollywood producers." But she herself has used the techniques of a political campaign in trying to fend off Government regulation of managed care.
For example, the association says it has developed a database with the names of millions of patients, H.M.O. employees and allies who can be dispatched at a moment's notice to answer critics of managed care. The group boasts that it "helped generate thousands of letters to the editor" last year.
"We've made a real effort to take our message, our campaign, to voters, physicians, Medicare beneficiaries and opinion leaders around the country," Ms. Ignagni said.
The association is running advertisements in Iowa and New Hampshire to persuade Presidential candidates that they cannot win many votes by "bashing H.M.O.'s."
Ms. Ignagni hired an economic consulting firm, the Barents Group, a unit of KPMG, to estimate the local costs of Federal mandates, and she has publicized the results in news conferences around the country.
Even as Federal auditors contend that H.M.O.'s are overpaid by the Medicare program, Ms. Ignagni is asking Congress to increase those payments. She commissioned a study by the accounting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers to support her case. And she has recruited elderly people as lobbyists, urging Congress to increase reimbursement so health plans will not drop out of Medicare.
In all of this, Ms. Ignagni seems untroubled by the apparent contradictions between her old and new roles. "I've never had a sense that I was advocating something I didn't believe in," she said.

HEADLINE: Paper Trail Haunts G.M. After It Loses Injury Suit

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 11

 BODY:
The $4.9 billion verdict in a personal-injury lawsuit against General Motors on Friday might be only the start of the company's problems. Lawyers and safety consultants pursuing similar cases say corporate documents used as evidence in the case, many for the first time, could be troublesome for General Motors in the future.
The jury here awarded the record-setting damages to six people who were badly burned when the gas tank of their 1979 Chevrolet Malibu exploded after the car was rammed from behind by another vehicle. The plaintiffs have pledged to donate half of any punitive damages they collect after taxes to the state of California to pay for the care and treatment of burn victims, their lawyer, Brian J. Panish, said today. 
 Central to the case was a 1973 "value analysis" written by an Edward C. Ivey, an Oldsmobile engineer still employed by G.M., who calculated that fuel-tank fires after accidents were costing the company $2.40 per vehicle. Plaintiffs in the Los Angeles case had argued that General Motors did not design cars more safely because it would have cost the company more than it was losing in settlements with accident victims.
"The Ivey memo is an economic blueprint for lawyers," said Clarence M. Ditlow, executive director of the Center for Auto Safety in Washington, a group co-founded by Ralph Nader that is involved in similar cases. "It set a cost constraint on how much G.M. was willing to put into hardware to prevent a fire that was otherwise preventable."
General Motors argued that its vehicles were safe and that the Ivey memo was the work of a junior engineer and was never used in design.
"There was no evidence that any engineer who worked on this vehicle or any other vehicle at General Motors used the information in the Ivey document or used that approach in making decisions on design," said Richard W. Shapiro, a Phoenix lawyer who represented General Motors in the case decided on Friday.
Still, the company has long worried about the document and how it might be perceived. "Obviously, Ivey is not an individual whom we would ever, in any conceivable situation, want to be identified to the plaintiffs," in a lawsuit, a lawyer hired by General Motors wrote after interviewing Mr. Ivey in 1981. "The documents he generated are undoubtedly some of the potentially most harmful and most damaging were they ever to be produced."
General Motors has mainly succeeded in keeping the Ivey memo from being introduced as evidence since it first became known to plaintiff's lawyers in the early 1980's. Last year a judge in Florida threatened General Motors with "very severe sanctions" if it did not provide the memo and related documents. Some of that evidence was in turn used in the Los Angeles case.
The "cumulative effect" of documents released in successive trials allows plaintiffs to "lose less and win more," said Sheldon J. Schlesinger, a Fort Lauderdale lawyer who represented the plaintiffs in the Florida case.
In that case, a jury ordered General Motors to pay $60 million to the family of a boy killed in a fuel-tank fire after a trailer struck the 1983 Oldsmobile Cutlass station wagon in which he was riding. The award was later reduced to $33 million.
In the Los Angeles case, the jury in Superior Court of Los Angeles County awarded Patricia Anderson, her four children and a family friend, Jo Tigner, $107.6 million in compensatory damages and $4.8 billion in punitive damages after their Malibu, stopping for a red light, was rammed by a drunken driver on Christmas Eve 1993.
The award is the largest ever in a personal-injury lawsuit, said Thomas F. Harrison, publisher of Lawyers Weekly USA, a newspaper published in Boston that tracks such awards. He said the previous largest was $1.24 billion awarded in January by a jury in Wisconsin to the estate of a woman who had died from a fuel-related fire after a go-cart accident at a Florida amusement park.
General Motors said it was confident that Friday's decision would be overturned on appeal, and legal experts said it was highly likely that the award would, at the least, be significantly reduced.
Mr. Shapiro, the lawyer for General Motors, said the Los Angeles case might not have that much influence on other cases because other judges could have different views on what evidence is admissible. He contended that the Los Angeles judge, Ernest G. Williams, did not allow the company to present evidence showing that cars with the same body as the 1979 Malibu had explosions only once in every 23.5 billion miles.
Mr. Panish, the main lawyer for the plaintiffs in Los Angeles, said there were dozens of other cases involving General Motors cars with designs similar to the 1979 Malibu's, with the fuel tank close to the rear bumper, an estimate General Motors called exceedingly high. The company said that the Los Angeles and Florida cases were the only ones it had lost involving such cars and that the Florida plaintiffs were not awarded punitive damages.
Terry Rhadigan, a company spokesman, said the fuel tank had been moved forward around 1984. He said that the placement of the fuel tank behind the rear axle had been common in the industry before that time and that the change was made for overall design reasons, not because the design had been unsafe.
There are about 50 cases pending against the company resulting from fires in pre-1988 G.M. pickup trucks in which the fuel tanks were mounted outside the frame on the side of the vehicles, said Mr. Ditlow of the Center for Auto Safety.
News of the huge Los Angeles verdict could prompt more people to sue for older accidents. One is Linda McOscar, who said she and her three children were sitting in a 1980 Malibu beside a highway in South Texas in June 1980, when their car was rammed from behind by a truck driven by a drunken driver. The Malibu spun around and caught fire. Mrs. McOscar managed to crawl through a window, pulling her 10-year-old son, Spencer, who was in the front passenger seat, out with her. But 13-year-old Joey and 13-month-old Hillary, who were in the back seat, were killed.
Mrs. McOscar, of Monroe, Mich., said that when she heard about the Los Angeles verdict on the news, "It just blew my mind."
"I kept waking up in the night thinking in 1973 they knew there was a defect," she said. Although she and her husband received about $55,000 from General Motors in a settlement, they say they are thinking about suing based on the new evidence.
General Motors in the early 1980's hired six law firms to scour its records to find documents that could be damaging in such cases. These lawyers have been nicknamed the "fire babies" by plaintiffs' lawyers.
One such document is the Ivey memo, only one and a half pages long. It estimated how many fatalities there were from post-accident fuel-related fires and assumed a value of $200,000 per fatality. By dividing by the number of G.M. cars on the road, Mr. Ivey came up with an estimate of the cost to G.M. of $2.40 per vehicle. But Mr. Ivey also cautioned that "it is really impossible to put a value on human life" and that "a human fatality is beyond value, subjectively."
The memo does not say why the analysis was done. In depositions in this and previous cases, Mr. Ivey said that he could not remember anyone asking him to do the study and did not believe it was distributed.
But the lawyer's interview with Mr. Ivey in 1981 seems to contradict that position. According to the report by the lawyer, who worked for an outside firm hired by G.M., Mr. Ivey did not specifically recall being asked to do the analysis but said he thought he had been asked by a superior to help in "trying to figure out how much Olds could spend on fuel systems." Mr. Ivey said it was probably distributed to several people, though he did not know if it had ever been used.
Some other G.M. memos presented at the trial also showed that cost-benefit analysis was used on safety questions. In a 1974 memo, a G.M. official named R. G. Fischer performed a calculation similar to Mr. Ivey's and concluded that G.M. could spend $2 a car "effectively for rear impact protection." A Jan. 1, 1973, memo said that "cost/safety benefit is to be evaluated before releasing components" for performance that exceeds Federal requirements for fuel system integrity.
"This was literally an 18-year cover-up, and the jurors were outraged," said Mark Robinson Jr., one of the lawyers for the plaintiffs, who said the Los Angeles case was stronger than one two decades ago in which he won a big award for fuel-tank fire in a Ford Pinto -- $128 million in punitive and compensatory damages, which was later reduced to $7 million.
Coleman Thorton, the foreman of the Los Angeles jury, said in an interview that the Ivey memo had been just one factor in the verdict. More important, he said, was that Mr. Ivey, who testified through a videotaped deposition, and other General Motors officials appeared to be evasive.
"People who were well-qualified are not supposed to have instant amnesia," Mr. Thorton, a retired custodian, said. "That is the way that most of the witnesses for the defendant reacted."

HEADLINE: The Trillion-Dollar Problem

 BODY:
Only a few years ago, the idea of Congress and the President wrangling over a trillion-dollar budget surplus would have provoked disbelief. But it turns out that the new era of surpluses is just as contentious as the old era of deficits. As Congress returns to work today, House Republicans are preparing a tax cut so large it would use up virtually all of the surplus for 10 years, leaving no money to make Medicare solvent or to avoid deeper domestic cuts. The likelihood that President Clinton would veto an outsized tax cut is only spurring them on. Lawmakers seem to favor slogans over solutions.
But there is no reason to rule out progress this year on critical issues, including the urgent problem of insuring that the baby-boom generation has adequate health care in its retirement years. A little clear thinking will help everyone establish priorities at a time when there is enough money to address them. Some gains have already been achieved. The Congressional Budget Office projects a surplus of nearly $2.9 trillion in the next 10 years, and Democrats and Republicans agree in principle that the $1.9 trillion generated by Social Security taxes should go back into that system to keep it solvent well into the next century. The fight is over the remaining $1 trillion. 
 If Americans want to use that money for tax cuts, they need to know the consequences. The surplus rests on the assumption that Congress and the White House will carry out previously targeted spending cuts. No one thinks that will happen. The budget ceilings for this year, enacted in 1997, call for cuts that the Republican chairmen of the various appropriations committees already say are unrealistic. But the same 1997 law requires even more cuts in future years. At a time when Gov. George W. Bush is getting much applause for his brand of "compassionate conservatism," Republicans in Congress should think twice about more cuts in health, job training, environmental programs and research in science and medicine.
A more realistic approach would set aside a substantial part of the surplus to sustain current domestic spending and perhaps expand it in certain areas. President Clinton also wants to set aside another chunk for Medicare, where Republicans might have some incentive to agree. After the 1995 budget shutdowns, they should realize that the public punishes them every time they try to pay for tax cuts by trimming Medicare. It may be unrealistic to expect agreement on a specific plan to revamp Medicare, although Mr. Clinton's proposal to pay for prescription drugs has found some Republican support. But it is not unrealistic to set aside money for the job out of the surplus.
The reason for sequestering the money now is simple. If Republicans persist in cutting taxes deeply, the long-term consequences will be severe. It took 15 years of tax increases and budget cuts to overcome the deficits created by President Ronald Reagan's tax reductions in 1981. It makes no sense to repeat that pattern. As for the 10-year, $864 billion tax-cut scheme that Bill Archer, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, plans to push, one wonders what the rationale could be. With the Federal Reserve Board raising interest rates for fear of an overheated economy, no stimulus is needed. It is perverse to cut taxes for those who have benefited most from the current boom.
Any scenario for constructive engagement on the budget must start with negotiations in the weeks ahead. The best chance for success would come if Republicans came to their budget senses early and designed a more realistic scheme for the next 10 years. A signal from Mr. Bush, the party's new favorite son, might help. A trillion-dollar budget agreement would be better for everyone than a trillion-dollar breakdown.

HEADLINE: Asian Rebound Derails Reform As Many Suffer

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER and MARK LANDLER

 BODY:
Just two years after it began, the financial crisis that started in Asia and spread pain around the world appears to be over -- leaving many to wonder if the symptoms have abated before the disease could be treated.
All the conventional measures of health look good. Stock markets that tumbled soon after the crisis started in Thailand in July 1997 have bounced back, ranking among the world's best performers in the first half of 1999. Currencies that plummeted, leaving ruin in their wake, have crawled back. Foreign investors who fled Asia like moviegoers from a burning theater are returning, poking around for hidden bargains amid the embers. 
 President Clinton's plausible assessment nine months ago that the world faced "the worst financial crisis in half a century" now seems to many market watchers like a distant echo from another financial era.
But the recovery may have come too fast. In interviews with business executives, policymakers and investors in Asia and America, there is one common thread: The remarkable speed of the rebound has drained the political urgency out of many reforms that seemed so vital during the darkest days of the crisis -- and may still be essential to Asia's future.
Moreover, the pain that is invisible on traders' screens, but striking in the villages where unemployment and misery still lurk, will not ease any time soon.
Most Asian countries have not genuinely confronted the twin weaknesses of their economies: insolvent banks and deeply indebted corporations. Bad loans and bad habits still plague financial institutions from Korea to Indonesia.
"You hear a lot about reforms since the Asian crisis," James A. Harmon, chairman of the Export-Import Bank of the United States, said in an interview. "The truth is that many of the reforms are not proceeding. Old habits die hard."
Mr. Harmon speaks from bitter experience: Not long ago he quietly sought help from Indonesia's President, B. J. Habibie, in convincing one of the country's biggest conglomerates, the Bakrie Group, to begin repaying $80 million owed to the Ex-Im Bank, an American Government agency that lends money abroad to buyers of American-made goods. Mr. Harmon's message was clear: The United States stood behind the bailout that kept Indonesia from a wholesale financial meltdown, and its taxpayers should not be stiffed.
So far, Mr. Harmon has proved singularly unpersuasive, perhaps because the man who owes him, Aburizal Bakrie, has also emerged as one of Mr. Habibie's staunchest supporters. Mr. Bakrie did not respond to several requests for an interview.
In the place where the crisis began, Thailand, the man responsible for overhauling the battered financial system, Amaret Sila-on, rarely misses an opportunity to warn that less has changed than meets the eye.
Yes, he says, Thailand has finally created a bankruptcy court, after two years of foot-dragging by politicians who also head some of the country's biggest insolvent companies. But cronyism lives, he warns, as does the system that heedlessly lent money to the politically powerful. "If the rule of law still remains weaker than the rule of men," Mr. Amaret argues, "banks will return to their old ways despite the restructuring efforts."
The guiding ethic around Asia these days seems to be this: "Wait it out, because in a rebounding market, we will not have to change much." Foreign money is returning, in some cases fueled by Western companies seeking bargains, in other cases by mutual fund managers riding the momentum of a perceived recovery. Some funds may also belong to wealthy ethnic Chinese and others in Southeast Asia who sent cash abroad during the crisis, and now are gradually bringing it back home.
"A lot of C.E.O.'s are clinging to their jobs," said Razak Baginda, who directs the Malaysian Strategic Research Center, a research firm in Kuala Lumpur. "In a way, they've been saved by the stock market."
 
Corruption, Collusion And Complacency
While some of Asia's most troubled companies had to liquidate or sell out to Western investors, many firms that appear insolvent have remained frozen in place. The result is that the corruption and collusion that contributed to the crisis and the complacency that allowed banks to lend with abandon as governments looked the other way have not disappeared.
"There is no question that with improving markets, political pressure to change things is reduced," Stanley Fischer, the No. 2 official at the International Monetary Fund, said recently. Mr. Fischer argues that risks of a "systemic crisis" have been reduced, partly because of changes in his own institution.
James D. Wolfensohn, the president of the World Bank, which often openly disagrees with the I.M.F.'s prescriptions, calls the end of the crisis "a very mixed story," and worries that institutions like his own "no longer have the leverage to get the system fixed" now that the countries do not need immediate cash.
One reason the reforms have been so plodding is that no one ever really decided what caused the crisis. Americans were quick to point to traditions of cronyism and corruption. But those practices have characterized business in Asia for decades, and did not slow what was known as the East Asian miracle.
Asians, bolstered by some big-name Western economists, blamed the I.M.F. for worsening the crisis by forcing big spending cuts to trim deficits. The I.M.F. reversed its strategy after some months. In the end, American and I.M.F. officials note, the countries that most closely followed its advice -- Thailand, South Korea and Brazil -- appear to have rebounded the fastest. The two nations that were so mired in political chaos that they never executed the I.M.F.'s plans -- Russia and Indonesia -- are still in deep trouble.
Pressure from Washington has been uneven. For much of last year, the Asian crisis dominated White House strategy sessions, with many senior officials fearing it could puncture Wall Street's party. But the sense of crisis abated last September after Russia's economic collapse was contained more quickly than anyone expected. And gradually the impetus for wide-ranging reforms slackened, and grand plans for remaking the world financial system became modest adjustments, including new I.M.F. mechanisms to respond earlier to "economic contagion" hitting otherwise well-run countries.
Some problems that contributed to the crisis seem to have been at least temporarily addressed. Virtually all the crisis-hit countries frittered away state foreign currency reserves trying to keep their currencies strong -- and tried to hide that news from investors. Now that the I.M.F. has pressed countries to publish more information, data once considered state secrets can now be found on the Fund's Internet site (www.imf.org).
The Thai baht and the Korean won float freely, and the countries have rebuilt their war-chests of foreign currency mostly by exporting to the United States, and stacking up the dollars they get in return.
Moreover, Asian countries have largely halted their practice of borrowing on short terms from abroad to finance big, long-term projects. That proved disastrous when projects ground to a halt and currencies fell, forcing companies and banks to repay huge debts immediately.
Other bad habits are proving harder to break. No Asian country has yet put an effective bankruptcy law on its books, meaning it is still impossible to wipe out insolvent businesses, settle with creditors, and rebuild viable companies. Thailand has come closest -- opening its first bankruptcy court last month and staffing it with 60 judges.
Still, skeptics say it will take months for those judges to master complex bankruptcy law. And they will find it hard to fight proprietors of debt-ridden companies, some of whom sit in the Thai Senate and have bitterly opposed the passage of stronger laws.
 
Companies Tell Debtors: 'Go Fly a Kite'
In Indonesia, where the laws are even more toothless, the Government has resorted to shaming its corporate sector. The Indonesian Bank Restructuring Authority recently named the 100 worst debtors in local newspapers. But even conglomerates on the list, like the Bakrie Group, are dragging their feet on resolving their debt problems.
Bakrie has offered to give its banks equity in return for canceling its $1 billion in debt. The Export-Import Bank and other creditors object that the plan would leave the Bakrie family, which dug the conglomerate into a hole in the first place, with considerable influence. And they believe Mr. Bakrie has wildly overstated the value of that equity. Still, some local bankers say Bakrie's creditors may have little choice but to go along.
"When companies tell their creditors to go through regular legal channels, that basically means, 'Go fly a kite,' " said a senior official at an American bank in Jakarta, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Rizal Ramli, an Indonesian economist, said the Government lacked the courage to go after well-connected tycoons. "During the Suharto era," he said, "there were only five conglomerates that were untouchable because of their ties to Suharto. Now, there seem to be many more."
As long as Asia's banks cannot pursue debtors, they cannot clean up their balance sheets. Nearly half of all loans carried on the books of Thai banks are classified as nonperforming -- meaning they will probably never be repaid. As a result, Thailand's banks have not made fresh loans, hampering economic recovery, even with a resurgent currency and stock market. The same is true in Indonesia, Malaysia, and Korea -- and of course in Japan, whose banking problems continue to affect the rest of Asia.
Hopes that the crisis would bring accountability to Asian business are fading fast, too. In Malaysia, the infrastructure giant Renong ran up $2.4 billion in debts, despite winning lucrative franchises to run toll roads and bridges. Renong's creditors blamed the youthful chairman, Halim Saad.
Renong is now being rescued by a $2.2 billion bond offering by one of its subsidiaries, which operates Malaysia's key north-south toll highway. Although the bonds are not guaranteed by the Government -- which would make it a direct bailout -- analysts say it will result in higher tolls or force the Government to extend the company's franchise. Mr. Halim, a protege of Finance Minister Daim Zainuddin and a favorite of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, has meanwhile kept his job.
 
Risks of Backsliding In a Very Clubby World
Nowhere, perhaps, is the danger of Asia backsliding more apparent than in the case of Philippine Airlines. The flagship carrier of the Philippines has been staggering under $2.2 billion in debt -- the victim of costly fleet expansion at the time of the regional crisis.
Philippine Airlines, commonly known as PAL, is controlled by Lucio C. Tan, one of the country's leading tycoons and a loyal supporter of the Philippine President, Joseph P. Estrada, who used a PAL plane for free during last year's presidential campaign.
The Government has so far refused to bail out the airline, but Mr. Estrada has made it a personal mission to keep Philippine Airlines flying. He has backed a rehabilitation plan that would leave Mr. Tan, a tobacco-and-beer mogul, in control. The Ex-Im Bank, which financed PAL's purchase of Boeing planes, opposes the plan -- and seized a PAL Boeing 747 this year when it flew into the United States.
A court forced the bank to return the plane, but now it has threatened to seize four Boeing 747's, saying it fears PAL is not maintaining them well enough to preserve their value as collateral. Mr. Tan has not responded to interview requests.
Philippine Airlines proposes to recover -- by getting the Government to reduce the number of rival carriers allowed to fly into the Philippines. That would run counter to the movement to open Asia's markets. "This would be a disaster, not just for the tourist industry but for the country in general," said Emmanuel Gonzalez, the president of the Hotel, Resort and Restaurant Association of Cebu, a resort island.
As the Asian crisis recedes, Mr. Gonzalez is finally seeing his business improve. But the Philippine Airlines case reminds him how little has changed in the clubby world of Asian commerce. "When people here say, 'Wouldn't it be awful if we lost our flag carrier?' " he said, "I wonder if they're really saying, 'Wouldn't it be awful if we didn't get our free tickets anymore?' "

GRAPHIC: Graphs: "As the Economic Crisis Fades, So Does the Urgency for Reform"
 
SOUTH KOREA
A surging stock market has lifted domestic demand, and exports are strong. But the Government has yet to tackle its powerful, debt-plagued conglomerates, known as chaebol, and momentum toward opening markets are losing steam.
 
THAILAND
Thailand finally passed a bankruptcy law. Banks have been able to raise fresh capital, but they have made little progress whittling down bad loans. The stock market recovery has outpaced that of the economy as a whole.
 
INDONESIA
Free elections and a measure of stability are the biggest changes. While the economic contraction is not as crippling as feared, there has been little progress in over-hauling a shattered banking system. Tycoons still demand -- and get -- preferential treatment.
 
MALAYSIA
Malaysia stymied those who predicted that its capital and currency controls would choke the economy. The currency is stable, and foreign reserves are up. But the restructuring of companies has been glacial.
 
RUSSIA
Nearly a year after the ruble's collapse, the country's economy is slowly sinking, but Russians simply endure it. Political chaos has made any real reforms impossible. The I.M.F. is about to lend Russia enough money to keep the country from default.
 
BRAZIL
Perhaps the clearest case of an American-backed I.M.F. bailout doing the job. The economy has bounced back from its troubles last winter far faster than anyone expected. But the rest of Latin America remains mired in recession.

HEADLINE: From High to Low, Hopefuls for 2000 Are Awash in Funds

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11

 BODY:
Representative Shelley Berkley, a freshman Democrat from Nevada, has raised nearly half a million dollars in 10 weeks. Mayoral candidates who are not even favorites are also filling their war chests. And the Democratic National Committee is out of debt.
At all levels, the political system is awash in money. Gov. George W. Bush of Texas may have the most startling bankroll, $36.3 million, but he is part of a phenomenon and not the phenomenon itself. 
 As candidates for Federal office and the national party committees prepare to file their midyear fund-raising reports with the Federal Election Commission, it is becoming clear that money for the 2000 elections is rushing in faster than ever. The strong economy has made it easier to get contributions, and candidates are mobilizing their fund-raising efforts earlier than in previous election cycles.
Fund-raising has become the chief barometer of early political strength, so candidates have been working feverishly to fortify their war chests. And lack of money can be a sign of terminal weakness.
For example, one major factor when Dennis Moore ran in 1998 for a Kansas Congressional seat where no Democrat had won in 40 years was that Representative Vince Snowbarger's June 30, 1997, campaign finance report showed he had only $9,567 in cash on hand. Mr. Moore took the seat back for the Democrats with a narrow victory.
In the six months since he was sworn in, Mr. Moore has worked the phones almost every day to make sure no one sees him as financially vulnerable this year. "I like to learn from other people's mistakes, not my own," he said. Next week his campaign will report about $310,000 cash on hand, a startling total for a freshman.
Representative James E. Rogan, Republican of California, read that President Clinton and various Hollywood figures had targeted him for defeat after his role as an impeachment manager. But other people read that too, and 1,000 of them sent him campaign contributions. So he started a direct mail campaign that has succeeded beyond all expectations, and he will report more than $750,000 in the bank next week.
Governor Bush's $36.3 million Presidential take is spectacular, but others are raking it in, too. Bill Bradley, basically running as "not Al Gore," took in $11.5 million. The National Republican Congressional Committee reports a record haul. The Democratic National Committee is, of all things, out of debt for the first time since September 1996.
Political consultants of both parties report that money is easier to raise than they can remember.
"I've even seen it in a few mayoral campaigns this year," said David Dixon, a Democratic operative here. "Even the sort of midlevel candidates are raising more money than ever before."
Consultants and political strategists start with a predictable set of explanations, largely independent of party.
First of all, they say, their candidate or party has really caught the national mood and people want to help. Secondarily, their staffs have done a terrific job.
And finally, they add, in the words of Shelly Kamins, a developer from Potomac, Md., who runs Bush events here: "Certainly one of the factors is the prosperity in the country. You've got a lot more people who are able to give a thousand dollars."
Mr. Dixon said local contributions were increasing, as new businesses were turning good profits.
"Fifteen years ago you asked them to work phone banks," he said of these donors. "Now you ask them to contribute."
Actually, donors sometimes do not have to be asked. Ronald Weiser, Mr. Bush's chairman in Michigan, said he found the enthusiasm for his candidate "absolutely amazing." In past campaigns, he said, it was hard work to find supporters, especially people who would take on fund-raising.
"This year they are coming to us, asking if they can raise money for Bush," he said. "We say yes, they can."
For most candidates for Congress, an intense battleground because a six-seat shift would give Democrats control, the calls have to be made. Steve Gray-Barkan, a California consultant working for Adam Schiff, Mr. Rogan's likely opponent, hails his client as "a fanatical phoner." Representative Berkley of Nevada, who has raised $485,000 this year, almost all of it since she returned from a honeymoon in April, said, "I'm relentless on the telephone."
"After you've been turned down 10 times," she said, "picking up the phone and making the 11th call, that's the secret."
Mr. Moore said: "I hate to make these calls, but it's a fact of life. You've got to do it if you want to stay in Congress."
Rachel Gorlin, a Democratic consultant, said those calls may be easier to make than they used to be, when "candidates just dreaded picking up the phone and calling people, likely as not to hear complaints." Now, she said, the reception is likely to be civil and to lead to a contribution.
Where is this leading? Norman J. Ornstein, a Congressional scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, an economic and political research foundation here, sees one likely impact of all the money that seems to be available. In the race for the House, he said, there will probably be only 25 or 30 districts that seem competitive by the fall of 2000, "races where both sides spend $2 million and where you get outside groups spending a few million more."
As a result of a 1996 Supreme Court decision, those "outside groups" will include, in a big way, the national party committees. Some of them will not file reports until July 20, but what their spokesmen say indicates they are all sharing in the wealth.
Even the Republican Senate Campaign Committee, whose reports through May show lower receipts than two years ago, is comfortably in the black, and will be more so in a couple of weeks when it receives its half of a record-breaking $9 million joint House-Senate dinner.
At the Republican National Committee, prospecting for new donors, while expensive, has turned up 51,000 fresh checkbooks, "a huge number of people to join a party in an off-year," said Mike Collins, the press secretary. The National Republican Congressional Committee will report a record-breaking $26 million take, and, more to the point, its cash on hand is at $9.3 million, compared with $5.7 million two years ago and $4.5 million four years ago.
Among the Democratic committees, the House campaign committee expects to report more than $14 million raised, or more than twice as much as it took in two years ago. The Senate campaign committee will report $3.9 million in cash on hand, eight times as much as two years ago. Jim Jordan, the committee's political director under Senator Bob Torricelli of New Jersey, the chairman, called the haul a tribute "as much to hard work and a talented staff and a determined chairman as to economic conditions or macro political issues."
And the Democratic National Committee expects to report $21 million in fund-raising and a surplus of $500,000 to $700,000. The chairman, Joe Andrew, said the high numbers were attributable largely to "the Clinton-Gore economy, the best in a generation."
Fred Wertheimer, an architect of the 1974 Federal Election Campaign Act who now leads an advocacy organization called Democracy 21, sees prosperity as only one factor in the torrent of money available.
"All the brakes are off the system," Mr. Wertheimer said. When Mr. Bush's "Pioneers," his club of leading fund-raisers, "are raising $100,000 at $1,000 a contribution," Mr. Wertheimer said, "they will be raising a million or more each when they start collecting soft money."
"We're in a different stratosphere here," he said.
Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, head of the Republican Senate Campaign Committee and his party's chief opponent of change in the campaign finance laws, disagreed. "For most Americans if they are interested in politics at all," he said, "the way they express that is they write out a check for their favorite candidate or cause."
The big ideological causes whose backers send money are likely to be the usual ones: guns, abortion and gay rights. But there is one new one, impeachment. There is even an Impeachment Managers Political Action Committee, which hopes to raise $130,000 through an Internet site that has brought in some money already without an official start-up. The modest financial goal would be enough to give each of the 13 impeachment managers $5,000 for a primary and $5,000 for the general election.
But even if ideology directs some of the dollars, it is the economy that is providing them.
"Everybody is pouring money in," said Tom Downey, a lobbyist here who raises money for various Democrats. "They are rich and the economy's strong. At every level there is more money."
Warren Tompkins, a Republican consultant in Columbia, S.C., said, "People are making more money and they are willing to let go of a little of it."

LENGTH: 414 words

HEADLINE: What James Farmer Leaves Behind

 BODY:
James Farmer, the former head of the Congress of Racial Equality, who died on Friday at 79, was the last of the major civil rights leaders of his generation, and one of the first to begin the struggle. Moved by what he had learned in college of Gandhi's use of nonviolent disobedience, Mr. Farmer founded CORE as a local group in Chicago in the early 1940's, and it was there that he first used Gandhian tactics to integrate the White City Roller Skating Rink. It worked in Chicago, and chapters sprang up east and west, in New York, Philadelphia, Los Angeles and Seattle. But it was unthinkable to try to take the effort into the deep South in the 1940's.
It was not until the late 1950's and early 60's that black and white civil rights activists began to defy the laws and customs of segregation in places like Alabama and Mississippi. To endure the consequent broken skulls and jaws and legs, to suffer shootings, burnings, bombings and lynchings, all without violent resistance, so that the nation could learn from the example of what was done, required a depth of courage and dignity and faith that has never been surpassed in the history of this nation. 
 Mr. Farmer was one of the principal leaders of that time. He directed the daring Freedom Rides that began integrating interstate bus service in the South in 1961. "My father was a Freedom Rider, I'm a Freedom Rider's son," he would sing out in jail. "He was one of the founding fathers not just of the New South, but of the New America," said Representative John Lewis, who was beaten unconscious and jailed with Mr. Farmer on one of the bus rides.
Mr. Farmer and CORE also formed an important bridge between the more traditional, legalistic organizations, like A. Philip Randolph's Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters, Roy Wilkins's National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and Whitney Young's Urban League, and the newer groups that grew in street power as the 1960's progressed. Among these were the Southern Christian Leadership Conference of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee led by Mr. Lewis, Julian Bond, James Foreman and others.
Together, James Farmer and the others led the effort to overcome a system of legal oppression that had endured, in one form or another, from the beginning of the nation. That is achievement enough for their generation. The effort to win greater fairness, and economic opportunity, remains for ours.

HEADLINE: Preventing the Next Power Failure

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Two July 9 front-page articles on recent power failures highlight the need for stand-alone energy sources. As demands of an affluent, wired society outstrip capacity, "off-grid" energy sources become essential, just as they are for poor countries with inadequate systems and supplies. 
 As energy demands grow and oil prices rise, surely it is time for a national debate on energy policies. Several principles may help: Low energy architecture and co-generation can dramatically improve energy efficiency. Manufacturing stand-alone renewable energy sources, like fuel cells, solar and wind-driven units, can provide security for medical laboratories, pump and purify water in developing countries and catalyze economic growth while helping to stabilize the climate.
PAUL R. EPSTEIN, M.D.
Boston, July 9, 1999
 
The writer is associate director, the Center for Health and the Global Environment, Harvard Medical School.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1148 words

HEADLINE: FOES REPORT PLAN TO BEGIN PULLOUT IN KASHMIR REGION

BYLINE: By BARRY BEARAK 

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, July 11

 BODY:
India and Pakistan said today that guerrilla infiltrators battling Indian troops in the last two months along the icy ridges and mountaintops of Kashmir would begin a phased withdrawal, heralding an end to the latest confrontation between the world's newest nuclear powers.
India and Pakistan, who have fought two wars over Kashmir since winning independence from Britain in 1947, were very cautious with their statements today, carefully portraying any silencing of the guns in terms of victory for their side. 
 The recent conflict has been depicted so differently in each country that the citizens of one would barely recognize the war that their counterparts have been following in the news.
While the Pakistanis were describing the development as a gradual cease-fire between warring parties, the Indians explained things more as the recognition of a fait accompli: Most of the invaders into its territory, the state of Kashmir, had already been killed or thrown out.
Either way, if the calm in the mountains holds -- and the step-by-step process is continued -- it would bring to an end the most serious tension between India and Pakistan in 30 years and the first major confrontation since the nations tested nuclear weapons in May 1998.
In a hastily called news conference tonight, Pakistan's Foreign Minister, Sartaj Aziz, said that a "disengagement" by Muslim militants was under way from the fierce fighting, some of it hand to hand, that has taken place in the strategic heights above a vital Indian supply route.
"The director generals of military operations of the two nations met today and agreed on the modalities of de-escalation, including sector-wise cessation of ground and air operations," Mr. Aziz said. "We have been informed that disengagement in the Kaksar sector, which began yesterday, has been proceeding satisfactorily. The disengagement for the Mushkoh sector will begin tonight. Gradually, the disengagement will be completed in the entire area."
The move toward peace was made exactly a week after Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan made a sudden trip to Washington and promised President Clinton that he would take "concrete steps" to end the crisis, seeking the withdrawal of guerrilla forces. He returned with a promise that the President would take a "personal interest" in solving the 52-year dispute over Kashmir.
Although statements from both sides in recent days had hinted at a shift away from diplomatic stalemate, neither India nor Pakistan gave any account of what exactly had led to today's meeting of their senior military chiefs, and the plans for phased withdrawal.
India's leaders have insisted the militant Muslim invaders in Kashmir were thick with Pakistani army regulars, and that the infiltration was a long-planned Pakistani military operation. For the Indians, then, what is taking place now is an anti-climactic withdrawal of defeated remnants.
They had already declared that 95 percent of the intruders had been driven out.
There is "some evidence of withdrawal," Brajesh Mishra, India's national security adviser, said today in New Delhi after a meeting of the leaders of political parties convened by Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee. "It is our hope that in seven days, the status quo of the L.O.C. will be restored if it goes according to plan," he said, referring to the 450-mile Line of Control that divides the Indian and Pakistani-controlled parts of Kashmir.
Since 1947, when India and Pakistan were carved from the British Empire, dominion over the storied Himalayan area of Kashmir has been in dispute, and was the direct cause for two of the three wars between the two nations.
Today, the Indian Maj. Gen. J. J. Singh said, "A decisive moment has now arrived for army operations to finish," adding stiffly that the military will not halt its offensive until every invader has been driven from the mountains.
The matter of whether retreating soldiers would be allowed "safe passage" has been a contentious issue in India since the tide began going its way on the battlefield.
Mr. Mishra was not so tough-talking. When asked if the Indian Army was slowing its attack, he said, "The Indian Army has no tradition of shooting at the backs of people."
In Islamabad, the attempt is to paint the latest turn as a diplomatic achievement for Mr. Sharif and a military victory for the Kashmiri mujahedeen, the Muslim guerrillas that the Government says have challenged the Indians with only moral support from Pakistan.
"In the past few weeks, the mujahedeen action has been gloriously successful as the just and legitimate cause of Kashmir has engaged the international community's undivided attention throughout the period," Mr. Aziz said. He said the focus must now "shift to the expeditious solution of the Kashmir dispute, so that one billion people who inhabit South Asia can lead a life of peace and engage in the endeavors for economic development and presperity."
Brig. Rashid Qureshi, Pakistani's top military spokesman, sat beside Mr. Aziz at the news conference and boasted repeatedly of how the mujahedeen had gotten the best of the Indian Army.
The Indians "have been talking about spectacular victories without having lost any casualties," he said. "That has been done to uplift their sagging morale because they have suffered tremendous casualties," he continued.
But such consistent praise for the mujahedeen's battlefield successes has created a problem for Mr. Sharif, whose trip to the United States is seen by many here as a "sell out" of the freedom fighters who, from most Pakistani accounts, have been heroically prevailing in a holy war.
In denying that any of the invaders are Pakistani soldiers -- something that many Western observers have openly called disingenuous -- the Prime Minister is now left to answer this troubling question: Who is it that is "disengaging" from the mountains, since the mujahedeen have in that last few days proclaimed they hold out till their last breath?
Such stirring defiance was reaffirmed earlier today by the United Jihad Council, an umbrella group of Kashmiri mujahedeen organizations. After Mr. Aziz's news conference, the council made no immediate comment.
Mr. Sharif is scheduled to address the nation Monday night, in which he is likely to reiterate earlier assertions that he in fact does have the mujahedeen's support for a strategic withdrawal -- and that he has convinced them that they have little more to gain from remaining in their bunkers in the mountains.
Brigadier Qureshi said tonight that he had no information about where the mujahedeen would now go, but he said he was sure they would be able to disperse without the Indians doing them harm and move on to continue their holy war elsewhere in Kashmir.
"One must understand that the mujahedeen are fully capable of taking care of themselves," he said.

HEADLINE: Better to Fix Up Cities Than Tear Them Down;
Unglamorous Tactic

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Slash-and-Burn Urban Renewal" (Op-Ed, July 9):
Perhaps the most remarkable renewal program I've witnessed took place in Wyandotte, Mich., an otherwise sleepy suburb in the shadow of downtown Detroit. Several years ago city planners split Wyandotte into separate development and taxing districts.
Within each district, the city identified marginal neighborhoods that were in danger of sliding into decay.
The city used money raised in the tax-exempt bond market to carefully select and purchase one or two houses in each such neighborhood. By condemning, renovating and upgrading those houses at city expense, the city stabilized the neighborhood, induced residents to stay and improve their own homes, attracted new families and arrested the decay.
The appreciation in property values permitted the city to repay the bonds without a broad-based tax increase. The tactic was not glamorous. But as far as I could tell, it worked.
 
DAVID A. BERNAT
New York, July 9, 1999
 
The writer is a director in the public finance department, Prudential Securities.

HEADLINE: MEDIA;
Big Turnout for Minority Journalists

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER

DATELINE: SEATTLE, July 10

 BODY:
If the gathering here this week had been a medical convention, it would have been billed as a gathering of experts seeking cures for terminal nearsightedness. More than 5,000 minority journalists -- and hundreds more people who train them, hire them, study their work, make their computers and advertise with their news organizations -- spent days debating what news organizations must do to put the world in focus.
The overarching assumption was that major news organizations will have continuing trouble keeping their audiences. "We need to paint a more complete picture of America," was the way that Catalina Camia, the president of Unity: Journalists of Color Inc., put it at the opening session of the group's second-ever national convention, which brought together members of the National Association of Black Journalists, the Asian-American Journalists' Association, the Native American Journalists Association and the National Association of Hispanic Journalists. 
 The event nearly foundered nine months ago when a faction of the black group said that Washington State was not a fit site because it had passed an anti-affirmative action initiative. But after rancorous debate, the groups voted to keep the gathering in Seattle. So for some, the existence of the convention was a victory. But for many, jobs mattered most.
"More people of color in the newsrooms -- that's the bottom-line goal of all of the four organizations," said Sheila Brooks, a member of the National Association of Black Journalists who is chief executive of SAB Productions , a television and video production company. "But it's not going to change unless we pound and pound and pound." The convention included a job fair at which scores of news organizations interviewed minority candidates.
"We've made at least one hire here -- at least," said Leonard Downie Jr., the executive editor of The Washington Post. Rob Dean, the managing editor of The New Mexican in Santa Fe, with a circulation of 25,000, had not filled the job opening he had, but said he talked to about 15 candidates and is taking six resumes home. Telly Hughes, a recent graduate of Illinois State University who, at 21, is looking for an entry-level job in broadcasting, came away with a fistful of business cards and a head filled with advice. "I can't believe these established people take time to talk to me," he said.
But hovering near the surface of this gathering was the knowledge that, five years after Unity had its first convention in Atlanta in 1995, the number of Hispanic, Native American, Asian and black newspaper journalists has risen to only 11.55 percent from 10.49 percent, for a total of 6,365 journalists out of 55,100 in newspaper newsrooms, according to an annual diversity survey of the American Society of Newspaper Editors.
But in local television stations, minorities in the work force dropped to 19 percent in 1998 from 21 percent in 1996, according to the Radio-Television News Directors Association.
The Census Bureau estimates that 28 percent of the country's population belongs to one of those four minority groups; that figure is expected to reach almost 38 percent by 2025.
Still, the stubbornness of the statistics and the sense at the convention that minority journalists are leaving the profession faster than they can be replaced did not dampen the spirits of some for whom the convention was like a family reunion. Organizers were pleased to see network correspondents and the publishers or editors of the country's five largest newspapers who came to recruit, and three Presidential candidates who addressed the group.
The jam-packed schedule featured multiple seminars by day -- sometimes six at a time -- and multiple parties by night -- at least six at a time. Sponsors included companies like Knight Ridder, Apple Computer Inc. and the Adolph Coors Company.
As the convention started, the Freedom Forum, a foundation based n Washington, released a survey showing that more than half of minority journalists plan to leave the business in the next five years even though 60 percent said that they liked their jobs "very much." Figures for nonminority journalists were unavailable.
The apparent paradox in the survey can perhaps be explained by ex-journalists like Mary Lou Fulton and Ron Funabiki. Ms. Fulton, whose mother is Mexican, describes her eight-year journalism career, mostly at The Los Angeles Times, in tones that mix real gratitude with deep dissatisfaction.
"Newspapers often believe that if you have enough different colored noses in a newsroom, that's going to make a better newspaper," said Ms. Fulton, who was by turns a local reporter and the editor of The Los Angeles Times's short-lived City Weekly. "I think having enough noses is essential, but you also have to have different coverage strategies." She praised the newspaper's new Hispanic desk, saying that earlier coverage of minority communities was one dimensional.
But for all that, she said, nothing could have kept her from the lure of the Internet, which she discovered five years ago after she had received a master's degree in public administration. Now 35, "an old woman" in her new world, she is leaving her job as a vice president for editorial operations of Yahoo's Geocities unit and is being interviewed for top jobs at two Internet start-ups, she said.
Mr. Funabiki, 50, who is Japanese-American, spent twice as much time in the business as Ms. Fulton, but reflected the same mix of satisfaction and frustration. At The San Diego Union, he had some choice assignments, including a self-designed beat covering the economics of the Pacific Rim. But Mr. Funabiki said he felt his career prospects were limited.
"I wasn't really angry or upset, but I wasn't satisfied with things, either," he said. In 1990, after 19 years in the business, he accepted an offer to start a new program at San Francisco State University focused on analyzing mainstream journalism. After five years, he moved to the Ford Foundation as a program officer.
Both Mr. Funabiki and Ms. Fulton came back to Unity this week -- Ms. Fulton as a panelist for a session on high-technology with Vice President Al Gore, and Mr. Funabiki to see how Unity used some of the $400,000 in grants Ford has made to it in recent years.
The reality of attrition, however, is making it hard to keep the minority numbers rising. A recent article in American Editor cited studies showing that journalism schools over all are producing about 750 minority print journalists a year -- exactly the number of people who, like Mr. Funabiki and Ms. Fulton, have been lost to attrition.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 13, 1999, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about Unity, the joint convention of minority journalists' organizations last week in Seattle, misstated the given name of a former San Diego reporter now at the Ford Foundation. He is Jon Funabiki, not Ron. The article also misstated the year of the group's first joint convention and misidentified a short-lived local section that formerly employed another minority journalist, at The Los Angeles Times. The meeting was in 1994, not 1995. The section was City Times, not City Weekly.

HEADLINE: Asian Rebound Derails Reform As Many Suffer

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER and MARK LANDLER

 BODY:
Just two years after it began, the financial crisis that started in Asia and spread pain around the world appears to be over -- leaving many to wonder if the symptoms have abated before the disease could be treated.
All the conventional measures of health look good. Stock markets that tumbled soon after the crisis started in Thailand in July 1997 have bounced back, ranking among the world's best performers in the first half of 1999. Currencies that plummeted, leaving ruin in their wake, have crawled back. Foreign investors who fled Asia like moviegoers from a burning theater are returning, poking around for hidden bargains amid the embers. 
 President Clinton's plausible assessment nine months ago that the world faced "the worst financial crisis in half a century" now seems to many market watchers like a distant echo from another financial era.
But the recovery may have come too fast. In interviews with business executives, policymakers and investors in Asia and America, there is one common thread: The remarkable speed of the rebound has drained the political urgency out of many reforms that seemed so vital during the darkest days of the crisis -- and may still be essential to Asia's future.
Moreover, the pain that is invisible on traders' screens, but striking in the villages where unemployment and misery still lurk, will not ease any time soon.
Most Asian countries have not genuinely confronted the twin weaknesses of their economies: insolvent banks and deeply indebted corporations. Bad loans and bad habits still plague financial institutions from Korea to Indonesia.
"You hear a lot about reforms since the Asian crisis," James A. Harmon, chairman of the Export-Import Bank of the United States, said in an interview. "The truth is that many of the reforms are not proceeding. Old habits die hard."
Mr. Harmon speaks from bitter experience: Not long ago he quietly sought help from Indonesia's President, B. J. Habibie, in convincing one of the country's biggest conglomerates, the Bakrie Group, to begin repaying $80 million owed to the Ex-Im Bank, an American Government agency that lends money abroad to buyers of American-made goods. Mr. Harmon's message was clear: The United States stood behind the bailout that kept Indonesia from a wholesale financial meltdown, and its taxpayers should not be stiffed.
So far, Mr. Harmon has proved singularly unpersuasive, perhaps because the man who owes him, Aburizal Bakrie, has also emerged as one of Mr. Habibie's staunchest supporters. Mr. Bakrie did not respond to several requests for an interview.
In the place where the crisis began, Thailand, the man responsible for overhauling the battered financial system, Amaret Sila-on, rarely misses an opportunity to warn that less has changed than meets the eye.
Yes, he says, Thailand has finally created a bankruptcy court, after two years of foot-dragging by politicians who also head some of the country's biggest insolvent companies. But cronyism lives, he warns, as does the system that heedlessly lent money to the politically powerful. "If the rule of law still remains weaker than the rule of men," Mr. Amaret argues, "banks will return to their old ways despite the restructuring efforts."
The guiding ethic around Asia these days seems to be this: "Wait it out, because in a rebounding market, we will not have to change much." Foreign money is returning, in some cases fueled by Western companies seeking bargains, in other cases by mutual fund managers riding the momentum of a perceived recovery. Some funds may also belong to wealthy ethnic Chinese and others in Southeast Asia who sent cash abroad during the crisis, and now are gradually bringing it back home.
"A lot of C.E.O.'s are clinging to their jobs," said Razak Baginda, who directs the Malaysian Strategic Research Center, a research firm in Kuala Lumpur. "In a way, they've been saved by the stock market."
 
Corruption, Collusion And Complacency
While some of Asia's most troubled companies had to liquidate or sell out to Western investors, many firms that appear insolvent have remained frozen in place. The result is that the corruption and collusion that contributed to the crisis and the complacency that allowed banks to lend with abandon as governments looked the other way have not disappeared.
"There is no question that with improving markets, political pressure to change things is reduced," Stanley Fischer, the No. 2 official at the International Monetary Fund, said recently. Mr. Fischer argues that risks of a "systemic crisis" have been reduced, partly because of changes in his own institution.
James D. Wolfensohn, the president of the World Bank, which often openly disagrees with the I.M.F.'s prescriptions, calls the end of the crisis "a very mixed story," and worries that institutions like his own "no longer have the leverage to get the system fixed" now that the countries do not need immediate cash.
One reason the reforms have been so plodding is that no one ever really decided what caused the crisis. Americans were quick to point to traditions of cronyism and corruption. But those practices have characterized business in Asia for decades, and did not slow what was known as the East Asian miracle.
Asians, bolstered by some big-name Western economists, blamed the I.M.F. for worsening the crisis by forcing big spending cuts to trim deficits. The I.M.F. reversed its strategy after some months. In the end, American and I.M.F. officials note, the countries that most closely followed its advice -- Thailand, South Korea and Brazil -- appear to have rebounded the fastest. The two nations that were so mired in political chaos that they never executed the I.M.F.'s plans -- Russia and Indonesia -- are still in deep trouble.
Pressure from Washington has been uneven. For much of last year, the Asian crisis dominated White House strategy sessions, with many senior officials fearing it could puncture Wall Street's party. But the sense of crisis abated last September after Russia's economic collapse was contained more quickly than anyone expected. And gradually the impetus for wide-ranging reforms slackened, and grand plans for remaking the world financial system became modest adjustments, including new I.M.F. mechanisms to respond earlier to "economic contagion" hitting otherwise well-run countries.
Some problems that contributed to the crisis seem to have been at least temporarily addressed. Virtually all the crisis-hit countries frittered away state foreign currency reserves trying to keep their currencies strong -- and tried to hide that news from investors. Now that the I.M.F. has pressed countries to publish more information, data once considered state secrets can now be found on the Fund's Internet site (www.imf.org).
The Thai baht and the Korean won float freely, and the countries have rebuilt their war-chests of foreign currency mostly by exporting to the United States, and stacking up the dollars they get in return.
Moreover, Asian countries have largely halted their practice of borrowing on short terms from abroad to finance big, long-term projects. That proved disastrous when projects ground to a halt and currencies fell, forcing companies and banks to repay huge debts immediately.
Other bad habits are proving harder to break. No Asian country has yet put an effective bankruptcy law on its books, meaning it is still impossible to wipe out insolvent businesses, settle with creditors, and rebuild viable companies. Thailand has come closest -- opening its first bankruptcy court last month and staffing it with 60 judges.
Still, skeptics say it will take months for those judges to master complex bankruptcy law. And they will find it hard to fight proprietors of debt-ridden companies, some of whom sit in the Thai Senate and have bitterly opposed the passage of stronger laws.
 
Companies Tell Debtors: 'Go Fly a Kite'
In Indonesia, where the laws are even more toothless, the Government has resorted to shaming its corporate sector. The Indonesian Bank Restructuring Authority recently named the 100 worst debtors in local newspapers. But even conglomerates on the list, like the Bakrie Group, are dragging their feet on resolving their debt problems.
Bakrie has offered to give its banks equity in return for canceling its $1 billion in debt. The Export-Import Bank and other creditors object that the plan would leave the Bakrie family, which dug the conglomerate into a hole in the first place, with considerable influence. And they believe Mr. Bakrie has wildly overstated the value of that equity. Still, some local bankers say Bakrie's creditors may have little choice but to go along.
"When companies tell their creditors to go through regular legal channels, that basically means, 'Go fly a kite,' " said a senior official at an American bank in Jakarta, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Rizal Ramli, an Indonesian economist, said the Government lacked the courage to go after well-connected tycoons. "During the Suharto era," he said, "there were only five conglomerates that were untouchable because of their ties to Suharto. Now, there seem to be many more."
As long as Asia's banks cannot pursue debtors, they cannot clean up their balance sheets. Nearly half of all loans carried on the books of Thai banks are classified as nonperforming -- meaning they will probably never be repaid. As a result, Thailand's banks have not made fresh loans, hampering economic recovery, even with a resurgent currency and stock market. The same is true in Indonesia, Malaysia, and Korea -- and of course in Japan, whose banking problems continue to affect the rest of Asia.
Hopes that the crisis would bring accountability to Asian business are fading fast, too. In Malaysia, the infrastructure giant Renong ran up $2.4 billion in debts, despite winning lucrative franchises to run toll roads and bridges. Renong's creditors blamed the youthful chairman, Halim Saad.
Renong is now being rescued by a $2.2 billion bond offering by one of its subsidiaries, which operates Malaysia's key north-south toll highway. Although the bonds are not guaranteed by the Government -- which would make it a direct bailout -- analysts say it will result in higher tolls or force the Government to extend the company's franchise. Mr. Halim, a protege of Finance Minister Daim Zainuddin and a favorite of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, has meanwhile kept his job.
 
Risks of Backsliding In a Very Clubby World
Nowhere, perhaps, is the danger of Asia backsliding more apparent than in the case of Philippine Airlines. The flagship carrier of the Philippines has been staggering under $2.2 billion in debt -- the victim of costly fleet expansion at the time of the regional crisis.
Philippine Airlines, commonly known as PAL, is controlled by Lucio C. Tan, one of the country's leading tycoons and a loyal supporter of the Philippine President, Joseph P. Estrada, who used a PAL plane for free during last year's presidential campaign.
The Government has so far refused to bail out the airline, but Mr. Estrada has made it a personal mission to keep Philippine Airlines flying. He has backed a rehabilitation plan that would leave Mr. Tan, a tobacco-and-beer mogul, in control. The Ex-Im Bank, which financed PAL's purchase of Boeing planes, opposes the plan -- and seized a PAL Boeing 747 this year when it flew into the United States.
A court forced the bank to return the plane, but now it has threatened to seize four Boeing 747's, saying it fears PAL is not maintaining them well enough to preserve their value as collateral. Mr. Tan has not responded to interview requests.
Philippine Airlines proposes to recover -- by getting the Government to reduce the number of rival carriers allowed to fly into the Philippines. That would run counter to the movement to open Asia's markets. "This would be a disaster, not just for the tourist industry but for the country in general," said Emmanuel Gonzalez, the president of the Hotel, Resort and Restaurant Association of Cebu, a resort island.
As the Asian crisis recedes, Mr. Gonzalez is finally seeing his business improve. But the Philippine Airlines case reminds him how little has changed in the clubby world of Asian commerce. "When people here say, 'Wouldn't it be awful if we lost our flag carrier?' " he said, "I wonder if they're really saying, 'Wouldn't it be awful if we didn't get our free tickets anymore?' "

A front-page article yesterday about Asia's recovery from its financial crisis omitted a given name and title in some copies for a Philippine businessman who commented on a proposal to have the Government restrict competition. GRAPHIC: Graphs: "As the Economic Crisis Fades, So Does the Urgency for Reform"
 
SOUTH KOREA
A surging stock market has lifted domestic demand, and exports are strong. But the Government has yet to tackle its powerful, debt-plagued conglomerates, known as chaebol, and momentum toward opening markets are losing steam.
 
THAILAND
Thailand finally passed a bankruptcy law. Banks have been able to raise fresh capital, but they have made little progress whittling down bad loans. The stock market recovery has outpaced that of the economy as a whole.
 
INDONESIA
Free elections and a measure of stability are the biggest changes. While the economic contraction is not as crippling as feared, there has been little progress in over-hauling a shattered banking system. Tycoons still demand -- and get -- preferential treatment.
 
MALAYSIA
Malaysia stymied those who predicted that its capital and currency controls would choke the economy. The currency is stable, and foreign reserves are up. But the restructuring of companies has been glacial.
 
RUSSIA
Nearly a year after the ruble's collapse, the country's economy is slowly sinking, but Russians simply endure it. Political chaos has made any real reforms impossible. The I.M.F. is about to lend Russia enough money to keep the country from default.
 
BRAZIL
Perhaps the clearest case of an American-backed I.M.F. bailout doing the job. The economy has bounced back from its troubles last winter far faster than anyone expected. But the rest of Latin America remains mired in recession.
