HEADLINE: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD;
In Africa, a Deadly Silence About AIDS Is Lifting

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN, M.D. 

 BODY:
Earlier this year, AIDS became the leading killer in Africa, just 18 years after the infection was first recognized. But if political and religious leaders had responded with effective public health programs much earlier, they might have prevented hundreds of thousands, if not millions, of deaths.
Some leaders simply denied the scientific evidence that H.I.V. was being transmitted in their countries. Others mistakenly believed they had more pressing health problems to address. 
 Now, as the epidemic in Africa becomes an even greater catastrophe, Dr. Peter Piot, Assistant Secretary General of the United Nations and head of its AIDS programs, says he sees signs of momentum among African leaders to fight the disease. The momentum promises to slow the relentless transmission of H.I.V., conveyed on the continent primarily through heterosexual sex, Dr. Piot said in an interview.
Nelson Mandela, the former President of South Africa; his successor, Thabo Mbeki, and Dr. Negasso Gidada, the President of Ethiopia, are among the leaders of countries with high infection rates to speak out on AIDS for the first time recently in their own countries and to beef up prevention efforts.
And, in May, at their annual meeting in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, African finance ministers for the first time called AIDS a major threat to economic and social development.
The United Nations General Assembly recently called for a 25 percent reduction in new H.I.V. infections among young people over the next five years in the countries most affected by AIDS. And the Clinton Administration, appalled by the staggering dimensions of the African AIDS epidemic, is planning an initiative to help, Dr. Piot said.
Large-scale efforts clearly are needed. In sub-Saharan Africa, H.I.V. has infected 34 million people and killed 11.5 million since 1981, dwarfing malaria and tuberculosis. Last year, AIDS accounted for 1.8 million deaths in sub-Saharan Africa, nearly double the 1 million deaths from malaria and about nine times the 209,000 deaths from tuberculosis, the World Health Organization says.
Based on meetings with leaders of 10 African countries this year, Dr. Piot says he has noted a striking change in attitudes toward AIDS: at earlier meetings, he initiated discussions about AIDS; at the recent sessions, African leaders admitted their problems and asked for help.
"It is such a big change," Dr. Piot, a 50-year-old Belgian and a pioneer in AIDS research in Africa, said in a brief visit to New York. In years past, Dr. Piot said, even meeting with an African head of state was difficult.
He recalled an incident about 15 years ago when he and another AIDS expert waited nearly a day in the office of the Kenyan Minister of Health while officials debated whether to expel the two because they had talked to reporters about AIDS in Kenya.
In 1985, Zaire refused to give me a visa to report on AIDS, and the Government of Kenya confiscated issues of The International Herald Tribune, which carried my articles, as leaders denied the severity of their AIDS problem.
African political leaders remained silent even when AIDS was killing members of their own families.
In 1985, the press secretary to Kenneth D. Kaunda, then the President of Zambia, denied my request for an interview about AIDS. The press secretary threatened to expel me for reporting on what he called an American disease. A year later, Mr. Kaunda lost a son to AIDS.
Three years after that, Mr. Kaunda became one of the first to speak out. In describing his family's loss at an international AIDS meeting in Montreal, Mr. Kaunda said that if scientists failed to cure AIDS, the epidemic would become "a soft nuclear bomb on human life." But in the years of Mr. Kaunda's silence, hundreds of thousands of Africans became infected.
Yet even now realism has not fully set in. Dr. Piot still encounters government officials who "ask me why I use the word epidemic," he said.
It takes an average of nine years for H.I.V. to progress to AIDS, and the virus spread widely and silently for a decade before being discovered. Yet even with the undetected early spread, there was time to initiate programs to prevent subsequent infections, as was done effectively among gay men in the United States and other developed countries.
In South Africa, H.I.V. rates soared during Nelson Mandela's Administration, a fact that he later acknowledged.
"It's the silence that is letting this disease sweep through the country," Mr. Mandela said on World AIDS Day in December. "It is time to break the silence."
Dr. Piot applauded Mr. Mandela and Mr. Mbeki, his successor, for calling national attention to AIDS, but said, "It took a long time, and a lot of deaths could have been prevented if they had spoken out earlier."
Today, AIDS continues to thin the ranks of Africa's small middle class, killing at least one teacher a day in Malawi and the Ivory Coast. It is devastating already weak economies across Africa and forcing children to drop out of school to till the farms and care for sick parents.
Dr. Piot challenged African finance ministers at their annual meeting in Addis Ababa in May to learn more about how AIDS was devastating their economies.
"After my speech, there was dead silence," Dr. Piot said. "I thought, another of those moments of supreme denial."
But then, he added, "One after the other, the finance ministers spoke, often making personal references to AIDS in the family or a colleague."
That evening, many joined him for a drink. "The problem was how to stop the discussions," Dr. Piot said. "That was a great moment for me."
The next day, Dr. Gidada, the President of Ethiopia, and His Holiness Abune Paulos, the Patriarch of the Ethiopian Orthodox Church, shook hands with H.I.V.-infected Ethiopians in meeting with them publicly for the first time, Dr. Piot said.
"That may have been a small thing, but it was highly symbolic in Africa," he added.
Uganda, which acted early, showed that educational programs could change sexual behavior after AIDS had struck in vast numbers.
Senegal also thwarted the assault of AIDS, Dr. Piot said, taking "vigorous action" on sex education, AIDS prevention and condom promotion to keep the infection rate below 2 percent. "It is a major political challenge to invest in AIDS prevention when there is not a huge problem," Dr. Piot said, "yet that is exactly what Senegal has done."
Through programs that political and religious leaders encouraged, the Senegalese postponed having first sexual intercourse, used condoms more often and had sex with fewer partners and less sex with prostitutes, surveys there showed.
Nigeria, Africa's most populous country, stands in stark contrast to Senegal, with an infection rate of about 9 percent and rising. A new regime appears to be willing to tackle the AIDS problem in Nigeria, which the previous regime denied, Dr. Piot said.
Dr. Piot's team has a budget of $60 million a year, only enough to act as a catalyst for others to undertake prevention efforts. His AIDS team, for example, calls on African leaders to urge drastic efforts to fight the epidemic.
The latest figures show that international aid paid for $150 million of the $165 million spent on AIDS prevention in Africa in 1997. Uganda accounted for much of the $15 million that the African countries spent.
"It's a scandal that African countries have not spent more," Dr. Piot said.
Although the World Bank and other international agencies make money available for projects in Africa, much of it goes unspent because of bureaucratic complexities and other problems.
Dr. Piot said his agency was trying to identify untapped funds to direct toward prevention efforts, while recognizing that those nations "cannot afford everything for AIDS, certainly not lifetime anti-retroviral drugs."
Taken in combination, those drugs can cost $15,000 a year for a single patient, require adherence to rigid schedules, and often demand sophisticated monitoring tests unavailable in developing countries. That means few Africans can benefit from the drug cocktails, which are prolonging lives and often restoring health among H.I.V.-positive people in developed nations.
To reach a largely captive audience, and one in its sexual prime, Dr. Piot is encouraging governments to spend more of their military budgets, which usually receive high priority, on AIDS prevention.
In Uganda, the infection rate is about 10 percent in the general population and up to 30 percent in the military. "There are African countries where it is said that more than 50 percent of all the military are H.I.V. infected," Dr. Piot said, "and that is a problem of national security."
It also means that many spouses and children are infected. So Dr. Piot's team aims to encourage teachers' unions, school systems and youth groups to join prevention programs in Africa.
In some West African countries, for example, Scouting groups have created an AIDS badge for those who do good deeds for people with H.I.V., Dr. Piot said.
His agency has also teamed on AIDS efforts with Caritas, a Catholic health agency based in the Vatican that is responsible for health care in many African countries, Dr. Piot said.
Although the Vatican does not approve of the use of condoms, Dr. Piot said that he had seen many Catholic priests, nuns and organizations promote condom use in Africa.
In June 1998, Dr. Piot's agency issued the first country-by-country analysis of H.I.V. It showed that one in four adults was infected with H.I.V. in certain parts of Africa and that AIDS was hitting so fiercely that it compared to the greatest epidemics of history. The report was a crucial factor in changing political attitudes, Dr. Piot said.
Dr. Piot said he was criticized for the report by many Western epidemiologists and health workers, who called the figures exaggerated.
"A lot of the criticism had to do with turf battles, from scientists who believe their disease is more important than someone else's," Dr. Piot said, "and it's the type of nonsensical competition that exists in all countries."
But now, the criticism has come full circle. In 1992, a team headed by the late Dr. Jonathan M. Mann at the Harvard School of Public Health, published estimates of H.I.V. infections in sub-Saharan Africa ranging from 20.8 million to 33.6 million by 2000.
The World Health Organization criticized Dr. Mann's estimates as excessive. Now, academic scientists are criticizing the figures of Dr. Piot's team. "When we look at the figures today, they are worse than the scenarios Jonathan had published," Dr. Piot said.
Larger budgets are needed. But pumping money into a country where AIDS is a low priority will not end the epidemic. "If a country does not recognize that it has an AIDS problem, then it is not willing to take on the tough questions," Dr. Piot said. "Outside support for something that can only be solved from the inside will not work.
"We can only win," he added, "if there is a mass movement."

HEADLINE: China's Bid To Send Astronauts Into Space

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
China is closer to becoming only the third nation in history to launch humans into space, a feat that could come as early as next year, say international space experts.
After years of saying it would "one day" or "soon" put people into space, and initiating and postponing efforts to do so, the Chinese government has finally embarked on a serious program to make it happen, these experts believe. 
 "I think evidence of a manned space program in China is very real and that they are serious," said Charles Vick, a space issues expert with the Federation of American Scientists, a Washington policy group.
According to specialists following Chinese space developments, Chinese officials had hoped to put two astronauts into space by October to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Communist takeover of China. But, they said, delays in developing a new rocket for lifting heavy payloads, and problems with other equipment, make such a crewed flight unlikely until at least next year.
Nonetheless, the first flight in the program, an unmanned test of the new rocket and spacecraft, could still come in October.
"Assuming there is no major failure during the first unmanned flight of the system, I would expect a Chinese manned flight a year to 15 months afterwards," said Phillip S. Clark, a British space consultant who closely follows the Chinese program. "Only the United States and Russia have the capability to send people into space and China seems ready to become only the third nation to join this exclusive club."
Lynn Cline, the official in charge of external affairs at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, said the space agency had no detailed knowledge of China's plans. "For many years, they have set as a goal building a manned spacecraft, and earlier said they wanted to make a manned flight this year," Ms. Cline said. However, she said, the agency has heard that this flight has been delayed for unknown reasons and that there will be an unmanned mission instead this year.
Renewed interest in human spaceflight by China flared last month when pictures said to show the Chinese spacecraft and rocket suddenly appeared on the Internet from an anonymous source. The pictures depict a spacecraft based on the Russian Soyuz design atop a large rocket with four booster motors attached to the sides.
Mr. Clark, in an article to appear next month in the British magazine Jane's Intelligence Review, describes the rocket as the Chang Zheng 2F, an upgraded version of one of China's largest satellite launchers, the Long March CZ-3E. The new version is capable of placing a 10 metric-ton payload into low Earth orbit, he said, while the Chinese manned spacecraft weighs about 8.4 metric tons.
The spacecraft itself resembles the Russian Soyuz, which is built in three sections -- a propulsion section, an orbital section and a return module -- but it is larger and carries two pairs of solar-power panels instead of one set as the Russian craft does, Mr. Clark said. The central orbital module, instead of being spheroidal like the Soyuz, is more cylindrical, he said. The Chinese version is designed to make docking with other craft and transferring crew members easy.
The detailed color photographs were supposedly taken by a construction worker at China's Jiuquan launching site near the Gobi desert. They show a completed rocket and spacecraft being rolled out of an assembly building to a gantry and firing pad.
The new building looks a lot like NASA's giant Vehicle Assembly Building at Cape Canaveral, Fla., where Apollo moon rockets, and now space shuttles, were put together for missions. The rocket is on a mechanical crawler with tank-like treads that slowly move it to a launching pad, just as American shuttles are transported. Previously, Chinese space rockets were assembled from components on the pad before launchings, not transported there ready to fly.
Initial discussion about the pictures focused on whether they were clever fakes. Some spacecraft experts questioned whether the pictures were of small-scale models or images put together with computer-aided drawing and photo manipulation software. After carefully examining details in the pictures and calculating the size and positions of elements in the images, most experts now believe they are authentic, for the most part.
"There's too much detail there to be faked," Mr. Vick said.
However, Mr. Clark and other experts said the image of the large assembly and integration building where the rockets are prepared may have been enhanced in some way. The pictures taken by the worker are supposed to be from a promotional brochure created for the construction company that put up the building, and that company may have been trying to emphasize its work in the images, Mr. Clark said.
Some experts also question the relatively close proximity of the assembly building to the launching pad, compared with the arrangement at Cape Canaveral, as evidence of possible photo manipulation. But Mr. Vick noted that the launching arrangement for the new European Ariane 5 rocket also has the service building and launching pad similarly close together.
China launched its first satellite in 1970 and has maintained an active space program that includes launching commercial satellites for clients in other countries.
Chinese officials began discussing sending humans into space in the late 1970's and reports of astronaut training began emerging in the 1980's. Talk of manned spaceflight then ended for several years, partly because of social upheaval in China, and revived in the early 1990's.
The push toward the current manned flight effort, dubbed Project 921, began in March 1995, when China made a deal with Russia to acquire space technology, including information on life-support systems, docking mechanisms for spacecraft and spacesuits. In October 1996, two Chinese astronauts and more than a dozen trainers and support workers arrived at the Russian cosmonaut training center outside Moscow and stayed for about a year, experts said. At about the same time, Beijing announced plans to fly a manned spacecraft for the nation's anniversary celebration, but has said little about the program since.
Officials and scientists questioned about the program in China give conflicting answers, with many declining to comment on possible dates for manned flights until the government announces them.
But one thing Chinese scientists and outside experts agree on is that most of the technology being developed is Chinese, even though some is an adaptation of Russian ideas and equipment.
Dr. Joan Johnson-Freese, an instructor at the Asia Pacific Center for Security Studies in Honolulu, and author of the book, "The Chinese Space Program: A Mystery Within a Maze" (Krieger Publishing, 1998), said the Chinese always have multiple agendas. China wants to prove that it is a technically sophisticated nation and a great power that does not need outside help, she said.
Recent investigations by Congress and the Pentagon that accuse China of stealing secrets and benefiting from American companies illegally transferring rocket and satellite information to China have embarrassed the Chinese and given them something to prove, she said.
"There is no economic payback for a manned space program," Dr. Johnson-Freese said. "The manned space club is very exclusive. It's all for the prestige."
China is willing to spend part of its limited funds to develop technology that is distinctly its own for sending humans into space, she said.
"This way, China can say: 'This is not U.S. technology. This is not Russian Technology. This is very much Chinese technology,' " she said. "It's saying, 'We don't need to steal your secrets and expertise -- we have our own.' "

Rumors are circulating that China is poised to launch humans into orbit. China's space program has been orbiting satellites for almost 30 years. Below are some key dates.
 
APRIL 24, 1970
China launches its first satellite, the 381-pound DFH-1, aboard a three-stage rocket. Lofted primarily for propaganda purposes, it broadcast the music of Dong Fang Hong (The East Is Red).
 
MARCH 3, 1971
China's second satellite, Shi Jian 1, was similar to DFH-1, but replaced music with scientific instruments - a cosmic ray detector, an X-ray detector and a magnetometer.
 
NOV. 26, 1975
China's first recoverable satellite, Fanhui Shi Weixing, presumed to be carrying prototypes of ground- observing cameras, is launched and retrieved three days later.
 
SEPT. 19, 1981
Three satellites are launched aboard one FB-1 rocket.
 
APRIL 8, 1984
China's first successful communi-cations satellite, Shiyan Tongbu Tongxin Weixing, is launched into a geostationary orbit and functions for more than four years.
 
APRIL 7, 1990
China flies its first non-Chinese commercial payload - Asiasat 1. Originally launched from a United States space shuttle in 1984 as Westar 6, the satellite was stranded in orbit when a booster rocket failed and had to be rescued by a subsequent shuttle (above) and sold to Asiasat.
 
JULY 16, 1990
The CZ-2E heavy-lift launching vehicle, capable of placing nearly 20,000 pounds into low Earth orbit, makes its maiden flight. Experts speculate that an advanced version of the booster will place Chinese astronauts into orbit.
 
FEB. 14, 1996
Six people are killed and a $126 million Intelsat satellite is lost when guidance system problems cause its booster rocket, a CZ-3B, to crash on its maiden flight.
 
OCTOBER 1996
Two Chinese astronaut trainees, Li Qinglong and Wu Jie, arrive in Moscow for spaceflight training. They return to China in September 1997, and are thought to be in line for the first manned flight.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
U.S. and Canada Get $125 Million Ruling on Europe Beef Ban

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, July 12

 BODY:
A World Trade Organization panel ruled today that the United States and Canada were entitled to nearly $125 million in sanctions from the European Union because of its illegal ban on hormone-treated beef.
The amount was about half what the United States had sought but more than double what the European Union had thought was reasonable. 
 The arbitration panel's decision clears the way for the United States and Canada to move to the next stage of the sanctions process under the rules of the Geneva-based global trading group. They must now seek formal permission to impose the sanctions; a range of European imports could be hit with 100 percent tariffs, in effect doubling their price.
Unless the European Union rescinds the hormone-beef ban or reaches a settlement with the United States and Canada, the sanctions could be formally imposed on July 26 when the World Trade Organization's dispute resolution body holds its next regular meeting.
The European Union never complied with a ruling by the trade organization two months ago that its ban on hormone-treated beef was illegal. The 15-nation European trading bloc has said that it is investigating evidence that shows such beef poses health risks. The United States and Canada have said that the hormones, which are used to promote cattle growth, are harmless.
Although cattle producers in the United States expressed disappointment with the scaled-down damages, officials from both sides in the trade dispute sought to put the best face on the outcome.
Sir Leon Brittan, outgoing trade commissioner of the European Union, which had hoped for a figure of about $53 million, said the arbitration panel's ruling showed that the claims of the United States and Canada were extravagant. Rita Hayes, the United States trade representative at the World Trade Organization, said the ruling recognized the "serious damage" the exporters had suffered.
In an earlier trade confrontation, the United States eventually won authorization for $191.4 million in punitive duties on European exports because of the European Union's policy of favoring imports of bananas from former European colonies in the Caribbean. As in that dispute, United States officials moved quickly to activate trade organization mechanisms and seek retaliatory measures in the beef dispute.
The beef dispute reflects profoundly different views in the United States and Europe over altered or adulterated foods. European fear of food tampering increased with the outbreak of "mad cow" disease in Britain several years ago. More recently, those anxieties intensified over a scandal in Belgium over chicken and other food products contaminated with the cancer-causing chemical dioxin.
The United States has a strong regulatory body in its Food and Drug Administration, but there is no European-wide body to track food adulteration.
The preliminary United States list of European goods that could be sanctioned in the beef dispute includes canned meats, Roquefort cheese, truffles, paprika, chewing gum, chocolate and mineral water. The Canadian list includes beef, cucumbers, gingerbread, gin, vodka and soup.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury PricesRally as Argentine Markets Drop Sharply

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Bond prices rallied, driving yields to six-week lows, as plunging Argentine stocks and bonds led a rout in Latin America that raised the allure of Treasuries.
"You're seeing some flow out of those markets into Treasuries," which are among the safest investments, said Dave Jallits, who helps invest $5.5 billion at Strategic Fixed Income in Arlington, Va. Problems in Argentina and neighboring countries may also limit the extent of Federal Reserve interest rate increases, he said. 
 Bonds received an additional lift from the strong demand for the Ford Motor Company's record-setting $8.6 billion debt sale on Friday, a sign other corporate sales may find ready buyers. Expectations that Government reports later this week will point to tame inflation also bolstered Treasuries, traders said.
The price of the benchmark 30-year bond rose 1 8/32, to 90 30/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.90 percent from 6.00 percent on Friday.
Bonds gained as Argentina's benchmark Merval index slumped 8.7 percent, a three-month low. A J. P. Morgan & Company index of Argentine dollar debt lost 2.6 percent. That drove its yield to 9.53 percentage points more than comparable United States Treasuries, wider even than Venezuela, rated two notches lower by debt-rating companies.
Argentine bonds fell as rising interest rates and a slower-than-expected recovery from recession prompted an investor flight. The securities also fell as Eduardo Duhalde -- the Peronist candidate for president -- told a radio interviewer that he would entreat Pope John Paul II to support a debt moratorium for cash-short nations like Argentina.

HEADLINE: The Politics of Patients' Rights

 BODY:
After a year of stalling by the Republicans, the Senate began debate yesterday on how to curb unfair health insurance practices. There is widespread public concern that the shift to managed care has left consumers defenseless when they are improperly denied needed care by their health plans. That is the rationale for Federal action.
Knowing that voters care about this issue, Republican leaders are offering a bill that, they hope, will give them political cover at election time. But the bill is weak, and will do little to deter wrongful actions by health plans. The Democrats will try as best they can to strengthen it with amendments aimed at closing loopholes. 
 The Republican bill applies only to the 48 million Americans covered by plans in which large employers act as their own insurers. That would leave 110 million Americans in all other plans unprotected. The bill would extend grievance rights and allow external review of benefit denials to 75 million more people. But those rights would be tightly restricted, and there are enough loopholes to allow unscrupulous plans to circumvent the appeals process. The bill, for example, may bind external reviewers to a plan's definition of medical necessity, even if that definition is unfairly narrow.
The bill does not adequately insure access to specialists. Nor does it amend the Employee Retirement Income Security Act, known as Erisa, to allow patients covered by private employer-sponsored insurance to sue health plans for damages caused by wrongful denials of coverage. Current law allows no meaningful recovery in that circumstance, allowing insurers to escape responsibility. When Erisa was created in the 1970's, there was no widespread problem with denial of care since most insurance was based on traditional fee-for-service care. But the health system has changed, and the players that now control access to care should not be shielded from liability.
The Republicans argue that more regulation will increase costs to industry and consumers. But that argument could apply to all consumer protection laws designed to limit marketplace abuses. The need for a basic framework of rights is particularly strong in a health care system where a patient has very few options once a plan decides to deny coverage. Moreover, the modest increased costs are well worth the benefits. Improving consumer confidence can help sustain the growth of managed care, which remains a practical and necessary strategy for containing costs.

HEADLINE: Lessons From the Blackout

 BODY:
Last week's blackout in northern Manhattan and power shortages in New Jersey provided timely reminders that the New York metropolitan region's power supply is not inexhaustible. On the contrary, a robust economy, combined with the increasingly widespread use of computers, fax machines and other high-tech devices, has created an appetite for electricity that could someday exceed the region's capacity to generate it. One answer is to build more power plants and transmission capacity. But that should be only one element in a broader strategy that seeks as well to conserve energy and exploit newer, more efficient technologies.
Most of the post-blackout criticism has focused on Consolidated Edison and its delivery problems uptown. Though Con Ed has one of the lowest rates of power failure in the industry, it clearly needs to upgrade old feeder cables like those that failed in Washington Heights and Inwood. But pressure must also be brought to bear on Albany. Inspired by utility deregulation, Gov. George Pataki has opened New York's doors to new power plants that can deliver electricity more efficiently, and there are now six applications before the state to build or expand plants. Yet because of a bizarre legislative foul-up, there is no state agency authorized to grant siting permits. Until that regulatory catch is resolved, nothing will happen. 
 Even then it will take several years to build new plants, which means that other strategies must be explored. One such strategy, familiar but vital, is energy conservation. Consumers should be encouraged to buy air-conditioners and other appliances that do more but consume less power, through incentive programs offered by the utilities. In the early 1990's power companies spent $300 million statewide on conservation programs, a figure that has dwindled to $66 million. Albany can revive the program. Meanwhile, businesses should take advantage of new efficiencies in equipment and building design, and Congress should think about targeted tax credits.
A parallel strategy would involve the aggressive application of newer technologies, chiefly the "on-site" generation of power from photovoltaics and fuel cells. Such devices, attached to buildings and homes, will reduce the burden on utilities like Con Ed and, equally important, provide a reliable source of power during emergencies. For example, the blackout may have damaged or delayed hundreds of experiments that medical researchers from Columbia University were conducting at laboratories in Washington Heights. Reliable on-site power could have provided a margin of safety.
Although the long-term solution will involve building new plants and upgrading transmission lines, as well as replacing unreliable components of the existing system, energy efficiency and on-site power are of major importance. They are also environmentally desirable. Conservation, by definition, produces no pollution, indeed reduces it. Fuel cells are also relatively clean sources of power.
The blackout inconvenienced many New Yorkers. But it may also have forced the city, the state and industry to think creatively about how to address the needs of all New Yorkers.

HEADLINE: Pakistani Makes Case For a Halt To Fighting

BYLINE: By BARRY BEARAK 

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, July 12

 BODY:
Castigated by many as a betrayer of the dream of a liberated Kashmir, Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif said tonight in a televised speech that -- to the contrary -- he has helped usher the cause onto the world stage and prudently steered away from an all-out war.
"People are not aware of the anxiety we passed through during the past one and a half months," he said, explaining why he had coaxed Pakistani-backed guerrillas to return from mountaintop redoubts they had seized a few miles inside Indian-controlled Kashmir. "This is no secret that the threat of a big war with India was looming by the way things had deteriorated between India and Pakistan." 
 He added ominously, "Missiles with nuclear warheads were directed toward us and our air force was put on alert."
The 25-minute speech was the Prime Minister's first public statement since he returned from a hastily arranged visit to Washington on July 4. There he promised President Clinton to take "concrete steps" to end the fighting, which had pitted several hundred well-armed Muslim infiltrators against the Indian Air Force and battalions of infantry.
The trip to Washington puzzled and angered many here. Jubilant news accounts had led them to believe the well-positioned guerrillas were making easy prey of woefully vulnerable Indians attempting frontal assaults up steep peaks. The fighting had put the emotionally charged Kashmir issue onto front pages worldwide, and then the Prime Minister seemed to knuckle under to American pressure.
But with a troubled political opposition, a weakened judiciary and an intimidated press, there is little on the political horizon to challenge Mr. Sharif. In fact, for all the discontent, even the nation's usually intrepid Islamic fundamentalists have been unable to mount anything but relatively muted street protests.
"Our decision to give diplomacy another chance, to try it once again, is not a result of haste, nor has it been taken under pressure," Mr. Sharif insisted. "A sage has said that it takes more courage to come out of a war than to start a war."
He said the guerrillas had made the world understand that "Kashmir is a nuclear flashpoint."
A withdrawal of the fighters -- known here as the mujahedeen, or Muslim holy warriors -- began on Saturday. While the pullback may be a testament to the Prime Minister's persuasive skills, it also lends support to consistent Indian accusations that the invaders were mostly Pakistan Army regulars, a view shared by many analysts.
Mujahedeen organizations have not helped Mr. Sharif's credibility. While he thanked the guerrillas today for heeding his plea, leaders of several of the groups called Mr. Sharif a traitor and denied they were making any retreat at all.
In a typical criticism, Rifaat Hussain, a professor of international relations in Islamabad, said: "Nawaz shouldn't have had such an early loss of nerve. Now he's nowhere. His idea of defusing the crisis was to run to Washington."
Indeed, in his speech, Mr. Sharif made much of the assurance he received from Mr. Clinton that the President would take a personal interest in settling the Kashmir situation, a 52-year-old dispute that has led the nations into two all-out wars. "An assurance by the leader of a power like America is not insignificant," Mr. Sharif emphasized.
The Pakistanis want the world to compel India to permit a plebiscite, a vote to which India once committed itself. The vote would allow the Kashmiris -- most of whom are Muslims -- to choose whether they want to belong to largely Hindu India or Muslim Pakistan.
Mr. Sharif's speech was quickly assailed by political rivals. The leading opposition, the Pakistan Peoples Party, called for his resignation, but the party has called for his resignation before, and it is a party in disarray. Its leader, the former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, lives abroad, and faces arrest if she return because she has been convicted of corruption.
Democracy is constantly rumored to be endangered in Pakistan, which has a powerful military that is said to be frustrated by inept and corrupt civilians at the helm. But military leaders seem to support Mr. Sharif's decision to reduce tensions with India, which has a numerically superior military and a less feeble economy.
Tonight the Prime Minister spoke of resuming the "Lahore Declaration process," a high-level dialogue that began in February with a bus trip to Pakistan by India's Prime Minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee.
But any talks are likely to be heavy with distrust. As Indians see it, Mr. Sharif has proven a duplicitous rogue who pretended to be a peacemaker while endorsing a plan by his generals to launch an adventure into Kashmir. To the Pakistanis, Mr. Vajpayee is an opportunist who has used the conflict to whip up a war hysteria to benefit himself in coming elections.
Their goals concerning the Kashmir dispute are different:
Mr. Sharif hopes that the past two months of alarming headlines will cause the world to recognize the danger of the situation. Mr. Vajpayee welcomes no such attention and says Kashmir is best kept a bilateral concern.
Among the more stirring parts of Mr. Sharif's speech was his likening of the Kashmir situation to a volcano, and the mujahedeen to lava. "As long as lava boils, it finds its way to the plains," he said. "And the Kashmiri resistance, like that lava, will find someplace else. And it will never cool off."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Argentine Stocks Fall Again, and Other Latin Markets Follow

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, July 12

 BODY:
The Argentine stock market had its worst session in seven months today, falling 8.7 percent on fears that the Government deficit was widening and a year-old recession was deepening.
The broad drop came on the heels of a 4.4 percent decline of the main stock index on Thursday, the last day of trading before the country's Independence Day holiday on Friday. 
 The tumble in what was until recently a favorite emerging market contributed to a selling mood that pulled down stock prices across Latin America; Brazil's market fell nearly 3 percent and Mexico's market shed 1.5 percent. The slide in Argentina also caused concerns on Wall Street about more areas of potential weakness.
"Argentina faces severe challenges as it tries to deal with a strengthening U.S. dollar, weak agricultural commodity prices and stagnant global export markets," wrote David Malpass, senior economist at Bear Stearns, in a report today. Mr. Malpass attributed today's sliding stock prices to "shortfalls in tax revenues during the recession and concerns over congressional inaction."
Concerns about the health of the Argentine economy have grown since the Government revised its economic data a month ago. The decline in first-quarter output was recalculated to 3 percent, from 2.8 percent. At the start of the year, the Government projected that the economy would grow this year, but economists now estimate that the contraction could be as steep as 2.5 percent.
The sharp devaluation of the Brazilian real in January has made Argentine exports increasingly uncompetitive with the country's largest trading partner, particularly hurting the automotive and steel industries.
With tax receipts falling sharply, the Government has also had to raise the yearly fiscal deficit to $5.1 billion -- nearly double the number first discussed in negotiations with the International Monetary Fund.
And unemployment is expected to climb to at least 15 percent in the next few weeks, almost 3 points higher than last October. Private forecasters in Argentina have estimated that industrial production has fallen nearly 13 percent in the last year -- well above Government estimates.
There is a growing impression among investors that President Carlos Saul Menem is losing influence in his final months in office. Last week, he and his congressional supporters backed down on a new vehicle tax to pay teacher raises when tens of thousands of truck drivers went on strike across the country. To some analysts, the retreat suggested that the Government would also back down on needed tax measures under pressure from other interest groups.
The two leading presidential candidates have also contributed to the market's anxiety by not declaring their economic policies.
Both of them -- Gov. Eduardo Duhalde of Buenos Aires, the candidate of the ruling Justicialist party, and Mayor Fernando de la Rua of Buenos Aires, of the opposition Alianza party -- also hurt investor confidence recently when they suggested that Argentina would need relief from payments on its $130 billion foreign debt. This weekend, Mr. Duhalde said he would seek support from Pope John Paul II for a debt moratorium for struggling countries like Argentina.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Th e organization that specializes in the business of doing good is doing well on the Internet.

BYLINE: By Lisa Napoli 

 BODY:
THE Advertising Council, the nonprofit organization that produces and distributes public-service announcements, has risen in the last four months from 23d to 9th place in rankings of the most visible advertisers on the Internet, according to Nielsen/Net Ratings, an Internet measurement service.
That is not because the council has increased its advertising budget. It has no such budget. As it does in other media, on the Internet the council relies on the benevolence of Web sites to run its advertisements in unsold space. 
 As a result, banner advertisements that the council created on behalf of nonprofit groups on recycling, drunken driving, crime prevention and nearly 20 other public-service causes appeared 133 million times on the Web last month. Such messages reached 16.2 percent of all people who surf from home, according to Nielsen/Net Ratings.
This puts the organization in the ranks of such other highly visible on-line advertisers as the Microsoft Corporation and Amazon.com.
The council's increased visibility represents a gesture of good will on the part of Web publishers. But what does it say about the medium that so much advertising space is being given away?
"It's another indication that there's a ton of unsold inventory on the Web, as if we needed any more," said Jim Nail, an analyst who covers Internet advertising for Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass.
Indeed, 40 percent to 70 percent of the ad space on even the most highly trafficked Web sites goes unsold, said Rich LeFurgy, chairman of the Internet Advertising Bureau, an industry trade organization. For what Mr. LeFurgy calls second- or third-tier sites, the proportion of unsold space is even higher.
One explanation for the unsold space is that the Web offers practically infinite publishing opportunities. Thus it has exponentially more advertising capacity than do television, radio and print media, which have limited space and air time.
Reluctant to have space allotted for advertising appear empty -- the digital equivalent of dead air time in broadcast media -- Web sites often plug in ads promoting their own services to take up the space. But a site can use just so many of those ads without looking tired.
"So why not plug in some public service, be a good guy?" Mr. Nail suggested as the reason for the widespread use of the public-service banners. "When people see that, they say, 'Hey, this site is good.' "
Besides perceiving that the Web site at hand has a social conscience, the public is also exposed to messages intended to improve society and public safety and to promote the nonprofit groups that advocate these causes.
The spirit of mobilizing communities is what propelled the advertising industry to create the War Advertising Council 57 years ago. Then, the group's focus was to rally the nation in support of World War II. One of its first initiatives was a campaign featuring Rosie the Riveter, the character that motivated women to enter the work force during the war. Now, the organization is known as both the Advertising Council and the Ad Council.
In 1997, the council added an on-line component to its public service campaigns. The banners are created by advertising agencies that volunteer staff time, and are available on the council's Web site (http:// www.adcouncil.org) to anyone who wishes to display them.
Peggy Conlon, president of the Ad Council, likens the increasing use of council banners on line to the early days of television, when public-service commercials helped fill air time.
"The more stations that went on the air, and the more hours they programmed, the more space there was to fill," she said. "We're being brought along on the Internet by the phenomenal growth of the industry."
Over the years, the council has grown significantly: in 1998, the group received $1.2 billion in donated space from all media. Donated space on the Internet soared from $5 million in 1997, based on cost estimates given the council by the contributing sites, to $28 million in 1998. That makes the medium an even bigger supporter of public-service campaigns than newspapers, which contributed $21.2 million in space in 1998. Even so, the sacrifice is a bit different: Web publishers have a lot of unsold space to give away, while traditional media companies often donate space they could have used for paid advertising.
Last year, the National Crime Prevention Council was the top-ranked media campaign for the Ad Council, receiving $128.1 million in donated media space. Jacqueline Aker, media director for the National Crime Prevention Council, said the Internet played an important role in helping her organization achieve its mission of educating the public about crime prevention, with 5,000 people a day visiting its Web site.
An anti-crime campaign aimed at teen-agers has received what Ms. Aker described as exceptional placement on line because many teen-age-theme Web sites are wary of accepting excessive paid advertising.
"Some sites like the Cartoon Network use our banners all the time," she said. "The creative makes a big difference, too. Our banners are really cool." They were fashioned by Saatchi & Saatchi, along with its interactive agency Darwin Digital, both of which are New York units of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C.
For all the good that such public-service advertisements do, some people still suggest that the incredible reach the Ad Council has achieved is a sign of a sluggish climate for advertisers on the Web. Wenda Millard, a council board member who is executive vice president of the on-line advertising network Doubleclick Inc., called that view cynical.
"Not all inventory on the Internet is going to be valued by advertisers," she said. "Some of the top sites may be top sites based on traffic, but it might not all be desirable space. I think it's very natural that you'll have tons of open space. The barriers to entry for the Web are so phenomenally low that literally your grandmother can create a Web site."
And if Grandma wants to put a public-service ad for the council-created character Smokey Bear on it, all the better.

HEADLINE: Tracking Just What The Doctor Ordered;
Medicare Changes Would Bolster Prescription Management Services

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS

 BODY:
Barrett Toan calls himself a silent partner in the health care system. And if President Clinton has his way, there will be many more like him.
Mr. Toan is the president of Express Scripts Inc., which supervises the filling of 295 million prescriptions a year for 47 million people with private health insurance. In calling for Medicare coverage of prescription drugs, Mr. Clinton wants to see Express Scripts and similar companies play the same role for 39 million older Americans and disabled people. 
 While such companies, known as pharmacy benefit managers, have been popular for a decade or so, most consumers have only a vague idea of the powerful force they exert over which drugs are sold and which pharmacies sell them.
With the plastic identification cards issued by Express Scripts and similar companies, a patient can walk into a pharmacy, hand over $10 and walk out with $70 worth of medicine. The pharmacy benefit manager negotiates the complex arrangements behind that transaction.
Mr. Clinton would give such companies a great new responsibility, managing drug benefits for Medicare patients, who use a third of all drugs prescribed in the United States. But that shift would also illuminate some practices that have largely escaped public notice, including the power of pharmacy benefit managers to affect doctors' decisions and their dealings with drug companies. The arrangements, which include rebates from the drug companies to the managers for giving preference to certain drugs, would become much more visible.
Pharmacy benefit managers organize the market for prescription drugs, securing deep discounts from drug manufacturers and retail pharmacies for large employers or health plans. They try to influence doctors' prescribing habits and encourage the use of lower-cost drugs, including generic substitutes for brand-name medicines. They strongly recommend certain drugs over others in each therapeutic category -- antihistamines and treatments for high cholesterol or high blood pressure, for example.
In some ways, pharmacy benefit managers are like health maintenance organizations: they try to control the cost of care. So far, they have not engendered widespread hostility among consumers, as some H.M.O.'s have.
"We think we could play a useful role in Medicare," Mr. Toan said in an interview at his headquarters here. "We help consumers get the maximum value for the dollars they spend on pharmaceuticals. Many elderly patients are paying prices 20 to 25 percent higher than what our customers pay because they don't get the type of discounts we can negotiate."
But doctors and pharmacists are concerned about the market power of pharmacy benefit managers. While Express Scripts is independently owned, some of its chief competitors are owned by drug companies and drugstores.
"Our offices are besieged with faxes and phone calls urging us to change the drugs we prescribe for patients," said Dr. Raymond Scalettar, a Washington rheumatologist. "It's very troubling, very intrusive, and not necessarily in the patients' best interest."
Some people are equally troubled by the practice of drug manufacturers' giving cash rebates to the pharmacy benefit managers in return for having their products included on the list of preferred drugs. Pharmacists worry that some drugs may be chosen more for their rebates than for their efficacy. The terms of rebate agreements are considered proprietary information and are a carefully guarded secret.
Such concerns would grow if these companies managed drug benefits for Medicare recipients.
The President's plan to cover prescription drugs is part of his proposal to reorganize Medicare to make it more competitive and financially secure as members of the baby boom generation approach retirement age. Administration officials see pharmacy benefit managers as a way to prevent explosive growth in the cost of Medicare drug benefits without resorting to Federal price controls, which are anathema to drug makers.
Gene Sperling, the President's chief economic adviser, who helped design Mr. Clinton's Medicare proposal, said, "There are no price controls in this."
Rather, Mr. Sperling said, the Government would simply get "reasonable discounts," like other health plans that buy large quantities of drugs.
Nationwide, pharmacy benefit managers handled 1.8 billion prescriptions last year. Employers, labor unions and private health plans have increasingly turned to such companies to control drug spending, which has grown much faster than other health spending in recent years.
A study by the General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, found that pharmacy benefit managers had reduced the cost of drug benefits for Federal employees by 20 percent to 27 percent.
Drug benefit managers develop networks of retail pharmacies that may include thousands of drugstores. In return for a large volume of business, the drugstores must give discounts. Under a typical arrangement, a drugstore receives the average wholesale price for a drug, minus 15 percent. The pharmacist also gets a small dispensing fee, perhaps $2 for each prescription.
Elderly people often pay the highest prices for prescription drugs because their purchasing power is fragmented. Under Mr. Clinton's proposal, the Government would hire a private company in each region of the country to manage drug benefits for the large numbers of Medicare patients who are still in the traditional fee-for-service program.
Howard J. Bedlin, vice president of the National Council on the Aging, a research and advocacy group, said, "There's an emerging consensus that pharmacy benefit managers have an important role to play in Medicare reform, but you have to build in certain consumer protections" to guarantee the confidentiality of patients' records and to inform consumers of any restrictions on their choice of drugs.
Express Scripts, like other pharmacy benefit managers, reviews prescriptions before they are filled at retail drugstores across the country. The pharmacies file claims electronically. Express Scripts can immediately tell the pharmacist if the customer has insurance and how much of a co-payment to charge.
In addition, Express Scripts has records of other drugs that a patient has bought. This allows it to tell the pharmacist if the new drug would duplicate an existing prescription, if it could cause harmful interactions with other drugs or if a prescription is being refilled too early. The company at this point could also notify the pharmacist if another drug or a generic is preferred.
While employers and H.M.O.'s praise the work of drug benefit managers, many doctors and pharmacists have had frustrating experiences.
Edward F. Dillon, co-owner of Grubb's Pharmacy, a century-old store on Capitol Hill in Washington, said he understood the need to hold down health costs but had been exasperated by the techniques of pharmacy benefit managers.
"In some cases," Mr. Dillon said, "you have a college-age customer service representative calling a doctor with 30 years of experience and asking, 'What is your medical justification for this drug?' "
John M. Rector, general counsel of the National Community Pharmacists Association, which represents 35,000 independent pharmacies, said the preferences for certain drugs were often based on "back-room deals that the consumer never knows about."
For example, Mr. Rector said, a pharmacy benefit manager "sometimes tells the pharmacist to dispense a more expensive, inappropriate brand-name drug because the P.B.M. is getting a rebate or kickback from the manufacturer."
But Mr. Toan said most of the money from cash rebates was passed on to the sponsor of a health plan, reducing the overall cost of drug benefits for patients.
Mr. Toan, a former director of the Missouri Social Services Department, said Express Scripts was "the nation's largest independent pharmacy benefit manager." PCS Health Systems of Scottsdale, Ariz., another benefit manager, has been owned since January by Rite Aid, the drugstore chain. Their biggest competitor, Merck-Medco Managed Care, is owned by Merck & Company, the drug manufacturer.
Express Scripts manages $10 billion a year in drug spending for its clients, which include Bethlehem Steel and Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Missouri.
Stuart L. Bascomb, executive vice president of Express Scripts, said some drugs would not be affordable for many people without the discounts obtained by pharmacy benefit managers. The average retail prescription price of common cholesterol-lowering drugs, for example, is $100 a month, or $1,200 a year.
In one respect, Medicare is different from other clients of Express Scripts. Mr. Toan refused to give details of its contracts with drug manufacturers and pharmacies. But Congress and the public would probably insist on knowing the details of any discounts negotiated on behalf of Medicare patients.
The Comptroller General of the United States would want to audit Medicare's drug spending. Medicare officials would be tempted to regulate the activities of pharmacy benefit managers to protect Medicare patients and to save taxpayers' money. And pharmacists would demand an explanation if they were excluded from the list of drugstores serving Medicare beneficiaries in a particular region.
Even with the best efforts of drug benefit managers, Mr. Toan said, "Medicare, like commercial health plans, would probably face double-digit increases in drug costs, in the range of 15 percent a year."
Under Mr. Clinton's proposal, beneficiaries would have to pay half of any drug costs covered by Medicare.
"That would serve as a check against unnecessary use of medicines," Mr. Toan said. On the other hand, he said, "a lot of new medicines will address conditions of the elderly, and that might keep up a fairly steep increase in drug spending."
Independent pharmacists complain that they have little opportunity to negotiate with pharmacy benefit managers because contracts are offered to them on a "take it or leave it" basis. They say payments are so low that they often lose $5 or more on a $50 prescription.
In response, Mr. Toan said, "That's our job, to seek the lowest price we can get for our customers."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Malaysia Pushes Flagging Plan for Its Own Silicon Valley

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: CYBERJAYA, Malaysia, July 10

 BODY:
When 25 senior executives from technology companies around the world gathered here this week to tour Malaysia's Multimedia Super Corridor project, it had all the appearance of a somewhat dutiful pep rally for a technology-friendly Southeast Asian leader.
The meeting, however, was far from routine -- either in its lush tropical setting or in the object of the corporate kudos: Mahathir Mohamad. 
 Dr. Mahathir, the Prime Minister of Malaysia, has been engaged in the fight of his life over the last year. As the Asian economic crisis tore through this normally tranquil country, Dr. Mahathir, 73, imposed widely criticized controls on Malaysia's capital markets, vilified foreigners for causing Asia's misery, and imprisoned his popular former deputy, Anwar Ibrahim.
Many people here feared that the furor would doom Dr. Mahathir's ambitious vision to make Malaysia the technology lodestar of Asia. The Prime Minister's actions baffled some members of the panel of foreign executives that advises him on his flagship project, the Multimedia Super Corridor. The project, which was started in 1996, officially opened Thursday and is expected to take two decades to complete.
If the three-day meeting in honor of the opening did not quite dispel the manyfears, it provided a much-needed psychic boost.
"I am very pleasantly surprised by the amount of progress, frankly, that has been achieved," said Lewis Platt, the chairman of Hewlett-Packard and one of the executives on the advisory panel. Mr. Platt said he had heard a stream of bad news about Malaysia and the Super Corridor.
Dr. Mahathir's grand plan to carve an Asian Silicon Valley out of vast palm-oil plantations here is not dead -- though it is not thriving either. While Malaysia has signed up 228 companies to invest in the Super Corridor, only 9 have moved into the 270-square-mile swath of land between Kuala Lumpur and its futuristic airport. Just one, the accounting firm Arthur Andersen, is American.
Despite the upbeat remarks of Mr. Platt and other executives, most major foreign companies are still guarded about their commitments. The slow pace of investment has forced Malaysia to roll back its plans.
"When you plan for X number of dollars, and your economy suddenly shrinks by 6 percent, you have to scale things back," said Mohamed Arif Nun, the head of operations at the Multimedia Development Corporation, which runs the venture. "But it has not destroyed the integrity of the project."
Indeed, now that Malaysia has settled down a bit, Dr. Mahathir seems determined to get things back on track. In a ceremony inaugurating Cyberjaya, the new city that will be the heart of the Super Corridor, the Prime Minister reminded his visitors that they had 12 months to move their operations into the area -- or lose a package of tax exemptions and other incentives.
A handful of companies are here now. N.T.T., the Japanese telephone giant, just opened a research center, while Alcatel, the French telecommunications equipment maker, announced plans to open an operation with 40 engineers. But the big American players -- Hewlett-Packard, I.B.M., Microsoft and Sun Microsystems among others -- have yet to break ground or even rent office space.
Jaya is a Malay word meaning success, and Cyberjaya's planners confidently predict that it will someday be home to 240,000 people. For now, it feels like an ultra-modern ghost town. Roads and bridges crisscross land that used to be covered by palm trees, while fiber optic cable snakes underground.
There is even a new Multimedia University to serve, Stanford-style, as an academic hothouse for the community. The school, which opened in May, has 2,600 students and will eventually enroll 15,000.
Executives here acknowledged that last year's spate of troubles made the Multimedia Super Corridor a tough sell. Zasmida Abu Samah, the manager of sales and marketing for Cyberjaya's real estate developer, said it was difficult to lure new tenants between January 1998 and last fall.
"Last year was very hard," she said. "After January 1998, it was dead silence. We couldn't get people to call us."
Ms. Zasmida said companies began expressing interest again after Malaysia was host for the annual meeting of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum last November. Although the meeting was rocked by a speech in which Vice President Al Gore rebuked Malaysia for its suppression of freedoms, it did not generate violent street protests, as some had predicted.
"The political situation is something we pay close attention to," said Frank Smith, a partner at Ernst & Young in Singapore. "But it hasn't been a particularly destabilizing influence on our business."
Ernst & Young, the accounting and consulting firm, had proposed to build a regional technology center in Cyberjaya. Although the firm is revising the plan, Mr. Smith said it still planned to move operations here. "We just didn't do it as fast as we planned," he said.
Dr. Mahathir's decision to impose controls on Malaysia's capital markets last fall was a bigger cause for concern. The move, which he said was necessary to stabilize Malaysia's currency, the ringgit, drew harsh criticism. The Prime Minister worsened matters with outbursts against foreign currency traders.
During talks with the executives, Dr. Mahathir was questioned about the policy, according to a panel member. "He said, 'all we did was fix the currency.' " said the panel member. "But he acknowledged he may have been precipitate in his comments." Even if Malaysia can lay all fears to rest, it still faces formidable rivals. Singapore and Hong Kong are both building multi-billion-dollar technology parks -- seizing on high technology as a ticket out of their own doldrums.
Perhaps hedging its bets, the Multimedia Development Corporation announced plans to build a film studio and theme park in Cyberjaya -- marrying Silicon Valley with Hollywood, according to its proponents.
Some of the visitors said the all-encompassing nature of the Multimedia Super Corridor could give it an edge. With plans for schools, apartments, even golf courses, Cyberjaya is no mere office park.
"Most of these other countries are building technology parks to incubate small companies, which is fine," said John Gage, the chief researcher at Sun Microsystems. "But Malaysia thinks very, very differently."
As he puts a tumultuous year behind him, Dr. Mahathir must now hope that the world will come to share his vaulting vision.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow Creeps to New Record; Other Gauges Are Mixed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stocks were narrowly mixed on light volume yesterday, although the Dow Jones industrial average did edge up to a record. The struggle in the stock market came despite a big day in the bond market, where long-term interest rates fell sharply, with the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond ending at 5.90 percent.
Traders said bonds benefited from a big slide in the Argentine and Brazilian stock markets. Money flowing out of those markets may well have sought safe haven in the United States Treasury market, they said. 
 Any improvement in interest rates, however, will be short-lived if reports on producer and consumer prices scheduled for this week are viewed unfavorably.
"The producer price data will be an important determinant in whether bond yields relax further or are pushed back up," said Thomas M. Galvin, chief investment strategist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
The inflation reports, as well as a heavy schedule of corporate earnings reports expected this week, caused many stock traders to stay on the sidelines.
"The concern is about earnings, and whether or not expectations, which are high, will be exceeded," said William Meehan, chief market analyst at Cantor Fitzgerald. "Many stocks, especially technology shares, have had huge moves in advance of these reports. Unless a company really blows past the estimates, I expect we might see some profit taking when the numbers are announced."
Helped by a gain of 1 3/4, to 53 1/2, in International Paper, which is scheduled to release its second-quarter earnings today, the Dow rose 7.28, to 11,200.98, although broader market measures slipped.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was down 4.18 points at 1,399.10. Declines in General Electric and America Online more than offset gains in technology issues like Lucent Technologies, Microsoft and MCI Worldcom.
The Nasdaq composite index fell 2.63 points, to 2,790.44. Big declines in Internet stocks like Yahoo and Amazon.com pulled the index down.
Small stocks, however, had a decent day. The Russell 2000 index of small-company shares rose 1.32 points, to 459.30.
Volume was sluggish, at 668.8 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange and 970.9 million shares on the Nasdaq.
Mr. Galvin of Donaldson, Lufkin said that a report expected from Intel after the market closes today would say a great deal about how technology shares might fare in the second half of the year. In addition to releasing financial data for the second quarter, Intel is expected to provide an outlook on the next six months.
"If Intel says Y2k is not an issue, that will clearly be a positive" for the market, Mr. Galvin said, referring to concerns about the Year 2000 computer problems. Shares of Intel slipped 13/16 yesterday, to 65 7/16.
Shares of Amgen Inc., the world's largest biotechnology company, fell 3, to 66 5/16, but were at $72.25 in after-hours trading on the Nasdaq. On Friday, citing "unusual" trading in its stock, the company said it would report second-quarter results after the market closed yesterday, about 10 days ahead of schedule. Profits rose 24 percent, to $268 million, or 50 cents a share in the quarter, surpassing both the 41 cents a share earned a year earlier and Wall Street expectations of 46 cents a share.
Eastman Kodak, a Dow component, gained 1 11/16, to 72 13/16.

HEADLINE: The Quill Holds the Power: Moscow's Media Wars

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, July 12

 BODY:
Someone not familiar with the average Russian's bent for intrigue might find it strange that one of Moscow's most influential newspapers was sold last week to an offshore investment fund run by two Iranians from a nearly empty Manhattan office.
But a lot is going on with the raucous press these days, much of it unsettling, and Russians who have been fitting the pieces together do not find such a sale strange at all. They suspect that the Iranians are a front for one power broker or another. An election campaign is beginning, and everyone with power, from business moguls to the Government, is angling to influence the outcome. 
 Influence has sometimes been a synonym for money, but the consensus this year is that the press -- or perhaps the faction that has the most control over it -- will play a crucial role in choosing who will lead Russia. The nation will elect a lower house of Parliament this winter and a successor to President Boris N. Yeltsin next summer.
The reason, analysts say, dates to early 1996, when a deeply unpopular Mr. Yeltsin appeared destined to lose his re-election campaign until Russia's information outlets rallied behind him -- and helped pull off a spectacular comeback victory.
"For everybody involved in this election, l996 proved that control of the media -- the support of the media -- is crucial in Russia," said Floriana Fossato, a correspondent and expert on the Russian press for Radio Free Europe in Moscow, "in fact, particularly in Russia."
The chief difference this time, of course, is that the press is not about to unite behind Mr. Yeltsin or his favored candidate. The solidarity of 1996 sprang from fears that a Communist victory would end capitalist reforms and lead to the closing of opposition newspapers and television stations.
Today Mr. Yeltsin is even more unpopular, but his likeliest successors, by and large, are democrats, if not always capitalists. Few worry these days about either a Communist victory or a serious crackdown on newspapers or broadcast outlets.
That is not quite the same as saying the Russian press is free. Moscow has at least 15 dailies of note and dozens of weeklies. They flaunt a range of opinion that makes American newspapers look pinched, and rarely a day goes by without the flaying of some hapless official or business power.
But most papers and magazines remain tools of their owners, who are not squeamish about ordering up stories to suit their views.
More than once, feuds among oligarchs and officials have been played out in the press. The most spectacular example occurred this spring, when an inquiry by Russia's prosecutor general into high-level corruption was sidetracked by a videotape on state-controlled television showing a man strongly resembling him in bed with two women.
Given that sort of power, it was not at all surprising that someone decided to snap up Kommersant, a business-oriented daily that is said to be millions of dollars in the red. It does not circulate widely outside Moscow, but its reputation for independence and accuracy has given it influence well beyond its circulation.
The newspaper's buyers, two 30-ish unknowns, paid perhaps $20 million for an 85 percent stake. Although the new owners vigorously deny it, few in Moscow believe that they are anything more than fronts for someone seeking an extended reach in anticipation of a new Government. It is unclear, though, why the buyer would want to be secretive about it.
The denials about the buyers' intention have not gained credibility from the disclosure that the remaining 15 percent stake was bought by Boris Berezovsky, the most ambitious of Russia's business leaders.
"There's no doubt that these events are directly connected with the elections," said Misha Berger, the editor of the respected daily Segodnya. "Kommersant is the act of a group of private investors or politicians in Russia. Maybe it was a contest between Berezovsky and Chubais."
He was referring to Anatoly Chubais, once Mr. Yeltsin's chief economic adviser, now the chairman of the electricity monopoly and for years an enemy of Mr. Berezovsky.
Mr. Chubais, who remains a backstage adviser to Mr. Yeltsin, was widely reported to be seeking control of Kommersant with the help of a Moscow bank.
It would take a small book to describe all the political jockeying among the media barons. But any report would begin with Mr. Berezovsky, an arch-capitalist and onetime Yeltsin ally whose relations with the Kremlin are strained.
More than anyone, Mr. Berezovsky has been beefing up his holdings. He is already the principal force at the Moscow newspaper Nezavisimaya Gazeta and at Russian Public Television, a nationwide network that is 51 percent state-owned. And he bought control this spring of TV6, a popular Moscow station hit hard by last year's fiscal collapse.
He said at a news conference last month that his holdings would work to promote liberal economic reforms and to restrain the Communist Party. Some analysts believe he plans a campaign to try to end Communist control of the lower house.
Mr. Berezovsky's purchase angered Mayor Yuri Luzhkov of Moscow. Through city entities, the Mayor controls a small stake in TV6, a share of a Moscow newspaper, a major publishing house and two-thirds of Center TV, a channel whose content might best be termed all-Luzhkov, all the time.
Mr. Luzhkov, an early contender for president and a political enemy of Mr. Berezovsky, complained that TV6 would not cover him fairly if Mr. Berezovsky owned it.
For sheer ambition, however, neither man is likely to match the Russian Government, which experts say has been conspicuously busy fine-tuning its huge information machine.
Late last month the country's second state-controlled television network, RTR, abruptly canceled a popular long-running program, "Top Secret," which specialized in political muckraking, sometimes aimed at the Government itself.
Network officials said the program had descended into "kompromat," roughly translated as mudslinging. Program executives responded that it was RTR that had broadcast the video that seemed to show the prosecutor and the women.
About the same time, Igor Shabdurasulov, the general director of the largest state-owned television network, ORT, told a convention of Russian journalists his views on the campaign: "We will determine for ourselves which political parties and movements correspond to our political understanding."
The Government owns 100 of Russia's 550 television stations and 18 percent of the 12,000 registered newspapers and magazines, said Kim Iskyan, an analyst with MFK Renaissance, a major investment bank in Moscow.
"With the overwhelming majority of broadcasters and print media outlets controlled by groups that have political power as their ultimate aim (including the Government itself), the media has come to be a means to the end of power, rather an end in and of itself," Mr. Iskyan wrote in his latest analysis.
And it is used with great effectiveness. After Russia's lower house approved the nomination of Sergei V. Stepashin as Prime Minister this spring, state-controlled television suddenly broadcast a stream of advertisements promoting the candidacy of Vladimir Zhirinovsky, a right-wing nationalist leader, for governor of Belgorod region. Most analysts assume the ads were a thank-you for Mr. Zhirinovsky's delivery of his followers' votes to Mr. Stepashin.
Last week Mr. Yeltsin signed a decree combining all press functions, from issuing broadcast licenses to overseeing communications satellites to forming media policy, into a single Cabinet agency headed by a state television official, Mikhail Lesin, one of Mr. Yeltsin's top image-makers.
Prime Minister Stepashin rejected expressions of concern that the Government was forming a propaganda ministry, but he allowed that the agency would "consolidate all the state's capabilities in -- pardon the old-fashioned word -- 'ideological work.' "
In an interview on Friday, Mr. Yeltsin's spokesman, Dmitri Yakushkin, said the ministry was an old idea that Mr. Stepashin had decided to carry out and that its functions would be mainly technical.
Russian journalists note that the new ministry will have potentially sweeping powers to revoke broadcasting licenses and even to pressure newspapers, and they expressed the hope that Mr. Stepashin is simply guilty of infelicitous phrasing stemming from his years working on internal security.
They take heart that Mr. Yeltsin has repeatedly insisted that the press be unfettered, even as it attacked him. At the same time, they are unnerved by his mercurial personality and by nagging reports that he is reluctant to cede power.
"I don't think we have to exaggerate the meaning of these events, but we can't ignore them either," said Mr. Berger, the editor. "During the last year, Yeltsin has been an even stronger advocate of freedom of the press. But maybe something changed. We hope it didn't, but it can."
