HEADLINE: D'Amato Trying to Settle Cipriani-Union War

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Former Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, never known for delicate diplomatic skills while in office, is now trying to settle the bitter and protracted war between the restaurant workers union and the Cipriani family over the landmark Rainbow Room and some of the city's most expensive restaurants and catering halls.
But the restaurant war, which has forced celebrities like Leonardo DiCaprio, Julia Roberts and Arthur Miller to take sides, may turn out to be a particularly tough challenge for Mr. D'Amato, now a consultant and lobbyist. 
 Even as the union established a daily picket line outside the Rainbow Room and the Ciprianis tried to toss the union out of its flagship restaurant on Fifth Avenue in the spring, Mr. D'Amato shuttled between the two sides trying to bring an end to the conflict. But the battling only seemed to intensify.
The restaurant family lost tens of thousands of dollars when the union persuaded General Motors, George magazine, HBO and many others to cancel their events at Cipriani 42d Street, the family's catering hall, according to court papers. In May, the Ciprianis sued the union and filed for bankruptcy protection for Harry Cipriani, its chic and profitable restaurant in the Sherry-Netherland Hotel.
"In the past eight months, the union has been trying to put pressure on Harry Cipriani in order to get some positive results at the Rainbow Room," said Giuseppe Cipriani, who runs the family's New York operations. "That's why I put the company into Chapter 11."
But in bankruptcy court last week, both sides discussed asking the court to formally appoint Mr. D'Amato as the mediator in the conflict. Mr. D'Amato, the Senator who excoriated President Clinton for years, took on the Swiss Government on behalf of Holocaust survivors and sang schoolyard ditties on the Senate floor, said, well, maybe.
"There are some contentious issues," Mr. D'Amato said yesterday. "There are tough-minded people on both sides. If I can facilitate an end to the hostilities, I'd like to do it. But there has to be a zone in which a settlement is possible. If that exists, I would formally agree to become involved."
Mr. D'Amato, who has advised the Cipriani family in the past and knew some of the union leaders, said he would not take money for his efforts. "It's really a labor of love," he said. "It's not for economic reasons."
The war began last December when the Cipriani family took over management of the Rainbow Room at Rockefeller Center and fired the 250 workers who were represented by Local 6 of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Union. The union vowed to fight and immediately set up a picket line. The war spread to the Ciprianis' newly opened catering hall on 42d Street and to Harry Cipriani, where the union had represented workers since 1992.
Mr. Cipriani refused to compromise, saying the union was killing his business, although Harry Cipriani is regarded by many people in the industry as one of the most profitable restaurants in the city.
At the urging of both sides, Mr. D'Amato got involved in May, and though the first meeting appeared to go well, Mr. Cipriani did not return to the bargaining table, according to two people who were involved in negotiations.
In a move that does not bode well for Mr. D'Amato's efforts, Mr. Cipriani offered to sign a union contract at the Rainbow Room if the union would agree to slash the wages and benefits of workers at Harry Cipriani in half, said Peter Ward, president of the Hotel Trades Council. After Mr. Ward refused the offer, Mr. Cipriani flew to Washington last week in an unsuccessful attempt to win over the national union.
"He's asking the union to give him a gigantic subsidy at the restaurant he owns exclusively, in return for a union contract at the Rainbow Room, which is owned by him and his investors," Mr. Ward said. "So he's holding his investors' interests hostage to his own. It's just not going to happen."
Meanwhile, Mr. DiCaprio and the film director Martin Scorsese decided to move their benefit for the Film Foundation to another location rather than cross a picket line to get into Cipriani 42d Street. "Leonardo DiCaprio feels strongly about picket lines and the rights of workers," said Ken Sunshine, a spokesman for the actor.
Ms. Roberts and Mr. Miller crossed pickets lines at the catering hall for events in May.
The union has been busy on other fronts as well. In response to complaints by the union and others, the city's Department of Consumer Affairs is investigating whether the Ciprianis should have a license to operate the catering hall. Consumer Affairs recently cited Mr. Cipriani for failing to obtain a license for a sidewalk cafe at his SoHo restaurant, Downtown, at 376 West Broadway.
Last week, both sides decided to give Mr. D'Amato one more try.
"At every war there is a beginning and an end," Mr. Cipriani said. "We are looking forward to the end."

HEADLINE: Credit Card Scheme Tied to Car Rentals

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
One thing that hundreds of people who fell victim to an elaborate credit card scheme had in common was that they had all rented a car from the Thrifty car rental agency in Warwick, R.I., over the last three years, officials said.
The other thing they had in common was that a former employee at the agency was accused of selling copies of their rental car agreements for $20 apiece to a group of Nigerian immigrants in New York who used the information to steal $1.4 million, according to prosecutors from the Queens District Attorney's office. 
 The immigrants used information from the rental agreements to dig for more data in computer banks to call banks and transfer money from the victims' credit card accounts into bank accounts that they had opened under false identities, prosecutors said.
Nine Nigerian immigrants were arraigned yesterday in the credit card scheme, which was also linked to a broad range of other crimes, including tax fraud, forgery of drivers' licenses and Social Security cards to help illegal immigrants obtain employment, and dealing in drugs. All nine pleaded not guilty to the charges, which were handed up in a 268-count indictment.
The Queens District Attorney, Richard A. Brown, said 1,300 people from 21 states had had their credit identities stolen by the ring since early 1996. Law enforcement officials traced the illegal wire transfers, ranging from $600 to $44,000 and said most of the stolen money was sent back to Nigeria.
The former Thrifty employee, who was not identified, was also accused of selling rental car agreements in Chicago and Missouri but has not yet been charged in the case.
Mr. Brown said that although the banks that issued the credit cards eventually covered the losses, "the victims still suffered immeasurably because of the loss of their credit ratings and of their good names." He added that consumers ultimately wound up paying for this kind of fraud through high interest rates.
He said the rental agreements included the driver's license number of the renter, which in some states is the same as a Social Security number. The suspects are said to have used the Social Security numbers to obtain copies of birth certificates, which gave mothers' maiden names, the password that many banks use to authorize money transfers.
Both Mr. Brown and Police Commissioner Howard Safir called for changes in the banking industry to make it harder to transfer large sums of money by phone. They said law enforcement efforts were handicapped by the fact that banks seldom report this type of fraud and instead assume it as a cost of doing business.
"It's incomprehensible to me that banks would transfer large amounts of money out of an account based simply on a telephone call without any significant means of identification," Mr. Brown said.
Mr. Safir said a major hurdle in prosecuting this kind of credit card fraud was that neither victims nor banks readily reported the crime. "People are not rushing forward to report it because the credit card companies tell them they're not liable for it," he said. "So banks need to rush forward and report this, but they don't."
Mr. Brown said banks often made it easy to transfer money electronically to attract more customers. "They figure if one of 100 transactions is fraudulent, then that's the cost of doing business," he said.
Most of the illegal transactions in the current case, worth $1.1 million, were authorized by MBNA-America, a bank based in Wilmington, Del. Other financial institutions lost between $21,000 and $64,000.
Brian Dalphon, a spokesman for MBNA, with 40 million customers worldwide, said he believed that it was just coincidence that the bulk of the illegal transfers came out of MBNA accounts. "Our fraud losses are actually among the lowest in the industry," he said. "This particular scheme was brand-new. It was something we hadn't seen before, and since then, we've put in controls so that it won't happen again." He would not elaborate on the new controls.
Prosecutors said the credit card scheme was uncovered while police officers were investigating suspected drug dealing in the Rockaways. Wiretaps later led officials from one drug suspect to other suspects linked to the credit card theft and forgery. Officials said they did not know whether all the suspects were legal immigrants or where in Nigeria they came from.
The three charged with selling $16,500 worth of heroin face up to life in prison if convicted and are being held without bail. They are Joseph Omesiete, 44, a security guard from Far Rockaway, Queens; Babatunde Shodunke, 34, a taxi driver from Rosedale, Queens, and Bola Adeola, 34, a security guard from Arverne, Queens. Mr. Adeola also has been charged in the credit card scheme.
Prosecutors said the credit card operation was organized by Ayodele Peters, 28, who they said ran it from his home in Canarsie, Brooklyn. He faces seven years in prison if convicted and was unable to post $60,000 in bail. His lawyer, David E. Levine, said, "He wouldn't be sitting in jail for $60,000 bond if he had $1 million he'd stolen from people."
Mr. Levine also represents Mr. Peters's wife, Yewande Elegbe Peters, who faces 25 years in prison if convicted in the scheme. Mr. Levine said Mrs. Peters, who worked as a State Health Department inspector, gave birth two weeks ago to twin boys two months prematurely. "The birth was brought on by the aggravation of this case," he said.
The four other suspects were released on bail and face between 7 and 15 years in prison if convicted. They are Derrick Roundtree, a 35-year-old accountant from Flatbush, Brooklyn; Olusola Ashaye, a 42-year-old security guard from Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn; Abiodun Oguntoyinbo, a 38-year-old security guard from Bedford-Stuyvesant, and Adebiyi Otulaja, a 37-year-old youth counselor from Arverne.
Chris Payne, a spokesman for Thrifty, said he had little information on the case. "We do recommend that our locations take the utmost care in handling this kind of information," he said, adding that many agencies use shredders to destroy the forms.

HEADLINE: Globalization Widens Rich-Poor Gap, U.N. Report Says

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, July 13

 BODY:
Globalization is compounding the gap between rich and poor nations and intensifying American dominance of the world's economic and cultural markets, according to the latest human development report published today by the United Nations Development Program.
The 262-page report, the 10th the program has issued, is the first to focus on the spread of the Internet and computer technology as well as the impact of globalization. It concludes that the so-called "rules of globalization" should be rewritten to save the 60 countries that are worse off they were in 1980 from falling even further behind. 
 While short on specific proposals for making international markets work "for people rather than profits," the report recommends, as have previous versions, faster debt relief, redirection of aid to the poorest countries and a task force to review "global governance." It also endorses a tax of one American cent on lengthy E-mails to raise $70 billion a year that could be used to connect the world's Internetless.
The report warns that the glaring, growing inequalities in the distribution of wealth pose a "dangerous polarization" between rich and poor countries.
As in previous reports, it says little about what role the poorest nations themselves play in their predicament. It says little about the corruption and mismanagement of resources in many of the poorest countries that have discouraged foreign investment and squandered millions of dollars in foreign aid.
The report highlights the dominant role of the United States, and as a result, of English -- the language of choice for 80 percent of web sites -- in the new global telecommunications marketplace. It notes that 26 percent of Americans use the World Wide Web -- as opposed to 3 percent of Russians, 4 one-hundredths of 1 percent of the population of South Asia and 2-10ths of 1 percent for Arab states. And it says that the United States has more computers than the rest of the world combined.
It also notes that the annual sales of General Motors are larger than the gross domestic products of Thailand or Norway, and that Ford generates more income than Saudi Arabia. America and the other rich, industrialized nations hold 97 percent of all worldwide patents, it says.
Moreover, the report says, the gap between globally well-connected and unconnected peoples is likely to grow even faster given the technology explosion. The number of Internet users today, 150 million, is expected to grow to 700 million by 2001. An American needs to save a month's salary to buy a computer; a Bangladeshi must save all his wages for eight years to do so.
Richard Jolly, a British economist and the report's main author, said the report is neither anti-American nor anti-free market. "The report specifically endorses markets as the best guarantee of efficiency," Mr. Jolly said, "but not necessary of equity."
America, he said, was among the first to appreciate the dangers of monopoly and, as such, to pass antitrust laws to dilute concentrations of economic power. The international community, he said, has yet to figure out how to deal with such global market concentrations.

HEADLINE: Second Agency Downgrades Nassau County Bonds Rating

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

 BODY:
MINEOLA, N.Y., July 12 -- A second major bond-rating agency today downgraded Nassau County's credit to near-junk status, prompting the county's budget director to accuse Democrats in Albany of blocking a bailout of Nassau "for partisan political reasons."
Despite a booming economy and one of the nation's wealthiest populations, Nassau is confronted with a budget deficit of more than $200 million after years of growth in spending that was not matched by tax increases. Its bonds were steeply downgraded by Standard & Poor's on June 29. Moody's Investors Service today lowered Nassau's rating to an equivalent level, Baa2, just two notches above junk, and threatened another downgrade if the county does not obtain new sources of revenue soon. 
 In announcing the downgrade, Moody's faulted Nassau for delays in obtaining state legislative approval for a new one percent tax on property sales. "It just doesn't seem like a great deal of progress is being made, or a significant amount of positive discussions are taking place between the county and the state," said Helen Cregger, of Moody's.
Assembly Democrats led by Thomas P. DiNapoli, of Great Neck, in Nassau County, last week demanded that the county give the State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, a Democrat, extensive oversight powers in exchange for such a bailout.
In a statement released this evening, Michael Fabiano, the Nassau budget director, blamed Mr. DiNapoli and his colleagues for the latest downgrade. "The county has formulated a fiscal plan which addresses the issues raised by Moody's," Mr. Fabiano said. "Unfortunately, key elements of the plan, which require state legislative approval, have been blocked by Assembly Democrats for partisan political reasons. The action announced today by Moody's is not unexpected in view of the State Assembly's failure to act on the county's fiscal plan."
Told of Mr. Fabiano's statement, Mr. DiNapoli said, "Now's not the time for a blame game." But he quickly added that it was County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta, a Republican, who was guilty of inaction, for ignoring the Democrats's call for oversight by the Comptroller and other reforms. "We haven't heard back, except that they feel we're asking for too much," he said. "We give them a 20-page document, and they give a one-sentence response. They're just not dealing in reality."
In addition to lowering the rating on Nassau's $2.7 billion in long-term bonds, Moody's lowered Nassau's short-term credit rating from the highest to the second of three rating levels. Ms. Cregger said the lower rating would reduce the number of investors bidding for Nassau's short-term notes and increase the county's costs. The county expects to borrow a record $430 million in this way to pay its bills this year.
Moody's also said the county's plan to borrow against anticipated future income from its share of a nationwide tobacco settlement by the end of the year seemed "increasingly remote."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

Cost of Drink Recall Rises For Coca-Cola's Bottler
Coca-Cola's bottler, Coca-Cola Enterprises, said that it would take a $103 million charge against second-quarter earnings to cover expenses associated with the recall of soft drinks in Europe last month, about 70 percent more than previously acknowledged. The charge erases second-quarter earnings for the bottler.
Coca-Cola Enterprises said two weeks ago that the recall involved 14 million cases of soft drinks and would cost the company $60 million. But that number ballooned after 17 million cases of products were returned. Page C7. 

Schlumberger to Spin Off a Unit
Schlumberger said that it had agreed to spin off its offshore drilling unit, Sedco Forex Offshore, and merge it with Transocean Offshore to create the world's largest offshore oil-drilling company. Both companies said that the spinoff was a response to the high cost and greater technological demands of offshore exploration, where drilling is taking place in ever-deeper waters. Shares of Schlumberger rose 50 cents, to $64.8125. C7.
 
Justice Department Accuses Toyota
In a lawsuit that carries the potential for nearly $60 billion in fines, the Justice Department accused Toyota of putting faulty smog-control computers on 2.2 million vehicles. A1.
 
Goldman Sachs to Buy Hull Group
Signaling its support for new ways of trading securities, Goldman Sachs Group announced that it would buy Hull Group, a leading electronic trading company, for $531 million. C6.
 
Senate Debates Rights of Patients
The Senate opened a high-stakes debate over how to protect the rights of patients and regulate the companies that provide health insurance for most Americans. A12.
 
Cutback in Jeep Grand Cherokees
DaimlerChrysler is slowing production of the Jeep Grand Cherokee to a rate of 294,000 a year, down 60,000, in a sign that sales growth of sport utility vehicles may be easing. C2.
 
Dow Edges Up, but Nasdaq Slips
Stocks were mixed in light volume. The Dow Jones industrial average edged up 7.28 points, to 11,200.98, a record. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 4.18 points, to 1,399.10, and the Nasdaq composite fell 2.63 points, to 2,790.44. C10.
 
Bond prices rallied, driving yields to six-week lows. The yield of the 30-year bond fell to 5.9 percent from 6 percent on Friday. C10.
 
I.B.M. Plans to Acquire Sequent
Sequent Computer Systems, which was founded by former Intel executives and engineers, including Casey Powell, the company's chairman and chief executive, agreed to be acquired by I.B.M. for $810 million. Sequent was formed to create a new computer that would tie together multiple microprocessors, but despite market-leading technology, the company has struggled to increase sales in competition with larger rivals. C9.
 
New Publisher for The Boston Globe
A senior executive of The New York Times, Richard H. Gilman, has been named the publisher of The Boston Globe, which the Times Company owns. He replaces Benjamin B. Taylor, 52, who will continue as the chairman of the Globe Newspaper Company Board. C8.
 
N.A.A.C.P. to Press Networks
The president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People announced the start of a campaign to press television networks and advertisers to include more minorities in prime-time shows. A10.

The Argentine stock market had its worst session in seven months, falling 8.7 percent on fears that the Government deficit was widening and a recession was deepening. C6.

HEADLINE: Tax-and-Spending Talks Begin in Earnest

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 12

 BODY:
President Clinton and Republican leaders warily met today to discuss a broad array of tax and spending proposals that expose the deep divisions and distrust between the parties.
With Mr. Clinton back from a weeklong tour of impoverished areas and Congress returning to work after the Fourth of July recess, talks began in earnest in the Oval Office late this afternoon on matters of social policy and money that will drive negotiations in Washington through the fall budget-writing season, and probably well into the 2000 campaign. 
 Mr. Clinton invited the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott; the House majority leader, Dick Armey, and Speaker J. Dennis Hastert to the White House to discuss his plans for Medicare and Social Security and to hear Republican proposals for large tax cuts. The Democratic leaders of the Senate and House, Tom Daschle and Richard A. Gephardt, also attended the meeting.
The President told the Republican leaders that he was willing to work with them to use the bulk of projected Federal budget surpluses of $2.9 trillion over the next 10 years to insure the solvency of Social Security and Medicare, aides said after the meeting. But he repeated his view that Republican plans to cut taxes by $800 billion or more over the next decade would make it impossible to revamp Medicare or to add billions in new spending for education, the military and the environment.
Gene Sperling, the President's chief economic adviser, said the President expressed willingness to discuss tax cuts of a smaller magnitude, but only after dealing with what he views as more pressing priorities. Mr. Clinton has said he would be willing to devote about $250 billion of the estimated surplus over the next decade to tax breaks intended to spur retirement savings among low- and middle-income families.
While the atmosphere of the Oval Office meeting was described as friendly, Administration officials earlier in the day described the Republican tax-cutting plans as a "shell game" that threatened to undermine the economy, consume the estimated surpluses and put the Federal budget back into the red just as an encouraging scenario of surplus is about to begin.
Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers called the tax cuts "potentially explosive" if projected surpluses fail to materialize. Mr. Sperling said the Republican proposals were "puzzling, disappointing and disturbing" because they leave nothing for the repair of Medicare.
The vehemence of the White House reaction this early in the process led Republicans to question the President's sincerity when he says he seeks to put partisanship aside and reach a compromise this year.
"I'm still trying to figure out if he really wants to get things done -- cooperate on Social Security, Medicare, taxes, even trade -- or is he going to go the partisan route," Mr. Lott said in an interview with The Associated Press. "I get different signals from him. Most indicate he's going for partisanship."
For all the money being put on the table by the surplus, reaching a deal will not be easy.
The debate over how to apportion the excess revenue is about more than numbers. Republicans support a big tax cut not just because it would give money back to voters, but because it would move the money out of Washington, and therefore help their efforts to reduce the size and influence of the Federal Government.
Administration officials said their intent was not to block a tax cut, but to insure continued financing of military, education, health and environmental programs, while pumping new money into Medicare and avoiding the risk of renewed budget deficits.
As a result, any compromise would be more complex than finding a number between $250 billion -- the amount Mr. Clinton says is appropriate for a tax cut over the next decade -- and $864 billion, the figure in the Republican tax legislation that will be taken up by the House Ways and Means Committee on Tuesday.
"It would be a mistake to think you just look at these numbers and somehow say, well, can you just split the difference?" said Jacob J. Lew, the White House budget director. "You have to ask, what do you want to get on defense, what do you want to get on Medicare, and you have to put first things first."
In the end, though, the most complicating factors may be the political judgments made by leaders of both parties about how a deal, or the lack of one, would play on the campaign trail in 2000.
There are factions within both parties that see an ideological showdown as the best way of turning out voters on their behalf next year. And there are both Democrats and Republicans who believe that they will do better by going to the voters with a record of accomplishment, even if it means compromise.
The calculations will be particularly tricky for the White House, where Mr. Clinton, Vice President Al Gore and Hillary Rodham Clinton all have different political imperatives.

INTERNATIONAL A3-8
 
Ending 'One China' Policy, Taiwan Angers Beijing
Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-hui, has abandoned the political formula that has long helped avert war with China, declaring that it would no longer adhere to the principle that the Chinese mainland and Taiwan are two parts of the same country. Beijing's response was furious. A1 

Protests Spread in Iran
The largest demonstrations since Iran's revolution two decades ago spread throughout the country as security police and their vigilante supporters moved to crush pro-democracy student demonstrators outside Teheran University. Students demonstrated in 18 cities and towns. A1
 
India Ends Fighting in Kashmir
India announced that it had suspended a six-week military campaign against Pakistan-based fighters who had occupied Himalayan peaks in Kashmir. It also said it would not fire on the fighters as long as they complete their withdrawal by Friday. A6
 
Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan said in a televised speech that he has helped usher the cause of Kashmir onto the world stage and prudently steered away from an all-out war, contrary to accusations by many that he has betrayed the dream of a liberated Kashmir. A6
 
Israel Alters Settlement Policy
Industry and Trade Minister Ran Cohen, a member of the leftist Meretz Party, announced that he had suspended financing for construction of new Israeli factories in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. This is the first concrete move by the Government of new Prime Minister Ehud Barak to reduce support for settlements approved by the administration of Benjamin Netanyahu. A3
 
Suspected Terrorists Arrested
Federal prosecutors said that the fingerprints of two Egyptian associates of Osama bin Laden have been found on statements taking responsibility for bomb attacks against two American embassies in Africa last August. The two men were arrested in London on Sunday and ordered held by a British magistrate. A6
 
British Attempt Ulster Solution
Britain proposed legislation that seeks to obtain Protestant support for a new Northern Ireland government by requiring the Irish Republican Army to follow an enforceable disarmament timetable. The issue of when and how the I.R.A. will disarm has been the main objection raised by Protestants to carrying out the Northern Ireland peace settlement, agreed to 14 months ago and put into effect haltingly since then. HEADLINE: Doomed Domes of the 'Old' Diamonds

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, July 12

 BODY:
Seattle is about to say hello to Safeco Field, a brick-facade palace with cedar-lined dugouts, an exquisite turf of Kentucky bluegrass and ryegrass, and a retractable steel-rail canopy to insure that the game will go on, under the sky or shielded from the rain. At $517 million, the ball park, which opens on Thursday, is the most expensive in Major League Baseball history.
But the big welcome to (mostly) outdoor baseball here heralds an inglorious farewell to the hulking concrete mushroom next door known as the Kingdome, where the Mariners played indoors, on artificial turf, for 22 1/2 seasons. The dome is scheduled to be imploded next year, to make way for an open-air football stadium. 
 And in Houston, baseball is ditching the Astrodome, hailed as the Eighth Wonder of the World when it opened in 1965. The building, the country's first air-conditioned stadium, is being abandoned by the Astros next spring for a new downtown ball park that, like Seattle's, has a retractable roof. With football's Oilers having left for Nashville, the Astrodome's future is uncertain. Its major tenants now include the two-and-a-half-week Houston Livestock and Rodeo Show, an offshore-oil technology conference and assorted auto shows known as "dirt events," like the demolition derby and "Monster Truck Madness."
These are dark days for many of America's domed stadiums, which were once called technological marvels but, after barely a generation, are increasingly considered obsolete and antiseptic by fans and owners.
In several cases, in places that might be described as climatically challenged, owners have been able to entice or strong-arm their cities into adopting the vastly more expensive outdoor stadiums with retractable roofs and bolstered by the go-go economy of the 90's. That is fueled by the have-it-all philosophy that puts games outside on sunny days but brings them inside when the weather turns foul. These splashy convertible models are already in use in Toronto and Phoenix, and Milwaukee will open one next year.
Many other cities have already chosen gleaming new outdoor ball parks that hark back, in design and ambience, to the era of such venerable stadiums as Fenway Park in Boston, where the All-Star Game will be played on Tuesday night but whose own future the city is passionately debating.
And with the Minnesota Twins lobbying strongly for an outdoor ball park to get themselves out of the Metrodome, it is very likely that just one Major League Baseball team will be left playing inside a fixed-roof dome within a few years.
Even that team, the Tampa Bay Devil Rays, seems to be doing everything it possibly can to distract fans from the fact that they are stuck indoors watching a ball game. The stadium's name, the Thunderdome, was changed to Tropicana Field. The huge Diamondvision screen broadcasts live shots at night games of the sun setting over the nearby Gulf Coast. Palm trees are placed throughout, and in a section of the upper deck known as the beach, fans can order tropical drinks at a tiki bar or listen to island music.
The scenario is somewhat less bleak for domes as venues for professional football. Seven of the National Football League's 31 teams play indoors.
But not a single one has won a Super Bowl, a fact that is a source of endless speculation for fans (some say it is injuries from the artificial turf; others contend that the domed teams collapse when they have to face a team outdoors in January's playoffs), and nearly all new and proposed football stadiums, like the one here in Seattle, are of the open-air, real-grass variety.
And, for baseball at least, the verdict is clearly already in.
"There simply aren't any domes out there for baseball that people are excited about," said Andrew Zimbalist, an economics professor at Smith College who has written several books about the sports industry. "For football, there are at least some fans who like the fact that they don't get snowed on or get cold, and they never have to worry about the football hitting the ceiling."
But for baseball games, domes just aren't a hit. Perhaps even more important, said Professor Zimbalist, is that owners so far have been able to persuade cities and states to foot a hefty part of the bill for the fancy retractable models.
"Just a few years ago," Professor Zimbalist said, "a stadium would cost maybe $125 million. Now they're spending that just on the roof."
It is possible, of course, that cities will soon shun the convertibles, not necessarily for reasons of esthetics, but of cost. Seattle's new baseball Xanadu is a cautionary example: it is already roughly $100 million over budget, and the Mariners and local leaders are engaged in a bitter battle over who will pay that, putting something of a damper on Thursday's big opening, at which the Mariners will play the San Diego Padres.
But fans seem excited, and the new parks do hold out a best-of-all-worlds scenario: most of the time, they promise outdoor baseball under blue or night skies, but if the rain or cold or heat or humidity or even the mosquitoes come, the roof can slide in over the assembled heads in a matter of minutes.
And even though the Kingdome is a fixture of the skyline, few people seem to lament its passing. This is partly because it was never considered an object of beauty. Bob Wood, author of "Dodger Dogs to Fenway Franks" (McGraw-Hill, 1988), a book about baseball stadiums, called it "a festering pimple on one of America's loveliest urban faces."
Nor was the Kingdome, once described by Sports Illustrated as having "all the ambience of a port-a-john," ever seen as a fun place to watch a ball game. And it had its share of misfortunes. Heavy acoustic tiles once fell from the ceiling, nearly striking Cal Ripken Jr. of the visiting Orioles, who holds the record for most consecutive games played.
In Houston, feelings about the Astrodome seem to be a bit more complicated. Its opening was an event noted around the world and hailed by city leaders as one of the great human achievements of all time.
"Sparkling like a rare jewel on a one-time Houston swamp, the Astrodome is the Taj Mahal of all stadia from Rome's Colosseum on down to this day," exulted the 262-page book that celebrated the Astrodome's 1965 opening. The opening-day program read: "The searing Texas sun will still beat down, the angry Gulf winds will still howl, and the tropical rains will still fall, but not on the spectators in the Astrodome. They will sit in almost regal splendor."
The problem these days, of course, is that few people consider the air-conditioned, carpeted ambience of a fixed-dome stadium to be splendid at all. They prefer to watch a game outdoors -- unless, of course, it is too hot, or too cold, or too wet, which is where the retractable roofs come in.
The Kingdome is one of five Major League ball parks closing this year, and it is by far the youngest. With the Astrodome, the others are Detroit's Tiger Stadium, which opened in 1912, County Stadium in Milwaukee (1953) and the former Candlestick Park in San Francisco (1960).
With Safeco's cost cresting above the half-billion mark (the Kingdome cost $67 million, far less even adjusting for inflation), it is not clear whether municipalities will continue to finance convertible stadiums.
Many cities are not clamoring for them to begin with because their climates do not create a need for them, others have resisted any calls for new stadiums as primarily a ploy by owners for yet more lucrative luxury boxes. In New York, nearly every indoor, outdoor and both-ways iteration of new ball parks for the Yankees and the Mets has been discussed, including the possibility of a $1 billion, retractable-roof stadium on Manhattan's West Side, but the issue is far from resolved.
The Minnesota Twins now want to move outdoors but, at least at one point, their domed home, known as the Metrodome, was seen as a big factor in the team's success. In the 1987 World Series, the team lost all three games on the road, outdoors, to the St. Louis Cardinals, but won all four games in the dome, with deafening support from the home crowd, to win the championship.
In the main, fans in Seattle seem excited about the concept of outdoor baseball on real grass, although one nagging issue has come up.
What will it mean for the team's star slugger, Ken Griffey Jr., who hit more home runs than anyone else in the Kingdome (198), including, fittingly, the last one, in the Mariners' last game there on June 27?
Mr. Griffey, widely seen as the current player with perhaps the best chance of breaking Hank Aaron's all-time homer record of 755, could do less well in an outdoor park with damp air and other weather factors. Also, the distance down the line to right field, which he favors, is 326 feet, 14 feet longer than at the Kingdome. On the other hand, the new fence is shorter in some places.
The Mariners actually conducted a series of wind-tunnel tests and other measurements to try to calculate the new stadium's impact on their star's homer production. "But I don't think anyone will definitely know until we get out here and play ball," said Rebecca Hale, a team spokeswoman.
"I can tell you this, though," she said today at the stadium. "We've got a nice breeze going on right now. And it's blowing out."

The changing faces of baseball stadiums.
 
Peanuts and Cracker Jack 1912-1964
Built around the World Wars, these antiques are great to look at and not so great to sit in anymore. Boston's Fenway Park, built in 1912, and Yankee Stadium, built in 1923, contain many memories and not enough bathrooms. And while the outfield walls of Wrigley Field, below (1914), are covered with ivy, those lovable losers, the Cubs, still play inside. (Associated Press)
 
No Sky and Fake Grass 1965 to 1982
The Houston Astrodome, built in 1965, where Mickey Mantle hit the first home run, was considered one of the great wonders of the world at the time, but now artificial surface is the bane of all baseball fans and players. Cookie-cutter stadiums were a politician's dream way to save money and house multiple sports, but fans eventually found them to be so similar as to be boring. Seen one, seen 'em all. (Associated Press)
 
The Revival Period 1992 to . . .
A backlash to the cookie cutters: architects and fans harked back to the days of Ebbets Field and the Polo Grounds. Baltimore's Camden Yards (above), opened in 1992, begins the ballpark renaissance that will continue with the opening of the ballparks of Detroit and Milwaukee in the next 12 months. (Associated Press)
 
High-Tech Playgrounds 1998 to . . .
Baseball fields that double as amusument parks and video-game rooms, where there's as much action on the concourse as there is on the field - all housed under retractable roofs. Virtual reality for the kids, luxury suites for the vice presidents, the Bankone Ballpark in Phoenix (below), even has a swimming pool, where home- run balls have actually landed. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Revive Marriage To End Poverty?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Heather Mac Donald's call to "revive marriage" to end poverty and protect poor children reverses cause and effect (letter, July 11). The "explosion of out-of-wedlock births" among black women closely parallels the decline in job opportunities for the black fathers of these children. 
 In New York, job losses took a high toll among young black men. Their rate of participation in the labor force fell by more than half between 1950 and 1980, and rose only slightly afterward. The thousands now in prison for drug dealing are exiles from a job market that largely excluded them and a school system that failed them.
William Julius Wilson's research in Chicago showed that black men born in the war years were two and a half times more likely to marry the mothers of their children than were those born a generation later. Behavior did not change, but the economy did.
 
SUMNER M. ROSEN
New York, July 11, 1999

HEADLINE: U.S. Lawsuit Faults Toyota On Pollution Warning Lights

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 12

 BODY:
The Federal Government sued Toyota today, accusing it of violating the Clean Air Act by selling 2.2 million automobiles on which the "check engine" light would not illuminate even when the vehicles were emitting excessive pollution.
The lawsuit, which theoretically could involve penalties of as much as $60 billion, came after Toyota rejected an offer to settle the case out of court. It is the latest in a series of similar disputes pitting the Government against auto makers and truck makers. In each case, the Government has contended that the vehicles' computer diagnostic equipment had been programmed to meet Federal standards during laboratory tests, but not during actual driving on the road. 
 What sets the Toyota case apart is the company's decision to fight the Government in court. In previous cases, involving General Motors in 1995, Honda a year ago and seven manufacturers of heavy-duty diesel engines last October, the manufacturers chose to pay fines and take remedial action before litigation began.
Toyota's stance in theory exposes it to large penalties. Christine Romano, a Justice Department spokeswoman, said that under the Clean Air Act, Toyota could face a fine of $25,000 to $27,500 for each of 2.2 million vehicles that allegedly failed to comply, depending on when each vehicle was sold.
But the maximum possible penalty, nearly $60 billion, is extremely unlikely. The law directs judges to consider a company's economic gain from pollution, its previous environmental record and its ability to stay in business if it pays the maximum fine. Toyota has a fairly good environmental record, its gains from the alleged pollution are unclear and the maximum fine would equal eight months of its global sales.
Previous settlements out of court have been much smaller. Honda, for example, settled a similar dispute a year ago involving 1.7 million Honda and Acura automobiles. To offset any emissions from vehicles with poorly functioning warning lights, Honda extended the warranty on all of these vehicles' emissions equipment to 14 years or 150,000 miles instead of 3 years or 36,000 miles, and offered free tuneups, at a cost estimated by Federal officials at $250 million.
Honda also paid $10.1 million in Federal fines and $2.5 million in fines to the state of California, which also accused the auto maker of violating state rules. And Honda agreed to pay for $1 million of Federal environmental research and $3.5 million of environmental research by California. Those $17.1 million in payments plus the warranty costs were considerably less than the company's likely liability in excess of $42.5 billion.
California also ordered Toyota last September to come up with a plan to fix 330,000 vehicles sold there that are among the 2.2 million vehicles involved in the Federal case. Toyota refused, and hearings began today before an administrative law judge in Sacramento.
In the Federal case, Toyota on Friday rejected a settlement offer that involved fines of more than $100 million.
The current dispute involves vehicles' so-called evaporative emissions of unburned gasoline, which contribute to smog. Toyota contends that state and Federal rules require vehicles' warning lights to meet tests only in laboratories. Tiny quantities of gasoline fumes constantly escape from a vehicle's gas cap and from joints in the gasoline tank and fuel lines. These losses are periodically monitored by vehicles in recent model years using systems that measure the pressure of the gasoline vapor in the system. A warning light is supposed to go on when the pressure falls while the ignition is on.
The rules do not give regulators the authority to conduct random checks, as they have done, on whether the vehicles actually perform in use the way they did in the laboratory, said Joseph Tetherow, a company spokesman.
The vehicles "only had to meet lab tests," Mr. Tetherow said.
When California first adopted rules in 1991 regarding the evaporative emissions and the activation of engine lights, Toyota developed a system and it passed the state's laboratory tests and was certified for use, Mr. Tetherow said, adding, "They said it was in compliance, they gave their approval before we went ahead and put it in our vehicles."
Jerry Martin, a spokesman for the California Air Resources Board, said that, "in-use compliance has always been a part of the board's program." Regardless of how the administrative law judge rules, the board can subsequently rule for or against the company, Mr. Martin said.
Environmental regulators contend that without reliable warning lights, consumers will not know when their vehicles start producing unacceptable levels of pollution.
Carol M. Browner, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said tonight, "Today's action shows this Administration's commitment to insure that companies will not profit from polluting and that the public health will be protected."
The Justice Department filed today's lawsuit on behalf of the Environmental Protection Agency.
The suit covers most of Toyota's vehicles from the 1996 through 1998 model years. Specifically, it covers Lexus cars as well as Toyota Camry, Avalon, Corolla, Tercel, and Paseo cars; Sienna minivans; 4Runner and RAV4 sport utility vehicles; and Tacoma and T100 pickup trucks.
Mr. Tetherow said that none of the vehicles involved posed any threat to the environment or public safety. If the warning lights on all of these vehicles failed, the combined annual evaporation of hydrocarbons from their fuel tanks and engines would be equal to the painting of two medium-sized houses, he said.
The Clean Air Act allows a maximum penalty of $25,000 per vehicle sold by Jan. 31, 1997, and $27,500 per vehicle sold after that. Toyota sold 588,650 vehicles in the 1996 model year with the contested emissions systems, 857,620 in the 1997 model year and 735,897 in the 1998 model year. But Ms. Romano said she did not have the precise number sold before the date when the peak penalty rose.

HEADLINE: $25 AND UNDER;
Vietnamese Cuisine With an Accent on Fresh and Lively

BYLINE: By Eric Asimov 

 BODY:
TEN years ago, New York had only a couple of Vietnamese restaurants in the Chinatown area and one or two other Manhattan outposts. But in the early 1990's, Vietnamese restaurants began to pop up all over, becoming novel pleasures and then neighborhood staples.
With popularity, though, came Chinese Restaurant Syndrome, in which takeout becomes so lucrative that a restaurant degenerates into an assembly-line delivery operation, forsaking freshness for economy and speed. Several Vietnamese restaurants fell victim to this, but they did not remain popular, and they closed. Unlike Chinese restaurants, which can apparently get away with using lots of oil and cooking everything to death, Vietnamese restaurants showcase light, fresh ingredients, with plenty of herbs, salads and raw vegetables. Forsake these, and the cuisine loses its reason for being. 
 Saigon Grill, which opened its first, very small restaurant several years ago on the Upper West Side, understands the need to safeguard the flavors. Even though it does a sizable takeout business, it has never sacrificed liveliness for speed. Now, with a new branch on the Upper East Side that opened a month ago, Saigon Grill is proving again to be a top-flight Vietnamese restaurant.
Though it's twice as big as the first place, Saigon Grill is still not much to look at -- simply a bright, plain dining room. The food is the thing. Chao tom ($3.95), for example, a common appetizer of grilled shrimp paste wrapped around a short stalk of sugar cane, is often bland and tasteless, more appealing in theory than in practice. But Saigon Grill's version is rich and shrimpy. To eat it, remove the thick paste from the cane, and then wrap the paste in a lettuce leaf with some mint and pickled carrot. Dip the whole thing in nuoc cham, the sweet-and-tangy condiment, and you have a wonderful dish.
Banh cuon ($4.95) is also a superb appetizer, a soft cylindrical rice crepe stuffed with chicken, mushrooms and carrots and served with the piquant nuoc cham. Goi cuon tom ($4.25), a shrimp summer roll, is soft and soothing, full of mint and basil and with a pronounced anise flavor. Goi du du ($4.95), green papaya salad, is spicy and well balanced, flavored with basil and pungent nuoc mam, or fermented fish sauce, and topped with thin strips of grilled beef and crushed peanuts. Goi tom nuong ($5.95) is a refreshing salad of greens, cabbage, carrots and cucumber topped with grilled shrimp.
Appetizers are so good that it is tempting to make a meal of them, especially in hot weather, but Saigon Grill offers some delicious main courses, among them noodle dishes like bun with chicken ($6.95), which is thin, cool rice noodles with salad, herbs and savory grilled chicken served satay-style on wooden skewers. It is sometimes difficult to remove the chicken from the skewers without sending it flying across the table or puncturing yourself. Goi banh cuon with beef ($6.95), thin, warm rice crepes topped with herbs and beef, also suffers from the skewer problem, but the combination, activated by a dose of nuoc cham, is worth the effort.
Xuong nuong ($7.95), very thin grilled pork chops, tastes pleasingly of lemongrass and lime, while tom kho to ($9.95) is worth trying for the combination of shrimp and bean-curd skin in a soupy brown sauce tasting of garlic and pepper. Occasionally, the food is underseasoned, like thit xao gung ($7.95), sauteed pork in a traditional honey-ginger sauce, which needed an extra jolt of fish sauce to bring out the flavors.
This is just a taste of the extensive menu, which also includes the soups that I like so much at the West Side branch. Saigon Grill doesn't yet have its liquor license, but it has something better: Vietnamese iced coffee ($2), made with sweetened condensed milk. It tastes like a coffee milkshake and is better than dessert.
 
Saigon Grill
1700 Second Avenue (88th Street), Yorkville; (212) 996-4600.

HEADLINE: Pay Off the Debt

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "The Trillion-Dollar Problem" (editorial, July 12): Every economic statistic brings home the fact that our economy is as close to full employment as it can hope to be without inflation. A contemplated tax cut of any magnitude would add significantly to purchasing power, thereby immediately stoking inflation. 
 The tax cut has been justified with the argument that the surplus represents excess money that belongs to the taxpayer. This ignores that from 1980 on, not enough taxes were collected.
We as a country have an obligation to pay back the debt then incurred. It also ignores that the present economy owes its stability to the ongoing reduction of the national debt, leaving more investment capital in private hands.
 
RICHARD HYSE
Oswego, N.Y., July 12, 1999
 
The writer is professor emeritus of economics, State University of New York at Oswego.

HEADLINE: U.S. Import Prices Declined 0.2% in June

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
Import prices fell in June after rising for three consecutive months as the cost of oil and other imports declined, the Labor Department reported today.
Import prices fell two-tenths of a percent last month after rising a revised eight-tenths of a percent in May. The May figure had initially been reported as a rise of seven-tenths of a percent. 
 Prices of major imports like oil and farm products have been weak the last couple of years as economic crises in Asia and Latin America have depressed worldwide demand.
That has helped keep inflation down in the United States. In the 12 months ended in May, the Consumer Price Index rose only 2.1 percent. The consumer price report for June is scheduled to be released at 8:30 A.M. on Thursday.
Petroleum import prices fell nine-tenths of a percent in June after a 7.8 percent rise in May that was revised from 8 percent. It was the first time since February that petroleum import prices fell. In the last three months, hefty gains were reported on petroleum import prices.
Excluding petroleum, import prices declined two-tenths of a percent in June after a two-tenths of a percent rise in May, which was revised from one-tenth of a percent. Import prices for all major categories fell in June.
The Labor Department said United States export prices were unchanged in June after a revised increase of one-tenth of a percent in May, which had previously been reported as flat.
Prices of agricultural exports fell two-tenths of a percent in June after gaining four-tenths of a percent in May, which had previously been reported as a rise of one-tenth of a percent. Nonagricultural export prices were down one-tenth of a percent after rising one-tenth of a percent in May.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japanese Regulators Consider Penalties for Credit Suisse

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 13

 BODY:
Japanese regulators met today to consider possible sanctions against Credit Suisse Group for obstructing a six-month investigation into its financial activities in Japan.
Credit Suisse, based in Switzerland and one of the world's biggest investment banks, could lose at least one of its licenses to do business in Japan, according to a Government official, and it might face criminal prosecution as well. 
 If the Japanese authorities were to revoke the license of Credit Suisse's Financial Products, which handles the firm's derivatives products business, it would cut off a large source of profit. Such a punishment also would turn into a huge embarrassment for Credit Suisse, which has acknowledged some problems in its derivatives business in Japan but says it has taken action to correct them.
The regulators who met today are officials of the Financial Supervisory Agency, Japan's financial watchdog. The agency also handed over the findings of its investigation to Credit Suisse's Tokyo office today. Results of the investigation were not immediately released.
"We are working to try to persuade the F.S.A. to levy fair penalties on Credit Suisse Group in Japan in light of our acknowledged shortcomings," said Robert Baker, a Credit Suisse spokesman in London."This should be balanced by the clear legality of our past transaction activity and by our discovery, reporting and prompt disciplinary action in relation to the conduct of a small number of our employees in Tokyo."
The investigation of Credit Suisse has received close scrutiny from foreign investment banks here as an indicator of how Japan will deal with them as it cleans up the country's debt-ridden banking system and eases financial market regulations.
The firm engaged in so-called window dressing, using a variety of financial trading tools to help Japanese banks and companies obscure their losses. Oddly, Credit Suisse is not likely to be punished heavily for that activity. Indeed, the legality of that business does not seem to be in question, although the Financial Supervisory Agency has begun investigating similar operations of Lehman Brothers here.
What outraged the regulators were efforts by Michael Winning, the executive in charge of handling legal matters at Credit Suisse in Tokyo, and other executives based here to hide the firm's activities by shredding some documents and shipping others out of the country.
Those activities, which Credit Suisse has acknowledged, give officials here grounds to refer the case to the public prosecutor's office for a criminal trial, which could result in financial penalties and even jail terms.
The case has been compared to the scandal that hurt Daiwa Bank in the United States several years ago when it tried to cover up more than $1 billion in trading losses at its New York branch. After United States regulators began their investigation at Daiwa, a Daiwa employee broke the seal on a box of evidence, which, among other things, led to a record fine of $340 million when Daiwa pleaded guilty in 1996.
In Tokyo, Credit Suisse suspended Mr. Winning and others who participated in the attempted cover-up and withheld the bonuses of other employees. But it has contended that its employees were engaged in an effort to hide evidence of violations of the "fire wall" -- the strict regulatory barrier aimed at keeping its banking operations separate from its securities operations -- not to thwart the agency's investigators and cover up evidence related to window dressing.
The authorities here began to scrutinize Credit Suisse's window dressing when Long-Term Credit Bank of Japan and Nippon Credit Bank were nationalized by the Government last year. Both banks were Credit Suisse clients, and their employees helped investigators understand how the banks had hidden their losses using Credit Suisse products and services.

HEADLINE: Palestinians Move to Avoid Friction With Israel at U.N.

BYLINE: By WILLIAM A. ORME Jr. 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, July 13

 BODY:
In an effort to avert friction with Israel's new Government, Palestinian leaders will seek the speedy adjournment of a United Nations meeting that was to have considered possible sanctions against Israel for human rights violations and settlement activity in Gaza and the West Bank.
The meeting, in Geneva on Thursday, should end after just "an hour or two" of formal remarks and resolutions to hold a future conference on the issue, a senior Palestinian official said today. The conference had been intended as an open-ended examination of Israeli control of the West Bank and Gaza, sponsored by the General Assembly and led by Switzerland, in its role as custodian of the Geneva Convention. 
 "This is a compromise," said Nabil Shaath, the Palestinian Authority's minister for planning and international cooperation, in a telephone interview from Geneva. "The idea is to make the message clear, but not confrontational."
In public statements and in meetings with Western diplomats here, the newly appointed Foreign Minister, David Levy, has said the conference could be a divisive distraction from the planned resumption of peace talks. Though Palestinian officials say Prime Minister Ehud Barak did not raise the conference in his 75-minute meeting Sunday with the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, Mr. Barak stressed the importance of beginning comprehensive negotiations in an atmosphere of mutual trust, without recriminations.
"We are really giving Barak an opportunity to set up his program of action," Mr. Shaath said.
But Israeli diplomats criticized the Palestinian plan to reconvene the conference in November, or next January. "We see this entire exercise as an attempt to single out Israel, and we firmly reject it," Dore Gold, Israel's representative at the United Nations, said today in a telephone interview from New York.
American and Israeli diplomats are urging European members of a steering commission for the gathering to oppose setting a new date for the conference, which could in theory attempt to impose economic sanctions or other penalties on Israel. The threat of such a conference would be "a sword of Damocles hanging over the peace process," said one Israeli official.
In February, the United Nations General Assembly almost unanimously adopted a resolution calling for a conference of all Geneva Convention signers on July 15 to examine violations of the convention by Israel in the occupied territories of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. Israel and the United States cast the only dissenting votes.
Since then Israeli diplomats have tried without success to scuttle the conference, contending that there is no precedent for a new Geneva Conference focusing on a single regional conflict.
"The signatories of the Convention have never been convened for any purpose since 1949 -- not when the Soviets invaded Czechoslovakia or Afghanistan, or when the Iraqis invaded Kuwait," Mr. Gold said. Israeli diplomats say they have sought to persuade other United Nations members with histories of border wars that there could be similar intervention in their own territorial disputes.
The Geneva meeting is being boycotted by the United States, as well as by Israel, which says that Australia and several other United Nations members have also decided to avoid the session.
Palestinian officials who originally pushed for the conference acknowledged that their motivation was to bypass the standard diplomatic mechanisms of the United Nations, where anti-Israel resolutions are passed overwhelmingly by the General Assembly only to be quashed by American vetoes in the Security Council.
Mr. Shaath, one of the architects of the conference, suggested a few months ago that the tenets of the original convention would permit imposing penalties against Israel for its treatment of the occupied territories.
Today, he struck a more conciliatory note, while emphasizing the continuing Palestinian concern about Israeli settlers and a commitment to an eventual meeting on the issue.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow Falls, Led by Banks, on Fears About Latin Markets

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday, led by big banks, including J. P. Morgan & Company and Citigroup Inc., on concern that volatile Latin American financial markets could hurt profits for companies that do business in the region.
But stocks pared losses in late trading on optimism for corporate earnings reports as worries about Latin America waned, investors said. 
 "The reality is we're getting a spate of earnings reports this week and next, and we think those will be at or above expectations," said Robert Christian, chief investment officer for Wilmington Trust, which oversees $25 billion in Wilmington, Del.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 25.96 points, to 11,175.02, slicing a 116-point decline as Latin American financial markets rebounded and the Procter & Gamble Company gained after announcing a dividend increase.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 5.54 points, to 1,393.56, and the Nasdaq composite index declined 12.21 points, to 2,778.23.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 1/32, to 90 29/32. The bond's yield was unchanged at 5.90 percent.
Stocks may fall today in response to a report from Intel that second-quarter profit was lower than expected at 51 cents a share, compared with the latest analysts' estimate of 57 cents. Shares of Intel traded at 65 1/8 after the announcement; they had closed earlier with a loss of 1/16 at 65 3/8.
Traders sold Argentine bonds Monday and in early trading yesterday after the ruling party's presidential candidate said he might seek to renegotiate the Government's $130 billion of debt. Latin American markets recovered as Wall Street firms reassured clients that Argentina would weather the crisis. The candidate, Eduardo Duhalde, backtracked this afternoon and said he would not seek debt relief.
Banks that do business in Latin America or trade stocks and bonds from the region declined. J. P. Morgan fell 2 5/16, to 138 1/4, contributing 12 points to the Dow average's loss. While Latin America accounts for only 4 percent of J. P. Morgan's assets, the region contributed 17 percent of the bank's $963 million of earnings last year.
Citigroup lost 1 1/16, to 47 11/16, and the Chase Manhattan Corporation fell 1 1/2, to 82 5/8.
Procter & Gamble gained 1 15/16, to 88 15/16, after the company, a maker of household products, said it would raise its dividend 12 percent as cost-cutting bolsters company profits.
Merrill Lynch & Company rose 1 3/8, to 79 1/4, after the brokerage firm said second-quarter profit grew 23 percent. The firm earned $1.57 a share in the quarter, above the $1.46 average forecast by analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation and the $1.31 a share it earned in the quarter a year earlier.
Some investors were not willing to make big bets on stocks until they see the Producer Price Index and retail sales reports due today, and the Consumer Price Index report due tomorrow. Those reports will provide clues to whether the Federal Reserve will have to raise interest rates again this year to head off inflation and keep the economy growing.

HEADLINE: Would Tax Cuts Prove Too Stimulating?

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
For all the recent talk of cutting taxes, Congress rarely cuts them when the economy is growing robustly, as it is today, and unemployment is low. The worry among economists is that the extra money in people's pockets may make an already strong economy too strong, finally stoking inflation after a long period of relatively stable prices.
Yet that danger is hardly mentioned in the rising public debate over the Republican and Democratic proposals for tax cuts. 
 Why not? In part, it is because the advocates of the tax cuts, as well as many of the opponents, agree that any reductions will probably be small, at least in the initial years. And few analysts expect any final tax cut to come close to the $864 billion over the next decade that has been proposed by House Republicans.
"Most of the tax cut proposals are phased in gradually over a number of years," said Senator Connie Mack, Republican of Florida, the chairman of Congress's Joint Economic Committee and the author of a proposal to cut taxes by $137 billion over 10 years, most of it toward the end of the period. "I think the immediate economic stimulus will be small," he said.
The Federal Reserve, however, is concerned. "If taxes were cut while the nation's resources are highly employed, that would put more pressure on monetary policy," Edward M. Gramlich, a Fed governor, said. He suggested, in effect, that the Fed might have to raise interest rates to prevent the extra spending that would overstimulate the economy. Others worry that the higher rates might reduce investment or bring down inflated stock prices, damaging the economy through these avenues.
Stock prices should already be reacting to the prospect of a tax cut, some people say, but they have not so far because too many people on Wall Street express doubt that tax cut legislation will be enacted before next year's election -- or soon afterward, for that matter.
"A bunch of friends on Wall Street have asked me why the markets are so quiet about the tax cut proposals," said James E. Glassman, a senior economist at Chase Manhattan Bank. "Wall Street is unusually quiet because it realizes that there will just be gridlock on this issue near term -- a lot of proposals and no real action."
Still, Mr. Gramlich's concern reflects a view widely shared among economists -- that broad tax cuts tend to stimulate spending and therefore should be reserved for recessions or periods of slow growth. In the early 1960's, President John F. Kennedy proposed a tax cut in this spirit, and President Ronald Reagan's tax cuts, which started during a recession, contributed to the long expansion in the 1980's.
By contrast, President Lyndon B. Johnson's 10 percent income tax cut, carrying through on the original Kennedy proposal, came when the economy had turned from the weak Kennedy years to the much more robust mid-1960's. The Fed responded by raising rates.
And the altered mix was damaging, says Alan S. Blinder, a Princeton University economist who served as Fed vice chairman from 1994 to 1996. The new mix -- higher interest rates to offset more fiscal stimulus from the tax cut and from stepped-up spending for the Vietnam War and for the Johnson social programs -- shifted the economy toward consumption and away from investment. Inflation also got a foothold.
Some economists contend that fiscal policy has lost its punch since the 1960's while monetary policy has evolved to the point that the Fed can regulate the economy through interest rate adjustments, offsetting tax cuts without damage.
"Monetary policy administered by the Fed is far more important as far as economic stabilization is concerned and regulating aggregate demand," said James Gwertney, the Republican-appointed chief economist of the Joint Economic panel.
Mr. Blinder disagrees. Monetary policy has its limits, he said. A tax cut offset by higher interest rates today "would reverse the policy mix that we have followed in the 1990's with such splendid effect: low interest rates and high corporate investment," Mr. Blinder said.
Henry Kaufman, a Wall Street economist and consultant, adds a related reason for not using the budget surplus to finance tax cuts, as both parties now propose. "With the surplus, we could have some timely fiscal action when the economy goes inevitably into recession," he said. "We would not for once have to worry about deficit financing."
Clinton Administration officials say that their more modest tax cut proposal gets around the problem of encouraging too much consumption. By offering incentives, particularly to the poor, to invest the tax cuts in retirement accounts, they say, private savings will rise, and the savings will then be available for corporations to borrow and invest in productive equipment.
But many economists say that such tax rebates would not go dollar for dollar into retirement accounts. Upper-income people in particular have the wherewithal to shift savings from one account to another to qualify for a tax refund, which would then be spent on consumer goods, according to this view. That has been the experience with individual retirement accounts.
This is not the supply-side view. For supply-siders, tax cuts -- particularly a Republican proposal to reduce the capital gains tax on the profit made from the sale of stocks and other assets -- encourage investment by reducing its risk. While supply-siders are a distinct minority among economists, they are a vocal one in the incipient debate about a tax cut's effect on the economy.
In their view, suppliers, not consumers, are the chief economic actors. And suppliers respond to tax cuts by investing their capital in new supply. Far from stimulating demand beyond an economy's capacity, the supply-siders say, a tax cut increases the supply of goods and services, which are then consumed.
No one pushes this view harder than Jude Wanniski, an economics consultant and adviser to Steve Forbes and various other Republicans involved in tax-cutting proposals. "The Government, by cutting tax rates, is simply removing the barrier to investment," he said.

HEADLINE: 'What Is China?' Taiwan's New Answer Is Puzzling

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: BEIJING, July 13

 BODY:
What in the world is Taiwan's President up to?
It's a question that puzzled countless Government officials, scholars and common people in China and Taiwan today, many of them surprised by the news that the President, Lee Teng-hui, had suddenly changed the island's official stance toward China by dropping his Nationalist Government's long-standing premise that Taiwan and the mainland are parts of the same country. 
 Danger was the first word in many minds, because tampering with Taiwan's political status is akin to tweaking a hornet's nest, easily provoking military action from Beijing, where eventual reunification with Taiwan is considered a patriotic imperative.
Taiwan and China have acted independently of each other for the 50 years since Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalist forces retreated to the island, defeated by the Communists in a civil war.
But any hint that Taiwan is moving toward a formal declaration of independence rings loud alarm bells in Beijing. Mr. Lee's shift inevitably complicates relations between Beijing and Washington, which itself continues to abide by the one-China formula, and local politics in Taiwan, where a presidential campaign is getting under way.
Yet Mr. Lee seems to be looking farther afield.
Expected to step down next spring after 12 years in office, a time of remarkable transition in Taiwan from an authoritarian state to an economically lively democracy, Mr. Lee appears to want to cement his legacy as the father of a modern Taiwan separate from mainland China.
Politicians and scholars who have followed the career of Mr. Lee, Taiwan's first native-born President, say he is driven by a overwhelming sense of mission.
"Lee Teng-hui in his heart is a romantic," said Fung Hu-hsiang, a Taiwan legislator who opposes Mr. Lee's moves away from China. "In his later years, his sense of mission is pushing him to clarify Taiwan's role with the mainland."
Yet Mr. Fung, a political opponent of Mr. Lee who believes the policy shift is potentially disasterous, cited another possibility echoed by several political analysts: Mr. Lee may want to create a crisis to justify a postponement of next year's election so that he can remain in office.
In March 1996, China launched several missiles into the ocean near Taiwan in what was officially described as a military exercise but was clearly intended to intimidate voters who were about to cast votes in Taiwan's first free presidential election.
But instead of being intimidated, anxious voters rallied around Mr. Lee, giving him an overwhelming victory. It was a risky strategy, but Mr. Lee apparently reasoned that the chances of a military invasion by China were slight, and he was proved right.
"If it's like 1996 again, and missiles are raining down, he could try to justify staying on," said Chang Ling-chen, a political science professor at National Taiwan University. "If China is smart, they won't respond so strongly this time."
Mr. Lee's new move came on Saturday when he said in a German radio interview that China and Taiwan should deal with each other on a "state to state" basis, implying that they are two separate countries. On Monday, a Government spokesman, clarifying Mr. Lee's remarks, went a step further and dropped the "one China" idea that has guided China-Taiwan ties, effectively giving up the notion of eventual reunification.
It all complicates Taiwan presidential politics, perhaps most notably for James Soong, the popular former official from Mr. Lee's Nationalist Party, who is expected to run as an independent. Mr. Soong's position on relations with Beijing is less than clear, and a new focus on the issue could damage him.
But of paramount concern to outsiders is the reaction from Beijing, whose long-held official position is that reunification of the motherland is a historical necessity and that it will use military force to achieve it if negotiations fail. Short of military action, China could apply economic pressure on Taiwan.
Today China's state-run media issued some of the vitriol that has come to be expected on this issue from the Communist authorities, who called Mr. Lee's move "a monumental disaster."
Yet Beijing's public response was not as harsh as could have been. Zhang Qiyue, a Foreign Ministry spokeswoman, sidestepped several questions about Taiwan, suggesting that China's leadership is mulling a course of action, which could take some time.
"They're probably trying to figure out what Lee is doing, and why he is doing it now," said an international relations scholar in Beijing, who felt the topic too sensitive to be quoted by name. "They may think the U.S. is behind him, telling him what to do."
In fact, American diplomats here seemed as surprised as anyone by Mr. Lee's move, which counters Washington's efforts to push Taiwan and China into meaningful discussions.
A critical meeting is scheduled for October in Taiwan with China's top Taiwan negotiator, Wang Daohan, who would be the most senior official from Beijing to visit since the civil war ended in 1949. Whether that meeting will be held is now in doubt.

HEADLINE: Whirlpool Posts Earnings Rise

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: BENTON HARBOR, Mich., July 13

 BODY:
The Whirlpool Corporation, the largest United States maker of appliances, said today that its second-quarter profit rose a more-than-expected 23 percent on higher sales in North America.
Net income at the company, which makes Kenmore, Kitchenaid and Whirlpool products, rose to $99 million, or $1.30 a share, compared with profit from operations of $81 million, or $1.05 a share, a year earlier. Whirlpool had been expected to earn $1.24, the average estimate of nine analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation. 
 Rising demand in North America, where Whirlpool gets almost three-fourths of its profit, offset the impact of recession in Brazil, Latin America's largest economy. The company said it expected to continue its strong performance in the second half.
"Low interest rates, high housing activity and strong consumer confidence are boosting appliance sales in the United States," said Efraim Levy, an analyst at Standard & Poor's, who rates the shares as "accumulate."
Sales rose 1.2 percent, to $2.62 billion from $2.59 billion.
Whirlpool announced the results after United States stock markets had closed. Its shares fell $1.4375, to $70.8125.
