HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
ArgentinaRattles a Bit, and Latin Investors Shake

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Worries about Latin America have spooked investors again. And when worried, they jump for the relative safety of the American bond market.
The result has been a nice rally in bonds, despite the looming possibility of another interest rate increase by Federal Reserve policy makers in August. 
 The latest market tremors come from Argentina, now facing a tough recession, a growing budget deficit and a presidential election in October. All that adds up to building uncertainty about the country's economic restructuring -- something not helped by a presidential candidate's comment last weekend that he would ask the Pope to support debt relief.
On Monday, the prices of Argentine bonds fell sharply, pushing interest rates higher, and the country's main stock index dropped 8.7 percent. The selloff spread quickly to markets in Brazil, Mexico and the rest of Latin America.
Yesterday, Argentina had a small rebound and the demand for United States Treasury securities eased. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond, which dropped to 5.90 percent on Monday from 6.00 percent on Friday, was unchanged. Several emerging-market analysts said that the Latin American selloff had been overdone and that fears of an Argentine bond default or currency devaluation were overblown.
But even if the markets went too far, the outlook for Latin markets for the next several months is no longer rosy.
Some analysts expect continued pressure on Argentina's markets. And such concerns could spill over to the rest of the region, especially if the Fed decides to raise rates further next month. Higher United States rates would make it harder for Latin nations to attract foreign capital.
"What worries me is all the noise you can have between here and the election," Jose Luis Daza, managing director of emerging markets at J. P. Morgan Securities, said.
Joaquin Cottani, chief economist for Latin America at Lehman Brothers, said that Argentina would continue to be a "target of instability."
"The only thing that the Government will be able to do," he said, "is try to convince investors that this has been an overreaction, that things are likely to improve." Still, he noted, "Nobody expects, even in the Government, that the situation will be too good for the rest of the year."
Concerns about Argentina's economic future cannot be cleared up easily. The election will produce a new administration, with unknown policies, and until then the candidates may try to attract domestic votes with comments that unsettle international investors.
The selloff on Monday was a case in point. Gov. Eduardo Duhalde of Buenos Aires, a presidential candidate, said he wanted to ask Pope John Paul II to support a debt moratorium for Argentina and other struggling countries.
For the market, that was not a good move. Investors grow uneasy over suggestions that a country may not keep paying its debt, even though a candidate's priorities may shift when elected. Venezuela's new President, Hugo Chavez, spoke of restructuring that nation's debt during his campaign, but since taking office has tried to reassure investors.
In Argentina, until the election is resolved, there is little the outgoing Government of Carlos Saul Menem can do to rebuild investor confidence.
Argentina is expected to be able to meet its borrowing needs for the rest of the year, which diminishes any immediate threat of default. But there is a much greater likelihood of corporate defaults, Mr. Cottani said.
Also by the first quarter of next year, the outlook on a Government default could be more uncertain. And it will fall to a new administration to determine how large the financing gap will be and how to bridge it. "We will have time to see whether the risks remain entering the first quarter of next year," Mr. Cottani said.
Mr. Daza said that Latin American interest rates do not indicate investor fears about an Argentine debt default. Short-term rates would be higher than longer-term rates if the markets were worried, he said.
But the widening spreads between the rates on Latin debt and those for comparable United States Treasury debt show that many investors are indeed concerned about their ability to sell Latin bonds quickly, and without big losses, if the Argentine situation -- or the overall outlook -- takes a sudden turn for the worse.
According to J. P. Morgan, the spread for Argentina shrank yesterday by 35 basis points -- or hundredths of a percentage point -- after widening 98 points Monday, to 9.72 percent. At the same time, the spread between Brazil's debt and comparable American bonds narrowed by just 1 basis point after widening by 70 points Monday. And the spread with Mexico grew by 10 basis points after widening by 56 points Monday.
Thus, the markets seem to have overreacted Monday to Argentina's situation. But its problems continue to concern investors about countries that have been considered safer bets.
On the plus side, the market climate for Latin America is much better than last summer and fall, when first Russia defaulted on its debt and devalued its currency and then Long Term Capital Management, the giant hedge fund, teetered near collapse.
But, as Mr. Daza said, the Argentine Government and the nation's presidential candidates "need to work more to calm the markets."
Given the sensitivity of investors, that is no small task. "The guy who got mauled last year is saying 'I have to lighten up,' " Barbara Kenworthy, portfolio manager at Prudential Mutual Funds, said. "People are antsy."

HEADLINE: Merrill Posts 23% Increase In Earnings

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
Merrill Lynch & Company, the nation's largest brokerage firm, posted robust second quarter earnings yesterday, even as the financial powerhouse struggles with infighting and tension in its upper ranks. 
 Buoyed by a stock market that continued to produce gravity-defying gains last quarter, Merrill reported earnings of $673 million, or $1.57 a share, up 23 percent from the $549 million, or $1.31 a share, it earned in the corresponding period last year.
Merrill's earnings easily topped analysts' expectations of $1.46 a share, according to consensus estimates compiled by the First Call Corporation. In trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, shares of Merrill rose $1.375, or about 1.8 percent, to $79.25.
But Merrill's shares still trade well below their 52-week high of $109.125, and should the stock market slow or the economy enter a recession, Merrill's earnings could suffer. Indeed, Merrill may be vulnerable to a takeover later this year or next if its stock price weakens or if it is unable to successfully execute its plans to bolster its sales presence on the Internet.
"I think Merrill is very well positioned for the global trends driving the industry today -- investment banking trends in Europe, strong trends in the U.S. that continue and Asia's longer-term prospects," said Richard Strauss, a securities industry analyst with Goldman, Sachs & Company. "But investors are also going to be keeping a close eye on its Internet strategy, and in the near term I think that expectation is just as important."
The sharp reversal in Merrill's fortunes in the last year has produced a startling shift in how the once seemingly impregnable firm is perceived by many of its competitors and Wall Street. The firm's finances were hammered by last year's economic chaos overseas, and it was slower than firms like the Charles Schwab Corporation to embrace the enthusiasm for trading that is sweeping the Internet.
On Monday, Merrill announced that Herbert M. Allison Jr., its president, resigned after being told he would not run the firm one day. Mr. Allison, a cool, detached figure who seemed oddly out of sync in Merrill's gregarious, hard-driving culture, had been at odds with Merrill's chief executive, David H. Komansky, for some time. Differences within the firm about how to respond to the growth of the Internet also added to managerial tensions.
While the stock market seemed to react mildly to Mr. Allison's departure, there is still concern about the lack of a clear successor to Mr. Komansky and how quickly the company will put its house in order.
"There's a sense around the Street that Merrill is adrift," said a senior executive at a rival firm. "I still marvel at where this company was two years ago and where they are today."
Merrill counters that it is focused on achieving its financial goals and has managers in place who are up to the task of running the firm in an era of brutal competition and rapid change in the financial services industry.
"We're very fortunate to have many talented executives in senior management and great bench strength," said Paul W. Critchlow, a Merrill spokesman.
Nonetheless, some analysts yesterday questioned how deep Merrill's managerial bench truly is. Leading candidates to succeed Mr. Komansky include John L. Steffens, a vice chairman who heads on-line efforts and supervises the firm's army of retail brokers, and Jeffrey M. Peek, who oversees asset management. Beyond that, some say, the candidates are slim.
Although attention has focused on Mr. Allison's shortcomings since his resignation was announced, Mr. Komansky has presided over a string of high-profile blunders or miscues in recent years. Those include the aggressive marketing of complex financial products known as derivatives to Orange County, Calif., which helped send the county into bankruptcy; a big expansion into emerging markets, which created financial headaches last year, and an unusually deep involvement in the near collapse of the Long-Term Capital Management hedge fund.
Although Merrill also has had difficulties with its $5 billion acquisition of the British firm, Mercury Asset Management, which it acquired last year, Merrill said Mercury's funds were performing better and that it was "absolutely happy" with its returns on that investment.
Merrill's earnings announcement yesterday disclosed smart gains in its overall asset-management business. Revenue from the business was up a record 7 percent from last year, to $1.16 billion, while total assets under management grew 5 percent, to $516 billion.
Analysts were generally pleased with the results from asset management and other key units as well.
"Trading was a bit lighter than I expected and investment banking a bit better," said Joan S. Solotar, an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "Over all, it was a solid quarter."
In the period, Merrill's net revenue, which includes interest income less interest expense, rose 12 percent, to a record $5.4 billion. Commissions rose 8.8 percent, to $1.59 billion, and trading revenue jumped 7.6 percent, to $1.06 billion.
Investment banking revenue totaled $908 million in the second quarter, up 1.1 percent from last year's booming quarter. Merrill said equity underwriting revenue was sharply higher from that of last year's second quarter, and nearly double the levels recorded in the first quarter of 1999. But underwriting fees in most debt categories declined in the second quarter, reflecting concerns about interest rates, the firm said.
Analysts said they expected Merrill to post solid results for the third quarter. But uncertainty about the firm will probably emerge starting in December, when Merrill is scheduled to introduce new Internet-related products and trading accounts.
"People are worried about the fourth quarter, when on-line trading and the retail products that come along with it will be rolled out," said Sallie Krawcheck, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company.
Other analysts shared Ms. Krawcheck's interest in how Merrill's Internet strategy will be deployed.
"There is an inherent conflict with their brokers, which may be compounded by the fact that Launny Steffens will be running both the retail and Internet sides of the business," Ms. Solotar said. "I am hopeful management realizes it needs a cohesive Internet strategy and has a window of five months to put it together."

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
A Refurbished Tower Keeps Its Feel

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
Yes, the Noguchi sculptures are still in place on the first floor of the building at 666 Fifth Avenue and they are actually much easier to see because of the renovations, despite the fears of preservationists. The fears were expressed at the beginning of the just-completed $20 million upgrading of the building, between 52d and 53d Streets, which included converting the T-shaped pedestrian arcade and lobby, with their Noguchi sculptures, into a unified enclosed space slathered in marble.
For the first time, Isamu Noguchi's "waterfall" fountain, a 40-foot-wide combination of corrugated glass, undulating stainless-steel fins and trickling water, is now visible from Fifth Avenue because of the elimination of a retail space long used by Alitalia as a ticket office. 
 Officials of Sumitomo Realty and Development, a subsidiary of Sumitomo, the Japanese company, said the renovation was designed to bring the entrance of the building out to Fifth Avenue and make more productive use of the retail spaces, which had been chopped into small stores and recessed behind building columns.
The Noguchi fountain was never in danger, said Arthur L. Bocchi, a senior managing director of Sumitomo, but another Noguchi work, the "landscape of the clouds" ceiling over the elevator banks, came in for a hard look.
"When you do a renovation, you look at everything, and many tenants were not happy with that ceiling," he said. He said some parts of the elevator lobby were blasted with harsh light, while others were eerily dark.
But as Sumitomo officials investigated, they found that the problems had less to with Noguchi, a noted sculptor who died in 1988, than with the difficulties in maintaining the work in an operating office building.
"It is a maintenance nightmare," said Tatsuru Kono, the president of Sumitomo (NY). "The reason for the glare was that the light bulbs and lenses had been changed over the years. So we went back to the original and tried to get as close to the artist's original intent as possible."
In all, Sumitomo officials said they spent $1.3 million to restore and preserve the Noguchi artworks. The architect for the project was Nobutaka Ashihara, a friend and student of Noguchi's.
When the building opened in 1957 as the Tishman Building -- the current owner more often refers to it by its street address -- the first floor consisted of a mix of stores and open walkways facing Fifth Avenue and the side streets, with the entrance to the offices toward the back of the building.
"The walkways were dark and uninviting spaces," Mr. Bocchi said. "What we had was a midblock lobby for a Fifth Avenue building."
Because of the unusual layout, he said, the building could not command the rent premiums that its prime location would otherwise command. "The building has always done well even in bad economic times," Mr. Bocchi said, "but other buildings have gotten higher rents than ours, even though their location and services are not as good."
The renovation has eliminated the Alitalia ground-floor office, although the airline remains a tenant, and the open walkways. The lobby entrance has been extended to Fifth Avenue, with the fountain visible to visitors as they enter the front door.
The retail space has been extended to the avenue as well, with part of the second floor being removed to accommodate two-story glass windows to display the wares of the two big tenants, the first National Basketball Association store on the south side and Brooks Brothers on the north.
"The building had simply not taken advantage of its retail potential on Fifth Avenue," Mr. Bocchi said. This is not a small point in a part of town where annual retail rents can surpass $500 a square foot.
The two big stores have replaced a jumble of retail spaces that included a bookstore, a jeweler, a clothing store and some snack shops.
The open-air passage from 52d to 53d Street has been enclosed, with revolving doors providing admission to the space. Mr. Kono said it was important to be able to heat and air-condition the lobby of a first-class office building, something that was impossible with the open passages.
(Though some groups have lamented the loss of the passages for midblock transit between the side streets, many people appear to be walking through the enclosed building as they did in the past.)
A subway entrance once reached from the passage has been reoriented and now faces 53d Street. Mr. Kono said transit officials favored the new entrance for security reasons because it has fewer blind turns.
To keep the presentation of the building pristine, Sumitomo officials said they resisted the temptation to put a newsstand or snack bar in the new lobby. But they said one might be installed in the below-ground retail space leading to the subway station; the space already contains a shoe store, a photo shop and a shoe repair store.
On the 40th floor of the building, where the "Top of the Sixes" restaurant was once situated, is now the Grand Havana Room, a cigar bar that also serves lunch and dinner six days a week.
Sumitomo (NY) has owned the building at 666 Fifth Avenue since 1987. Officials said the recent renovation was the first major refit of the building since it opened.

HEADLINE: CONCRETE CHOICES: A special report.;
Freeways, Their Costs and 2 Cities' Destinies

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: SALT LAKE CITY

 BODY:
Even a thousand feet above the valley, from the peak where Brigham Young mapped out his Mormon empire in 1847, one of the largest public works projects in the nation dominates the briny expanse of the Great Basin. Two thousand workers are pouring concrete around the clock, turning 6 lanes of Interstate 15 into 12 lanes through Salt Lake City and its loping suburbs.
And no sooner will the $1.6 billion expansion be completed in two years, state officials say, than they will need a new, parallel highway to keep traffic moving along the 100 miles of the Wasatch mountain front, where most of Utah's 2.1 million people live. 
 The Salt Lake metropolitan area is growing by 1,000 acres a month, much of it to the alarm of Utah's political and business leaders. But almost by default, in a blitz of highway construction, the state's leaders are encouraging the very thing they say they do not want: the instant towns of one-acre housing lots and no sidewalks, the car-dependent office parks and big box stores in a sea of pavement, the brown air that obscures the mountains.
More than a thousand miles away, in Milwaukee, a city that expanded along the lines of its highways a generation ago, sledge-hammers of regret will soon begin swinging. The city plans to use more than $20 million in Federal transportation money to tear down a half-built section of highway that was supposed to cut right through old Milwaukee. It will be the nation's largest highway deconstruction project.
"The urban superhighway should be relegated to the scrap heap of history," said John O. Norquist, Milwaukee's three-term Mayor, who toured the country recently to make his case that cities should be removing highways, not building new ones.
There is no greater form of subsidized social engineering than the interstate highway, Mayor Norquist says, which hastens flight out of the city without doing much to ease traffic congestion.
Salt Lake City and Milwaukee, two cities with roughly equal metropolitan populations (about 1.5 million), each having declared war on sprawl, are examples of how Federal transportation subsidies are still one of the biggest forces shaping urban areas.
For all the debate over the quality of life in America's gangly new suburbs, and the effort by such politicians as Vice President Al Gore and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey to make it a national issue, highways can reshape communities in fundamental ways, often with little public comment. These two urban areas are using Federal highway money to go in opposite directions, Salt Lake to speed people into and out of the city, Milwaukee to restore a neighborhood and revive city life.
While Mr. Gore has trumpeted the Clinton Administration's plan to preserve open space with tax credits worth $700 million, the Federal Government is offering cities and states $162 billion over the next five years for building, maintaining and expanding roads. The money is from the largest public works bill ever made law, last year's $217 billion transportation bill.
Much of the money from that bill, after a change in policy under President George Bush in 1991, can be used for commuter rail systems, subways, bike paths, even tearing down highways. But most of it will be used to serve cars. And whether a highway is widened or torn down, aimed at the center of a city or routed around it, it shapes destiny.
In Salt Lake, for example, new subdivisions are already rising in the open spaces through which Gov. Michael O. Leavitt has proposed the building of the Legacy Highway to parallel I-15.
In Milwaukee, a neighborhood of new housing, restaurants, shops and a theme park is taking shape in what will no longer be the path of the Park East Freeway, which it to be demolished. In this case, the market is following the highway's elimination.
 
Utah's Situation
Effects of Zoning And More People
More than most cities in the American West, Salt Lake was carefully planned from inception, its blocks and avenues platted with geometric precision, its neighborhoods zoned to reflect village atmosphere and to enhance the communal economics of the Mormon pioneers.
In some ways the city is still like a big small town. But Salt Lake is on its way to becoming a Phoenix of the Wasatch Range, bordered by new suburbs whose only connection to one another are the highways.
Few people here seem to want this. Governor Leavitt, a two-term Republican, has proclaimed that the Beehive State "will no longer subsidize urban sprawl" -- at least as a deliberate strategy. But indirectly, Utah seems to be doing just that.
New highway projects, combined with local zoning that virtually mandates big lots and big houses, are adding more helium to the balloon of Greater Salt Lake. The metropolitan area is projected to double in size, to more than 800 square miles, by 2020, while the population grows 50 percent. Some people whose lives are in the path of urbanization are bitter at the Government's role.
"We have 300 acres of prime dairy land and there is nothing my family would like better than keep milking cows on this land," said Carolynn Gibson, whose family operates a dairy farm, which began as a homestead, about 30 miles north of Salt Lake City.
But the pressures to sell out are enormous. Hardly a week goes by when the family is not offered a windfall to sell their acreage to a developer.
What has made grazing land look appealing to house builders, driving up property values around the Gibson farm, is Governor Leavitt's proposed Legacy Highway, which would ultimately run more than 100 miles, north and south.
Farmers oppose the highway because it could wipe out up to half of the region's 43 remaining dairy farms. Two Federal agencies also oppose it, saying the highway would cut through what biologists consider some of the most important inland bird breeding grounds in the Western Hemisphere.
"We could make a ton of money and just quit the sweat," Mrs. Gibson said. "But there's something about the sense of it. It makes no sense to keep putting pavement over farmland."
But from his Capitol office in Salt Lake City, Governor Leavitt, a descendant of pioneer stock, looks at a map of the narrow Wasatch front -- mountains on one side, a salty lake or marsh on the other -- and asks, "Where are we going to put all these new people?"
Utah has the nation's highest birth rate, averaging 20 births per 1,000 people in the 1990's, more than double the average. The state is projected to add a million people in the next 20 years, more than 70 percent from births, and two million more by 2050. Dairy farms could be a luxury, the Governor says.
The state's political climate, distrusting anything that smacks of government planning, has made it impossible to pass limits on growth. The Legislature did enact a Quality Growth Act this year, establishing a commission to recommend policies but, as its own preamble says, it "mandates nothing."
Critics of Utah's growth say there is a contradiction: while the Governor says he wants growth to be guided by the free market, his $10 billion in highway construction plans are a giant Government push for growth up and down the Wasatch Range.
"What we have done over the last 50 years with the Federal highway system is subsidize the worst kind of sprawl," said Robert Adler, a professor of law at the University of Utah. "In building these roads, you skew people's choices."
When the Governor invited Utah residents to offer their opinions on growth as part of the Quality Growth process, more than 17,000 people filled out questionnaires. Few responding to the unscientific survey said they wanted to continue in the direction the state was headed, with big lots, no farmland protection and total dependence on cars.
A majority of respondents said they preferred houses on smaller lots, just under a third of an acre, near rail or transit lines, in neighborhoods with a mix of small businesses and town houses. But local zoning codes and the subsidies for new roads make it difficult to create those neighborhoods.
As in most American suburbs, zoning codes in Utah keep businesses apart from housing to protect property values and minimize traffic. One result, though, is that residents are forced into cars for even small errands. And as Salt Lake has grown, many of the small towns in the path of the metropolitan area tried to preserve their rural feel by banning housing lots of less than an acre.
But with one-acre zoning, a million more people, at four per household, would consume most of the open space left in the Salt Lake Valley, according to Envision Utah, a group set up by business and political leaders to guide the state on growth.
"There is a disconnect between cause and effect," said Stephen Holbrook, executive director of the group.
As in many other parts of the country, builders who try to design more compact developments are stymied.
Gerry Tully, a Salt Lake developer, spent years persuading city officials in Farmington, a town of 10,000 people just north of Salt Lake, to let him build 175 homes, including some town houses, on 100 acres with one-acre zoning. Mr. Tully only recently succeeded, after telling residents at several public hearings that the best way to keep some of their open space was to build more compact neighborhoods around parks and green space.
Hugging the bird-congested shore of the Great Salt Lake, Farmington is on the cusp of big change, shaped by the automobile. Signs in front of farms and big new houses protest the Legacy Highway.
State traffic engineers say the number of cars in the metropolitan area will double in 10 years. So even with the interstate widened all the way up to Farmington, Mr. Leavitt said, he has little choice but to build more highway. The state is also building a single-track commuter rail line to the city's downtown sports complex. The rail line is scheduled to open a year before the 2002 Winter Olympics in Utah.
The Salt Lake metropolitan area is following a cycle that is well-known to other cities. Atlanta, after building a ring of highways sliced by other highways, has one of the most traffic-clogged metropolitan areas in the country. The future shape of the Atlanta area may hinge on whether the region decides to go ahead with plans for a new $5 billion outer beltway.
Other cities have turned down plans to widen highways and are rejecting designs for new ones.
Like Utah, Maryland is expected to grow by a million people over the next generation. But that state will no longer finance roads, sewers and other developments that help to expand urban areas into open land.
These limits on growth have their own critics. Some people are denied the American dream of owning their home, these critics say, when restrictions are placed on new highways to the edge of suburbia, where land and housing are cheaper.
"You have some very well-meaning people whose idea of future homes are a bunch of apartment complexes stacked up next to light rail depots," Governor Leavitt said.
 
The Highway
Solution or Problem For Congestion?
Among mayors, traffic engineers and other people who are passionate about urban design's influence on people, there is a vigorous debate over whether building highways causes people to drive more, adding to congestion rather than reducing it.
The arguments boil down to this: When a new road is built, people take trips that they might otherwise not have taken. New homes, businesses and stores brought on by the highway will appear, and it will soon be clogged. But if the crowded highway is removed, or not widened, people will find other ways to get around, taking public transit, side roads, walking or biking -- anything to save time.
Recent studies in England and California support the theory that new roads add to overall driving time, concluding that every 10 percent increase in highway capacity produces at least a 5 percent net increase in driving time.
Supporters of this theory point to San Francisco, where the Embarcadero Freeway along the waterfront, damaged in the 1989 earthquake, was removed; or Portland, Ore., where a six-lane highway was torn down and replaced with a downtown park, or New York, where the West Side Highway was closed after a collapse. In all three cases, traffic in the area of the highway fell when it was taken out of use.
"We have all this experience over the last 20 years, from Los Angeles to Atlanta to Phoenix, that shows that building and widening freeways do not solve our traffic problems," said Keith Bartholomew, a professor at the Wallace Stegner Center for Land, Resources and the Environment at the University of Utah, "and yet here we are in Utah saying somehow this time it has to work."
If the new highway will not reduce traffic, why build it? Governor Leavitt says he has no choice: the millions of new people in Utah will have to get around somehow, and the overwhelming majority of people -- as much as 97 percent, according to some surveys -- will not use mass transit.
Even cities that have embraced rail transit have not noticeably reduced traffic congestion. Americans prefer their cars.
Still, others wonder whether there is a way to accommodate people's preference for the automobile without encouraging a runaway metropolis. A city left to true market forces, not shaped by Government subsidies for either highways or railways, might take an entirely different shape.
Mr. Tully, the Salt Lake developer, says current trends indicate that 70 percent of new housing in the region is likely to be outside the Salt Lake City limits. If the Legacy Highway were not built, he said, it would be closer to 50 percent, because many developers would look at building housing in underused sections of the city. But perhaps the biggest factor driving the housing market is the new freeway, most of which will be underwritten by the Federal Government.
"I would love to have lunch in Paris every day," said Roy Kienitz, executive director of the Surface Transportation Policy Project, a nonprofit study group in Washington. "But I'm not asking the Government to buy me a ticket on the Concorde."
 
Milwaukee's Response
Rejecting Subsidies, Saving Neighborhoods
In Milwaukee, Mayor Norquist has spent more than a decade trying to keep the Federal Government from influencing the place known as Brew City U.S.A. Unlike most Democrats, Mr. Norquist opposes Federal money for housing, highways, education and welfare. The money is virtually free, so cities take it. But they do so at their peril, he argues in his book, "The Wealth of Cities," published last year by Addison-Wesley.
Cities like Detroit, St. Louis and Cleveland lost people and neighborhoods to interstate highways, Mr. Norquist says. In Milwaukee, which is surrounded by highways going every direction, the black section of the city and the old Italian neighborhoods were wiped out by highway construction in the 1960's, he says. Shopping centers and a sizable part of the metropolitan area's people followed the highways west, north and south.
"All this sprawl was subsidized," said Mr. Norquist, sitting in his office in the 105-year-old City Hall, a Flemish Renaissance building topped by a clock tower 400 feet above the sidewalk. "Sprawl is the direct result of accommodating the automobile."
Other urban experts say suburban development is the price for creating the world's first mass middle class. The highway follows public sentiment, they argue.
"You're saying people can go out and have a quarter-acre, half-acre, an acre, build their own house, maybe put a little swimming pool in it, all the things they want, and we call it bad, nasty sprawl," Ben Wattenberg, a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute, has written. "Why don't we call it great?"
Mr. Norquist says he is not against all highways, just those that slice up cities. He points to Canada, where its central Government does not pay for urban highways, and cities like Vancouver and Toronto have responded with a mix of transportation systems that preserve their neighborhoods.
Nor is he against the suburbs, where nearly half of Americans now live. But as a big-city mayor, trying to enliven parts of central Milwaukee that once pulsed with commerce and housing, Mr. Norquist has a natural bias.
A final link in the long-term highway plan for Milwaukee called for the Park East Freeway to cut across the northern edge of downtown, across the Milwaukee River to Lake Michigan. While the part that was built is still in use, neighborhood opposition killed construction of the second half, and now the Mayor has obtained money to tear down the part that was built.
The Mayor views what has happened since the highway was halted as a sort of laboratory for his theory that cities will develop naturally without Federal highway subsidies. At the point where the highway was brought to a standstill, a cluster of new housing has arisen, in a neighborhood that includes John Ernst Cafe, Milwaukee's oldest German restaurant. Children ride bikes with cards pinned to the wheels for motorized effect, the elderly play chess in a new pocket park and people carry groceries home from a supermarket at the center of East Pointe Commons housing development.
It is the kind of neighborhood favored by the so-called New Urbanists, a group of architects, planners and others who advocate more compact development. The neighborhood is not for everybody, says Mayor Norquist, but by stopping the highway the city has allowed people to make a choice. There is no subsidy either way.
As the highways carried people away from the city, the new suburbs have tended to zone out the kind of things that make a neighborhood interesting, Mr. Norquist said, echoing the sentiments of Mr. Tully in Utah. Mr. Norquist points to cozy old streets in Milwaukee, where people live in apartments that are directly above storefronts, and walk to schools and businesses.
"This used to be Main Street, U.S.A," he said. "It's now a code violation all over America."

HEADLINE: Report Says Profit-Making Health Plans Damage Care

BYLINE: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 13

 BODY:
Patients enrolled in profit-making health insurance plans are significantly less likely to receive the basics of good medical care -- including childhood immunizations, routine mammograms, pap smears, prenatal care, and lifesaving drugs after a heart attack -- than those in not-for-profit plans, says a new study that concludes that the free market is "compromising the quality of care."
The research, by a team from Harvard University and Public Citizen, an advocacy group in Washington, is the first comprehensive comparison of investor-owned and nonprofit plans. The authors found that on every one of 14 quality-of-care indicators, the for-profits scored worse. But because the researchers favored national health insurance, some questioned their findings. 
 "The market is destroying our health care system," Dr. David U. Himmelstein, associate professor of medicine at Harvard University Medical School and the study's lead author, said in a telephone interview. "We have had a decade or more of policies aimed at making health care a business, and they have failed."
Investor-owned health plans, which are typically made up of loose networks of doctors, have come to dominate the American medical landscape in recent years. These plans, offered by companies like Aetna, U.S. Healthcare and Cigna Healthcare, last year covered 62 percent of all patients in H.M.O.'s, as compared to 26 percent in 1985. Yet most research on quality of care in H.M.O.'s has focused on traditional nonprofits, among them Kaiser Permanente, in California, and H.I.P., based in New York.
The new study, which appears this week in the Journal of the American Medical Association, analyzed quality-of-care data from 248 investor-owned and 81 not-for-profit plans in 45 states and the District of Columbia. These plans provided coverage to 56 percent of all Americans enrolled in H.M.O.'s in 1996, the year from which the patient information was drawn.
Among the findings: In profit-making H.M.O.'s just 63.9 percent of 2-year-olds were fully immunized, as compared to 72.3 percent in nonprofits. Lifesaving beta-blocker drugs were given to 59.2 percent of heart attack patients in for-profit plans, but 70.6 percent of patients in nonprofits got the drugs. Diabetes patients were less likely to receive annual eye exams to prevent blindness in profit-making plans; the figure was 35.1 percent, as against 47.9 percent in nonprofits.
The investor-owned plans fared worse, the authors said, even when all other factors, like location of the plan, and whether the doctors were employees or members of networks, were taken into account. While the study had certain limitations -- it did not examine how patients fared, for instance -- the authors, who paid for the research themselves, said the data were the best available.
The study is being published just as the Senate is embroiled in a divisive debate over how to protect patients' rights and regulate H.M.O.'s. While the authors say the timing is coincidental, the work is already influencing the discussion. In a statement released today, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachussetts Democrat who is pushing for H.M.O. regulation, said the research "contains strong new support for H.M.O. reform."
But representatives of the insurance industry, which opposes regulation, argue just the opposite. They say the study demonstrates that, even at their worst, health maintenance organizations provide better care to patients than fee-for-service arrangements that were common 10 years ago.
"The best conclusion that can be drawn from this study is that managed care is improving the quality of health care for those Americans that are covered by health plans," said Susan Pisano, a spokeswoman for the American Association of Health Plans, which represents both for-profit and nonprofit plans.
Ms. Pisano also accused the authors of confusing "analysis and ideology."
Dr. Himmelstein did not dispute that he had a bias. "My bias is that for-profit H.M.O.'s kill people," he said.
But Eli Ginzberg, a health care economist at Columbia University who did not participate in the study , said Dr. Himmelstein's political views did not discredit the Harvard professor's work.
"There is no question that he has an agenda, but I think he is reading his data correctly," said Professor Ginzberg, adding that it was hardly surprising that nonprofit plans deliver better care. "Let's face it, people went into the for-profit managed care business to make bucks," he said. The study was made public here today at the offices of Public Citizen, whose director, Dr. Sidney M. Wolfe, was a co-author.

HEADLINE: Bush Tells New Jersey 'Compassionate Conservatism' Is Nation's Best Hope

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: NEWARK, July 13

 BODY:
Gov. George W. Bush brought his high-rolling Presidential campaign to New Jersey for the first time this evening, telling a roomful of Republican campaign contributors that his brand of "compassionate conservatism" is the best hope for continuing the nation's prosperity while strengthening its moral character.
At a fund-raising dinner held at the Sheraton hotel next to Newark International Airport, Mr. Bush delivered his standard campaign speech about tax cuts and the importance of personal responsibility, making scant reference to New Jersey or issues affecting urban areas like Newark. He spoke briefly with reporters and declined to say whether his campaign, which had raised a record $36.3 million by July 1, will refuse Federal matching funds. Such a move would give Mr. Bush more flexibility in his campaign spending. 
 Although some supporters conceded that Mr. Bush's message was short on specifics, many said they were optimistic that his charm, conviction and ideals would play well with New Jersey's moderate Republican voters.
"He talked about his ideas," said Irene G. Almeida, chairman of the Passaic Valley Sewerage Commissioners, who attended a private roundtable discussion between Mr. Bush and an assortment of Republican officials before the dinner. "He didn't go into details, but those will come later. The good thing is to see how he talks to people, his warmth. And that he really seems to believe deeply in what he's saying. You can just see it in the way he talks."
Mr. Bush, who flew in from Austin, Tex., also had reason to feel upbeat. Clifford M. Sobel, the finance chairman of the New Jersey Republican Party, announced that the event raised $1 million, meaning that Mr. Bush has now raised more money in the state than any other candidate -- including Bill Bradley, the Democratic Presidential hopeful and former United States Senator who lives in Montclair. About 500 people paid at least $1,000 each to attend the dinner.
Although the first Presidential primaries are still half a year away, Mr. Bush has become a daunting front-runner for the Republican nomination and the list of his supporters at the event today included most of the prominent New Jersey Republicans.
The co-chairmen of the event were Donald T. DiFrancesco, Speaker of the State Senate, and Jack Collins, Speaker of the Assembly. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, who has said she will not endorse a Presidential candidate until after this November's elections, met privately with Mr. Bush before he made his speech, and many of her cabinet members and campaign officials attended the event.
During his half-hour address, Mr. Bush spoke about his desire to spread the nation's prosperity and reach out to the poor. He also vowed to make public education a priority, and pointed to his success in improving the test scores of Texas students during his five years as Governor.
But the biggest applause came when Mr. Bush made a reference to President Clinton's impeachment and the Monica Lewinsky scandal.
"When I put my hand on the Bible, I'll swear to uphold the dignity of the office," he said.
Outside the hotel, Mr. Bush was greeted by a small group of demonstrators from the gun control group Ceasefire New Jersey, who protested his opposition to several proposals to limit the sale of handguns.
When questioned by reporters, Mr. Bush defended his record of supporting gun owners' rights and said he did not think it would hurt his prospects in states like New Jersey, where public opinion polls show that a majority of voters embrace gun control.
"That's what elections are for," he said. "But I'm proud of my record."

HEADLINE: Hotel Chains Improved Their Hiring, the N.A.A.C.P. Says

BYLINE: By WINNIE HU 

 BODY:
The nation's largest hotel chains improved in hiring minority workers and reaching out to minority businesses and consumers last year, according to an annual survey conducted by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
Kweisi Mfume, president of the association, unveiled a "report card" for hotels and a separate one for telecommunications companies yesterday afternoon at the group's annual convention at the New York Hilton and Towers in midtown Manhattan. 
 "We believe, quite frankly, that unless communities of color become disciplined consumers, we run the risk of still sitting like beggars on bags of gold, looking at the lack of reciprocity in our communities, and continuing to see trade as a one-way street," he said.
Both surveys were based on information provided by the companies in five areas: hiring of minority workers, promotion of minority employees, relationships with businesses owned by members of minorities, advertising in black media outlets and philanthropy in minority communities.
Marriott topped the list of 14 companies in the hotel survey, getting a B+ (and a numerical grade of 3.7), followed by the economy chain Cendant (B+ and 3.56), whose properties include Days Inn, Howard Johnson and Super 8 Motels. The Hilton chain ranked third with a B.
"We're No. 1 and we intend to stay there," said Dave Sampson, vice president for diversity projects at Marriott International. The company was handing out announcements saying Marriott was the "highest-rated hotel company" in the survey. Last year, Marriott was given a C+.
Mr. Sampson oversees a department that was created 18 months ago to recruit small service-providing businesses owned by women and by members of minorities. So far, his department has contacted about 200 such companies and signed about 20 to contracts.
In contrast to the two earlier hotel surveys, none of the companies received a failing grade this year. But four -- Bass/Holiday (which includes Holiday Inn) Wyndham, Starwood (Westin, ITT Sheraton) and Omni -- came in at the bottom with a grade of C.
Gloria Rogers, 57, a delegate, said she took the report cards seriously and would avoid hotels that had low grades. "If you walk into a hotel that's all white, you're not going to feel as welcome and accepted, and you will be neglected," she said. "So to us, this is very important."
In the telecommunications survey, Bell South received the highest grade of B+ (numerical grade 3.55), followed by Bell Atlantic, the largest phone service provider in New York, with a B+ and 3.5. The only failing grade went to Alltel, because it did not respond to requests for information, said Linda Haithcox, national manager of economic development for the N.A.A.C.P.
This was only the second year for the telecommunications survey, and Mr. Mfume said that it was too soon to see any improvements. But he urged the delegates not to patronize companies that had a D or a failing grade.
Like report cards from school, the highest grade is an A, but Ms. Haithcox said that no company has yet received it. "If they deserve an A, they will get it," she said.
Several representatives of companies ranked in the N.A.A.C.P. report cards attended yesterday's presentation and most emphasized that their companies had made long-term commitments to diversity that would not change because of the report cards.
Mark Bonavia, a director of corporate communications for Sprint, said his company had made many improvements even though it received a C grade for the second year. For instance, he said, Sprint has made a point of recruiting at historically black colleges like Howard University in Washington and Florida A &M University in Tallahassee. Last year, about 20 percent of the company's 12,000 new employees were black.
In addition, Mr. Bonavia said, Sprint spent $8.14 million in 1998 for advertising in magazines, newspapers and television stations that cater to blacks, but $1.45 million the year before.
"Despite the fact that we made colossal progress year to year on paper and in practice, you really can't step up your diversity efforts on multiple fronts because you want to improve your grade or a rating," he said. "You do it because it makes your business better."

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Unemployment Rate Rises in New Jersey

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
New Jersey's unemployment rate crept up again in June to its highest level since the end of 1997. But the 4.9 percent rate is still considered near full employment for the Garden State, State Labor Department officials said yesterday.
Unemployment rose slightly from 4.7 percent rate in May. The New Jersey rate has risen since sinking to 4.1 percent in February. 
 The indicators were mixed: New Jersey employers continued to create more jobs, but fewer New Jersey residents held jobs during the month.
The State Labor Commissioner, Mel Gelade, said the higher rate did not concern him because so many other economic factors in New Jersey remained strong. He noted that New Jersey employers created 1,600 more jobs during the month. Mr. Gelade added, however, that there would be concern if the state rate continued to rise the rest of the year.

HEADLINE: Asia's Future, and Ours

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Not only has the rebound in Asia derailed reform (front page, July 12), but a return to rapid growth in the region will also renew the threat of environmental meltdown. 
 At 8 percent growth, 80 percent of the industrial sector in Asia in just 25 years will consist of plants not yet built. It is expected that more than 60 percent of world income will originate in Asia by 2025. And it is projected that up to 400 million people will be added to the region.
It is the momentum of these forces, not just the numbers, that suggests that the world's environmental future will be determined in large measure by what happens in Asia. If concern for the environment is made part of economic reform, the prospects are bright. If not, the Asian rebound will be a problem for all of us.
 
OWEN CYLKE
Bethesda, Md., July 12, 1999
 
The writer is an economist at the Policy Group, United States-Asia Environmental Partnership.

HEADLINE: SUNY Woos Harlem Pastor To Lead Nassau Campus

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
Several top officials at the State University of New York are pressing the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d, pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem, to become president of SUNY's Old Westbury campus, and he has indicated his strong interest.
"I hope we will be able to convince him to come and lead our institution," Thomas F. Egan, SUNY's chairman, said yesterday in a statement. 
 Under SUNY rules, a search committee must be formed to propose candidates, whose names will be forwarded to the trustees, but Mr. Egan and other SUNY officials said they considered Mr. Butts, 49, to be the leading candidate. "He is an extremely gifted and outstanding individual with the strongest leadership qualities," Mr. Egan said.
Mr. Butts said last night that if offered the position, he would be "excited about taking it."
But referring to the search process, he said: "Right now, I don't think it's a matter of me making up my mind. It's a matter of whether a formal invitation will be made. If they asked me tomorrow, I would say yes. I am excited about it. It would be a great challenge for the 21st century. There are no more important things than education and faith."
William R. Howell, a businessman who is chairman of the search committee and of the college's advisory council, said last night that while he had met with Mr. Butts informally, the search committee would not hold its first meeting until the end of this month and that he intended to conduct a full search.
A SUNY official said the position of president pays between $120,000 and $150,000.
SUNY's Old Westbury campus is about 20 miles from Manhattan in Nassau County, and about half of its approximately 3,700 students are members of minority groups. SUNY officials say the college has suffered from weak leadership and years of sparse funding by SUNY.
Mr. Butts's interest in Old Westbury is said to have grown out of discussions he had with Randy Daniels, a SUNY trustee, about wanting to teach a college course, and being referred to the Long Island campus.
SUNY officials say they began talking to Mr. Butts after he visited the Old Westbury campus earlier this year to discuss the possibility of teaching a course as an adjunct professor, and became intrigued with the idea of becoming more involved with the college.
Academia would mark a sudden turn for Mr. Butts, who has been with the Abyssinian Baptist Church since 1972 and for more than a decade has toyed with the idea of entering politics. Earlier this year, he said he might be interested in running for mayor of New York in 2001 or for the United States Congress in 2000.
Mr. Butts said accepting the Old Westbury position "would obviously take me out of the running for anything."
That "doesn't mean I would not be involved in politics," he added. "I will certainly have my own opinions. I intend to be fully politically involved in what goes on in the city and state."
Once the ultimate outsider who criticized mainstream politicians on issues of race, in recent years Mr. Butts has developed close ties to the business community and to political officials as he sought to nurture economic development in Harlem.
He may have distanced himself from some potential allies last year, when -- to the consternation of many of New York's black leaders -- he endorsed Gov. George E. Pataki in his bid for re-election.
Mr. Butts said last year that the Governor had been helpful in providing money to support development in Harlem, and he has also led prayer breakfasts for Mr. Pataki, who is close to several of the SUNY trustees who are backing Mr. Butts.
In April, Mr. Butts was attacked in the black press and on black talk-radio programs for reaching out to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in the wake of the fatal shooting of Amadou Diallo by police officers in the Bronx.
Founded 31 years ago as a college dedicated to serving "nontraditional students," including adults and high school students who were not well prepared for college, Old Westbury has been criticized in recent years for being one of SUNY's least selective four-year colleges.
Last year, SUNY trustees brought in Dr. W. Hubert Keen, a biologist who had been provost at the City University of New York's York College, as interim president, to try to transform the campus.
SUNY officials yesterday gave him credit for introducing great change in a short period, but said that it was not clear whether Dr. Keen planned to seek the post of permanent president.

HEADLINE: Would Tax Cuts Prove Too Stimulating?

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
For all the recent talk of cutting taxes, Congress rarely cuts them when the economy is growing robustly, as it is today, and unemployment is low. The worry among economists is that the extra money in people's pockets may make an already strong economy too strong, finally stoking inflation after a long period of relatively stable prices.
Yet that danger is hardly mentioned in the rising public debate over the Republican and Democratic proposals for tax cuts. 
 Why not? In part, it is because the advocates of the tax cuts, as well as many of the opponents, agree that any reductions will probably be small, at least in the initial years. And few analysts expect any final tax cut to come close to the $864 billion over the next decade that has been proposed by House Republicans.
"Most of the tax cut proposals are phased in gradually over a number of years," said Senator Connie Mack, Republican of Florida, the chairman of Congress's Joint Economic Committee and the author of a proposal to cut taxes by $137 billion over 10 years, most of it toward the end of the period. "I think the immediate economic stimulus will be small," he said.
The Federal Reserve, however, is concerned. "If taxes were cut while the nation's resources are highly employed, that would put more pressure on monetary policy," Edward M. Gramlich, a Fed governor, said. He suggested, in effect, that the Fed might have to raise interest rates to prevent the extra spending that would overstimulate the economy. Others worry that the higher rates might reduce investment or bring down inflated stock prices, damaging the economy through these avenues.
Stock prices should already be reacting to the prospect of a tax cut, some people say, but they have not so far because too many people on Wall Street express doubt that tax cut legislation will be enacted before next year's election -- or soon afterward, for that matter.
"A bunch of friends on Wall Street have asked me why the markets are so quiet about the tax cut proposals," said James E. Glassman, a senior economist at Chase Manhattan Bank. "Wall Street is unusually quiet because it realizes that there will just be gridlock on this issue near term -- a lot of proposals and no real action."
Still, Mr. Gramlich's concern reflects a view widely shared among economists -- that broad tax cuts tend to stimulate spending and therefore should be reserved for recessions or periods of slow growth. In the early 1960's, President John F. Kennedy proposed a tax cut in this spirit, and President Ronald Reagan's tax cuts, which started during a recession, contributed to the long expansion in the 1980's.
By contrast, President Lyndon B. Johnson's 10 percent income tax cut, carrying through on the original Kennedy proposal, came when the economy had turned from the weak Kennedy years to the much more robust mid-1960's. The Fed responded by raising rates.
And the altered mix was damaging, says Alan S. Blinder, a Princeton University economist who served as Fed vice chairman from 1994 to 1996. The new mix -- higher interest rates to offset more fiscal stimulus from the tax cut and from stepped-up spending for the Vietnam War and for the Johnson social programs -- shifted the economy toward consumption and away from investment. Inflation also got a foothold.
Some economists contend that fiscal policy has lost its punch since the 1960's while monetary policy has evolved to the point that the Fed can regulate the economy through interest rate adjustments, offsetting tax cuts without damage.
"Monetary policy administered by the Fed is far more important as far as economic stabilization is concerned and regulating aggregate demand," said James Gwertney, the Republican-appointed chief economist of the Joint Economic panel.
Mr. Blinder disagrees. Monetary policy has its limits, he said. A tax cut offset by higher interest rates today "would reverse the policy mix that we have followed in the 1990's with such splendid effect: low interest rates and high corporate investment," Mr. Blinder said.
Henry Kaufman, a Wall Street economist and consultant, adds a related reason for not using the budget surplus to finance tax cuts, as both parties now propose. "With the surplus, we could have some timely fiscal action when the economy goes inevitably into recession," he said. "We would not for once have to worry about deficit financing."
Clinton Administration officials say that their more modest tax cut proposal gets around the problem of encouraging too much consumption. By offering incentives, particularly to the poor, to invest the tax cuts in retirement accounts, they say, private savings will rise, and the savings will then be available for corporations to borrow and invest in productive equipment.
But many economists say that such tax rebates would not go dollar for dollar into retirement accounts. Upper-income people in particular have the wherewithal to shift savings from one account to another to qualify for a tax refund, which would then be spent on consumer goods, according to this view. That has been the experience with individual retirement accounts.
This is not the supply-side view. For supply-siders, tax cuts -- particularly a Republican proposal to reduce the capital gains tax on the profit made from the sale of stocks and other assets -- encourage investment by reducing its risk. While supply-siders are a distinct minority among economists, they are a vocal one in the incipient debate about a tax cut's effect on the economy.
In their view, suppliers, not consumers, are the chief economic actors. And suppliers respond to tax cuts by investing their capital in new supply. Far from stimulating demand beyond an economy's capacity, the supply-siders say, a tax cut increases the supply of goods and services, which are then consumed.
No one pushes this view harder than Jude Wanniski, an economics consultant and adviser to Steve Forbes and various other Republicans involved in tax-cutting proposals. "The Government, by cutting tax rates, is simply removing the barrier to investment," he said.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: July 15, 1999, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about the effect of potential tax cuts on the economy misidentified the presidential candidate who is being advised by the economics consultant Jude Wanniski. It is Dan Quayle, not Steve Forbes.

ORGANIZATION: REPUBLICAN OF FLORIDA (62%);

While supply-siders are a distinct minority among economists, they are a vocal one in the incipient debate about a tax cut's effect on the economy.
In their view, suppliers, not consumers, are the chief economic actors. And suppliers respond to tax cuts by investing their capital in new supply. Far from stimulating demand beyond an economy's capacity, the supply-siders say, a tax cut increases the supply of goods and services, which are then consumed.
No one pushes this view harder than Jude Wanniski, an economics consultant and adviser to Steve Forbes and various other Republicans involved in tax-cutting proposals. "The Government, by cutting tax rates, is simply removing the barrier to investment," he said.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: July 16, 1999, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the effect of potential tax cuts on the economy misstated the proposal of Senator Connie Mack, Republican of Florida. His plan calls for $766 billion in cuts over 10 years, with $137 billion of that amount coming in the first five years, not a total of $137 billion for the decade.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Construing His Airness As a Neo-Imperialist

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:

MICHAEL JORDAN AND THE NEW GLOBAL CAPITALISM
By Walter LaFeber
Illustrated. 191 pages. W. W. Norton & Company $22.95.
It is not exactly news that Michael Jordan may well be one of the most familiar figures in the world today. As arguably the greatest basketball player ever to play the game and as a pitchman for products ranging from Nike sportswear to McDonald's fast food, Mr. Jordan has become as recognizable to natives of Lhasa, Tibet, and students at Beijing University as he is to hometown fans of the Chicago Bulls. 
 Yet Walter LaFeber, a history professor at Cornell University, is out to make a larger point in his catchily titled new book, "Michael Jordan and the New Global Capitalism." Arguing that Mr. Jordan represents a new form of culture that is sweeping the globe and changing ways of life everywhere for good or ill, Mr. LaFeber poses the question: Is Mr. Jordan simply a great salesman or does he represent what some see as an insidious form of cultural imperialism? If the answer is the latter, what are the implications for America's relations to the world?
The prospect of getting answers to these questions is intriguing enough to draw the reader through much material familiar to any basketball fan or reader of the financial pages. Mr. LaFeber begins by tracing Mr. Jordan's roots, emphasizing his atypical background (for an African-American ballplayer) of having grown up in a rural area relatively innocent of race prejudice and the civil rights struggles of the 1960's.
The book's focus then turns to the history of basketball since its invention by Dr. James Naismith in 1891 as a pastime for keeping the young men at Springfield College in Massachusetts out of trouble between the football and baseball seasons.
Conceding that within decades the game became the special preserve of blacks in the inner city (especially New York), Mr. LaFeber nevertheless stresses how quickly basketball caught on with women (in 1896, the women of Stanford defeated Berkeley 2 to 1 -- each basket counting a point -- in a game watched by hundreds of female fans), how soon it became internationally popular and how well it lent itself to broadcasting on television.
With Mr. Jordan's entry into the National Basketball Association in 1984 (as the third pick in the annual draft of college players after the Houston Rockets took Hakeem Olajuwan and the Portland Trailblazers selected the now forgotten Sam Bowie), several synergistic forces came together, Mr. LaFeber argues. Mr. Jordan himself quickly developed into both a peerless player and an appealing spokesman for commercial products.
The new commissioner of the N.B.A., David Stern, introduced innovative policies that allowed professional basketball to begin its leap to international prominence. New communications technology permitted television to provide the medium to broadcast that leap. And the Nike corporation, led by Phil Knight, established itself as a paradigm of the modern transnational company, the distinguishing characteristics of which are to depend largely on overseas production, to be knowledge-based rather than reliant on industrial goods, to look to the world instead of just the United States for profits, to be driven by large-scale advertising campaigns carried by the new communications technology and to lie beyond the control of any single government.
What the synergy of these forces produced, writes Mr. LaFeber, was called "soft power," referring to "the influence of U.S. culture and commerce, rather than to its military and political muscle." The author continues: "Transnationals such as Nike epitomized such soft power. Their influence was made greater by widespread use of the English language -- the international language of computers, science and many of the young who considered themselves 'cool.' "
"Recent students of 'post-imperialism' ," he goes on, "argue that transnational corporations have created in many nations a new class -- a native 'nationalist managerial' class -- which works to help the transnational spread its power among people of whom this new class is a part." He concludes: "This post-1970's class can provide a vital support on the important local political level for transnationals. The new corporations thus not only change buying habits in a society, but modify the composition of the society itself. For the society that receives it, soft power can have hard effects."
Do all of Mr. LaFeber's points connect to form a picture of the future of the global economy? Not really. For one thing, the book is more about Mr. Jordan than the effects of what he has done. We learn much about his suffering from having struck a "Faustian bargain" with the media, but not very much about why precisely his image has proved so appealing. (The author barely mentions perhaps the most striking feature about Mr. Jordan, not his airness, but instead that he's hairless.)
When Mr. LaFeber does explore how Mr. Jordan and Nike operate, he fails to examine in detail the implications of the low wages the company is accused of paying to foreign workers, or the extent of its mass cultural influence. One wonders what will happen when the supply of cheap labor dries up, as it is bound to do if, as Nike representatives have argued, its influence in poor countries has helped to create a middle class. One wonders too if the mass culture that transnationals are accused of spreading can't be resisted by advocates of high culture, just as it continues to be here in the United States.
Finally, on the question of whether Mr. Jordan is good or bad for the world, Mr. LaFeber cops out. He cites a few trivial examples on both sides. He then concludes somewhat lamely: "In the new tightly wired world, Americans cannot escape these questions" of whether global capitalism is benign or evil. "They can only begin to deal with them by understanding the history of how we all became part of a global market economy and market society." Presumably he has written a piece of that history. But it doesn't provide very many answers.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: The Volatile Issue of Taiwan

 BODY:
By most measures of civic development, Taiwan has evolved in recent years into a far more appealing model than mainland China. Taiwan's politics is now fully democratic, its economy market-based and thriving and its press free and spirited. But relations between Taiwan and the mainland remain as tense and explosive as ever, and each side takes every opportunity to provoke the other. The latest dispute was set off when Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-hui, abruptly announced a new definition of Taiwan's status, needlessly angering Beijing and complicating relations between the United States and China.
In a radio interview last weekend, Mr. Lee asserted that Taiwan and China were, at least for now, two separate states. That cast aside the traditional and usefully ambiguous formula of "one China." That doctrine, adopted by Washington and Beijing when they began serious diplomatic courtship in 1972, affirms that "there is but one China and Taiwan is part of China." In practical terms, it means that Washington has committed itself not to recognize Taiwan as an independent state. 
 The merit of this formula is that it allows Taiwan and the mainland to coexist as separate political entities so long as both acknowledge a commitment to eventual reunification. Mr. Lee has not only challenged that status quo, but has virtually asserted Taiwan's independence. As he surely knew it would, his statement struck a nationalist nerve among mainland Chinese, stirring sentiments that the Communist leadership there has always been quick to exploit.
The combustibility of this issue should not be underestimated. Four years ago tensions increased after Mr. Lee exploited a private visa to attend a Cornell reunion to promote his vision of a more assertive Taiwan. Beijing, accusing Washington of going back on its earlier commitments, chilled relations with the United States. Several months later Beijing conducted missile tests and war games near Taiwan during the island's 1996 presidential election campaign.
Beijing should not make the same mistake of resorting to military threats. That bullying turned Taiwanese opinion sharply against the mainland and reunification. Mr. Lee, for his part, should abandon talk of separate states and instead reaffirm Taiwan's desire for eventual peaceful reunification on terms consistent with its current freedoms.
The United States, meanwhile, should try to stay out of the public crossfire while counseling restraint to both sides. In particular, Washington should make sure Mr. Lee clearly understands that while Americans support Taiwan's democracy, the United States believes the island's future is ill served by needless confrontations with Beijing. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Buying Spree And Inflation Hold Course

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
Everybody from the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, to the vacationing teacher with a 401(k) has been wondering lately how long the good times can last before inflation returns.
A while longer, it appears. According to data released yesterday by the Government, American consumers may have moderated their spending but are still on a buying spree. And prices, at least on the wholesale level, are still going nowhere. 
 Sales by stores, gas stations, car dealerships, restaurants and mail-order outlets -- which account for roughly 40 percent of what American consumers spend -- were up one-tenth of 1 percent last month. The gain came on top of increases in the previous two months that turned out to be even bigger than initially reported.
Retail sales other than cars and light trucks, which dipped after an enormous bulge in May, were up nearly half a percent, about as much as the month before.
At the same time, producer prices for finished goods fell one-tenth of a percent, the Labor Department reported. And to the surprise of most forecasters, who had been expecting a small increase in the "core" inflation rate, which excludes volatile food and energy prices, the index fell instead by two-tenths of a percent.
"What we've got is so much spending, so little inflation," said John Lonski, chief economist at Moody's Investor Service.
Despite the good news on inflation, the bond market fell slightly yesterday, apparently on worries that increases in commodity prices at earlier stages in the production pipeline may eventually lead to higher prices for finished goods. But there are several reasons to discount those fears, at least for now.
One month's numbers are never more than a tiny, and often unreliable, clue to the big picture. But the contrast between sales and prices is enough to produce profound cognitive dissonance.
Last quarter, sales at auto dealerships were up more than 8 percent from a year ago, but wholesale prices for passenger cars fell 1.3 percent last month. The nation's roads are jammed with sport utility vehicles, vans, pickups and other gas guzzlers, but gasoline prices dropped three-tenths of a percent. Appliance sales have been soaring in a hot housing market, but wholesale prices for dishwashers, dryers and the like were down six-tenths of a percent.
What's going on? Even though demand for everything from cellular phones to fall clothes is growing rapidly, so, apparently, is supply. And that means that many companies are in no position to take advantage of the situation by raising prices.
"The nearly unmatched vigor of consumer spending hasn't done much for the pricing power of American companies," Mr. Lonski said. "There's more than enough supply to meet the demand."
Not only is lingering weakness abroad producing a gusher of inexpensive imports, but the United States is awash in retail outlets, and more megastores and megamalls are being built to add to the already Darwinian competition among retailers.
The final verdict on inflation is never in, of course. The most important measure of inflation in June -- the Consumer Price Index, which covers services like health care, utilities, rent and education as well as items that people buy in stores -- is not due out until today.
Moreover, the few disquieting notes in the wholesale price report that were spotted by the bond market bear watching. In particular, prices for raw materials -- which include crude oil, ore and scrap, grain and the like -- were up, reflecting the world economy's becoming a bit firmer. And prices for intermediate goods like metals, plastics and chemicals jumped nearly half a percent in June. Indeed, after falling for 10 consecutive months through February, raw materials prices have been rising for the last four months.
"There's a clear inflection point," said William Dudley, chief economist at Goldman, Sachs.
Still, raw and even intermediate goods are only the beginning of a long chain that stretches from mines, farms and oilfields all the way to gas pumps and grocery stores. The critical question is whether companies at the end closest to the consumer can pass along higher input prices, or whether they will have to absorb them by holding the line elsewhere or taking lower profits.
"That depends on what happens to other costs," said Richard Rippe, chief economist at Prudential Securities. And so far they have been restrained. Pay increases, Mr. Rippe points out, have actually been a bit less generous in recent months. Productivity gains, meanwhile, have been strong. As a result, unit labor costs have been rising at an annual rate of less than 1 percent in non-financial corporations. At the same time, costs related to capital -- interest, depreciation and indirect business taxes -- have been falling.
Consumers, meanwhile, show few signs of flagging. Consumer spending has slowed since last winter, when it was growing at an annual rate of nearly 7 percent, but it has not slowed very much, only to about 4 percent. By any historical yardstick, that is still pretty rich.
Consumers are confident enough to spend plenty of time at the malls because jobs are plentiful. And with a record fraction of the population working, total wage and salary income rose to more than $4 trillion in 1998. Even more remarkable, household net worth grew more than $3 trillion last year.
The gains have kept coming. The latest reading for after-tax personal income shows that it is almost 4 percent higher than a year ago. And that is above and beyond inflation.
In short, not much is happening to discourage Americans from their favorite recreation. That is sure to keep Mr. Greenspan and everyone else scanning the inflation numbers anxiously for hints that things are not really as good as they look today.
