HEADLINE: Increase in Ford's Earnings Tops Wall Street Estimates

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., July 14

 BODY:
The American automobile market, widely dismissed a few years ago as too competitive and glutted to be profitable, carried the Ford Motor Company to earnings that were better than expected in the second quarter. Strong United States sales of high-profit sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks offset losses in South America and deteriorating results in Europe.
A $146 million one-time charge related to Ford's acquisition of Volvo's car making operations in March depressed earnings, which fell 1.8 percent from a year earlier, to $2.34 billion, or $1.89 per share. This was 4 cents better than the consensus estimate of Wall Street analysts, according to First Call. 
 Excluding the one-time charge, Ford's profits climbed to a record $2.48 billion, or $2 a share, from $2.38 billion, or $1.91 a share.
Wayne Booker, Ford's vice chairman and chief financial officer, predicted the good times would continue in the company's core American market. "I don't foresee a major decrease in demand taking place," he said.
Despite the positive results, Ford shares fell 56.25 cents, to $52.9375 on the New York Stock Exchange. The shares have suffered in recent months as higher interest rates have caused investors to worry that cars might become less affordable.
Ford's second-quarter sales rose 13.4 percent, to $42.28 billion from $37.3 billion, mainly because of the $6.5 billion Volvo acquisition but also because of rising sales of its own brands. The gain appeared large enough to make Ford bigger than DaimlerChrysler A.G. but not big enough to displace General Motors as the world's largest corporation in terms of sales.
This week's issue of Fortune magazine ranked G.M. first on its Global 500 list, followed by DaimlerChrysler and then Ford. But the rankings included the merger of Daimler-Benz and the Chrysler Corporation, which took place in November, but not the Ford acquisition of Volvo cars, which was concluded in March.
G.M. spun off its auto parts unit, Delphi Automotive Systems, in late May, which will shave its annual revenues by about $6 billion. But crippling strikes a year ago in Flint, Mich., cost the company up to $10 billion in sales, and labor experts predict that experience will not be repeated this year, allowing G.M.'s sales to rebound.
With G.M. scheduled to release its second-quarter figures next Tuesday, its officials declined to discuss today which company was bigger.
Ford has been reviewing for more than a year how it might spin off its automotive parts business, Visteon Automotive Systems. The company has not made any decisions, partly because it is negotiating a new national labor contract; the United Automobile Workers union's contracts with Ford, G.M. and DaimlerChrysler expire on Sept. 14.
"We have several alternatives on Visteon, and we haven't decided on any direction yet," Mr. Booker said in an interview today, adding that, "We believe we have some time to sort out what is the best alternative, whether it's continue as it is, a partial spinoff or some other alternative."
Visteon, which has begun reporting its results separately even though Ford still owns all of it, announced today that it had earned $282 million after taxes in the second quarter, up 17 percent from a year earlier. Sales rose 7 percent, to $5.1 billion.
Ford's overseas operations, once highly profitable, fared worse in the second quarter. In Europe, where fierce competition and stagnant demand have most auto makers struggling, profits shrank to $89 million from $310 million a year earlier, although $125 million of the drop came from the one-time Volvo charge.
In a statement, Ford acknowledged for the first time that it might not be able to turn around its European operations this year, as officials had previously predicted. "Although Volvo Car will contribute to operating earnings in 1999, it will be a challenge for Ford to achieve its full-year 1999 milestone for Europe, which is to grow earnings compared with 1998," the company said.
Continued economic troubles in South America, particularly Brazil, also hurt Ford. The company lost $120 million in the region in the second quarter, reversing a $14 million gain a year earlier.
Ford's profitability allowed the company to build its cash hoard to $23.96 billion, up from $22.28 billion a year earlier, despite a string of recent, small acquisitions in addition to the Volvo deal.
The key to that profitability lay in North America, where automotive operations produced $1.97 billion in after-tax earnings, an improvement of $314 million from the second quarter of 1998, when sales were also strong.
"I remember analysts' asking Ford Europe if they wanted to withdraw from North America," in the early 1980's, said Scott Merlis, a managing director at Wasserstein Perella Securities Inc. "Times change."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Cutting the tax oncapital gains: the theory and the evidence.

BYLINE: By Michael M. Weinstein 

 BODY:
CONGRESS is once again flirting with cutting the tax on capital gains, the profit from selling stocks, bonds and other investments. House Republicans, led by Bill Archer of Texas, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, have proposed lowering the top rate on capital gains to 15 percent from 20 percent as part of an $864 billion package of tax cuts spread over 10 years. The goal, they say, is to stimulate savings, investment and economic growth.
It's a nice-sounding theory. But many economists say it lacks credible evidence. Joel Slemrod, director of the Office of Tax Policy Research at the University of Michigan, speaks for many of his colleagues when he says that the "idea of cutting capital gains tax to move the economy significantly is implausible." The amount of taxes involved, which in typical years hovers between $20 billion and $50 billion, "is too small to shift an $8 trillion economy," he said. 
 For tax cuts to spur investment, people must save more and then turn more savings over to corporations for investment in plants, equipment or research and development. But Alan J. Auerbach, a professor of economics at the University of California at Berkeley and a former chief economist for the Joint Committee on Taxation, points out that much current savings is exempt from the capital gains tax. The tax does not hit pension funds or other nonprofit organizations. Nor does it affect most foreigners. Without a new wave of saving, there can be no new wave of investment.
For this and other reasons, Professor Auerbach says, "the impact of the capital gains tax is highly attenuated." Stocks held until death are exempt from the capital gains tax, which is watered down further by being imposed only after investments are sold. Investors who hold on to inflated stocks get to postpone paying taxes -- in effect, receiving an interest-free loan from the Government.
The capital gains tax, Professor Auerbach says, "affects investors who receive most of their profit from capital gains on stocks; but perhaps half of the nation's investment is financed with equity, half of the return on stocks comes from capital gains, and half of all equity is owned by taxable investors." In this situation, cutting the tax on capital gains cannot pack much of a wallop.
Professor Auerbach estimates that the proposal would raise the profit on investments by 1 percent to 2 percent at most. Too weak to encourage much future investment, the cut would do little more than provide windfall profit to investors for existing investments -- hardly, economists say, a smart use of taxpayer dollars.
Steven M. Fazzari of the Jerome Levy Economics Institute contends that the case for cutting the capital gains tax depends on three weak links. First, the tax cut must reduce the cost to investors of acquiring new plants and equipment. Second, investors must respond to cheaper capital by investing more. And finally, more capital equipment must translate into more output. Each of these steps, he says, is small.
According to Mr. Fazzari, a 30 percent cut in the capital gains tax -- more than Mr. Archer is proposing -- would be expected to reduce the total cost of acquiring plants and equipment by businesses by only about 2 percent. A 2 percent reduction in the cost of investment would lead to an increase of about five-tenths of a percent in the amount of new investment. And a five-tenths of a percent increase in new capital would translate into an increase of about sixteen-hundredths of a percent in economic output. The economic effect "would be minute," Mr. Fazzari says.
Professor Auerbach acknowledges that capital gains tax cuts can alter the timing of people's decisions to buy and sell stocks and bonds. Obvious proof was provided in 1986, when investors sold twice as many securities as expected in anticipation of higher rates that took effect the following year. But timing mostly affects when the Government collects revenue, not how much it eventually collects.
Sponsors of the tax cut say investors are locked into holding stocks they would sell if not for high taxes on profits. Perhaps so. But this "lock-in" effect has almost no effect on corporate investment. If Mr. Archer's tax-cut proposal encourages Harry to sell his Exxon stock to Sally for $1,000, the sale will not put a dime into Exxon's coffers.
There remains an issue of fairness. The proposal would overwhelmingly benefit the wealthy. Robert McIntyre, director of the Citizens for Tax Justice, estimates that the capital gains tax cut would be worth less than $20 for families earning $40,000 to $60,000 a year but more than $8,000 for families earning more than $300,000 a year.
If the tax cut would truly bolster economic growth, raising wages and reducing unemployment, then its skewed impact might be tolerated. In such case, the best option for Congress would be to pass the tax cut, reap the economy-wide benefits and find a way to raise taxes on wealthy families. But if Mr. Slemrod, Professor Auerbach and Mr. Fazzari are right, the tax would do little more than enrich the already rich.

HEADLINE: Clinton Joins in Gore's Call for Licensing of Gun Owners

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE, July 14

 BODY:
President Clinton today called for licensing of handgun owners and said the question before the nation was, "Will we have common-sense gun laws, or government by the gun lobby?"
Addressing a meeting of the Democratic Leadership Council, the centrist party group that the President credits with providing the values behind his Administration's policies, he said, "We ought to take the next step on licensing people who own handguns to make sure that they are trained to use the guns and that they should have them and that would solve all the loopholes because if you had a bad background you couldn't get a license, you couldn't own one." 
Mr. Clinton raised the issue in the context of praising Vice President Al Gore, who called for licensing of handgun owners on Monday, and said other Presidential candidates should follow Mr. Gore's example of making specific promises.
"You probably ought to tell people what you're going to do when you get the job, and then you would be more likely to do it," he said.
While he appeared to acknowledge the difficulty of enacting such legislation, something he said three weeks ago Congress would not pass, he told his audience that his success in balancing the budget showed that "we can do things that are not imaginable at the moment if we will have good ideas and work on them in a disciplined way."
Mr. Clinton gave the Vice President another lift when the White House announced that he would join in five fund-raising events for the Gore campaign, one in Arkansas on Aug. 7 and four in Washington, two on Aug. 10 and two on Sept. 23.
Though the President discussed his latest budget proposal and the need for the nation to help the poorest of its citizens, campaign politics was plainly on his mind. He began his remarks by offering a dismissive interpretation of "compassionate conservatism," the term Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the front-runner in the race for the Republican Presidential nomination in 2000, uses to describe his approach to government and politics.
Mr. Clinton said: "This 'compassionate conservatism' has a great ring to it, you know. It sounds so good. And I've really worked hard to try to figure out what it means. I mean, I made an honest effort.
"And as near as I can tell, here's what it means -- it means: 'I like you, I do. And I would like to be for the patients' bill of rights, and I'd like to be for closing the gun-show loophole, and I'd like not to squander the surplus and save Social Security and Medicare for the next generation. I'd like to raise the minimum wage. I'd like to do these things. But I just can't, and I feel terrible about it.' "
The President also raised another likely Democratic campaign theme when he recalled the Administration of President George Bush, the Governor's father. "We may have to remind our fellow citizens in times to come just what it was like back then -- how high the unemployment was, how stagnant the wages were, how steeply growing the inequality was, how fast the social conditions were worsening."
Governor Bush himself arrived in Baltimore as Mr. Clinton was leaving and tying up downtown traffic for 40 minutes. The Governor visited an inner-city school, where a student asked him if he would support an increase in the minimum wage. He did not answer directly, but he said he was worried about "pricing people out of work."
When the President turned to poverty, he announced a change in food stamp rules that Agriculture Department aides said could add 22,000 recipients to the current total of 18 million. The rule change would allow food stamps to people who own a car.
The conference itself, billed as a "national conversation" involving 170 elected officials who are allied with the Democratic Leadership Conference, also dealt with poverty more than the group often has in the past, when critics like the Rev. Jesse Jackson said the initials stood for "Democratic Leisure Class."
Lieut. Gov. Kathleen Kennedy Townsend of Maryland told the group it was time to "redirect our efforts, over and over again, to expand the winner's circle" to help those areas that had not shared in the nation's prosperity.
"In the hollows of Appalachia, the migrant worker camps of California and the row-house blocks of East Baltimore," she said, "there is still enormous poverty in our country."
Another voice was sounded for the poor by Mayor Jesse Norwood of Prichard, Ala., who is president of the Conference of African-American Mayors. He complained that the Internet's growth had bypassed poor rural areas, and said that in his city of 34,000 people, "we are no longer interested in the photo ops with no money."
But Mr. Norwood also said that in keeping with the leadership group's philosophy, it was up to local leaders to take charge of their situation. "We can't wait on Washington to give us a grant or give us a loan," he said.

HEADLINE: Con Ed Questioned at Hearing on Blackout

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
The 18-hour blackout in northern Manhattan last week has raised serious questions about whether Consolidated Edison's network of underground power cables can handle New York City's growing demands for electricity, the director of the Mayor's Office of Emergency Management said yesterday.
The director, Jerome M. Hauer, voiced his concerns in testimony before the City Council's Consumer Affairs Committee, which yesterday held the first government hearing on the blackout and other power failures that occurred after electrical demand surged during last week's heat wave. 
 Earlier in the hearing, the chairman of Con Edison, Eugene R. McGrath, confirmed that repeated failures of underground power lines, called feeder cables, led to the blackout. As Con Ed workers were trying to bring two repaired feeder cables back on line, the cables caught fire, forcing the utility to shut off all power north of 155th Street in Manhattan.
More than 200,000 people in Washington Heights and Inwood lost power shortly after 10 P.M. on July 6, at the height of a blistering three-day heat wave during which temperatures climbed to more than 100 degrees.
At yesterday's hearing, several Council members, including the Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, said they were concerned that Con Edison had not adequately bolstered its infrastructure to accommodate the city's increasing needs.
Mr. Hauer, the city's disaster manager, agreed.
"I think that is basically the heart of the concerns that we all have about what went on in Washington Heights," Mr. Hauer testified. "As neighborhoods have grown, as they have become so vital around the city and we have seen new developments and new businesses, has the infrastructure kept up with it?"
Mr. McGrath, in his testimony and in response to questions, explained that Con Edison determines how many feeder cables to use in each of its networks based on complex calculations that take into account the peak energy demand in the preceding summer, as well as historic weather trends and an analysis of changing demographics and economic factors in the area.
Con Edison is considered one of the most reliable utility companies in the world, and when Mr. Vallone suggested at one point that energy companies in the South were better equipped, Mr. McGrath took exception. "Excuse me," he said, "No one has a more reliable cable system in the world than we have."
Mr. Hauer also sharply criticized Con Edison for giving the city conflicting information about the status of emergency repairs in the hours preceding the blackout.
"I think we need to have one voice from Con Ed because we were getting a number of different analyses of what was going on, particularly in Washington Heights," Mr. Hauer said. "I'd like to understand why there was the difference of opinion in Con Ed as to how the system was functioning."
Yesterday's hearing was the first of several government inquiries scheduled in response to last week's blackout. Today, the New York State Assembly is to hold a similar hearing with many of the same officials, including Mr. McGrath, expected to testify.
While energy experts have recently warned that the power systems in the New York City area are quickly approaching their physical limits and may soon be unable to generate enough electricity to meet the city's needs, Mr. McGrath testified yesterday that the blackout last week was not a result of an inadequate energy supply but of repeated failures in the utility's distribution infrastructure.
Comparing the electrical supply to the water supply to help illustrate his point, Mr. McGrath likened the breakdown of feeder cables last week to a water main break that causes a temporary, localized interruption of service, as opposed to a drought situation in which there is not enough water in a reservoir to meet customer demand.
But his explanation, delivered in a matter-of-fact and unapologetic tone, was not appreciated by Council members, who repeatedly demanded to know specific information about maintenance and inspections of the nearly 90,000 miles of feeder cables all across the city.
While many people in the neighborhoods of northern Manhattan had questioned whether Con Edison had chosen to cut off power to a mostly poor and minority area of the city, the Council members seemed to accept the company's explanation that it could not have chosen to shut off power elsewhere.
Instead, the Council members focused their questions on why the Washington Heights network was served by only 14 feeder cables and whether the number of cables should be increased. "Who made the decision that only 14 feeder cables should service Washington Heights?" Mr. Vallone asked.
Consolidated Edison has appointed a three-member independent panel to review the blackout and to determine the precise reasons why the feeder cables in Washington Heights failed. Joe Petta, a spokesman for Con Edison, said the panel would also examine whether the appropriate number of cables had been in use in Washington Heights and what changes should be made to prevent future blackouts.
In addition to hearing Mr. McGrath and Mr. Hauer, the Council heard testimony from several residents of Washington Heights as well as local business owners and officials from the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, which was one of the largest customers to lose power.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has criticized Con Edison repeatedly since the blackout and has said the city will file a lawsuit against the utility seeking to recover damages both for the city and its residents. Michael D. Hess, the city's Corporation Counsel, said the city planned to file the suit today.
And yesterday, Mr. Giuliani continued his attacks on Con Edison's response as too passive.
"What Con Edison should be saying is here are the things that have to be done to make it virtually impossible for blackouts to take place," he said. "We need more power. We need to purchase more power. We need more alternatives. We need a more modern infrastructure, meaning we have to improve the feeder cables so we have better material. We need to insulate them better."

HEADLINE: Working Mother Regains Custody of Two Children

BYLINE: By MELODY PETERSEN 

 BODY:
A Florida appeals court overturned an earlier decision yesterday that had denied a Miami lawyer and mother primary custody of her two children because she worked long hours.
As a result of the ruling, the lawyer, Alice Hector, will regain primary custody of her two young girls from her former husband, Bob Young. 
 Mr. Young, an architect who had been unemployed for several years, had argued that he should be given custody of the two girls because he had spent more time with them than his former-wife, who often worked late as a partner at Steel, Hector & Davis, a Miami law firm. Ms. Hector's uncle is a partner of the firm.
Barbara Green, Mr. Young's lawyer, said yesterday that Mr. Young would try to appeal the decision. "I know the court worked hard on this decision," she said, "but we think it is very wrong."
Neither Mr. Young nor Ms. Hector could be reached for comment.
Seven judges on the 10-judge appeals panel ruled yesterday that the trial court that had originally heard the custody battle had been correct when it awarded primary custody of the girls to Ms. Hector.
The majority disagreed with Mr. Young's contention that the trial court had favored awarding the children to Ms. Hector simply because she was a woman.
Mr. Young had argued that the trial court had discriminated against him and all stay-at-home fathers. "Dads can be moms, too," he had said last year.
But last year, when the appeals panel overturned the trial court's decision, Ms. Hector had said that she believed that the three-man panel took a hard stand against her simply because she was a mother pursuing a challenging career. She insisted that despite her demanding job, she spent more time with the two girls than her former husband did.
Last year, Ms. Hector quit her job at Steel, Hector and opened her own small firm so that she could work more flexible hours.
Mr. Young is a senior program director at the Y.M.C.A. of Greater Miami.
The majority on the appeals court said that the trial court was correct when it relied on evidence suggesting that Ms. Hector had been a constant and dominant influence in the children's lives, while Mr. Young had not. When the two girls were very young, Mr. Young had been away from home for months at a time, settling business matters and hunting for gold believed buried in the desert.
But in recent years, Mr. Young had been a volunteer at the girls' school, founded a Brownie troop and coached the soccer team.
The three judges who dissented yesterday were the same three who had ruled against Ms. Hector last year. In his dissent, Alan R. Schwartz, the chief judge of the Third District state appeals court, said, "there was no question" that the trial court's decision had been "dictated by the evil of gender bias."
Judge Schwartz said that if the genders of the "hard-working and high-earning lawyer and the stay-at- home architect" had been reversed, "the male attorney's claim for custody would have been virtually laughed out of court."

HEADLINE: State Auditors to Examine Books of Distressed City

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: EAST ORANGE, N.J., July 14

 BODY:
State officials have begun auditing the books of this financially struggling city as a prelude to providing $7 million to close the city's budget gap and ordering reforms intended to balance future budgets.
East Orange is one of five economically distressed cities eligible this year for a recently re-enacted type of state aid. The other cities are Jersey City, Paterson, Camden and Irvington, where state audits are to begin soon. 
 Getting the assistance requires intense study of a city's fiscal practices by the state's Division of Community Services.
The state's involvement with the municipalities' finances falls far short of the kind of daily supervision of spending and even policymaking that cities such as New York and Yonkers experienced in the 1970's, when budget deficits prevented them from borrowing money to meet expenses.
Nevertheless, the state's role is considered strong fiscal medicine from the administration of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman because it requires the municipalities not only to open their books to the state but to accept any financial reforms the Division of Community Services orders after seeing the cities' records.
"This is about oversight and accountability, not state control," said Julie Tripodi, the assistant director of local government services of the Division of Community Services, who met with East Orange officials on Tuesday. "All five of these towns have immediate budget problems and were not able to put together a balanced budget this year without an infusion of cash. And there were conditions attached to that cash."
She said the meeting with East Orange officials was the first among the sessions the division plans to hold with officials in all five cities, which are eligible for special allotments totaling $40.5 million set aside in the most recent state budget.
Robert Bowser, the Mayor of East Orange, said in an interview that he welcomed the state's review of the city's $120 million budget and any recommendations for fiscal reform from the state agency.
"These are very experienced people who have worked with urban areas, and if their ideas are better than ours, then we'll do it," he said. "But this administration has a five-year plan that we need to implement, and I am sure some of those things are going to be similar to what the state calls for."
Mr. Bowser said he hoped recommendations from the state agency would resolve political disputes between him and his opponents on the 10-member City Council, who he said had undercut initiatives he had proposed to close the budget gaps he inherited.
The mayor's major proposal for balancing the budget is to sell water to other localities and to bill the individual customers for those localities.
Councilman Mark Scotland, one of Mayor Bowser's opponents, also said he hoped an outside auditor could resolve differences among officials, although he said he expected the auditors to embrace the Council's approach to the city's financial problems.
The aid is provided under the state's Distressed Cities Act, which was passed in 1986 under the administration of former Gov. Thomas Kean to deal with the state's older, more urbanized areas' long-term financial problems. The act provided state aid to dozens of municipalities suffering from declines in tax revenues in the midst of increasing spending needs, in return for state-supervised spending and management reforms.
The program was replaced in the early 1990's by Gov. Jim Florio with a supplemental assistance program that had no spending and budgeting reform conditions attached to it, but the 1986 program was re-enacted last month.
Ms. Tripodi said she could not predict when the audits would be completed or the kinds of recommendations the auditors might make. Everything will be reviewed, she said.
In the past, the overseers have required municipalities to eliminate jobs, reduce services, reform purchasing and investment practices, and change fees for services as diverse as parks and parking.

Morgan Stanley Won't Be Charged
Morgan Stanley Dean Witter will not face criminal charges for its conduct in the arrest of a former employee, the Manhattan District Attorney said. The Wall Street firm, which paid $10,000 to a confidential informant who helped set up a police sting operation against the employee, Christian L. Curry, still faces a discrimination suit filed by Mr. Curry. C9.
 
Tests Show Light Trucks Can Tip
Regulators said that nearly 100 tests on a dozen automobiles showed that sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks sometimes tipped up on two wheels during very sharp turns and that cars almost never did. A21.
 
Nasdaq Hits Record, but Dow Falls
Led by Intel, the Nasdaq composite index rose to a record, climbing 39.90 points, to 2,818.13. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 4.61 points, to 1,398.17. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 26.92 points, to 11,148.10. C10.
 
New Airline to Call Itself Jetblue
The proposed start-up airline that had been using the name New Air as a place holder for the last six months announced that it would begin service early next year as Jetblue Airways. David Neeleman, the airline's chief executive, also outlined the features that he said would set Jetblue apart from its competitors, including fares averaging 65 percent less than those of competing airlines and the latest computerized reservations and check-in systems. C9.
 
House Committee Approves Tax Cut
The House Ways and Means Committee approved a measure that would reduce taxes by $864 billion over the next 10 years, brushing aside the threat of a veto. A21.
 
As part of the tax-cut plan, the top rate on capital gains would drop to 15 percent from 20 percent. Sponsors say the cut would stimulate economic growth, but economists are skeptical. Michael M. Weinstein: Economic Scene. C2.
 
Earnings Increase at Time Warner
Time Warner's second-quarter net income rose to $575 million from $23 million in the period a year earlier. Combined cash flow for Time Warner and Time Warner Entertainment rose 74 percent, to $2.02 billion. C8.
 
Retirees' Group Ends I.R.S. Dispute
The American Association of Retired Persons named a chief executive to a new taxable subsidiary, ending a dispute with the Internal Revenue Service that clears the way for the nonprofit group to enter new ventures. C9.

HEADLINE: Work on Weapons Affected Health, Government Admits

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 14

 BODY:
For the first time, the Federal Government is acknowledging that nuclear weapons production during the cold war may have caused illnesses in thousands of workers, and the Clinton Administration on Thursday will announce legislation that would compensate many of them for their medical care and lost wages.
Energy Secretary Bill Richardson detailed the legislation today in an interview, in which he depicted the workers as victims of the cold war and the rush to produce nuclear weapons. He said the safety standards, which had evolved since the 1940's, had been established in good faith but have since been deemed too weak to have protected workers. 
 The workers suffered from cancers and lung diseases after exposure to beryllium, asbestos, mercury, uranium and other materials, under safety standards set by the Energy Department and its predecessor, the Atomic Energy Commission.
"I am reversing a policy of denial of compensation," Mr. Richardson said.
He noted that the workers who had actually operated the Government factories were almost all employees of private contractors and thus were not eligible for the worker's compensation program that applies to Federal employees. And they were usually unable to collect under state programs because those were designed for injuries, not occupational illnesses.
A handful of Energy Department workers at the plants have fallen ill and have collected worker's compensation, said department officials, but that compensation program is run by the Department of Labor on a no-fault basis, requiring only a determination that the employee was exposed at work. The Energy Department has never acknowledged the cause of their illnesses.
The Clinton Administration will send legislation to Congress within weeks proposing compensation for victims of beryllium disease, a clear-cut case because the weapons program is almost the only user of beryllium.
Energy Department officials have estimated that compensation for those exposed to beryllium, some of whom suffer from a chronic, incurable, obstructive lung disease, will be about $15 million a year at its peak in a few years, when all those eligible are expected to have applied. Officials estimate that 500 to 1,000 people have beryllium disease or will develop it. Their compensation would depend on their lost wages and the extent of their disability.
An undetermined number of families would be eligible to collect benefits for deceased workers.
The Government will also study how to compensate people exposed to asbestos and radioactive materials. Radiation poses a particular challenge, because it causes diseases like leukemia and cancers that also have other causes, and the amount of radiation needed to cause a disease is in dispute.
Several people involved in the formation of the policy said that the Energy Department had originally favored including people exposed to radiation and other threats, but that the White House had demanded further study. President Clinton is expected to announce on Thursday that the National Economic Council will lead an inter-agency study, to be completed by April, on whether other illnesses should be included.
Representative Paul E. Kanjorski, a Democrat who has been seeking help for men who live in his northeast Pennsylvania district who had worked for a company processing beryllium, said that including exposure to other hazards might double the cost, to about $30 million a year.
Mr. Kanjorski said the action represented a major shift in Energy Department policy. "It's unique in terms of the department's normal mode of operating; it wasn't a knee-jerk 'No, find ways to defend against it,' " said Mr. Kanjorski.
The workers are mostly men in their 50's or older who spent decades in skilled blue-collar employment, from the World War II Manhattan Project to the present.
About 9,000 workers have already been screened, and at least 5,000 more will be, according to department officials, with hundreds showing job-related health problems.
Some work or worked at plants that date from the World War II effort to build the bomb, like Oak Ridge in Tennessee; others worked or still work at the Nevada Test Site, near Las Vegas; the Hanford nuclear reservation, in Washington State; Rocky Flats, near Denver; the Idaho National Environmental Engineering Laboratory, near Idaho Springs; Los Alamos National Laboratory, and the Savannah River Site, near Aiken, S.C.
At the Paper, Allied-Industrial, Chemical & Energy Workers International Union, which includes the former Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers union, Richard D. Miller, a policy analyst, said that "the Secretary has done an enormous public service by admitting the department has made people sick in the process of making nuclear weapons."
He said that the White House should have moved immediately to compensate those made ill by other agents besides beryllium.
Under the Administration proposal, people exposed to beryllium would apply for compensation as if they were Federal employees. As with the state programs, Federal worker's compensation limits payments to medical costs and lost wages; punitive damages are not allowed.
But unlike the state systems, the Federal system has no statute of limitations. Mr. Kanjorski, for example, said that the Pennsylvania program required filing within 300 weeks -- about 6 years -- but that some people had not developed symptoms in that period. Some states only allow for damages for people who have missed work, department officials said, while some victims have incurred medical costs but are still well enough to work. Other states do not allow people to file for greater levels of disability as their diseases progress. And most cap payments for lost wages at well below what the employees were paid.
Alfred F. Matusick, of West Hazleton, Pa., said he began having lung problems within two months of beginning work at the Beryllium Corporation, in Ashmore, where he worked from 1957 until it closed in 1981. Now, Mr. Matusick, 67, said, he gets up several times each night to take cough medicine, and cannot carry a grocery bag or walk more than a few yards without strain.
Mr. Matusick, who over the years operated furnaces, inspected beryllium products and did other jobs at the plant, thought of leaving. "But where else was I going to go?" he said. "Nobody else would hire you if they took X-rays of your lungs, or they found out that you worked for the Beryllium Corporation." He appealed to Mr. Kanjorski for help.

HEADLINE: Pataki Is Target in Bid to Expand Medicaid for Working Poor

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
Under a little-known provision in the 1996 Federal welfare law, New York has become eligible to receive several hundred million dollars a year from Washington to expand Medicaid coverage for one of its fastest-growing and most troubling uninsured populations: low-income working parents.
But while nine other states, including Connecticut, have quietly begun to take advantage of the rule -- under which the Federal Government shoulders at least half of the states' costs for expanding the program -- New York has not. And so a broad alliance of hospitals, unions and advocates for the poor is coalescing to pressure Gov. George E. Pataki to use state money to prompt the release of Federal matching funds. 
 The lobbying campaign will focus on the state's $25 billion share of the national tobacco settlement, which the Democrats who control the State Assembly want to see used mostly to expand coverage for the uninsured. In this way, money would be directed toward the problem without increasing Medicaid expenses in the state budget.
But Governor Pataki has advocated using most of the tobacco money to help reduce state debt, and spending only about $100 million a year on health-related expenses. Only part of that -- Mr. Pataki has not specified the amount -- is planned to help the uninsured.
Many experts believe that the problem will require much more money than the Governor is planning to commit. A study of the issue released this week by the Commonwealth Fund, a private philanthropic and research organization in New York, estimated that 266,000 working poor parents are ineligible for Medicaid and do not get coverage at work, though their children still qualify for public health-care coverage.
To cover all those parents, the state would need to spend about $420 million a year, an amount the Federal Government would be required to match, said Assemblyman Richard N. Gottfried, chairman of the Health Committee. Mr. Gottfried, a Manhattan Democrat, is a sponsor of a bill passed by the Assembly last month that would tap into the Federal Medicaid money by using tobacco money, which is to be paid to the states over 25 years to compensate for money spent treating tobacco-related illnesses. The plan has received some support from Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, who had once advocated using most of the tobacco money for tax cuts.
"Even if you look at this strictly as an economic issue," Mr. Gottfried said, "bringing in almost half a billion in Federal money with no extra burden on New York taxpayers is pretty compelling. But these are also people we should be helping."
Most troubling for New York and other states is that the uninsured people are doing exactly what many states want them to do: getting jobs instead of going on welfare. But in doing so, they fall into a health-care limbo.
They are people like Martilde Ramirez, a 30-year-old Brooklyn woman, who could have gone on welfare when her husband left several years ago. Instead, she got a job at a hat factory in Bushwick, Brooklyn, where she makes $5.40 an hour, barely enough to raise her three children, but too much to qualify for Medicaid. She does not get health insurance through her job, she said.
On Tuesday, she took her 1-year-old son, Angel Aguilar, to get inoculations at Woodhull Hospital in Brooklyn, where his bills are paid by a state-Federal health care program for children. But Ms. Ramirez, who emigrated from Mexico nine years ago, has not seen a doctor since shortly after she gave birth. Before that, she went for three years without seeing a doctor.
"If I get sick," she said in Spanish, through a translator, "then I think I will just have to go back to my country."
Dennis Rivera, president of the union that represents 150,000 health care workers, said the union will join health-care advocates and state hospital and community clinic groups in a campaign to pressure the Pataki administration to use much more of the tobacco money for the uninsured.
"We've got to organize that majority sentiment to exert pressure on the elected officials to do the right thing," Mr. Rivera said. "All the participants agree that some share of it should be used, but the question is how much."
Joseph Conway, a spokesman for the Governor's budget office, said, "The Governor has proposed using a portion of the tobacco settlement proceeds to address health-care-related issues, such as the uninsured and underinsured." He declined to say whether that portion will be any larger than what the Governor has already proposed. "At this point that's a matter that's going to be discussed with the Legislature," he said.
The predicament of the uninsured working poor is a daunting one for states as they scale back welfare because the lack of health care discourages parents from getting jobs. The Commonwealth Fund study, conducted with the help of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a Washington research and advocacy group, found that in New York State, low-income working parents are twice as likely to lack health coverage as those who are not working.
The states that have begun to tap into the Federal Medicaid money over the last year -- Connecticut, California, Rhode Island, Wisconsin, Missouri, Oklahoma, Ohio, Pennsylvania and Maine, along with the District of Columbia -- have often done so as part of comprehensive programs to encourage people to leave welfare and get jobs. The program does not set a limit on how high states can set eligibility limits for Medicaid, but will match whatever the states are willing to pay.
"It isn't that well known," said Tricia Leddy, an administrator for the Center for Child and Family Health in Rhode Island, which oversees Medicaid programs. "But it is very broad. You could drive a truck through it."
Most of the states began programs last year after the Federal Government began to encourage states to take advantage of the provision.
Rhode Island used the program to extend coverage beginning last November to parents earning up to 185 percent of the Federal poverty level -- which usually means, depending on family size, workers earning in the high teens. In the first eight months of the program, 8,500 parents signed up, costing Rhode Island about $2.35 million and the Federal Government $2.75 million.
The New York Assembly bill would extend coverage to working parents making up to 200 percent of the Federal poverty level -- or about $27,600 for a family of three.
The growing number of uninsured people in the state -- mostly the working poor, students, children and early retirees -- has become the biggest problem facing the health care industry. About 17 percent of people under 65 lack health insurance nationwide, but the number in New York is 19 percent -- roughly three million people -- and growing faster than the national average.
According to the New York State Health Department, city hospitals provided $1.2 billion in care to those who could not pay in 1997, the last year for which figures are available. The same year, the state collected, through taxes on hospitals and insurers, only $635 million in a charity pool used to compensate hospitals for such care.
Because of the shortfall, hospitals and clinics are forced to shift charity care costs onto patients with insurance, driving up health-care costs for businesses and prompting many small businesses to cancel coverage -- adding, in turn, to the problem.

HEADLINE: Bush Adds $800,000 to Election Bank Account in Sweep Through Washington Area

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 14

 BODY:
Campaigning within a few miles of the White House, George W. Bush swept through the capital region today, picking up $800,000 in contributions, winning the endorsement of a Republican rival and promising the nation "a fresh start after a season of cynicism."
Mr. Bush, the Governor of Texas, tried to walk the thin line between humility and confidence that he would win his party's Presidential nomination. 
 "I'm running with one thing in mind -- I'm running to win," he told more than 500 people who raised $400,000 for him at a luncheon at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in McLean, Va., "I intend to become the next President of the United States."
He later gladly accepted the endorsement of Representative John R. Kasich, the Ohio Republican who dropped out of the Presidential race today. Mr. Bush told Mr. Kasich he would "fit perfectly on my team," and, "I intend to use you."
Aides to Mr. Kasich said that once Bush officials heard in the last few days that Mr. Kasich planned to abandon his Presidential bid, they sought his immediate endorsement, fueling speculation that Mr. Kasich's ready compliance would make him eligible for a post in a Bush Administration.
Mr. Kasich joins a stampede of 122 Republicans of the 223 in the House who have endorsed Mr. Bush. Asked at a news conference in Washington what Mr. Kasich's chances were of becoming his running mate, Mr. Bush told reporters, "They just increased."
At the fund-raising luncheon attended by executives from the high-tech industry, Mr. Bush discussed his economic philosophy. The luncheon attracted luminaries such as the America Online's chairman and chief executive, Steve Case.
"You and I know that governments don't create wealth," Mr. Bush said. "Wealth is created by entrepreneurs and dreamers and doers and people who are willing to risk capital. The role of government is to create an environment in which entrepreneurship can flourish."
He said he would encourage the entrepreneurial spirit by reducing the marginal tax rates, cutting regulations, ending tariffs, rebuilding the nation's military power and curbing trial lawyers by enacting "long-lasting, meaningful, real tort reform."
After the Kasich endorsement in Washington, Mr. Bush moved on to Baltimore, where he promoted his belief in church-based programs to help children avoid lives of crime and drugs. He then attended another fund-raiser that brought in $400,000, making his total take for about five hours to about $800,000. That will be added to the record-breaking $36 million he has already collected.
Mr. Bush's supporters sought to play down any notion that they are taking his nomination for granted. The biggest danger to his campaign, his backers said, aside from the wealth of the rival party candidate Steve Forbes, is the air of inevitability that could irk some voters into thinking that they never had a voice in their party's nomination.
Vice President Al Gore, the front-running Democrat, picked up on that theme today, chiding Mr. Bush as being "ready to move into the mansion before the election."
"Bush has to win the nomination," said Haley Barbour, former chairman of the Republican National Committee and now a lobbyist and Bush backer, as he watched Mr. Kasich endorse the Governor. "He's not going to get it on a silver platter."

HEADLINE: World Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

THE AMERICAS
 
PERU: REBEL CHIEF SEIZED
The army announced that it had captured the last remaining commander of the Shining Path guerrilla group not already in jail after a patrol spotted him near Huancayo, in the jungles of central Huancayo Province. Oscar Ramirez Durand, left, who goes by the nom de guerre Comrade Feliciano, took over the Maoist group after the capture of Abimael Guzman in 1992. The group has been in a decline since Mr. Guzman's arrest and is now making only occasional hit-and-run attacks. Clifford Krauss (NYT)
 
ARGENTINA: LIFE TERMS SOUGHT IN '94 BLAST
A prosecutor sought life sentences for 19 people, including 10 former police officers, accused of being accomplices in the 1994 bombing of a Jewish center that killed 86 people. The prosecutor said he would be ready to present his case in two months. The United States and Israel have said they believe Iranian-back Islamic terrorists were behind the attack. Clifford Krauss (NYT) 

ECUADOR: EMERGENCY REIMPOSED
Raising the stakes in an increasingly bitter struggle for dominance, President Jamal Mahuad has reimposed a 60-day state of national emergency overturned by the opposition-controlled Congress. With a nationwide transport workers' strike well into its second week despite a rollback of an increase in fuel prices that set off the protests, and some areas running short of food and other supplies, Mr. Mahuad said "the gravity of the country's situation" required that he be given special powers. Larry Rohter (NYT)
 
MEXICO: MAYOR ASSOCIATE RANSOMED
Jesus Ortega, a close political associate of Mexico City's Mayor, Cuauhtemoc Cardenas Solorzano, was kidnapped off the street near his home and released several hours later when his wife paid a ransom of about $1,000. Mr. Ortega suffered the "express" kidnapping, a common form of crime in the capital, on the day when Mr. Cardenas opened a campaign to publicize his efforts to reduce crime. Julia Preston (NYT)
 
MEXICO: BANK CLEARED BY U.S.
Civil money laundering charges against Grupo Financiero Banorte S.A., Mexico's fifth largest financial group, were dismissed by a United States District Court judge, the first full exoneration of a Mexican bank in an investigation called Operation Casablanca. The United States has agreed to return $1.4 million in seized assets to Banorte and $200,000 to a subsidiary. Rick Wills (NYT)
 
EUROPE
 
FRANCE: CHIRAC TO STAY TILL 2002
France's Gaullist President, Jacques Chirac, said in a Bastille Day television interview that he would serve out his full seven-year term, ending in May 2002, despite the problems of sharing power with a Socialist-led Government since 1997. Mr. Chirac refused to say if he was thinking of running for a second term in 2002, when the Socialist Prime Minister, Lionel Jospin, is expected to run against him. Craig R. Whitney (NYT)
 
SPAIN: A JOINT PUSH FOR DEMOCRACY
Five foundations linked to the ruling conservative Popular Party or the opposition Socialist Party set up the Spanish Commission to Support Democracy, which aims to promote democracy in developing nations with projects like bringing 200 leftist guerrillas from Colombia to study in Spain. The National Endowment for Democracy, in Washington, supported the move, seen as a sign that Spain's democracy is secure 23 years after Francisco Franco died. Al Goodman (NYT)
 
SWITZERLAND: RUSSIAN INVESTIGATED
Geneva authorities have begun an investigation into money laundering allegations against a Russian presidential aide, Pavel Borodin. A judge said Swiss banks had been ordered to freeze any accounts held by Mr. Borodin, his wife and 22 other Russians who may be involved in the scandal. Also under investigation is the Swiss construction company Mabetex, which is accused of paying bribes in return for a $300 million renovation at the Kremlin. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)
 
KAZAKHSTAN, RUSSIA: SPACE BAN EASED
Kazakhstan eased a ban on space launchings from its Baikonur cosmodrome, clearing the way for Russia to send a cargo craft with vital supplies to the Mir manned space station. The ban remains in force only for rocket boosters of the type that crashed after takeoff on July 5 and prompted the former Soviet republic to temporarily suspend all launchings. (Reuters)
 
ASIA
 
INDONESIA: ELECTION RESULTS DUE
Tentative results from Indonesia's June parliamentary election will finally be ready today, more than five weeks after polling day, election officials said. The National Elections Committee said it had counted votes from 26 of the country's 27 provinces. A final result is due next Wednesday. (Reuters)
 
AZERBAIJAN, ARMENIA: 2 LEADERS TO MEET
President Heydar Aliyev of Azerbaijan will fly to Geneva today for one-day talks with his Armenian counterpart, Robert Kocharian, on the conflict over Nagorno-Karabakh, Azerbaijani officials said. Armenians and Azerbaijanis fought an undeclared war over Nagorno-Karabakh, an Armenian-populated territory within Azerbaijan that ended with a cease-fire in May 1994 after six years. (Agence France-Presse)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
IRAQ: ARMS TEAM ARRIVES
A team of inspectors from the Organization for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, an international group based in The Hague that monitors chemical weapons agreements, arrived in Baghdad to help the United Nations dismantle a laboratory that contains tiny amounts of mustard agents and other chemicals. The group lent its inspectors for the mission after Iraq refused to accept inspectors from the United Nations Special Commission charged with disarming Iraq of unconventional weapons. Judith Miller (NYT)
 
IRAQ: NEW U.S. ATTACKS
United States warplanes bombed Iraqi defense sites in the northern no-flight zone after being fired on by Iraqi antiaircraft artillery, the United States European Command in Stuttgart said. It was the 60th time since the end of last year that Air Force planes have struck Iraqi installations in the north in response to reported Iraqi threats. (AP)
 
ISRAEL: ARAB NAMED TO KEY PANEL
An Israeli Arab lawmaker was appointed for the first time to the Israeli Parliament's Foreign Affairs and Security Committee, breaking a longstanding ban on Arab membership. Hashem Mahameed, of the United Arab List faction, was named to the panel over the protests of the rightist Likud Party, which called his admission a security risk. Joel Greenberg (NYT)
 
SYRIA: AMNESTY FOR THOUSANDS
More than 150,000 prisoners, most held for cheating on food rations, will be freed under an amnesty by President Hafez al-Assad, the London-based daily Al Hayat reported. Other crimes covered by the amnesty include desertion from the military, smuggling, foreign exchange violations and economic offenses. (AP)
 
AFRICA
 
ALGERIA: O.A.U. MEETING ENDS
African heads of state vowed to end the conflicts that have sapped the continent's human and material resources as they ended a three-day summit meeting of the Organization of African Unity. A final declaration referred to conflicts in the Horn of Africa, Congo, Sierra Leone, Sudan, Burundi, Angola and Somalia, among others, as "many time bombs" left over from the colonial era. But it said the 52 member states did not intend to shirk their responsibility for problems "still bedeviling our countries." (AP)
 
UNITED NATIONS
 
TALKS ON EAST TIMOR
With violence threatening to delay a vote on the future of East Timor, the United Nations called officials from Indonesia and Portugal to another round of talks in New York for today and Friday. A spokesman said Nugroho Wisnumurti of Indonesia and Fernando Neves of Portugal, both senior foreign ministry officials, would also discuss what happens after the vote, to be held either Aug. 21 or 22. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: In Japan, Mired in Recession, Suicides Soar

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, July 14

 BODY:
In their annual sweep of the Aokigahara woods at the end of last year, police officers found 73 bodies.
There is nothing unusual about finding bodies in Aokigahara. The lush and sprawling forest nestled at the foot of Mount Fuji has long been one of the most popular places in Japan for suicides. What is different now is the number: a year earlier, the police recovered 55 bodies. 
 Japanese are killing themselves in record numbers.
Some 90 people a day committed suicide last year, a 34.7 percent rise over the previous year, according to statistics from the National Police Agency that provoked the Asahi Shimbun, one of Japan's leading daily newspapers, to declare the situation an "emergency."
Japan's economic recession, and the shame and stress caused by layoffs or the fear of them, are largely to blame, most experts say, although suicides often stem from a combination of factors, among them depression.
Japanese are grappling with unemployment that has risen to record levels as struggling companies slash their work forces and cut back on hiring new graduates in an effort to bring costs more in line with international standards.
A total of 32,863 people committed suicide in 1998, both the largest number and the highest rate of suicide recorded since the police began keeping records in 1947. "I don't recall anything like this ever before," said Yukiko Nishihara, who has run a suicide prevention line for more than 20 years in Osaka and now Tokyo.
Suicide in Japan has little of the stigma it carries in Western societies; in literature, history and even today, suicides are often portrayed as noble, a matter of conscience or an honorable form of protest. The rate of suicide in the United States in 1997 was 11.4 per 100,000, according to the latest figures from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, compared with 19.3 per 100,000 in Japan.
In recent years, though, there has been increasing criticism of suicide as irresponsible to survivors. And for years, suicide rates in Japan have been lower than those in several other industrialized countries. Statistics comparing this year's suicide rate in Japan with that in other countries do not exist.
This year, however, what caused most people here to catch their breath was the increase in the number of middle-aged men who killed themselves. There was a 44.6 percent rise in suicides among men aged 40 to 59, according to the police.
Japanese were also shocked by the number of young men who took their lives. Some 40 percent more men in their 20's committed suicide last year. Typically, this is a stable time in Japanese life, when young men could count on becoming "shaiin," literally members of society, by entering the work force. Now, jobs are harder to find.
"Even if you graduate from the best university, you cannot always find a job," Mrs. Nishihara said. "Young people are feeling very hopeless about their future."
The largest single increase -- 53.1 percent among children 10 through 19 -- is largely ascribed to family and school-related problems and mental illness, but experts say it is hard to link those deaths to the economy. Children here have historically tended to kill themselves at a higher rate than adults, Mrs. Nishihara said, so when adult suicide rates jump, the rates among people in their teens jump even more.
The shame associated with not having a job is immense, overwhelming and much understood by senior executives, who feel bullied by foreign investors and analysts pushing them to move more aggressively to cut jobs.
"Of course there is a relationship between restructuring and suicide," said Atsushi Murayama, the managing director in charge of personnel at the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company and one of the few Japanese executives who has spoken openly, if reluctantly, about the problem. "Foreign analysts and the foreign press also have responsibility, too."
Matsushita, like many other Japanese companies, has worked hard to avoid layoffs, a stance characterized as foot-dragging by foreigners but regarded as heroic here.
"Yes, we have to be competitive with global companies, but seniority pay emphasizes security," Mr. Murayama said. "We have to adapt to free-style competition but also take consideration of the Japanese social situation."
Having a job, however, apparently does not confer much of a sense of relief, either. Many men who killed themselves in the last year were employed but fearful of losing their jobs or overwhelmed by increased workloads that were a result of colleagues losing their jobs, according to experts.
Wages have fallen, too, which is especially disastrous for middle-aged men, who are usually the sole earner in families struggling to shoulder the heavy burden of both mortgage payments and supplementary educational programs, standard for many Japanese children.
A survey by the Bureau of Employment Security showed that of those unemployed white-collar workers in their 50's who have managed to find jobs after being laid off -- and many of them don't -- the average income is just 60 percent of what they were previously making.
Financial straits, however, are not as important as the loss of face that is a corollary to losing a job.
"Certainly, there are some people who commit suicide for financial reasons," said Hiroshi Kawahito, a lawyer who specializes in representing the families of victims of karoshi, literally death from overwork, and an outspoken commentator on suicide and its causes. "But I think the most important reason is that in Japan, if workers lose their jobs, they will be looked down upon by society."
Mr. Kawahito and a group of lawyers recently opened a one-day special telephone line that received more than 300 calls from families of karoshi and suicide victims and victims in the making. "Often companies scold the families of victims, saying the victim escaped his responsibilities and so behaved in an irresponsible manner," Mr. Kawahito said. "So in Japan, the culprit and the victim are often reversed, I think."
Families of suicide victims who die by throwing themselves in front of a train are good examples of that. The Chuo line has been nicknamed the Chuo-cide in some quarters because its tracks are a favorite among suicides. JR East, the company that operates the line, charges families a fee depending on how badly traffic is disrupted.
The line has reflected the overall trend in suicides. In the fiscal year that ended March 31, 33 people were killed on the line compared with 25 in the previous year. (The company calls the deaths accidents because, it says, it has no way of distinguishing the person who died as a result of suicide from a person who wandered drunk onto the tracks.)
Because gun ownership is severely restricted in Japan, many Japanese resort to throwing themselves in front of trains, hanging themselves, jumping off cliffs or overdosing, the police say.
The suicide rate has risen every year but one since 1990, when it dropped to the lowest level since 1947. That year coincides with the burst of the economic bubble, the effect of which gradually snowballed until Japan finally slid into a tenacious recession in 1997 that only just seems to be coming to an end.
But while economic distress has clearly helped increase the numbers, Shizuo Machizawa, one of Japan's few specialists in the field, suggests that the economic woes have worsened a trend that would have developed anyway.
Dr. Machizawa, like many observers of Japan after World War II, believes that the suicide rate is one response to a gradual breakdown of a system that rewarded traditional Japanese values of loyalty, hierarchy and paternalism. Typically, in Japanese companies, subordinates offer their department heads absolute loyalty, and in return Japanese executives take care of their charges with an almost fatherly devotion. Now, with pressures to lay off employees, cut costs and improve efficiency, neither the boss nor the subordinate can necessarily fulfill his side of the traditional bargain.
 "In the past, employees could predict their career trajectory," Dr. Machizawa said. "Now, they can't." As managers are forced to lay off staff or tell older workers that younger subordinates may be making more money, the sense of shame for the bearer of bad tidings can be overwhelming."
Kouji Nishigaki, the president of the NEC Corporation, which has embarked on one of the most sweeping employment cutbacks ever taken by a Japanese corporation, said, "I think Japanese managers have a great responsibility to secure employment for their work force so their lives won't fall apart,"
Nonetheless, a large chunk of the company's jobs cuts have come at the expense of employees in its international operations, while in Japan, a cutback in recruitment combined with early retirement will ultimately eliminate some 6,000 jobs.
NEC is just one of several Japanese companies that have hired Dr. Machizawa to consult with distraught and depressed employees and conduct seminars, although, in general, psychiatric care here is limited to administering antidepressants and advising patients to try to take time off, advice that is unrealistic in an era of rising unemployment.
Mr. Kawahito, the lawyer, noted that the number of people who kill themselves outnumbers the number of people who die in traffic accidents by a factor of three. "If there was an increase in traffic accidents, the Japanese Government would surely make an effort to reduce the number," he said. "But the suicide rate keeps going up and we have no Government policy."
In Aokigahara, several local groups have banded together with the police to fight suicide in the forest. They have nailed signs on trees along several of the paths leading into the woods, imploring potential suicide victims to think again.
"Life is a precious present from your parents," the signs say. "Think quietly about your parents, brothers and sisters and children. Do not agonize alone, please consult us first." The telephone number for the Fujiyoshida Police Precinct follows.
The police patrol the area looking for likely suicide victims and pick up about one person a day on average, a precinct spokesman said. "For instance, if someone is wearing a suit, we certainly stop the car and take them into custody," he said.

HEADLINE: For Hives and Honey In New York City;
Rooftop Beekeepers Defy Law to Get That Sweet Central Park Bouquet

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
The setting -- the rooftop of a brownstone on West 113th Street in Manhattan -- hardly evoked the lazy bee-hum of rusticity. Looming to the north was the brick bulk of Butler Library at Columbia University. To the southeast jutted the latticework scaffolding of the ever-unfinished Cathedral of St. John the Divine.
Suddenly, the swirl of bees hanging around two honeybee hives formed a cloud about the heads of four of the brownstone's inhabitants, Jill Laurie Goodman and her three children, urban beekeepers all. "Just look at them," Ms. Goodman said proudly of her bees, as if she were acknowledging a blue-ribbon Charolais steer at the county fair. "Aren't they amazing?" 
 If pigeon-fancying was the rooftop recreation of choice during the "On the Waterfront" era, urban beekeeping is poised to become a hot new bull-market avocation. Two summers ago, David Graves, a veteran bee master who was on the roof helping Ms. Goodman tend the hives, knew of just one beehive in the five boroughs: now he is aware of 13 hives in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx. And city beekeepers claim that there could be twice that number.
But few beekeepers reveal their presence because under the New York City Health Code the activity is illegal. Section 161.01 bans keeping animals that are "wild, ferocious, fierce, dangerous or naturally inclined to do harm." An offender could be fined up to $2,000.
"By nature, bees are wild, and people are in danger of being stung," pointed out John Gadd, a spokesman for the city's Department of Health. "And for those who are allergic to bees, it's a-life-or-death issue."
But like many other beekeepers, Mr. Graves -- a veteran hive master from Becket, Mass., who introduced Ms. Goodman to beemania two summers ago -- contends that honeybees rarely sting when they are away from their rooftop hives, which are locked and inaccessible to pedestrians. "A ban on bees is like a ban on nature," he said.
Mr. Graves has become the Johnny Appleseed of New York beedom. Four days a week, the 49-year-old farmer visits New York to sell home-produced honeys, jams, jellies and maple syrups from his Berkshire Berries cart. For six years he has been a fixture in the Greenmarkets at Union Square, the World Trade Center and West 77th Street at Columbus Avenue.
Two years ago, to increase the supply of his signature offering, New York City Honey, Mr. Graves began establishing hives on buildings owned by sympathetic New Yorkers. He maintains the hives, trains the owners to be beekeepers and gives them some of the honey as rent. The rest goes into his golden bottles, emblazoned with yellow-and-blue labels proclaiming his product "Beelicious."
Whether the Health Department plans any queen-bee busts is unclear. Last month the agency faced the rage of a group called New York City Friends of Ferrets when it adopted a list of more than 150 animal species deemed unfit for urban living.
"What is this administration going to do next, ban calico cats?" demanded City Councilwoman Kathryn E. Freed of Manhattan.
As for honeybees, the Health Department "has no idea what it's talking about," said Peter J. Solomon, a Manhattan investment banker and former Deputy Mayor for Economic Policy and Development, who has kept bees for 21 years at various country homes. "It's ridiculous to say they are dangerous."
Some bee authorities concur. "I disagree with the city's rating of the bees as a threat, though I can understand the city's concern," said Dr. Michael S. Engel, an entomologist at the American Museum of Natural History. "Honeybees won't hurt you unless you grab them, or go after their hive. They are docile and just want to go about their business of gathering pollen and nectar."
Furthermore, Dr. Engel contended, no ban "can get rid of bees as a threat in New York" because the city is home to millions of indigenous bumblebees, sweat bees and wood-boring carpenter bees, none of them raised by humans. Beyond that, yellow jackets are more dangerous than honeybees, Dr. Engel said, adding, "Wasps are aggressive hunters looking for the kill."
As for the allergy question, "If people are allergic to bees, they shouldn't be beekeepers, but that shouldn't mean that other people can't be beekeepers," said Ms. Goodman of Morningside Heights. "Some people are allergic to peanuts, but that shouldn't stop stores from selling peanuts."
All right, but why beekeeping? "After you do it, everything else in life is calm," said Mr. Solomon, the investment banker. "Let me tell you, 40,000 bees will teach you the power of concentration and patience."
But in the Big Apple? "I suppose I had some leftover farming yearning from the 60's," said Karen Lamberti, who has a hive on the roof of her East Harlem brownstone at 101st Street between Park and Lexington Avenues. "This is a way to do a bit of farming in the city."
Others have culinary motives. Carl Redding, 35, hopes for "a New York honey harvest for our Spicy Honey Chicken," he said. The dish is a specialty of his Harlem establishment, Amy Ruth's Restaurant. With Mr. Graves's help, Mr. Redding ensconced a hive on the roof of the restaurant, at 113 West 116th Street near Lenox Avenue, and tends the honeybees. "I also think it's important to teach kids from our neighborhood about farming," said Mr. Redding, who was the chief of staff for the Rev. Al Sharpton before the restaurant industry beckoned, "so they'll know that honey is made in hives, and not in the supermarket."
Ms. Goodman, a 50-year-old lawyer who is the counsel to the New York State Judicial Committee on Women and the Courts, decided that apiculture was the bee's knees after she happened upon Mr. Graves's farm stand at the Greenmarket. She noticed his demonstration beehive carrying the sign: "We are very gentle. We'd like to share our New York City honey. Do you have a rooftop?"
Ms. Goodman was intrigued. She then consulted her husband, Melvin Jules Bukiet, 45, a writer whose most recent novel is "Signs and Wonders." "I said I could think of nothing more terrifying, but this seemed to be a fascinating terror," he recalled.
Now she and her children -- Madelaine, 15, Louisa, 13, and Miles, 11 -- have set up a second beehive, their own, and enjoy beekeeping together.
"It's great because you can leave your tensions behind," Ms. Goodman said. "Honeybees are truly amazing creatures when you get to know them. We have such a complex relationship with them: we care for them, and provide them with a home, but we have no idea where they go. They have this whole mysterious life out there in the city."
Less theoretically, her daughter Madelaine volunteered, "If you spend time with them, they're furry and really cute."
The city's urban bee mavens inhabit their own entomological universe, sharing useful information about mite cures or re-queening protocols (that is, replacing a jaded queen bee). As might be expected, they are also given to apiary humor. There are puns about the, well, plight of the bumblebee and requests to "lend me your comb"; and, yes, there are questions about whether to bee or not to bee. Mr. Solomon, a graduate of the Harvard Business School, has been known to tell hive masters that he has a degree from "the Harvard bee school."
On a recent afternoon on her rooftop, Ms. Goodman unhinged the hive cover and she and Mr. Graves began examining the individual wooden bee frames, wedging out big pieces of honeycomb. Being from New York, it boasts a bouquet that is "more floral -- sweeter -- and has a lighter taste," said Mr. Graves. He noted that the bees forage in Central Park, at rooftop planters, outside florists' shops and in community gardens, rather than at upstate clover fields or deep-South orange groves.
But it isn't the easiest thing in the world to sweet-talk skeptical New Yorkers into buying urban honey for $5 a pound. "You would think that New York honey might have a rather strong flavor," said Judith Cramer, a computer-science teacher who had stopped by Mr. Graves's cart at the Union Square Greenmarket specifically to buy New York honey as a gift for a friend who lives in England.
"Actually, it's rather sweet," Mr. Graves said.
"No, you'd think that New York honey would be quite aggressive as far as honeys go," Ms. Cramer said with a laugh. "You know, it's the honey that says, 'What's it to you?' " She happily bought a bottle.
"I think honey could be a great cash crop for New York," said Mr. Solomon, who, when he was Deputy Mayor under Edward I. Koch, suggested passionately -- and unsuccessfully -- that commercial apiculture would be a novel way to revitalize parts of the South Bronx.
Back on the roof, Mr. Bukiet sighed as he surveyed the spectacle of his wife and children poking into their two big-city beehives.
"You raise your children in Manhattan, you think they'll be the ultimate urbanites, and instead you get a bunch of naturalists," he said, deadpan. "Where did I go wrong?"

HEADLINE: Political Briefing;
She's Got Momentum, And the Name Too

BYLINE: By B. Drummond Ayres Jr. 

 BODY:
Another Kennedy is making a move.
Robert F. Kennedy's oldest child, Kathleen Kennedy Townsend, who for four and a half years has been Lieutenant Governor of Maryland, held a fund-raiser at the Baltimore Zoo the other night, an event widely viewed as her first public step toward a run for governor in 2002. More than 3,000 of the Democratic faithful showed up. 
 After a slow start as Lieutenant Governor -- her early appearances were awkward, her early speeches scrambled -- Mrs. Townsend is on a political roll. She now comes across in public as, well, a Kennedy, one quick with the smile, the quip, the clap on the back, and she has slowly but steadily built a reputation as a strong advocate of aggressive economic development, better schools, innovative anticrime measures and community service. By the time she won election to a second term last fall, she had a job approval rating pushing impressively toward 75 percent.
In recent weeks, her name has begun to appear on lists of possible Democratic Vice-Presidential candidates for Election 2000. This week she is serving as a co-chairwoman of a Baltimore meeting of the Democratic Leadership Council, one of the party's most influential policy groups, whose president, Al From, calls her "a model for New Democrats." A veteran Maryland pollster, Keith Haller, says her political development in recent years has been "quite extraordinary."
Yet even as she moves toward a run for governor, making more headlines than ever, Mrs. Townsend refuses to discuss her political future. She told The Baltimore Sun the other day that she preferred to keep the focus on the present and her various policy initiatives, because "good policy is good politics."
But then she added, "I intend to be around for a long time."
