HEADLINE: The China Cloud: Is a Bomb Being Waved at Taiwan?

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: BEIJING, July 15

 BODY:
Buried in a tiresome-looking 36-page Government report lay what appeared to be a minor scientific detail, almost invisible because it was mentioned so casually, in a passing reference three sentences long.
But it was not minor at all. China has designed a neutron bomb, the report said, as well as miniature nuclear weapons. 
 It was the timing, not the content, of the disclosure that made it so significant. Scientists have known for years that China had the ability to make a neutron bomb, having detected multiple tests over the last 11 years. But today was the first time that China has publicly asserted owning such technology.
Why now?
The target of this news was apparently Taiwan. Coming just days after Taiwan had said that it was dropping its adherence to its longstanding principle that it and the Chinese mainland are separately governed parts of the same country, the announcement was timed to send a message across the Taiwan Strait -- we've got the stuff, so watch out.
Beijing has never renounced its right to use military force to recover the island, where Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalist troops took refuge after the Communists defeated them in 1949. Today, state-run media reiterated the Government's threat to block Taiwan independence.
The news on the bomb was obscured in a report intended to rebut the Cox Committee report, a Congressional study released in May that accused China of having stolen from the United States information on the designs for the neutron bomb, as well as for the W-88, the most advanced miniaturized warhead.
The Chinese rebuttal denies that China stole any secret nuclear technology from the United States and accuses the Cox report of being politically motivated, full of distortions and painted with a layer of racism directed at the Chinese people and at Chinese-Americans.
The principal suspect in the espionage allegation is Wen Ho Lee, a Taiwan-born American who was discharged from his job at Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico over security breaches but has yet to be charged with a crime.
China's assertions, similar to earlier denials of charges in the Cox report, were most curious for their timing, inexplicably being made a full two months after the Cox report.
The question of the week here is how Beijing will ultimately respond to Taiwan's shifting stance toward the mainland. The senior official who delivered the rebuttal today, Zhao Qizheng, replied when asked afterward that he could not say whether China would take military action.
Paradoxically, however, the announcement may signal China's decision to keep to a relatively restrained response to developments in Taiwan. Although any mention of a neutron bomb sounds intimidating, because it is designed to kill people with intense radiation that leaves buildings undisturbed, the delivery of the news was notably lacking in the rancor and fist-pounding of which Beijing is capable.
"Beijing learned from the last time, in 1996," said a former Clinton Administration official who is visiting here. "They know it's counterproductive to launch missiles."
The former official was referring to China's aggressive stance toward Taiwan three years ago, when Beijing was infuriated by political maneuvering by President Lee Teng-hui of Taiwan that had led to his 1995 visit to the United States, the first by a Taiwan President since Washington dropped diplomatic recognition two decades ago. Although Mr. Lee maintained his Nationalist Party's position that it sought eventual reunification with the mainland, Beijing saw his actions as attempts to raise the island's international profile and nudge it toward independence.
In March 1996, China launched missiles into the ocean near Taiwan to try to intimidate voters just before the presidential election. Instead, Mr. Lee scored a decisive victory.
This week, Mr. Lee made another move that risked angering Beijing, dropping the "one China" formulation that has helped avert war with China for decades by sidestepping the issue of sovereignty and saying the relationship between Taiwan and the mainland would more accurately be described as "state to state."
China's news media responded with tough warnings and a typical dose of vitriol in the Communist Party publication People's Daily. But no senior leader has emerged to speak publicly on the issue. Tonight, the evening news on state television calmly reported on a trip to Mongolia by President Jiang Zemin and on a meeting held by Prime Minister Zhu Rongji on the economy, without highlighting the neutron bomb.
China is thought to have first tested a neutron bomb in 1988, and continued to do so on numerous occasions. But until today it has never publicly discussed that technology.
The rebuttal, "Facts Speak Louder Than Words and Lies Will Collapse on Themselves," asserts that China began work on a neutron bomb in the 1970's, when the United States and the Soviet Union intensified their arms race.
"China had no choice but to continue to carry out research and development of nuclear weapons technology and improve its nuclear weapons systems, mastering in succession the neutron bomb design technology and the nuclear weapon miniaturization technology," the report said.
It denied that China stole the technology involved in those two designs and argued that many design details of the nuclear weapons cited in the Cox report were available in unclassified documents and on the Internet. It also rejects allegations in the Cox report that China had stolen American technology on launching satellites.
Although Chinese leaders act offended and exasperated by the espionage allegations, they are involved in many separate struggles with the United States, all at the same time.
This week, American officials are here to negotiate the issue of compensating China for damages that it suffered in the NATO bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade in May. Chinese leaders still say they find it hard to believe Washington's insistence that the bombing was accidental. Washington insists that a combination of unlikely errors and outdated maps caused the bombing. .
Only after the compensation issue is settled will China and the United States be able to proceed on resuming negotiations on obtaining membership for China in the World Trade Organization, a goal that China's leaders still seem determined to achieve. Yet the timing is tricky, as well as the substance of the talks.
Complicating both sets of negotiations are suspicions some Chinese leaders have toward the United States role in Taiwan's latest shift from the "one China" policy. Chinese scholars have argued that the United States, eager to contain a fast-emerging China, is encouraging Taiwan toward independence, ruining China's goal of reunification.

HEADLINE: Syrian Peace His Aim, Barak Tells Clinton

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
Prime Minister Ehud Barak told President Clinton today that Israel would embark on a "serious effort" in the next several weeks to restart negotiations with Syria, which is still formally at war with Israel.
In a private meeting with the President at the White House that lasted two and a half hours, Mr. Barak laid down several conditions that he would demand as the price of peace with Syria, according to a senior Israeli official who spoke with Mr. Barak after the session. 
 The Prime Minister told Mr. Clinton that Israel was prepared for "painful compromises and difficult decisions" to reach agreement with Syria, if it offers concessions in turn, the official said. Israel is willing to partly pull its troops back from the Golan Heights on the Israel-Syria border if the two countries can reach agreement on the status of Lebanon, terrorism, borders, water rights and normalization of diplomatic relations.
Mr. Barak told Mr. Clinton that Israel would never agree to return to the borders that existed before the 1967 war, the official said.
Today's meeting was the first of a series of discussions the new Israeli Prime Minister will have with the President and other top American officials over the next five days. The Washington talks come barely a week after he was sworn in as Prime Minister and are intended to dramatize his commitment to rapid progress toward political reconciliation.
Mr. Barak also told the President that he would continue the withdrawal of Israeli forces from the West Bank under terms of a deal reached with Palestinians at the Wye Plantation in Maryland late last year, but that "most" Israeli settlers would remain in the communities they have established there.
"We are at the moment of truth," Mr. Barak told Mr. Clinton, according to the Israeli official. "Our generation must find a way to solve this conflict. We will leave no stone unturned to reach peace agreements that will enhance the security of Israel."
After the meeting with Mr. Clinton, Mr. Barak met briefly with Vice President Al Gore and then Mr. Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton and Mr. Barak and his wife, Nava, flew by helicopter to Camp David to dine privately and spend the night.
Speaking to reporters in the Rose Garden in an appearance with Mr. Clinton before their meeting, Mr. Barak said he planned a vigorous effort to resume discussions with all of Israel's neighbors and with the Palestinians. He asked for the President's support, but at the same time expressed a desire for the United States to play a less prominent role in negotiations and in enforcing any ultimate agreements.
Mr. Clinton publicly agreed that the United States had become overly intrusive in the Middle East dialogue in the last several years. He said Washington should serve merely as a "facilitator" of talks involving Israel, its Arab neighbors and the Palestinians, not as an active participant.
"We should not be in a patronizing role; we should be in a supportive role," Mr. Clinton said in his public appearance with the Prime Minister. It was the first time Mr. Clinton had responded to Mr. Barak's complaint this week that the United States had been too deeply enmeshed in Middle East negotiations.
The President said the United States had intervened only when it appeared that progress toward peace had halted.
"We took a more active role, in effect as a mediator, when the bonds of trust and the lines of communication had become so frayed that we were in danger of losing the peace process," Mr. Clinton said. "And I did not want that to happen."
He said it was far preferable for the parties to talk directly to one another without American intercession, as Mr. Barak said he intended to do.
The Prime Minister said that he did not want the United States to serve as "policeman, judge and arbitrator" of relations between Israel and the Arabs. Mr. Barak seemed to be referring in part to the C.I.A.'s involvement in security issues with the Palestinians, a role that was established at the Wye accords and one that some critics say supplanted the chances of direct contact between the Israelis and the Palestinians on those issues.
Mr. Barak did emphasize today that restarting the Middle East dialogue would require "American leadership and support all along the way."
Mr. Barak said that he would abide by all agreements signed by previous Israeli governments, including the Wye accords. He said he intended to try to reach agreement on "all tracks" of regional peace talks, including a comprehensive accord with Syria.
However, he said he felt as if he had "got the mission of defusing a time bomb" by taking office after a three-year period in which Israel's relations with its neighbors, the Palestinians and the United States were badly strained by the cantankerous posture of the Likud Government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
Mr. Barak, who was sworn in just last week after winning a landslide victory over Mr. Netanyahu in May, has already met with Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, King Abdullah of Jordan and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt.
He said today that he was prepared to sit down with Hafez al-Assad, the President of Syria, to discuss peace with Syria and an Israeli withdrawal from Lebanon, which Syria essentially controls.
"It takes two to tango," Mr. Barak said. "I am ready, the arena is ready, maybe the dancing instructor is ready. We have to find an opportunity and begin."
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright is expected to travel to Syria in the next several weeks to sound out officials there on what conditions they will require for normalization of relations with Israel.
President Assad has insisted that Israel withdraw all of its forces from southern Lebanon and return land on the Golan Heights seized during the 1967 war. He also wants a permanent international observer force stationed in the Golan to insure that Israel lives up to its commitments.
Mr. Assad would also like the lifting of economic sanctions the United States imposed because of the American determination that Syria sponsors international terrorism.
Mr. Clinton said he had not meant to signal a shift in American policy toward Palestinian refugees or to prejudge the outcome of so-called final status talks when he said two weeks ago that the refugees should be able to settle "wherever they want to live."
The remark touched off a wave of criticism in Israel, where the "right of return" of hundreds of thousands of Palestinians scattered around the Middle East to territory now occupied by Israel is one of the most emotional issues still to be resolved with Palestinian leaders.
The refugee issue is one to be negotiated in the permanent status talks between Israel and the Palestinians, Mr. Clinton said.
"The United States, as a sponsor of the peace process, has asked the parties to do nothing to prejudge the final status issues," the President said. "We certainly should be doing nothing to prejudge the final status issues."
Mr. Clinton gave a similar answer in response to a question arising from Mrs. Clinton's statement last week that Jerusalem is the capital of Israel and that the United States should move its embassy to Jerusalem from Tel Aviv.
Her statement is at odds with Administration policy, which is that the status of Jerusalem has yet to be decided and that the United States Embassy will remain in Tel Aviv until it is.
For his part, Mr. Barak said he would like embassies from all nations to be in Jerusalem, which both Israel and the Palestinians claim as their historic capitals.

HEADLINE: Lawmakers Vote to Increase Their Pay and President's

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 15

 BODY:
The House voted overwhelmingly today to give members of Congress a $4,600 pay raise in January and to double the next President's salary to $400,000.
Lawmakers voted 276 to 147 to increase their own pay, rolling up nearly 2-to-1 margins among Republicans and Democrats alike. They then voted 334 to 82 to reject an effort by conservatives to prevent the Presidential pay increase. 
 The vote on legislators' salaries underlined the favorable political climate for the second Congressional raise in 18 months. The last raise before that was in 1993.
Not only do polls show Congress rated favorably by more than half the public, but it is also enjoying a time of economic plenty and growing budget surpluses. While in past years the Congressional pay question has often provoked heated battles, the issue came and went today with scarcely a mention and as an obscure parliamentary vote.
The scant debate opened with Representative Jim Kolbe, Republican of Arizona, saying he hoped lawmakers would support a procedural motion -- on a Treasury Department spending bill -- that in effect allowed the Congressional raise. It ended moments later when two Kentucky Representatives, Ken Lucas, a Democrat, and Ernie Fletcher, a Republican, said they would oppose it.
"It looked like there was so much bipartisan support for the COLA, I didn't think anybody wanted to make it a major, controversial issue," Mr. Fletcher said in an interview later. COLA is shorthand for cost-of-living adjustment, the official name for the raise.
Even so, the potential volatility of the issue was reflected by the votes of the House's most vulnerable blocks of members. The 42 freshmen voted 26 to 15 against the raise, and one did not vote. And the 44 lawmakers elected by margins of 10 percent or less last November voted "no" by 30 to 13, and one did not vote.
Most members of Congress earn $136,700 annually but leaders get more, with Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, Republican of Illinois, earning $175,400. The increase will be 3.4 percent -- by law rounded to the nearest $100 -- pushing most lawmakers to $141,300 and Mr. Hastert to $181,400.
Under a 1989 law, lawmakers get an annual raise automatically unless they vote to deny it, a mechanism that has at times let them avoid taking politically risky votes. A formula in the law links the increase to the one Federal workers will receive, which President Clinton has proposed to be 4.4 percent.
The Senate approved the Treasury measure on July 1 without language preventing the increase, and with no mention of it during debate. It is all but certain that the compromise version of the bill will be silent on the issue, which means the increase will take effect.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Smaller Computer Chips Promise Big Leap in Speed
Researchers from Hewlett-Packard and the University of California at Los Angeles have fashioned simple computing components no thicker than a single molecule that they say could be a step toward computers 100 billion times as fast as today's most powerful personal computers.
And they envision a world in which supercomputing power is so pervasive and cheap that it literally becomes an integral part of every man-made object. Page A1.
 
No Indication of Inflation in June
The Consumer Price Index -- which measures changes in the price of everything that American households buy, from candy bars to health care -- remained unchanged in June for the second consecutive month, indicating no inflation, the Labor Department reported. C2.
 
Coke Posts 21% Decrease in Profit
Coca-Cola's second-quarter profit fell 21 percent, in part because it had to pull millions of soft drinks off the market in Europe last month. Worldwide sales volume, measured in cases of finished drinks, fell 2 percent, compared with a 10 percent increase in the period a year earlier. The volume and earnings were about what Wall Street had expected, and Coke shares rose $2.125, to $64. C3.
 
Nasdaq and S.& P. Set Records
Stocks rose in response to news the Consumer Price Index showed no inflation and to strong corporate earnings. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 38.31 points, to 11,186.41. The Nasdaq composite index rose 21.24 points, to a record 2,839.37. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also set a new high, rising 11.45 points, to 1,409.62. C6.
 
Bond investors quickly bought up a $1.6 billion Southern California tax-exempt issue, and Nassau County, N.Y., offered $138 million in bonds. The yield of the 30-year Treasury remained at 5.91 percent. C6.
 
BP Amoco Plans $4 Billion in Cuts
BP Amoco, the newly formed petroleum giant, surprised analysts with ambitious plans to cut annual costs by $4 billion in the next three years -- double the previous target -- and shed $10 billion of assets. C4.
 
Boeing Earnings Beat Expectations
Boeing delivered stronger-than-expected earnings for the second consecutive quarter and raised its estimates of future profits, giving its beleaguered investors new hope after two years of disappointments. C2.
 
Arden Seeks to Redefine Image
Responding to a consumer study that found disparaging attitudes toward the beauty industry, the Elizabeth Arden Company is seeking to redefine its image in an unconventional campaign from J. Walter Thompson. One aspect is unretouched black- and-white photographs showing women of various ages and ethnic groups, with headlines like "I am the leader of my own free world." Advertising. C5.
 
Drug Executives Criticize Proposal
Top pharmaceutical executives said they shared President Clinton's goal of increasing Medicare beneficiaries' access to prescription drugs, but for the first time criticized specific features of his proposal. A14.
 
Index Funds Are Losing Favor
Although investors have increasingly favored mutual funds that track stock market indexes, the performance of competing funds has improved, and investors have begun cutting back on index funds. Market Place. C6.
 
Tougher Policy Hinted in Europe
The head of the European Central Bank, Wim Duisenberg, signaled that it might soon toughen monetary policy. C4.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Behind Umpires' Bold Move Is the Belief That Baseball's Risk Is Bigger

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
They saw a fight coming and decided that they, and not their employers, would pick the time and place to start it. Now baseball's major league umpires, whose letters of resignation, effective Sept. 2, were sent by fax to the league offices yesterday, will wait to learn if they have taken too great a risk.
"I live in Orlando," Rocky Roe, an American League umpire, said yesterday in St. Petersburg, Fla., before the Mets-Devil Rays game. "There's always the possibility I could be at Disney World looking for a job. Sure, there's an inherent risk." 
 Major League Baseball officials were silent yesterday on the umpires' unexpected action, saying only that they were reviewing the situation. But some are known to welcome the resignations, because they feel they would be able to start over with new umpires and regain the control they feel they have lost.
Like Roe, Richie Phillips, head of the umpires union, acknowledged the risk in the umpires' action. But, he said, if baseball hired replacement umpires, it would be taking a much bigger risk.
"They risk having 25 years of inferior umpiring ahead of them," Phillips said in a telephone interview, "in a game in which they will be presenting a very, very watered down product. That's a real risk."
The labor agreement between the umpires and the National and American Leagues expires Dec. 31. Negotiations for a new deal were going to be confrontational because the two sides have been headed for a fight for more than a year, and the tension has been especially high since the beginning of this year. The fight is just starting earlier than expected.
The umpires, who are barred by the labor contract from striking, decided to adopt the resignation strategy because they will receive $15.5 million in termination pay. The severance ranges from $150,000 for a 10-year umpire to $400,000 for one who has 20 or more years in the majors.
About a dozen and a half umpires out of the 66-member union do not qualify for severance, but those who do have agreed to share a percentage of their termination pay with the younger umpires. Phillips said resignation letters of 63 umpires were faxed yesterday.
The umpires acted before they could be acted upon. They believed management planned to try to induce lower-rated umpires to leave, telling them they could resign and receive severance or be fired and get nothing. Rather than have severance used as a weapon against them, the umpires opted to have it work for them.
In that way, the fight is economic. But it is also about respect. "A lot of times we feel that we're not appreciated," said Roe, a 20-year veteran.
The umpires chose a resignation date seven weeks away, figuring there would be time for the two sides to achieve an agreement that would prompt them to rescind their resignations. "Hopefully," Roe said, "the parties will be able to get together and negotiate in good faith and get a deal done."
The players pursued a similar strategy in 1994, figuring the owners would rush to an agreement to salvage the post-season. But the owners, for the first time, held firm, then congratulated themselves on their ability to do that as the World Series was canceled.
In previous work stoppages involving umpires, the leagues hired replacements, but they turned out to be inadequate and prompted players and fans alike to clamor for the return of the regular umpires. Fans at various parks booed umpires when they walked onto the field last night, but Phillips recalled different scenes.
"What Bud Selig and his errand boys don't understand," the Philadelphia lawyer said, referring to the commissioner, "is that in 1979, when the umpires returned May 19, they received standing ovations at every park in America. In 1984, in San Diego, when they returned for the fifth game of the Padres-Cubs series, the umpires got a standing ovation. After the 1995 lockout, upon their return, they received standing ovations."
But a different dynamic could come into play this time. While the umpires are gambling that the major leagues cannot do without them, management could decide to let them resign, then go out and hire permanent replacements. By hiring umpires on a permanent basis, they may be able to recruit more capable people than they have been able to lure for previous, temporary work stoppages.
Even some of the major league umpires could change their minds if they are faced with permanent loss of their jobs, which, including a $25,000 year-end bonus, pay from $95,000 to $262,500.
And not all of the union umpires are enamored of Phillips's leadership. Last spring about a dozen umpires approached Ron Shapiro, a noted player agent, and asked if he would be interested in representing the umpires. They told him they were concerned with Phillips's confrontational stance. But nothing developed, and an overwhelming majority of umpires continued to support Phillips, voting him a new five-year contract.
 The possibility of the commissioner's office hiring an entirely new crew of umpires contains an unusual element. New umpires would be represented by the same bargaining unit, the Major League Umpires Association. The old members of the union would go away, but not the union. The head of the union, of course, is Phillips, and he would continue under his five-year contract.
Asked yesterday what he thought would happen next, Phillips said, "I expect that in keeping with their attitude of smugness and typical management arrogance, they will start recruiting their amateur umpire force in order to intimidate the umpires."
One large group of umpires may not be available. With 220 of the 228 minor league umpires voting for it and the other 8 abstaining, a new union of minor league umpires has been formed. It has yet to be recognized by the minor league group that hires umpires, but the umpires are represented by Phillips and he said they support the major league umpires.
On the other hand, the lure of lucrative major league jobs, if offered, could be difficult to resist.

HEADLINE: Tax Refund Won't Help

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The Republican plan to give taxpayers a refund for the budget surplus (editorial, July 12) would be a grand mistake. The additional consumption would feed inflation and ultimately raise interest rates. That, in turn, would slow corporate investment, constrict construction, hamper the stock market and hurt taxpayers already strapped by credit-card debt and adjustable mortgages.
Using the surplus to pay down the debt, however, would benefit everyone. 
 Interest rates would have to fall, making the country competitive in export markets and supporting corporate investment in new technology and higher productivity. The American consumer would win, with credit costs falling and employment remaining high.
 
MICHAEL SCHNITKER
New York, July 14, 1999

HEADLINE: 2 Exchanges in Retreat From Times Sq.

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Nearly a year after Nasdaq and the American Stock Exchange created a stir in New York with grand plans to move to a new 40-story skyscraper near Times Square, the two financial markets have reversed course and now appear ready to stay in lower Manhattan.
The decision amounts to a retreat for Frank G. Zarb, the chairman of the National Association of Securities Dealers, which owns both Nasdaq and the American Stock Exchange. Mr. Zarb had planned to move to Times Square, a telegenic international crossroads, as a step in building a world financial market that would rival the New York Stock Exchange. But Mr. Zarb has since discovered that building a new headquarters in midtown, or even in lower Manhattan, can be expensive. 
 In a letter sent to city officials yesterday, Nasdaq said the two stock markets were now considering the expansion of the existing trading floor at the American Stock Exchange, at 86 Trinity Place, and leasing 290,000 square feet at either 1 Liberty Plaza or 1 World Financial Center for Nasdaq. City officials and real estate executives say they still expect the N.A.S.D. to move to New York from Washington.
At the same time, Nasdaq resurrected a threat to move its operations to Jersey City if it does not get a large package of tax breaks from New York, though real estate executives on both sides of the Hudson River say they doubt that the exchanges would leave Manhattan.
Noting that "the city's goal" was to bring the N.A.S.D. to New York, Randy L. Levine, Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, said: "We always left the exact location up to them. We'll continue to work with them to try and find a suitable home."
Last November, Nasdaq signed an agreement with the state and the city to build a new headquarters for the exchanges in a skyscraper to be built at 42d Street and the Avenue of the Americas, or a similar site, with a $200 million package of tax breaks and cash. Mr. Levine said yesterday that it was unlikely that Nasdaq would get anywhere near that amount now.
"The $200 million deal was for a new building," he said. "We usually grant a lower level of incentives when you're only leasing space."
Despite signing the agreement with New York on Nov. 3, Michael Jones, chief administrative officer for the N.A.S.D., said the association had made it clear to everyone involved that the exchanges were still examining the financial feasibility of building and occupying a new headquarters. Because it has several leases that are expiring, he said the association could not wait five years for a new building to be constructed.
"We're looking at all our options," said Mr. Jones, who is leading the search in New York. "New Jersey isn't out of the mix either. Right now, we have some immediate needs that a new building cannot meet."
But Mr. Zarb and Nasdaq have suffered many problems pursuing its plans. Mr. Zarb wanted a separate identity in a glamorous location that would get him out from under the shadow of the larger New York Stock Exchange and its chairman, Richard A. Grasso. A year ago, Mr. Zarb signed a deal to build a marketing center and the largest video billboard in Times Square at a new skyscraper, 4 Times Square. He also opened negotiations with the developer Douglas Durst and the city for a new headquarters in a proposed office tower next door.
But merger talks with the Philadelphia Exchange collapsed, and a Times Square tower looked expensive. In March, the city encouraged Nasdaq to consider moving into a subsidized trading complex in lower Manhattan that Mr. Grasso was planning for the New York Stock Exchange, an option that Mr. Zarb seemed unwilling to consider. Nasdaq briefly considered an offer from Brookfield Financial Properties, a major commercial landlord, to build a new tower at the World Financial Center.
"It shows that Zarb has a lot to learn from Dick Grasso," said Mitchell Moss, director of New York University's Urban Research Center. "Not everybody is ready for prime time."
Mr. Moss added that it had become clear over the last year that modern financial markets would be more about computers and phone lines than trading floors. "The new markets are built on computers, not real estate," Mr. Moss said.

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 37; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 631 words

HEADLINE: ART IN REVIEW

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER 

 BODY:

Pepon Osorio
'Transboricua'
Youngworld Children's Department Store
1915 Third Avenue, at 106th Street
East Harlem
Through July 25
A few years ago, Pepon Osorio's installation "Badge of Honor" made its debut in a storefront in a working class neighborhood in Newark. The piece, based on a video dialogue between a Latino boy and his imprisoned father, later appeared at Ronald Feldman Gallery in SoHo and elsewhere. But the resonance it generated in its original setting was extraordinary. 
 Work by Mr. Osorio, who recently won a MacArthur grant and who participated in the 1993 Whitney biennial, often travels this route from the real world to the art world. "Transboricua" is the latest example of that process.
Created for a public library in Providence, R.I., and now installed in Youngworld Children's Department Store in East Harlem, the piece looks more streamlined than some of Mr. Osorio's previous installations -- the amazing "Scene of the Crime (Whose Crime?)" now installed at the Bronx Museum of the Arts is an example -- but it is loaded with eye-catching symbolic detail.
It starts with a huge cage of cyclone fencing set amid the store's racks of bright "Hot Summer Fun" clothes. A mannequinlike figure is locked inside: a man wearing a dark suit, a broad-brimmed hat, a small backpack and boxing gloves, his face entirely swathed in patterned cloth. He stands on pink clay patio tiles surrounded by green plastic ground cover. A microphone is in front of him, and a stuffed peacock is nearby.
Every aspect of the piece is coded with meaning. The cage suggests both confinement and protection; the backpack is a sign of someone on the move. The man's glitter-covered hat carries the Puerto Rican national emblem, his face is covered by a Mexican flag and his boxing gloves are emblazoned with the official insignia of the Dominican Republic. He looks imposing and combative, but the music he appears to sing into the microphone (it is actually piped in from elsewhere) is a 1940's Puerto Rican lament about a man returning empty-handed from a long and arduous journey.
The dozens of cartoon eyes sewn to the man's suit echo the patterns on the tail of the peacock, and the motif is picked up in dozens of photographic pins, each carrying the portrait of a child. Before the pictures were taken, Mr. Osorio had asked the children to imagine what they might look like 50 years in the future, and they faced the camera with eyes closed, as if they were lost in thought. A single pair of eyes appears on a little video implanted in the man's backpack. Their pupils take the form of a world globe.
Installed under the direction of the curator Julia P. Herzberg, "Transboricua" is about many things. The title implies the idea of transition or transformation, one directly pertinent to the East Harlem setting: the barrio, once largely Puerto Rican, is now home to other Latino populations, a mix that has produced territorial tensions.
As Ms. Herzberg points out in a flyer, the piece also addresses a broader picture. Despite a history of poverty, America's Hispanic population does its share to keep a double-edged consumerist economy afloat. (Youngworld is evidence of that.) But that economy is reducing ethnic diversity to a global culture in which everyone is, to some degree, spiritually homeless.
Mr. Osorio manages to imbed all of this into his installation without making a big deal of any of it, and, most important, without sacrificing visual flair. And "Transboricua" will make its leap out of the community into the art world next fall. It will be installed in the Museo del Barrio on Fifth Avenue at 104th Street in September, where it will take on another, different, though surely no less dynamic life. HOLLAND COTTER
 
http://www.nytimes.com

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 38; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 4689 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE

 BODY:
Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free.
* denotes a highly recommended show. 

Museums
 
"THE AMERICAN CENTURY: ART AND CULTURE, 1900-1950," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through Aug. 22). This is the first half of a marathon end-of-an-era survey. (Part 2, covering 1950-2000, opens on Sept. 26.) It flows chronologically through four floors of the museum's galleries, resulting in a show of substantial if circumscribed pleasures. Most of the 600 paintings, drawings and sculptures are familiar icons from a canonical art history, one in need of shaking up. But if what is here is short on fresh insights, there are wonderful things to look at. And by the time you've worked your way from Gilded Age society portraits on the top floor to Jackson Pollock below, you've had a genuine time-travel experience: exhausting, diverting, sometimes moving, even pride-inspiring. Hours: Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Thursdays, 1 to 8 P.M. Admission: $12.50; $10.50, students and the elderly (Holland Cotter).
 
* "AMERICAN FOLK ART IN THE METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART," Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, (212) 879-5500 (through Sept. 5). One of the museum's less visible collections, this group of folk art portraits, views, genre scenes, marine paintings, religious works and so on has been assembled for its first-ever overall showing, and high time. The best are the portraits, which include a masterpiece or two by the great Ammi Phillips, along with the work of Joshua Johnston, Erastus Salisbury Field, Rufus Hathaway and other greats. A very appealing section of watercolors and drawings includes mourning pictures, a Victorian convention in which relatives of the dead are shown weeping by tombstones; tributes to heroes like George Washington and General Lafayette, calligraphic endeavors and a number of lively renditions of family groups and trees. Not to be missed are some wonderful New York views, like William H. Schenck's "Third Avenue Railroad Depot" (1859-1860), a handsome red brick building that served as a trolley turnaround and station between 65th and 66th Streets. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays and Sundays, 9:30 A.M. to 5:15 P.M.; Fridays and Saturdays, to 9 P.M. Admission: $8; $4, children and the elderly (Grace Glueck).
 
"BEYOND THE SQUARE: COLOR AND DESIGN IN AMISH QUILTS," Museum of American Folk Art, 2 Lincoln Square, (212) 595-9533 (through Nov. 7). A reticent but festive show of 20 splendid quilts made by members of a separatist religious sect from the late 1880's well into the 20th century. Most of the designs are based on 19th-century American prototypes, though the forms are often dramatically pared down and the Amish palette is distinctive, with wide stretches of rich colors: pink, pumpkin, snappy blue, wine-red. Because Amish law discourages ornament as an end in itself, the subtlest decorative flourishes in quilts are often found in stitch work, which is alive with wreaths, flowers and vines that reveal themselves only on close examination. The result throughout is work of both intense optical pleasure and a principled view of the world. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11:30 A.M. to 7:30 P.M. Free (Cotter).
 
"FAME AFTER PHOTOGRAPHY," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, (212) 708-9400 (through Oct. 5). Not the usual Modern exhibition, this breezily entertaining summer extravaganza includes hundreds of publicity stills, movie trailers, supermarket glossies and television excerpts that chart a trajectory from the world of Queen Victoria to that of Kato Kaelin. The subject is celebrity as a phenomenon redefined by photography. You'll leave it wondering whether something that has become so commonplace is still meaningful beyond its value as a marketable commodity. Hours: Saturdays through Tuesdays, and Thursdays, 10:30 A.M. to 5:45 P.M.; Fridays, 10:30 A.M. to 8:15 P.M. Admission: $10; $6.50, students and the elderly (Michael Kimmelman).
 
"CLARA GUTSCHE: THE CONVENT SERIES," Americas Society, 680 Park Avenue, at 68th Street, (212) 249-8950 (through July 25). At once matter of fact and quietly radiant, these 54 photographs taken in 20 Canadian convents include pristine interiors and pictures of nuns, shown in prayer, lined up outside their rooms, reading in the library, playing cards in the community room. They document a life of devotion, selflessness, unwavering daily routines and restrained joy, while also insinuating themselves into the history of portraiture, religious art and contemporary set-up photography (Roberta Smith).
 
* "EL NUEVO MUNDO: THE LANDSCAPE OF LATINO LOS ANGELES," Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum, Smithsonian Institution, 2 East 91st Street, (212) 849-8400 (through Sept. 5). For more than two decades, the photographer Camilo Jose Vergara has documented the process of physical change in the poorest neighborhoods in American cities. The story is often one of disintegration, but in the color pictures here he turns his eye on the largely Mexican community in Los Angeles, where transplanted cultural roots are in photogenic flower. Life is hard, but houses, stores and city walls are painted with vivid images of religious icons, consumer goods and yearned-for south-of-the-border vistas. Mr. Vergara's careerlong project is an important one; this show is a vivid installment in his expansive field work. And it takes on an extra resonance at the Cooper-Hewitt, a former Andrew Carnegie mansion. Hours: Tuesdays, 10 A.M. to 9 P.M.; Wednesdays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sundays, noon to 5 P.M. Admission: $5; children under 12 and the elderly, $3 (Cotter).
 
"OUR NEW CLOTHES: ACQUISITIONS OF THE 1990'S," Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, (212) 535 7710 (through Aug. 22). The Costume Institute didn't become a premier repository for things sartorial by sitting on its hands. It went out and shopped, and also accepted numerous gifts from donors. Now it is showing off its finds with its usual well-ordered clarity. The show's five sections include a dazzling display of white dresses, a sampling of male attire and a quick run through the mutations of the 18th-century open robe and petticoat combination, all the way up to Madame Gres. There are also mostly beautiful gowns once worn by celebrities like Lillian Gish, Susan Sarandon, Nancy Reagan, Madonna and Diana, Princess of Wales. Hours and admission: See above (Smith)
 
* "POMO INDIAN BASKET WEAVERS, THEIR BASKETS AND THE ART MARKET," National Museum of the American Indian, 1 Bowling Green, lower Manhattan, (212) 514-3712 (through Aug. 15). Baskets made by the Pomo Indians of northern California around the turn of the century were notable for the strength of their design and artistry, and when white settlers new to the territory discovered them a market began to develop. The baskets, in earth colors of black, tan and deep brown with subtle geometric designs, were often covered or accented with tiny colored feathers, clam shell disks (which once served the Pomo as money), abalone pendants and stones. They ranged in size from feast bowls that could feed a tribal gathering to miniatures so tiny they could be mistaken for seeds. This is a knockout presentation of the work of 47 early 20th-century Pomo basket makers. Organized by the University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archeology and Anthropology, it vividly tells the story of the weavers (mostly women), their patrons and collectors. Hours: Daily, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Thursdays, to 8 P.M. Free (Glueck).
 
* "SURREALISM: TWO PRIVATE EYES," the Nesuhi Ertegun and Daniel Filipacchi Collections, Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Sept. 12). The Surrealist collections formed by two friends fill the museum from lobby to ceiling. Although it has more than 700 objects, this powerful show is by no means a comprehensive survey but an intense, close-up experience of Surrealism that might be imparted by two obsessed acquisitors taking you on a personal tour of their treasures. Highlights include clusters of paintings by Dali, Victor Brauner, Magritte, Andre Masson and Yves Tanguy; a splendid group of boxes by Joseph Cornell; a brilliant selection of photographs rife with portraits by Man Ray; dozens of beautifully bound books, and remarkable drawings by Hans Bellmer and Masson. The show has notable omissions and a few surprising inclusions, but by and large the menu is gourmet. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 8 P.M. Admission: $12; $7 for students and the elderly (Glueck).
 
"THE UNPRIVATE HOUSE," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, (212) 708-9400 (through Oct. 5). Intelligently argued, selected and installed, the Modern's first survey of domestic architecture in 30 years rings in changes both esthetic and social: the fading of Post-modernism as an architectural style, the evolving notions of privacy and family, the pervasive effects of technology, the rise of the home office. These are reflected in 26 houses designed in the last decade by an impressive roster of architects, beginning with Rem Koolhaas, and presented in photographs, plans and models. The furniture from David Schaefer Furniture Company makes the theme of domesticity a tangible and comfortable reality. Although the spare-no-expense atmosphere sometimes gives the show the look of a high-end shelter magazine and it may be a while before video walls are the norm, several of the houses are geared to more modest budgets and needs. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).
 
Galleries: Uptown
 
JAN MATULKA, Richard York, 21 East 65th Street, (212) 772-9155 (through July 30). This exhibition of harbor scenes presents Matulka (1890-1972), one of the lesser-known but more engaging of American Early Modernists, at his most appealing. The paintings offer views of seaside houses, sheds and wharves, rocky shores, cozy, blue bays and chunky, toylike boats robustly painted in a brightly colored, chunky style that looks like a marriage of folk art and Cubism (Johnson).
 
* "STAMPED WITH A NATIONAL CHARACTER: 19TH-CENTURY AMERICAN COLOR PLATE BOOKS," Grolier Club, 47 East 60th Street, (212) 838-6690 (through July 31). Color in books is a commonplace today, but 200 years ago it was a rarity in American volumes and affordable only by upscale readers. With more than 100 examples, this thoroughly absorbing show traces the evolution of the American color plate book from 1800 to the end of the century when machine production ended laborious hand operations. Assembled from the collection of William S. Reese, a New Haven dealer and collector, its objects range from John James Audubon's giant portfolio "The Birds of America" to fashion books and medical texts with gruesome illustrations. Worthy of special note is the earliest color plate book produced in the United States, "The City of Philadelphia, in the State of Pennsylvania, North America, As It Appeared in the Year 1800," a handsome offering that might be called the first American coffee table book (Glueck).
 
Galleries: 57th Street
 
ELLIOTT GREEN, JANE HAMMOND, DAVID TRUE, TREVOR WINKFIELD, Tibor de Nagy, 724 Fifth Avenue, (212) 262-5050 (through July 26). Each of the painters in this well-selected show has developed his or her own idiosyncratic mix of Pop, Surrealism and figurative narrative. They harmonize well together, but Mr. True's big, zany cartoon version of the biblical Expulsion, with its eerie population of rubbery, incandescently hued characters, steals the show (Johnson).
 
JASPER JOHNS, Susan Sheehan, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 489-3331 (through July 31). Familiar Johnsian motifs are here embodied in prints from the 60's, 70's and 80's: the numbers 0 through 9 stenciled one over another; three versions of brushes in a Savarin coffee can; five expansive, hatchwork abstractions; a blotchy, black-and-white double flag; and the autobiographical suite "Four Seasons." Johns's distinctively deft, matter-of-fact touch animates them all (Johnson).
 
"LINEAR IMPULSE," Michael Rosenfeld, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 247-0082 (through Aug. 13). This crowded presentation of variously linear paintings and sculptures includes famous artists like David Smith, Mark Tobey and Lee Krasner. There are works in outmoded Modernist styles, like the Surrealistic Cubist paintings of Jimmy Ernst, but there are things that still look fresh, including richly layered paintings by Alfonso Ossorio and a dense ball of wire and glass by Claire Falkenstein (Johnson).
 
ALICE TRUMBULL MASON, Washburn, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 397-6780 (through July 23). Descended from a prominent Colonial New England family, Mason (1904-1971) studied with Arshile Gorky in the late 1920's. As this selection of works from four decades proves, she remained devoted to abstraction throughout her long, under-recognized career. Her modestly scaled paintings, always rigorously structured, sensuously painted and richly colored, were influenced by Miro early on and later by Mondrian, but they always have their own engaging personality (Johnson).
 
JOHN McLAUGHLIN, Ameringer Howard, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 935-1110 (through July 30). McLaughlin (1898-1976) dealt in Asian antiquities and served as a high-ranking translator during World War II before moving to California and, at age 50, beginning his distinguished career as a painter of austere, Zen-inspired abstractions. This show presents five dry, near-Minimalist rectilinear canvases and a series of lithographs from which Peter Halley might have got the barred windows of his cell paintings (Johnson).
 
JUDITH JOY ROSS, Pace Wildenstein MacGill, 32 East 57th Street, (212) 759-7999 (through Aug. 27). Ms. Ross makes understated, uncommonly sensitive photographic portraits, especially of children. Among her lovely gold-toned 8-by-10-inch works are pictures of a blond, messy-haired urchin slouched at his elementary-school desk, gazing at the camera with a look of heartbreaking ennui, and of a 10- or 11-year-old girl standing by a hazy lake with a Band-Aid on her knee and an ethereal aura (Johnson).
 
"WALKING," Danese, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 223-2227 (through Aug. 27). An unexpected variety of approaches to the theme of walking makes this an intriguing show. Among the 21 works are pictures of Marina Abramovic walking the Great Wall of China, a gouache painting of a maze pattern by Richard Fleischner, a photograph of an attractive woman in a phone booth shot by the pedestrian voyeur Garry Winogrand and Ann Truitt's striped minimalist column painted colors observed while walking outdoors (Johnson).
 
Galleries: SoHo
 
PEDRO BARBEITO, Basilico, 26 Wooster Street, (212) 966-1831 (through July 30). A young Spanish-born painter who lives in Brooklyn presents four absorbing paintings that look like complicated computer-generated diagrams. Mr. Barbeito applies layers of thick paint, following underlying grid patterns. At certain points, small-scale gridded structures made entirely of layered paint project several inches from the surface. There is a nice tension between disembodied rationalism and quirky materialism (Johnson).
 
BARTON LIDICE BENES, Lennon, Weinberg, 560 Broadway, at Spring Street, (212) 941-0012 (through July 30). Mr. Benes produces modern reliquaries: broad, shallow boxes divided into little cubbyholes, each containing a labeled, more or less sacred relic. Among the items displayed in "Celebrity" you'll find a police badge worn by Sean Penn in the movie "Colors" and a wad of Dustin Hoffman's chewing gum. These devotional works are for a Warholian world where the gods have devolved into celebrities (Johnson).
 
ROSS BLECKNER, Betsy Senior, 375 West Broadway, near Spring Street, (212) 941-0960 (through Aug. 27). The 10 new etchings in this show correspond to the large cellular abstract paintings Mr. Bleckner exhibited last fall. Patterns of luminous, blurry lines and glowing dots are Bleckneresque but the prints don't have the magical illusionism of the paintings (Johnson).
 
ALBERT HOFFMAN, Luise Ross, 568 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 343-2161 (through July 23). Hoffman (1915-1993), a junkyard proprietor in Absecon, N.J., was passionately devoted to carving wood in his spare time. A number of the works in this show have the sculptural and imaginative presence of the best folk art, including a bigger-than-life bust of a rabbi, an undulating eel that has a Brancusian formal economy and a fanciful representation of Neptune riding a sea turtle (Johnson).
 
CHIP HOOPER, "California Dreamin,' " Edward Carter Gallery, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 966-1933 (through Sept. 11). The Big Sur coast of northern California and the Southwest desert are explored in these contemplative black-and-white photographs, with a bow to the work of Ansel Adams. Viewing the daily moods and changes of the Big Sur territory, Mr. Hooper captures events ranging from the flaming eruption of dawn over the sea to the milky dusk that settles on Soberanes Beach. In his studies of ancient cliff dwellings in the desert, you can almost sense the spirits of the long-gone occupants. No affectations mar this work; the photography is robust, if on the traditional side (Glueck).
 
BILL KOMOSKI, Feature Inc., 76 Greene Street, (212) 941-7077 (through July 23). The reviving interest in abstract painting gives an edge to these four abstract paintings of similar format, loosely based on a grid or net structure. Long loopy strands and rivulets, puddly nonshapes and linear touches convey an idea of liquescence. Bright colors, along with solid and brushy blacks, redeem the deliberate laxity of form. Mr. Komoski has said that "exuberance" and "disquiet" are what he would like to convey in these expressive works; if that goal is not met 100 percent here, he still rates kudos for not pursuing novelty at the expense of painterly exploration (Glueck).
 
MIGUEL ANGEL RIOS AND SERGIO VEGA, CRG, 91 Grand Street, (212) 966-43600 (through July 23). Inspired by an eyewitness account of the 1541 exploration of the Amazon by Europeans, this exhibition of fragile sculptures, installation pieces and 34 drawings continues the Conceptual Art tradition of tackling unwieldy subjects with the slightest of visual means. The results range from sophomoric to reasonably successful, but the antic drawings of the journey's horrors and high points -- Mr. Rios's are the best -- suggest that a comic book treatment may be the only way to do the saga justice (Smith).
 
"SIGNS OF THE TIMES," American Primitive, 594 Broadway, near Houston Street, (212) 966-1530 (through July 25). Quirkiness prevails in this fascinating exhibition of more than 125 signs ranging from the late 19th century to the present. There are pieces of elegant folk art, vintage professionalism and poetic vernacular, like a bent and torn sheet of cardboard with the scrawled words: "I smile only from the truth. I don't wash car windows" (Johnson).
 
Galleries: Chelsea
 
"THE BUREAU OF INVERSE TECHNOLOGY," Postmasters, 459 West 19th Street, (212) 727-3323 (through July 31). The Bureau of Inverse Technology is a group of Neo-Dadaists who think up perverse applications for new technology. Though visually uninteresting, their most intriguing projects operate like chillingly plausible ideas in a dark science-fiction novel. "Suicide Box" proposes to correlate a real-time tracked suicide rate (people leaping from Golden Gate Bridge) with the Dow Jones Industrial Average to generate "a new economic indicator" called the "Despondency Index" (Johnson).
 
SAINT CLAIR CEMIN, Cheim & Read, 521 West 23d Street, (212) 242-7727 (through July 31). Mr. Cemin, one of his generation's most inventive sculptors (he was born in 1951) presents five marmoreal mock monuments, including a sphinx with a smoothly finished woman's face and a roughly carved body; an archaic, cartoonish horse pierced by a stainless-steel spear, and a square wind-filled sail carved from a single block of stone (Johnson).
 
"CHANGING FACES," Jim Kempner, 501 West 23d Street, (212) 206-6872 (through July 24). A crowded, wildly diverse and rewarding selection of 74 contemporary portraits, including Robert Mapplethorpe's luminous photograph of a beatific Alice Neel; John Currin's ink drawing of a winsomely sensual girl; a skittery lithograph by Kiki Smith depicting birds, a cat and someone's sideways head, and tiny, finely made portraits of artists by Jim Torok. Look also for works by Elizabeth Peyton, Chuck Close, David Hockney and William Kentridge (Johnson).
 
"EUROPE ON A SHOESTRING," Weber, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 691-5711 (through July 31). This roundup of European avant-gardists ranges from the amusing to the oblique. Highlights include a Roman Olpalka number painting; Alghiero E. Boetti's enormous steel-framed window with the delightful title, "Nothing to See, Nothing to Hide," and Hans Haacke's "Photo Opportunity," which pairs a portrait of George and Barbara Bush at a storm disaster site with a portrait of a poor Alabama farm family by Walker Evans (Johnson).
 
WADE GUYTON, Andrew Kreps, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 741-8849 (through July 30). Mr. Guyton has removed everything from the gallery's office and storage space and installed a puzzling, roughly made abstract sculpture of slotted Plexiglas units, two oblique architectural photographs and a piece of dark plywood. This stark and harsh environment contrasts sharply with the crowded, anarchic installation of Kreps's complete inventory in the main exhibition space (Johnson).
 
"KILL ALL LIES," Luhring Augustine, 531 West 24th Street, (212) 206-9100 (through July 30). This motley group show is held together by language, subversive intent and different kinds of static. Jean-Michel Basquiat's early graffiti wall writings are recorded in Henry Flynt's handsome color photographs; the 1998 United States bombing of Iraq is the subject of a sound piece by Dara Birnbaum, and Steve DiBennedetto's bright, fragmented abstract paintings are little exploding worlds unto themselves (Smith).
 
B. G. MUHN, Stux, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 352-1600 (through July 31). Mr. Muhn, who was born in Korea and teaches at Georgetown University, produces crafty, surrealistic paintings combining abstract elements, luminous color fields and images that may be highly finished or loosely sketched. Mood ranges from portentous to absurd, as in the picture of a rabbit with a big pink tongue on a tormented-looking bald man's head (Johnson).
 
"THE SEA, THE SEA," Murray Guy, 453 West 17th Street, (212) 463-7372 (through July 30). Among the attractions in this smart, understated selection of works related to oceanic themes are Kay Rosen's bouncy painting of the words "nausea" and "seasick"; deft painterly miniatures by James Sheehan and Pamela Golden; a lush seascape made of cut paper by David Thorpe, and dark, dense, postcard-size pictures of watery surfaces by Michael Blodget (Johnson).
 
"STARS AND STRIPES," Ricco/Maresca, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 627-4819 (through Aug. 14). In this absorbing exhibition of photographs and folk art America's star-spangled banner exerts iconic resonance. In Philip Jones Griffith's photograph "Vietnam," the flag flies in the distance while a soldier washes up in a crater; Jayne Hinds Bidaut's shadowy, contemporary tintypes depict full-bodied nude women wrapped in the flag, and a funky, flag-waving goddess of liberty weather vane, made in 1865, points the way (Johnson).
 
Other Galleries
 
"FOR MYLES," five myles, 558 St. Johns Place, Brooklyn, (718) 783-4438 (through July 24). A new exhibition space opens in Brooklyn with a six-artist show selected by Marian Griffiths, the former Sculpture Center director. Included are a snaky, 27-foot cast-iron spinal column by Jack Pospisil; Michael Lee Poy's globular, cosmically split "Crystal City"; poetic boxed works about hair by Cathleen Lewis; a meditative grid of padded paper and pins by Veronica Ryan; Terry Boddie's mixed-media essays on the martial art Capoelra, and ceremonial tiled stools by Maria Elena Gonzalez (Johnson).
 
ROMUALD HAZOUME, The Project, 421 West 126th Street, Harlem, (212) 662-8610 (through July 25). The first United States show of this West African artist includes two dozen small, masklike sculptures made from industrial and commercial materials: detergent jugs, video cassette casings, electric fan blades. Mr. Hazoume is a deft and witty assemblagist of objects and ideas: references to traditional art, consumer culture and an economy of recycling are all touched on here. In the back gallery are seven airy paintings of oracular pictographic forms painted on layers of earth. A welcome debut (Cotter).
 
* LIZA LOU, "American Glamorama," Grand Central Terminal, (212) 878-7178 (through July 26). The extreme beader Liza Lou followed up her unforgettable "Kitchen" (1995) with the spectacular "Backyard" (1997), on view along with other works in the Main Waiting Room. A life-size tableau of twinkling grass and goofy flowers surrounding a loaded picnic table, a ruby barbecue grill, a glittering lawn mower and more, all realized in zillions of glass beads, "Backyard" is not only a marvel of crafty industry, but also a funky, transcendental transfiguration of an iconic American scene (Johnson).
 
SUSAN WANKLYN, Cheryl Pelavin, 13 Jay Street, Lower Manhattan, (212) 925-9424 (through Sept. 18). To gaze upon Ms. Wanklyn's unassumingly radiant paintings -- shifty interweavings of richly hued translucent bands -- is to surrender to a fine visual hedonism. Ms. Wanklyn creates her luminous plaids using wide brushes and homemade, milk-based casein paint. Her process is transparently simple yet results in complex orchestrations of light, color and form. One moment you feel as if you are looking at a piece of a tablecloth, the next into veiled Rothkoesque space (Johnson).
 
Last Chance
 
JOSE BEDIA, Ramis Barquet, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 644-9090 (through today) and Annina Nosei, 530 West 22d Street, Chelsea, (212) 741-8695 (through today). The best works in this two-gallery show are visionary white line pictures made on shaped and unstretched black canvases. A pointy-eared figure at the top of a crystalline mountain grasps a great flying bird by the tail; a man warms his hands at a fire while a woman with flowing breast milk nurses a phoenix. Mr. Bedia, a Cuban-born artist living in Florida, condenses such fabulous narratives into luminous compositions of Art Deco-like elegance (Johnson).
 
"COLLECTING IN DEPTH: DRAWINGS BY GROSZ, SCHWITTERS, ERNST AND KLEE," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, (212) 708-9400 (through Tuesday). While a little on the dry side, this exhibition effectively encapsulates the careers of four major German modernists, layering their sensibilities like a sandwich and demonstrating the singular uses that each artist found for Cubism. In the outer layers, George Grosz and Paul Klee reformed the tensile lines and transparencies of Analytic Cubism for the purposes, respectively, of scathing social satire and psychologically charged fusions of fantasy and form. In between, Kurt Schwitters and Max Ernst took innovations of Synthetic Cubist collage into new territory. Schwitters used the detritus of everyday life to create a streetwise formalism that indexed different kinds of social interaction and human contact. Ernst extracted found images from their natural habitat in the public press to create a universe as fully imaged as Klee's, only scarier. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Consumer Prices Rise in New Jersey

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Consumer prices in southern New Jersey rose 0.6 percent from April to June and 2.4 percent for the year that ended in June, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.
Consumer prices in northern New Jersey rose 0.4 percent from May to June and 2.1 percent for the year that ended in June, the bureau reported. 
 The Consumer Price Index is compiled every two months for southern New Jersey and monthly for northern New Jersey.
Energy price increases were responsible for most of the increase in overall retail prices in southern New Jersey, said Alan M. Paisner, the bureau's regional commissioner in Philadelphia.
Seasonal factors accounted for most of the increase in northern New Jersey, said John L. Wieting, the bureau's regional commissioner in New York, citing increases in electricity prices and out-of-town lodging charges.

HEADLINE: Once, Conservatives Knew the Value of Transportation

BYLINE: By Bud Shuster; Bud Shuster, a Republican from Pennsylvania, is chairman of the House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Abraham Lincoln called Senator Henry Clay "my beau ideal," largely because he was dedicated to building America. Clay, whose nickname was "Capital Improvements Harry," helped pass legislation to construct roads and inland waterways to tie America together. During the Civil War, Lincoln authorized the construction of the first transcontinental railroad. Teddy Roosevelt championed the Panama Canal, and Dwight Eisenhower created the Interstate System.
Fiscally responsible Republicans, all. 
 Fortunately, most modern-day conservatives still believe in building America. Witness the strong support last year from conservatives at all levels of government for the Transportation Equity Act, which unlocked Eisenhower's highway trust fund and allowed it to be used for its intended purpose of improving highways and transit systems.
Unfortunately, some conservatives seem dedicated to breathing new life into Benjamin Disraeli's adage that "it is much easier to be critical than to be correct." These critics have little inclination to deal in facts or face the reality of a growing America. They know the cost of everything but the value of nothing. Some have called this "Know-Nothing Conservatism."
They criticize increased spending on transportation, but they do not differentiate between transportation trust-fund dollars and general tax dollars. They do not tell you that the trust fund receives money from an 18.3-cent-per-gallon tax on gasoline and an 8 percent surcharge on airline tickets, all of which is designated solely to pay for our country's transportation needs.
These conservative critics oppose investments by trying to discredit them. They call spending on public works in someone else's backyard a pork barrel project, but that is far from the truth. In the Transportation Equity Act, for example, only 5 percent of the money goes to Congressionally mandated projects. The rest goes to the Department of Transportation or to the states.
This year, some conservatives are once again keeping their heads buried in the sand. The House overwhelmingly passed the Aviation Investment and Reform Act last month, by a vote of 316 to 110; 67 percent of Republicans -- including the Speaker and the majority leader -- approved of this measure.
But this didn't stop some conservative critics from immediately attacking the bill as "busting the budget" and "fiscally irresponsible."
Never mind that many Americans are furious over the decline in air service. Never mind that our antiquated air-traffic control system, which fails somewhere nearly every week, needs both reform and an infusion of capital investment.
Never mind that the National Civil Aviation Review Commission established by our Republican Congress warns that "the United States aviation system is headed toward gridlock shortly after the turn of the century" and that "it will result in a deterioration of aviation safety, harm the efficiency and growth of our domestic economy, and hurt our position in the global marketplace."
Never mind that the money in the aviation trust fund will skyrocket to $90 billion within 10 years if we don't make the investment. Never mind that the aviation taxes would otherwise be used in smoke-and-mirrors budget gimmickry to help finance general tax cuts. Never mind that the bill does not contain any projects earmarked for any specific Congressional districts.
And never mind that some "Know-Nothing" conservatives in the media will attack this session for being a "do nothing" Congress. The one thing Congress is doing, over their objections, is building assets for the future of our country.
Perhaps the next time they attack Government spending, they might reflect on an observation by the columnist George Will: "Many of today's conservatives rallied 'round keeping control of the Panama Canal. But would such conservatives have built it in the first place?"

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Optimism on Corporate Profits Lifts Dow to Another High

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks powered ahead across the board yesterday, capping a week of record-setting sessions as Wall Street toasted good corporate earnings.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 23.43 points, or two-tenths of a percent, to 11,209.84, beating Monday's record of 11,200.98.
The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index gained 25.11 points, or nine-tenths of a percent, to 2,864.48, its third consecutive record finish. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index set its second consecutive record, rising 9.16 points, or seven-tenths of a percent, to 1,418.78.
In the broader market, declining issues edged out advances 1,481 to 1,474 on active trading of 714 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 1 3/32, to 91 6/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.88 percent from 5.91 percent on Thursday.
"Usually options expirations bring some extra oomph, but we didn't see that this week," said Barry Hyman, analyst at Ehrenkrantz King Nussbaum Inc.
The week ended with a double expiration: stock options and index options.
Despite setting records on Monday and yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average was ahead only 16.14 points for the week.
"This has been a technology rally and I think that's good for the overall market," Mr. Hyman said. "The technology sector has been and will remain the leading sector."
But he said that with many technology issues looking very expensive based on their charts, it would be good to see more rotation into economically sensitive stocks.
In the only major United States economic data out yesterday, the Federal Reserve reported that output by factories, mines and utilities gained two-tenths of a percent last month, the same as in May. It was the fifth consecutive monthly increase.
Notwithstanding steadily rising output, businesses ran at 80.3 percent of their maximum capacity in June, down slightly from 80.4 in May.
Peter Canelo, a Morgan Stanley Dean Witter market strategist, raised his 1999 profit growth outlook for the companies in the Standard & Poor's 500 index to 14 percent from 12 percent.
Among the active stocks, Microsoft jumped 5 1/16, to 99 7/16, on a report that the software giant was close to creating a stock to track its Microsoft Network business.
Microsoft also benefited from news that a Federal jury in Connecticut found that the company did not violate antitrust law in a suit brought by a small Connecticut software company.
Air Products and Chemicals fell 4 3/8, to 36 15/16, after it issued a profit warning for its fiscal third quarter because of pressure on its equipment and chemicals businesses. Earlier in the week, Air Products and Air Liquide of France announced a bid for BOC Group P.L.C. of Britain.

HEADLINE: Caterpillar Sees Profit Growth Slowing in '99

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, July 16

 BODY:
After months of hinting at a turnaround, Caterpillar Inc., the maker of construction and earth-moving equipment, warned investors yesterday that profit growth would continue to slide this year.
The warning came after Caterpillar said that its second-quarter profits had fallen 36.5 percent from a year earlier because of slumping demand for heavy machines and equipment. It was the fourth consecutive quarterly profit decline for Caterpillar. 
 Shares of Caterpillar fell 18.75 cents, to $58.9375, on the New York Stock Exchange.
The company said it revised its outlook because sales of more profitable machines and equipment, like mining trucks, had dipped while sales of less profitable equipment, like truck engines, had gained -- upsetting the more favorable profit mix that had been the basis for an earlier projection.
Second-quarter sales were $5.1 billion, Caterpillar said, down from $5.6 billion in the second quarter of last year, and profits in the latest quarter were $283 million, down from $446 million a year earlier. Earnings per share were 78 cents, slightly below Wall Street expectations and down from $1.20.
Wall Street analysts said they were disappointed by the results and by the company's warning, but several analysts said investors were already looking ahead to early next year.
"Caterpillar, at this point, is a 2000 story," said David Bleustein, an analyst at Paine Webber. "We expect the benefits of the global recovery to more than offset any slowdown there might be here in the United States."
That turnaround, however, was expected to come earlier this year. In March, Caterpillar executives sounded an upbeat note at a convention in Las Vegas, Nev., saying that signs of a recovery in Asia, corporate belt-tightening and a push to diversify its business could put the company on sound footing in 1999.
But today, the company pushed that optimism further out, saying that it did not expect a big jump in profits until the fourth quarter of this year.
"We're trying to fix this," said F. Lynn McPheeters, chief financial officer at Caterpillar, which is based in Peoria, Ill. "We thought the mix of business would turn a little earlier."
Although Caterpillar says its warning grew out of a slowdown in the sale of more profitable mining and oil exploration equipment, the company pegged its yearlong profit slump to a recession in parts of Asia, Latin America, Africa and the Middle East and weakness in the mining and oil exploration industry.
Despite those problems, Caterpillar executives say the company has made great strides in diversifying its mix of businesses, noting gains in everything from solar turbines to truck engines and financial services.
Revenue in 1998 was a record $21 billion, and this year the company expects revenue to be slightly below that figure. Profits, though, could be down 20 percent to 25 percent because of fierce competition and the unexpected slump in some of the company's most profitable products, the company said. Although profits dipped last year to $1.5 billion, it was the third consecutive year the company recorded a profit of more than $1 billion. Even with a sharp slowdown, the company could still earn $1 billion this year.
"We'll have profits that are down but reasonable, considering the recession we've had in many of our businesses," Mr. McPheeters said today in a telephone interview.
He also said that the company had already seen a slight upturn in Asia, the only region where sales gained from a year earlier, and that Caterpillar had not yet benefited from a Federal highway bill that recently went into effect.
The company said it would continue to benefit from cost reduction put into place a year ago, and there are expectations for a solid fourth quarter, with some analysts estimating a profit jump of 40 percent or more from a year ago, when Caterpillar suffered a steep decline.
Wall Street analysts, though less optimistic in March than the company was at that time, now say they believe the company's fortunes will turn in 2000. While several analysts dropped their third-quarter and year-end estimates, according to the First Call Corporation, which surveys analysts, no analyst altered a prediction for next year.
"This is being seen as a one-quarter problem," said Charles Hill, director of research at First Call. "This is a pretty mild analyst reaction."
