HEADLINE: Talks Halt On Bombing Of Embassy In Belgrade

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: BEIJING, July 16

 BODY:
Chinese and American officials wound up two days of negotiations today on compensation for the NATO bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, without reaching an agreement.
An American official said talks would resume later this month. 
 The stalemate was a disappointment to officials who had hoped an agreement would clear a persistent stumbling block in relations between the two as a potential military conflict brews over Taiwan.
Presidents Clinton and Jiang Zemin have each expressed a desire to recover some of the good will that was lost over sharply diverging views of the NATO air campaign in Kosovo and that was further eroded by the embassy bombing in May. Yet the deadlock, after inconclusive bickering about money, appeared to represent a clash of midlevel officials who represent the less forgiving sides of their respective Governments.
An American official familiar with the talks described the officials' sharply different approaches as a "complete disconnect."
"It was lawyers' talking at lawyers," the official said. "Entirely different mind-sets."
If money was the topic, the underlying issue for China seemed to be an obsession with regaining national pride that it feels was wounded in the bombing and harmed further by what it regards as an utter lack of remorse by the Americans. Beijing has rejected American explanations that the bombing was an accident.
On the American side, lawyers in the delegation were most worried about setting a precedent for future compensation cases, to the extent that they even refused to use the term "compensation" in the talks, saying "humanitarian payments" instead.
A legal adviser to the State Department who headed the American team, David Andrews, issued a short statement that called the substance of the talks sensitive and complex. Progress was made, Mr. Andrews said, but he did not elaborate.
What is so sensitive and complex appears to be the starting point that Chinese officials still see the bombing as a deliberate attack on the Chinese nation, making them unwilling to discuss other bilateral issues until the bombing question has been resolved.
A senior Chinese official, Zhao Qi zheng, elaborated on the Chinese view on Thursday at a news conference. He ridiculed the American explanation that they hit the wrong target because of defective intelligence and outdated maps, comparing the odds that three outdated maps were used simultaneously to rolling dice and getting triple snake eyes.
"The chances of throwing a one, that's 1 out of 6," said Mr. Zhao, who heads the Information Office of the State Council, or China's Cabinet. "If you roll three dice, it is 1 out of 216. If you add in other errors, that is like rolling 10 dice. The chances are close to nothing."
Chinese officials have demanded compensation for the families of three Chinese who died in the bombing and for 20 who were injured, as well as for damage to the building. They have also asked that those responsible for the bombing be identified and punished.
In response, the Americans have demanded reciprocal compensation for damage to the United States Embassy in Beijing, where rock-throwing broke virtually every window in one building. The United State Consulate in another city, Chengdu, was burned in a riot.
"The United States hopes to make these payments as soon as possible," Mr. Andrews's statement said. "Both sides also raised their respective property claims."
A spokesman for the American Embassy said that Mr. Andrews would leave Beijing on Saturday and that he or someone else would resume talks at the end of the month.
Without a resolution over the bombing, officials say, it may be difficult for Washington and Beijing to regain footing on another, arguably far more significant, issue, China's entry to the World Trade Organization.
China's effort to join the organization, desired both by China's leaders and by the Clinton Administration, now looks increasingly vulnerable.
For a deal to go through this year, an agreement between the United States and China would essentially have to be worked out before Presidents Clinton and Jiang meet in September at the Asia Pacific Economic Conference in New Zealand. If this year's deadline is not met, China's entry may be delayed for several years, a potentially serious setback to China's ability to effect much-needed reforms in its state-owned industries.
China's top trade negotiator, Long Yongtu, said again this week that China would not resume trade talks until the bombing issue had been resolved.

COUNTRY: CHINA (96%); UNITED STATES (95%); SERBIA (94%); SERBIA & MONTENEGRO (93%); KOSOVO (92%); TAIWAN (92%);

HEADLINE: Industrial Production Gained 0.2% in June

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
Industrial production in the United States rose in June, the seventh month without a decline, led by increased demand for automobiles, computers and electricity.
Output at factories, mines and utilities rose two-tenths of a percent last month, capping a 3.9 percent second-quarter annualized increase, the Federal Reserve said today. The quarterly pace was the fastest in one and a half years and triple the first quarter's rate. 
 The Fed's industrial production report showed that manufacturing output rose one-tenth of a percent in June after rising three-tenths of a percent in May. Manufacturing grew at a 4.1 percent annual pace in the second quarter, up from a 1.5 percent rate in the first three months of the year.
Output of autos and trucks rose 2.7 percent last month, and home electronics rose 2 percent, accounting for almost all of the June factory increase.
Production of computers and office equipment rose 2.7 percent. For the second quarter, output of computers rose at a 48 percent annual pace, up from a first-quarter rate of 33.7 percent.
But production of carpeting and furniture fell half a percent, output of construction supplies declined six-tenths of a percent and appliance output dropped three-tenths of a percent. Analysts said the declines probably reflected the recent flattening of home sales.
The overall plant-use rate, which measures industrial capacity in use, fell to 80.3 percent in June from 80.4 percent in May. Analysts had expected a June reading of 80.4 percent. May was previously reported at 80.5 percent.

HEADLINE: West Virginia, Home Of the Gray in America

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: DUNBAR, W.Va., July 14

 BODY:
Ken Hechler may be the only candidate in the post-Monica era of American politics who gets away with singling out female strangers in a crowd of constituents, holding out his arms and grinning as he gently asks, "May I give you a hug?"
In receiving multiple hugs today for his daring, the merry-eyed Mr. Hechler, West Virginia's elected Secretary of State for the past 15 years, was helped by the fact that he is an 84-year-old political legend who was wooing a sea of gray-haired retirees at the crowded Kanawha Valley Senior Services picnic. 
 The tableau was revealing. For West Virginia now has the oldest per capita population in the union, having overtaken Florida in 1996. Its senior residents, in the upper half of a population with a median age of 38.6 (Florida's is 38.3), include a record tide of returning natives who choose to come home to retire after careers elsewhere.
"A significant factor in their return is the intrinsic bond in the Appalachian culture between the people and their land," said Thomas L. Dudley, research director for the state Bureau of Senior Services. Recent studies, he said, have established the state as leading the nation in attracting back original residents for retirement. They come in particular from urban areas in the East, attracted by West Virginia's lower cost of living and its rural, recreational spirit.
The current estimate is that with the elderly now accounting for 15 of every 100 state residents, the graying trend will continue upward to almost 25 per 100 by the first quarter of the new century. The state, which is widely recruiting non-native retirees the way Florida does, is making adjustments, with its older residents far more politically active than its young.
It is no wonder that Mr. Hechler, unfinished with a political career seeded in the Presidency of Franklin D. Roosevelt, has decided that a politician as old as he can be the wave of the future. Though he would seem a shoo-in for re-election to his state office, he has decided to run next year for his old seat in Congress, from which he retired after 18 years in 1976, turning to state politics.
"Life is a series of challenges and I don't want to just coast along here," said Mr. Hechler, a classic maverick who already has banjo-picking campaign advertisements on the radio.
To counter any bias that he is too old, he is offering his four younger primary challengers free baseball throws at him next week when he sits on the dunking stool at the Berkeley County Democratic picnic.
He campaigns from a signature red Jeep, always with young people at his side, often mentioning the four times a week he plays tennis. ("I'm saving golf for my old age.")
"With the oldest age average in the country, we don't expect any age bias in our politics," said Robert Perelman, the president of the rapidly growing state chapter of the American Association of Retired Persons. Mr. Perelman, 77, is a former chemical plant supervisor who teaches skiing in the winter.
Mr. Hechler is not alone as a political patriarch. West Virginia's Republican Governor, Cecil H. Underwood, is 76 and a phenomenon himself, having been the nation's boy-wonder Governor in 1956 at age 34, and then returning to politics in 1996 to be elected the oldest Governor.
"We're learning seniors do vote, but also that politicians will live longer and be more active, too," Earl Jarvis, director of Kanawha Valley Senior Services, said of the evolving lesson of West Virginia. "I'm encouraging more of my people to run for public office."
Mr. Hechler has lived a rich life as a college professor, a researcher for President Roosevelt, a speech writer for President Harry S. Truman, a book writer ("The Bridge at Remagen," a best seller about the World War II crossing of the Rhine) and an elected politician. In Congress, he bucked the state's coal industry and capped his career in Washington with the landmark Coal Mine Health and Safety Act of 1969.
He wants to go back to Washington for far more than the obvious issues brought up at the seniors' picnic, which are keeping Social Security and health-care programs effective for the elderly. He passionately campaigns for stronger controls on political fund-raising and handguns and for a half-dozen other issues, telling voters he can hardly be seeking a long, safe House career anchored in poll-tailored evasions.
"God will be setting my term limit," says Mr. Hechler rather nonchalantly. "But I don't want to be known as the candidate of the seniors," he insists. A native New Yorker, he moved here in the 1950's, fresh from working in the idealistic campaigns of Adlai E. Stevenson, to teach political science at Marshall College and try to engender fresh interest in politics among the young.
"He's a legend," said Bill Walker, a 24-year-old political science student from Marshall working the picnic crowd at Mr. Hechler's side as a summer intern. "Just to someday look back and say I learned politics from Mr. Hechler is a great honor," said the student. He exuded the kind of dedication seen in the young interns in a state program in which elderly mountaineers have been reinstilling the art of fiddle-playing. The skill had nearly been lost when earlier generations were forced to emigrate to find work.
"I'll tell you, people my age are soured on politics lately," said Mr. Walker, who is determined to run for office at the earliest opportunity.
As the elderly come to the fore, state politics are shifting to consider issues like how the revenue base will hold up as more retirees claim special tax abatements. "Most studies show incoming retirees are actually increasing the economic base," said Mr. Dudley of state senior services. "They bring in an average of $250,000 in liquid assets, and they're a tremendous resource in volunteer work, politics and civics."
Like all states, West Virginia faces the potential trauma from the retirement of a wide swath of talent when the baby-boom generation hits 65. "We'll feel it a little quicker," Mr. Dudley said. But he noted there were all sorts of variables, including a slow but promising reversal from the state's traditional loss of young workers, plus a redefinition of retirement itself.
"Close to half of the Governor's cabinet came out of retirement to serve," noted Mr. Dudley, who is busy preparing for Governor Underwood's regional conference in September on the problems and opportunities of the elderly. Next year, West Virginia will play a principal role in the United Nations' International Year of the Older Person as host of the conference on rural health.
Mr. Hechler appreciates those issues but puts more passion into railing against mechanized mountaintop coal mining and its effects on the environment, citizenry and general attractiveness of West Virginia now that all the retirees are flocking in. He has been hiking the state on this issue, just as he has been hiking nationally for campaign finance reform, a buoyant old New Dealer come round one more time.
"Oh, that's Ken Hechler," an elderly woman told her friend as the candidate confronted them at the picnic. "You ought to know him -- he's been around 100 years."
Mr. Hechler, a whippet on the hustings, responded: "One hundred years! Whoopee!" And he asked if he might give the woman a hug.

HEADLINE: Iran's View of U.S.: Evil, Bumbling or Unimportant

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: TEHERAN, Iran, July 16

 BODY:
At Friday Prayers here at noon today, the United States was presented as the all-powerful hidden hand behind Iran's worst civil unrest in two decades.
In a docudrama on television a few hours later that included clips of Jimmy Carter and Sam Donaldson, America was presented as an inept, pagan military giant that could not even rescue its own hostages in 1980 because God was on the other side. 
 The two vastly different characterizations underscore the contradictions in the official Iranian view of the United States.
On the one hand, the United States is blamed as the evil mastermind behind every misfortune -- the recent political unrest, the crippled economy, the dramatic fall of Iran's currency and the cultural pollution of the youth. On the other, the United States is scorned as the helpless superpower that has tried over the years to destroy the Islamic Republic but has failed miserably.
Then there is a third view, espoused by the reformist newspapers that back President Mohammad Khatami, that Iran can no longer play the role of victim and has to solve its own problems.
"Why do we accuse the foreign enemy, instead of acknowledging the truth and finding our own weakness?" an editorial in the newspaper Khordad asked about the violent street demonstrations of the last week. "Do we have a foreign enemy that is so strong that it managed to penetrate and riot even in the most central streets of Teheran?"
But that was not the view expressed at Teheran University, the country's biggest official platform. There, the Government sent Hassan Taheri Khoramabadi, the most junior of the four rotating speakers at Friday Prayers, to address the tens of thousands of worshipers.
American meddling was part of a plot to destroy Iran's economy, the cleric said. "America wants to prove to the European and our neighboring countries and the Middle Eastern countries that there is no stability in Iran, that there's anarchy here," he said. "That way the others would not have relations and do business with Iran."
"Death to America!" the crowd chanted.
Mr. Khoramabadi said nothing less than the demise of the revolution was the goal of the American-backed protesters. "It is the revolution that they have taken aim at," he warned.
"Death to America!" the crowd chanted again.
He asked the country's top leaders to define "a red line for the revolution" that no one would be allowed to cross. "Differences in a family can be tolerated, but there have to be unbreakable limits," he said.
"Death to America!" the crowd chanted again.
So it went all through the sermon.
Fourteen months ago at the same pavilion on the first anniversary of his election, Mr. Khatami had a different message, a call to end the clergy's tight hold on power. He silenced a group of students when they uttered the familiar, "Death to America!"
"I prefer to talk about life, not death," he said, to cheering and clapping, considered an un-Islamic and Western affectation.
But the strategy did not work.
"The regime is like a shop that is selling this slogan," said a political science professor at Teheran University who a few days ago was willing to speak on the record but is no longer. "If they lose this slogan, they have nothing left to sell."
On the docudrama this afternoon, one of the most popular viewing times of the week, a different sort of anti-Americanism was on display, "Sandstorm," an officially produced film about the failed military raid by the United States to free American hostages in April 1980.
The use of television footage from the crisis lent an authenticity to the film. It showed Mr. Carter in his signature cardigan sweater in the Oval Office, consulting with Vice President Walter F. Mondale and other top aides; Mr. Donaldson, with long sideburns, reporting the seizure of the American Embassy on ABC News on Nov. 4, 1979, and an English-speaking hostage taker who interviewed blacks and women among the hostages. The hostages were released "on humanitarian grounds."
The rescue mission was a horrific combination of bad luck and poor planning. The plan was to raid the embassy from a staging area deep in the Iranian desert. The mission was halted after three of the eight helicopters involved had been put out of action by technical problems. In the evacuation, a helicopter collided with a C-130 transport plane. Eight Americans died. The evacuating Americans left behind a battlefield scene of burned and abandoned equipment, and their comrades' bodies.
The 90-minute film portrays the Americans as ruthless, obscenity-spouting veterans of Vietnam eager to free the hostages -- and perhaps restore the monarchy in the process.
"By tomorrow, we will have Iran in our hands," the commander said in the film.
"Tell me, old soldier, do you mean we're going to have a military coup?" asked the pilot.
"Did you think we're going with no plan and no invitation into the heart of the enemy?" the commander replied.
Much of the film was accurate. It portrayed a team of American spies' posing as journalists as they watched the embassy from a hotel across the street.
But like any docudrama, distortions abounded. The main Persian-speaking spy was a Zionist, who wears a yarmulke. When an American commando tried to pray, his commander did not let him finish.
The end of the film showed actual film of the rescuers' crash site and the eight bodies.
"Who stopped Carter's helicopters?" a male voice asked at the film's end, a quote from the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the father of Iran's revolution. "We stopped it. The sands stopped it. They were God's messenger."
In the reformist newspapers, a different sort of "dialogue" is being conducted.
The crackdown against the protesters and the pledge by the authorities to use all necessary means to prevent more trouble may have stilled the students, at least for the moment. But the move has emboldened commentators in several newspapers, who are writing in ways that they would not have dared even a few weeks ago.
The newspapers have become a voice of the country's conscience, demanding that Iran look for the reasons behind the unrest at home, not abroad.
One argument is that years of restrictions have led youths to rebel.
"When our kids are at school, they only hear things like, 'Do not do this, do not do that,' " Shahla Ezazi, a sociologist, wrote on Thursday in Neshat. "Instead of learning to become independent citizens capable of living in society, they react this way."

HEADLINE: Legislators In Nassau Approve Tax On Land Sales

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., July 16

 BODY:
Voting along party lines, the Nassau Legislature today approved a new 1 percent tax on property sales to help solve the county's deepening financial crisis. But Republicans in the majority made no public mention of the fiscal reforms they have conceded are necessary to rein in the county's budgetary practices.
Democrats in the State Assembly, whose approval is necessary before the new tax becomes law, have insisted that they will not do so unless Nassau agrees to tough oversight measures. Among other things, they want the State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, to be given approval power over all Nassau budgets and bond issues. The county's debt has been downgraded to near-junk levels in recent weeks, and bond-rating agencies have criticized the County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, for consistently spending more than the county raises in taxes. 
 An emergency legislative session called by Mr. Gulotta was delayed for hours this morning as Republicans sought to agree on measures that would satisfy the Assembly.
Officials involved in the private talks said the Republicans were amenable to giving Mr. McCall a seat on a new outside financial board that would be empowered to send Mr. Gulotta's budgets back for revision. But when told that any such measure would require a countywide referendum, the Republicans gave up, the officials said.
Frustrated, legislators from both parties then spent much of the day belittling Mr. Gulotta's budget director, Michael Fabiano.
They criticized him for asking for the new property-sales tax without having made any firm estimate of how much money it would contribute toward reducing the county's deficit of more than $200 million. "How much time would you need?" Presiding Officer Bruce A. Blakeman asked. "We'll give you a calculator. We'll give you a room."
Democrats lambasted Mr. Fabiano and Mr. Gulotta, who was not present, for never having put their deficit-cutting measures into writing.
"Where is the plan?" asked the minority leader, Judith A. Jacobs. "I have to assume there is no plan. There's a wish list."
Mr. Fabiano said that Mr. Gulotta's plan was really a "menu" of items, including tax increases and cost savings. "It's a fluid document," he said.
One legislator, Barbara J. Johnson, a Democrat from Port Washington, said, referring to the rating agencies that downgraded the county's bonds, "If this is the presentation you made to Moody's and Standard & Poor's, I can see why they downgraded us."

HEADLINE: Fears of Military Confrontation With China Shake Taiwan Financial Markets

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, July 16

 BODY:
Fears of a military confrontation with China swept through financial markets in Taiwan today, causing the biggest single-day plunge in the stock index in nine years.
In a panicky wave of selling that began on rumors of Chinese military action against Taiwan, the Taipei stock index fell 6.4 percent, or 506 points, to close at 7,411. The jitters spread across the region, with stock markets' dropping in Tokyo, Hong Kong and Singapore. 
 Tensions between China and Taiwan have been growing since last weekend, when President Lee Teng-hui of Taiwan unexpectedly dropped the long-held premise that Taiwan and China are separately governed parts of the same country. Mr. Lee declared that the countries ought to negotiate on a "state-to-state" basis.
The Chinese Government responded with denunciations of Mr. Lee and warnings that it was ready to use military force to stop Taiwan from declaring independence from China. The warning led newspapers in Hong Kong to report that China might seize a couple of islands off Taiwan as a show of force.
Military officials in Taiwan flatly denied the reports, saying they had detected no Chinese military movements. But the damage was done. Despite aggressive buying of shares by the Government this week, Taiwan's market has fallen more than 13 percent since the dispute erupted.
Domestic politics has deepened the instability. A popular former Governor of Taiwan, James Soong, announced today that he would break away from the governing Nationalist Party and run for president next year as an independent. Although Mr. Soong's move was widely expected, it exposed a fissure in the party, which has governed Taiwan for 50 years.
Some analysts said they worried that prolonged instability could derail the economy, which managed to get through the Asian crisis largely unscathed and had been picking up steam lately.
"We're expecting a low-intensity confrontation across the straits, which could last until the presidential elections next year," Dong Tao, a regional strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston in Hong Kong, said. "Obviously, the longer it lasts, the more negative the impact on the economy would be."
Mr. Tao said Taiwan was more vulnerable to a crisis of confidence than other countries, because a large percentage of people's wealth is tied up in stocks. So a further drop in share prices could cause a decline in consumer spending.
Taiwan's economy is driven by exports, particularly semiconductor chips and other computer components. A growing confrontation could prompt computer companies in the United States to cancel orders.
"It happened in 1995, it could happen again," Mr. Tao said, referring to a dispute in which China conducted military exercises and tested ballistic missiles near Taiwan. That crisis, defused after President Clinton sent two aircraft carrier groups to the region in 1996, had measurable negative effects on the country's growth.
Before the verbal fireworks this week Taiwan had emerged as the economic star of Asia. Although the country never fell into a wrenching recession like its rivals Hong Kong and Singapore, its growth slowed, from 6.8 percent in 1997 to 4.8 percent last year. After a shaky start this year, analysts said, Taiwan's domestic spending and exports had picked up strongly.
In January, Credit Suisse First Boston predicted that Taiwan's economy would grow 3.5 percent in 1999. In May, it raised its forecast, to 5.2 percent. Mr. Tao said the firm had been on the verge of raising it again, to 6 percent. Now, however, he said it would hold off until the end of the current crisis.
"From time to time, China finds ways to make Taiwan feel uncomfortable," Mr. Tao said. "I don't think it would go so far as to fire missiles."
Few experts said they believed that the tension would escalate into a shooting war. Some even said the sharp drop in the Taiwanese market is a good opportunity to invest. But the sell off was a reminder that the Asian recovery is a fragile phenomenon, driven by market psychology, as well as economic fundamentals.

HEADLINE: House Supports Trade Benefits To Aid Africa

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
The House approved a far-ranging American economic initiative for Africa today that offers enhanced trade benefits in exchange for the adoption of free-market practices by African nations.
The bill, passed by a vote of 234 to 163, would authorize quota-free and duty-free imports from 48 sub-Saharan African countries, including some of the world's poorest nations, for 10 years, with a particular focus on textiles and apparel. African-made textiles currently face import taxes of 15 percent to 25 percent. 
 If the legislation, known as the African Growth and Opportunity Act, were to become law, it would be the first major trade-promotion measure enacted in the United States since the 1994 North American Free Trade Agreement that established duty-free commerce between Canada, the United States and Mexico.
The African legislation has been quietly percolating through Congress for months. President Clinton, who has strongly supported such a measure since he visited Africa in 1998, began a concerted effort to push for passage earlier this year. House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois is also a strong supporter.
But the legislation still faces big opposition in the Senate, which rejected a similar measure last year. It also comes against a backdrop of increased trade protectionism in the United States, where companies in industries like steel and textiles fear a rising tide of inexpensive imports could hurt profits and jobs.
Proponents of the African legislation contend that United States trade with Africa is relatively small and any increased imports from Africa would have no harmful effects on the healthy American economy. American merchandise exports to the region totaled $6.7 billion in 1998 while imports from Africa amounted to $13.4 billion. By comparison, United States trade with Japan alone totaled $180 billion last year, according to Commerce Department figures.
The bill's supporters also contend that removing all quotas and taxes on African products would stimulate economic growth in the region and nurture the increasing number of fledgling democracies there.
"This will open a new era in U.S. relations with sub-Saharan Africa," said Representative Bill Archer, a Texas Republican who heads the House Ways and Means Committee.
After today's vote, Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative, said in a statement that the House had taken "a vital step toward promoting further economic growth and reform in Africa."
The prospects for Senate passage are unclear, even though its version of the bill is more restrictive.. It would require, for example, that African nations use American raw materials in the manufacture of their textile exports to the United States.
The Senate version is also incorporated into broader trade legislation that includes a Caribbean Basin Initiative, backed by Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader.
"U.S. policy has virtually ignored Africa," said Senator Richard Lugar, an Indiana Republican who is the Senate's main sponsor of the measure. "This bill encourages a transition from aid to trade for sub-Saharan countries committed to economic and political reform."
The bill does not affect foreign aid to African countries.
Opposition in the House and Senate comes largely from Southeastern lawmakers from districts with large numbers of textile workers.
"Everyone here wants to help Africa, but we don't want to do it on the backs of U.S. workers," said Representative Richard M. Burr, a North Carolina Republican whose district around Winston-Salem includes 22,000 textile employees.
Textile and apparel imports from sub-Saharan Africa represented less than 1 percent, or $383 million, of the $46 billion worth of all such imports in 1996, according to the International Trade Commission. A commission study found that even if all quotas and duties were removed, African textiles would still probably remain below 2 percent of total United States textile imports in the next 10 years.
Opponents say they do not fear direct competition from African businesses. Rather, they are concerned that large quantities of inexpensive textiles from countries like China may be shipped illegally through Africa to the United States. Supporters insist that the bill includes tough safeguards against that practice, called transshipment.
"It will be a national holiday in China when we pass this bill," said Representative Lindsey Graham, a South Carolina Republican.
The trade bill divided House Democrats, many of whom complained that the Africa legislation failed to include adequate protections for African workers and the environment. In today's vote, 136 Republicans and 98 Democrats supported the bill, while 63 Republicans, 99 Democrats and one independent opposed it.
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic leader, voted for the bill, while Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the Democratic whip, or No. 2 official, voted against it. Mr. Gephardt, however, opposes a Caribbean Basin Initiative and would oppose combining it with the Africa bill.
The Congressional Black Caucus was also badly riven over the bill. Representative Charles B. Rangel of New York, the ranking Democrat on Ways and Means, has championed the Africa trade bill over the last several years, and personally lobbied several wavering Democrats, House aides said.
But 14 of the black caucus's 36 members opposed the bill today, led by Representative Jesse Jackson Jr., an Illinois Democrat. These critics say that multinational companies will exploit African workers, and that the bill does not address other crucial issues like debt relief and AIDS in Africa.
"Tell me where in this bill it says multinationals must hire African workers?" Mr. Jackson said during today's debate on the House floor.

HEADLINE: Agreement at Last in Albany On $73 Billion Budget Plan

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 16

 BODY:
Three and a half months after the state budget was due, legislative leaders and Gov. George E. Pataki have agreed to the outlines of a $73 billion deal, legislators and top aides said today. The plan would preserve a prekindergarten program and make no new cuts in health care, while salting away $1.8 billion to pay for future tax cuts.
The Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, told legislators today to return to Albany on Monday, in order to convene conference committees to draft a detailed budget over the next week or two. 
 The news follows one of the most rancorous proceedings in what has become, in recent years, a uniformly rancorous process. For months, Mr. Silver has accused the Governor of sacrificing New York's needs to his ambitions for national office, while Mr. Pataki has charged that the Speaker was trying to spend so much that the state would rack up huge deficits and would have to forgo promised tax cuts.
This year, for the first time, a state law provides that legislators' salaries will be withheld as long as the budget is overdue, adding friction to an already heated atmosphere.
Last year, the two houses of the Legislature passed a spending plan that pleased nearly everyone, only to have the Governor veto $1.6 billion worth of items in it, most of them programs prized by the Democrats. That experience cast a long shadow over this year's budget talks, with Mr. Silver determined not to repeat it.
This week's breakthrough, officials said, rested in part on Mr. Pataki's assurances that he would not make widespread use of his veto pen this year -- though some vetoes remain likely -- as long as the Legislature remains within the agreed-to boundaries.
The legislative leaders had agreed weeks ago to spend about $1.1 billion more than Mr. Pataki proposed in January, but the Governor had indicated that their figure was a few hundred million dollars too high. In the last few days, Mr. Pataki agreed to the $1.1 billion in additions, but how one arrives at that number relies heavily on widely varying estimates of what some programs will cost, and he insisted on calculating more conservatively than Mr. Silver had hoped. There is still no accord on precisely how to reach that number, and officials warned that the agreement could fall apart on this issue.
Word of progress was met with wary relief by state officials who are painfully aware that tentative deals here have a habit of imploding over the finer points. "There is very nearly an agreement, but the operative words here are 'very nearly,' " said Zenia Mucha, Mr. Pataki's communications director.
Today, Mr. Silver and Mr. Bruno issued a joint statement, saying that they were "in virtual agreement" on an overall spending figure. Aides and legislators said the statement understates how close to a final deal the Legislature is, with the leaders having already agreed to a rough division of the money by category.
In intensive negotiations over the last six weeks, Mr. Pataki, Mr. Silver and Mr. Bruno at least partly abandoned their pledge not to return to the traditional practice of negotiating a budget among the three of them, with minimal input from rank-and-file legislators.
This year's budget is already the second-latest in state history, at 108 days overdue as of Saturday. If there are any snags, it could break the record set two years ago, when the final budget bills were not passed until Aug. 4, 126 days late.
Mr. Pataki appears to have achieved one of his two primary goals for this budget: the state's $1.8 billion surplus from the fiscal year that ended March 31 will be saved, not spent, to insure that the state will have enough money to absorb tax cuts that are already in law, and ones that are to go into effect over the next few years.
It is unclear whether he reached his other goal, to keep the spending increase under the rate of inflation. It is an important claim for a man who would like the national Republican Party to consider him for the Vice President's spot on next year's ticket, and is trying to reassert his credentials as a fiscal conservative, after last year's 6 percent overall spending increase.
In January, Mr. Pataki called for a 1.8 percent increase. Officials are saying the budget outline that the leaders have agreed to raises spending by more than 3 percent.
But state lawmakers routinely overestimate expenses when drafting budgets, so the true figures will not be known until the fiscal year ends next spring. Last fiscal year, the state spent $800 million less than was predicted by the enacted budget; the year before, it spent $1.1 billion less.
Mr. Silver and the Democrats have reportedly salvaged, for the next year, one of their prized programs, the state's year-old investment in prekindergarten classes, all-day kindergarten and lower class sizes in the early grades. Mr. Pataki had proposed eliminating the program and replacing it with a less expensive block grant that districts could spend as they pleased.
But the future of the program remains murky beyond this fiscal year, officials said, with the Governor unwilling to lock it into law permanently. The 1997 agreement that created it called for implementation in stages, with spending rising from more than $300 million over the next year, to $1.4 billion in a few years.
The state will probably increase aid to school districts by about the same amount as last year's record increase of more than $800 million, or more than 6 percent, officials said.
Early this year, Mr. Pataki proposed new Medicaid cuts, while Mr. Silver proposed undoing cuts made to the program in 1995 and 1996. Both demands were seen as bargaining positions, and both have been abandoned, officials said, though many thorny details must still be resolved. The 1995 and 1996 cuts, which expired on July 1, will be reinstated, officials said, but the state and local governments may not be reimbursed for the money they lost as a result for a three-month period.
The biggest victor is Mr. Bruno, who will apparently get a final budget that will look very much like the one his Republican majority proposed in March. The overall spending figure, the amount of education aid and the handling of Medicaid will all be very nearly what he had called for. And throughout the budget talks, it was Mr. Bruno who acted as the arbiter, maintaining good relations with both the Governor and the Speaker.
But officials said it remains to be seen what becomes of the tax cuts, particularly those for businesses, which the Senate leader sought.
The leaders have agreed to sell the state's malpractice insurance pool for doctors to a private insurance company, which officials said could raise about $250 million, but it was not clear tonight how the money would be spent.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Strong Corporate Earnings Push Stock Gauges Higher
Stocks ended a week of record-setting sessions as Wall Street cheered good corporate earnings. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index gained 25.11 points, or nine-tenths of a percent, to 2,864.48, its third consecutive record finish. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 23.43 points, to 11,209.84, beating Monday's record of 11,200.98. And, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index set its second consecutive record, rising 9.16 points, to 1,418.78. Page C3.
 
House Approves African Initiatives
The House approved a far-ranging American economic initiative for Africa that authorizes quota-free and duty-free imports from 48 sub-Saharan African countries. A1.
 
Deal Closer in American Air Dispute
American Airlines and its pilots may be close to settling the dispute that inconvenienced hundreds of thousands of passengers earlier this year when pilots called in sick, forcing the airline to cancel nearly 6,700 flights. C2.
 
Chalk Up One Victory for Microsoft
A jury in Bridgeport, Conn., found that Microsoft had not violated antitrust laws in its dealings with Bristol Technology. Despite the differences between that case and the Federal antitrust case brought by the Justice Department and 19 states, Microsoft has been portrayed in both cases as an overreaching monopolist that uses its market power as a club. Steve Aeschbacher, left, a senior corporate lawyer at Microsoft, said that the verdict strongly suggested that the jury was "impressed by all the evidence in the record of the intensity and dynamism of competition in the software industry." A1.
 
Industrial Output Rose in June
Output at the factories, mines and utilities rose two-tenths of a percent in June, the seventh month without a decline, led by increased demand for automobiles, computers and electricity. C14.
 
S.E.C. Sues on Stock Promotions
The S.E.C. filed suit in Federal court in Miami accusing Globus Group of Miami and its principal, Anthony DiMarco, of fraudulently promoting the shares of a dozen tiny thinly traded companies by issuing fake press releases and creating bogus reports from leading brokerage firms. C3.
 
Mexican Companies Still Scarred
Despite Mexico's strong stock market and economy, some big companies are still suffering from the country's banking crisis. C2.
 
Dealers Sue Ford Motor in Canada
Ford dealers in Canada are suing Ford Motor of Canada over plans to convert more than 100 Lincoln-Mercury outlets to the Ford name. The dealers contend the plan breaches their contracts by creating new competition within a 10-mile radius. C2.
 
Columnist Suspended in Share Deal
The San Jose Mercury News suspended a business columnist indefinitely for accepting an offer to buy 500 shares of Autoweb.com at the initial offering price of $14. She sold the shares two days after the offering and made a profit of $9,000. A8.
 
Air Products Warns of Weak Profit
Air Products and Chemicals warned that its third-quarter earnings would not meet analysts' estimates because of weak demand for chemicals and equipment. Air Products expects profit from operations of 48 cents a share in the quarter ended June 30, below the average estimate of 56 cents from analysts. C3.
 
China's G.D.P. Expanded by 7.6%
China's gross domestic product expanded by a slower-than-expected 7.6 percent in the first six months of the year, as extra state spending on investment projects failed to spur growth in other parts of the economy. C2.

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT CASE FAVORS MICROSOFT

BYLINE: BySTEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
It was a David versus Goliath case, a courtroom confrontation between a struggling little software maker and the mighty Microsoft Corporation.
Microsoft was accused of befriending the fledgling company when it suited its interests and then callously casting the company aside when it was no longer useful, denying it access to Microsoft's technology on fair terms. The tactic, the plaintiff's lawyers argued, was a violation of Federal antitrust laws and all but a death sentence for Bristol Technology Inc. of Danbury, Conn. 
Yet yesterday, as an uptick in Microsoft's stock price lifted the personal wealth of William H. Gates to nearly $100 billion, a Connecticut jury of five men and three women, ranging in age from 21 to the late 60's, whose job status ran the gamut from unemployed to corporate executive, sided with Goliath.
The jury in Federal District Court in Bridgeport, Conn., found that Microsoft had not violated antitrust laws in its dealings with Bristol.
The private suit in Connecticut has no direct impact on the major antitrust challenge Microsoft faces -- the Federal case brought by the Justice Department and 19 states. The charges and evidence are different.
But antitrust experts said yesterday's verdict would certainly hearten the Microsoft legal team in Washington. Despite the differences, Microsoft has been portrayed in both cases as an overreaching monopolist that used its market power as a club -- a characterization supported by piles of Microsoft E-mail and internal documents that spoke forcefully of destroying rivals and leaning on partners.
"This is a decisive triumph for Microsoft, and it has to be a shot of adrenaline for the Microsoft lawyers working on the Government case," said William Kovacic, a professor at the George Washington University law school. "This verdict may not have any direct effect on the Government case, but it shows Microsoft that it can win these cases, even when much of the evidence in court is unflattering."
In celebrating their victory, the Microsoft lawyers certainly echoed the same themes of the company's defense in the Government case -- that its business practices are merely the rough-and-tumble of modern capitalism, and that the computer software market moves so rapidly that Microsoft can scarecly be considered an entrenched monopolist.
"The considered opinion of the community in which Bristol operates is that Microsoft did nothing wrong," said David Tulchin, a partner at Sullivan & Cromwell who was Microsoft's lead trial lawyer. "All that Microsoft did was compete hard."
Steve Aeschbacher, a senior corporate lawyer at Microsoft, said that the verdict strongly suggested that the jury was "impressed by all the evidence in the record of the intensity and dynamism of competition in the software industry."
The verdict, legal experts say, may help Microsoft avoid a wave of private antitrust suits in the future, by giving potential plaintiffs second thoughts. A trial is expected to start early next year in a private antitrust suit against Microsoft in Utah, filed by Caldera Inc. Two other private antitrust suits have been filed, one in California and one in Texas, though no trials are scheduled.
Bristol had sought a stiff financial penalty against Microsoft -- damages ranging from $130 million to $263 million, which, if Microsoft was found to violate antitrust laws, would have been tripled.
The jury did find that Microsoft had violated a Connecicut law prohibiting "deceptive practices," like making misleading statements to a business partner. But for that unspecificed transgression, the jury awarded Bristol $1.
"That's not even a parking ticket," observed Mr. Kovacic of George Washington University.
Not even that for Microsoft, which has nearly $22 billion in cash on hand, according to its most recent financial statement.
Bristol said it was disappointed by the outcome and that it was exploring the option of appealing. "We still firmly believe that Microsoft engaged in anticompetitive behavior against Bristol," said Keith Blackwell, Bristol's chief executive.
Patrick Lynch, a partner at O'Melveny & Myers and lead counsel for Bristol, said: "This is a case of great importance to the entire computer industry. While the ruling is disappointing to Bristol, this is an issue that is not going to go away. Microsoft's abuse of its dominant position has to be addressed."
Still, antitrust experts say the Bristol suit was a high-risk legal case from the outset. First, they say, the case focused on the software markets for computer work stations and so-called server computers, which feed data out to desktop machines in computer networks. In those markets, Microsoft is not nearly as dominant as it is in the market for desktop operating systems for personal computers, where its Windows software runs more than 90 percent of PC's sold.
Second, antitrust experts note that Bristol relied on the theory that Microsoft had a "duty to deal" with Bristol. And the experts point out that duty-to-deal cases, which regard the plaintiff almost as a regulated utility, have been difficult to win in recent years. The main exceptions, they note, have been in industries with traditions of regulation, like telecommunications, or businesses involving natural assets, like ski slopes.
Significantly, for its sweeping antitrust case, the Government did depose Mr. Blackwell of Bristol. But the Justice Department chose to focus instead on Microsoft's use of its market power derived from its dominance of the PC operating system market. The Government has charged that the company used its Windows monopoly to stifle competition from the rise of Internet software. And the Government also steered clear of any duty-to-deal claims.
"Bristol chose to bring a case in one of the most prodefendant areas of antitrust," said Robert E. Hall, an economist at Stanford University. "Courts have been very reluctant to say that companies must share their intellectual property."
Bristol makes software that allows programs written for Microsoft's Windows to run on work stations or servers that use Unix, an industrial-strength operating system popular among corporate users. In 1994, when Microsoft was still having trouble cracking into the market for corporate computing, it signed a three-year licensing deal with Bristol. It allowed Bristol broad access to Microsoft's Windows technology.
But three years later, when Microsoft's own powerful operating system, Windows NT, was making strong inroads into the corporate market, the deal offered to Bristol was very different. Microsoft wanted corporate customers to switch from Unix to Windows NT, and Bristol said that its "translation" software -- once an asset for Microsoft -- was now seen by Microsoft as a potential impediment to the migration of customers to Windows NT.
So when renegotiating the contract, Microsoft offered Bristol a new license, but at four times the price and with far less access to Microsoft technology. "Microsoft's dealings with Bristol are a classic bait-and-switch," Mr. Lynch, Bristol's lawyer, said before the trial began in June.
Microsoft did not deny that its license terms had changed, but it explained that was because the market conditions changed. Besides, Microsoft says that another company, Mainsoft Inc., accepted the same terms that were offered to Bristol. Microsoft argued that Bristol was trying to elevate a garden-variety contract dispute into an antitrust case.
In 1997, Inc. magazine ranked Bristol 140th among the 500 fastest-growing companies in the nation, with a payroll of 70 people and estimated revenues of $8 million. But the failure to renew its Microsoft license has placed Bristol's future in doubt, and it has spent heavily on its suit.
"Bristol's mistake was that it chose to litigate instead of negotiate," said Mr. Aeschbacher of Microsoft.
The jury in Connecticut agreed.

HEADLINE: Gates Hits $100 Billion Mark, More or Less

BYLINE: By AMY HARMON 

 BODY:
Last month, in the largest gift ever by a living person to a charitable foundation, William H. Gates, the chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, donated $5 billion to support education and health care causes.
Yesterday, in a few hours of stock market trading, Mr. Gates's holdings surged by just about that amount, brushing $100 billion for the first time. 
 The mixture of awe and dismay that has long characterized America's fixation on Mr. Gates's personal wealth was perhaps best summed up yesterday by Vincent Malgapo, a contributor to the Silicon Investor electronic discussion forums: "Bill Gates MSFT stock worth $100 Billion right now!" read the comment, which was posted at 11:41 A.M. "WOW!"
Mr. Gates, who owns 19.8 percent, or about one billion shares, of the company he co-founded in 1975, owes his world record to the remarkable performance of Microsoft's stock. Shares of the software company climbed 5.4 percent yesterday to a record high of $99.4375, on expectations that it will establish a separate tracking stock for its Internet properties.
The company is the first to top $500 billion in market value. If it were a country it would have the ninth-largest economy in the world, behind Spain, which has a gross domestic product of $553 billion.
But the ballooning of Microsoft's stock price simply does not hold the same fascination as that of its chairman's brokerage account.
"He finally did it," said Paul Saffo, director of the Institute for the Future in Menlo Park, Calif. "This is what we've all been waiting for. How much interest do you suppose it generates? I bet it's a 747 per day."
Philip Greenspun, creator of the Bill Gates Personal Wealth Clock, a Web site that continuously calculates the value of Mr. Gates's Microsoft stock, had a more pointed speculation.
"Maybe this will convince my students they shouldn't work so hard to become rich," said Mr. Greenspun, a researcher at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's laboratory for computer science. "Because they're probably not going to be richer than Bill Gates, so they might as well do something interesting and valuable to society instead."
At a time of sustained economic prosperity, America's proclivity to celebrate wealth is reflected in the high marks Mr. Gates still receives in national opinion polls. And the 43-year-old executive, who lives in a $60 million mansion on the shores of Lake Washington with his wife and two children, has recently begun to contribute more to philanthropy.
But the $100 billion mark may also mark a change in popular perception.
"Gates has crossed a psychological marker and it's going to increase pressure on him to recycle more and more of that money through his foundations," said Ron Chernow, an economic historian. "There will be more attention focused on the extraordinarily lopsided distribution of wealth."
Of course, Mr. Gates is not the only software entrepreneur to become fabulously wealthy in recent years. Microsoft's co-founder, Paul Allen, and its chief executive, Steve Ballmer, are among the world's five richest people, along with the investor Warren E. Buffett, whose 39.9 percent stake in the investment holding company Berkshire Hathaway Inc. is valued at about $42.5 billion, making him second to Mr. Gates.
Dozens of founders of fledgling Internet companies have become worth millions on paper in a matter of months.
And by some calculations, Mr. Gates is poorer than John D. Rockefeller, who had in excess of 2 percent of the gross national product at the peak of his wealth in 1913.
Still, it may not be long before Mr. Gates passes another milestone.
"The key is when he reaches a trillion," said Lewis D'vorkin, an executive editor at Forbes magazine, which publishes an annual list of the world's 400 richest people. "If Microsoft share price grows in the next five years as fast as it has in the last five, he hits the big one in 2004."

HEADLINE: Newspaper Columnist Suspended for Buying Stock Through Friend

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
A San Jose Mercury News business columnist was suspended indefinitely yesterday for taking advantage of a friend's offer to buy shares of a fledgling company at a price not available to the general public.
The columnist, Chris Nolan, told one of her editors about the offer before she bought 500 shares of Autoweb.com at the initial offering price of $14, but he offered no explicit approval or disapproval, according to Ms. Nolan. The columnist, whose "Talk Is Cheap" column focuses on the gossip of Silicon Valley's high-technology businesses, said she made about $9,000 by selling her stock within the first two days after Autoweb.com first offered stock for sale to the public in March. 
 David Yarnold, the executive editor of the Mercury News, said yesterday that he felt "she clearly placed us in a situation where the public could perceive the Mercury News to have a conflict of interest."
The newspaper's ethics policy forbids staff writers to make news decisions about companies in which they have a financial interest. It also stipulates that business writers should not invest in local businesses.
Ms. Nolan's situation, which was first reported in The Wall Street Journal, reflects the way the culture of quick profits from initial stock offerings has become a routine part of Silicon Valley life. It also shows the value of being invited to buy stock at the offering price.
What has not changed, however, are newspaper and newsmagazine ethics policies. They remain strict in forbidding business reporters and editors from having any financial stake in the companies they cover.
Ms. Nolan's case troubles some because she did seek her editors' guidance and permission. Ms. Nolan said in an interview that the chief executive of Autoweb.com, Dean DeBiase, "has been a friend for many years" and that "I felt this was an offer from a friend."
Ms. Nolan is a member of the local chapter of the Newspaper Guild, and a union executive confirmed that he is investigating the situation.
Ms. Nolan also said yesterday that she had also sold Fortune magazine a first-person account of her experience with Autoweb.com -- a freelance arrangement that she said her editors had approved. Mr. Yarnold said last night that while Ms. Nolan had mentioned the article to editors "in a passing way," she "did not have affirmative permission to submit the article to Fortune."
While some colleagues said there was some sentiment among reporters that the editor's reactions were overly harsh, the one reporter who spoke on the record, the economics correspondent Jonathan Rabinovitz, said: "I like Chris. I think Chris is a great reporter. But you don't do that. It's that simple."

HEADLINE: MOST IN H.M.O.'S WOULDN'T BENEFIT FROM SENATE BILL

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16

 BODY:
Despite all the talk about protecting people in health maintenance organizations, most people in H.M.O.'s would gain no tangible benefit from many of the consumer-protection standards approved by the Senate this week as part of a bill to define patients' rights, lawyers and health policy experts said.
Many of the bill's basic consumer protections would apply to 48 million people in group health plans regulated by the Federal Government. Few H.M.O.'s are in that category, according to data published recently in the journal Health Affairs. 
 Most of the 48 million people, it appears, get their health care through traditional fee-for-service arrangements or through loosely organized forms of managed care that are less restrictive than the H.M.O.'s whose decisions about care have angered many consumers.
Even the application of the measure to those 48 million is in doubt because President Clinton has said he would veto the measure, many aspects of which remained unclear until today, because a substitute was put forward at the last minute.
In four days of debate before the final vote on Thursday, Republican senators said repeatedly that they did not want to usurp the states' authority to regulate insurance. In general, they said, they wanted to set Federal standards for health plans that could not be regulated by the states -- "self-insured" health plans established by employers for their employees.
The study in Health Affairs, by two economists at the Rand Corporation, Susan Marquis and Stephen H. Long, finds that only 2 percent of employers offer H.M.O.'s that would be covered by these standards in the Senate bill. And only 9 percent of employees are in such H.M.O.'s, they said.
Craig Copeland, a research associate at the Employee Benefit Research Institute, a nonpartisan organization, said today that "only a small number of the 48 million people are in H.M.O.'s -- at most 10 percent."
In a "self-insured" health plan, the employer insures itself, bearing the financial risk for its employees' medical costs and often paying the claims out of the assets of the business. By contrast, most H.M.O.'s bear the financial risk for their members. In return for fixed monthly premiums, the H.M.O.'s promise to provide whatever care is needed and covered under the insurance contract.
Prof. Timothy S. Jost of Ohio State University, the co-author of a treatise on health law, said, "Usually if a plan is an H.M.O. operation, it would be fully insured and therefore exempt" from many standards in the Senate bill.
An H.M.O. is one type of managed care. In other forms of managed care, patients may receive a discount if they use certain doctors and hospitals, but they are not required to do so. Republicans said that many people in these managed-care plans would gain protection from the Senate-passed bill.
But there have been fewer complaints about these plans because they are less restrictive and generally do not require patients to get permission to see a specialist or to go outside the network of doctors recommended by the health plan.
Democratic senators often complained that the Republican bill was a sham, but it was impossible to evaluate those assertions until the full text of the legislation became available on Thursday night. The Senate Republican leader, Trent Lott of Mississippi, offered the substitute several hours before the final vote, and that substitute was the measure passed by a final vote of 53 to 47.
As lawmakers sorted through the legislation today, one thing seemed clear. If the bill becomes law, patients could not immediately be sure of their rights, and some employers could not be sure of their obligations, because those rights and duties depend on the details and structure of a person's health insurance plan.
Employees working side by side could thus have different rights and remedies, depending on whether they were in an H.M.O., a traditional insurance plan or some hybrid.
Under the Senate Republican bill, all group health plans would have to have procedures so patients could obtain "an independent external review" of decisions to deny coverage on the ground that a particular service was medically unnecessary or experimental.
At least 18 states already require such appeal procedures, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures. Adrienne Hahn, legislative counsel for Consumers Union, said the Senate bill would supersede the state laws, including some that provide patients with more protection.
Senate Republican aides said they did not know if the bill would pre-empt state laws that give patients more extensive appeal rights. And the bill itself does not say.
Several miscellaneous provisions of the bill, largely overlooked in the debate on Thursday night, drew sharp criticism from Democrats today.
One provision would kill an experimental program for H.M.O.'s in Phoenix. The demonstration project would encourage price competition among H.M.O.'s by requiring them to bid for the privilege of serving Medicare beneficiaries.
Senator Jon Kyl, Republican of Arizona, joined H.M.O.'s in opposing the project, which they said would disrupt the local insurance market. But Senator Bob Graham, Democrat of Florida, said it was outrageous to block a program that sought to use the free market to save money for taxpayers and for the Medicare program.
"The language to destroy this pilot project was buried in a 250-page bill, and nobody was given an opportunity to read it," Mr. Graham said today.
The effort to define patients' rights takes Congress into a legal swamp that surrounds a landmark 1974 law, the Employee Retirement Income Security Act, known as Erisa. The law, which governs health plans covering 125 million Americans, has been described by the Supreme Court as "an enormously complex and detailed statute."
A major purpose of the law was to establish uniform Federal standards for health and pension plans, on the theory that employers would be deterred from providing such benefits if they had to comply with conflicting state laws.
Many provisions of the Senate-passed bill are framed as amendments to Erisa. But it is difficult to know for sure who would be protected under provisions of the bill that would, for example, guarantee access to emergency care, obstetricians and other medical specialists.
Each of these standards applies, in the words of the bill, to "a group health plan (other than a fully insured group health plan)."
Other standards, which establish procedures for patients to appeal a denial of coverage, apply to "every employee benefit plan." Still other standards apply to "a group health plan" or an insurance company that offers coverage in connection with a group health plan.
Sheldon Weinhaus, a St. Louis lawyer who often represents patients, said these provisions of the bill were "an invitation to mischief." Mr. Weinhaus said, "No one really knows, with any precision, what is meant by the terms 'self-insured' and 'fully insured.' " Employers and insurers often share the risk of paying for catastrophic medical expenses, he added.
One of the stronger provisions in the Senate bill would require all health plans to pay for overnight hospital stays after breast cancer treatments, including mastectomy, if a woman and her doctor agreed that such a stay was "medically necessary and appropriate."
Unlike many other provisions, this one would cover anyone with private health insurance.

HEADLINE: What Price the Most Expensive Diamond of All?

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, July 16

 BODY:
Safeco Field, the most costly single-sport stadium in North America, opened for Major League Baseball on Thursday night, a $517 million expanse of art and green grass cradled by the marine air of Puget Sound and the hopes of fans long blanketed in misery. But what was once heralded as a grand local celebration of the national pastime is now soured by protests, legal threats and a growing squall over how much the public should pay for stadiums that enrich private owners.
The focus of the battle here is the Seattle Mariners' ownership group. The owners, who include Microsoft billionaires, promised to cover all cost overruns on the new park but have now stunned even the team's strongest allies by asking for tax dollars to pay for most of an overrun totaling $100 million, on top of $372 million that taxpayers have already contributed to the stadium's cost. 
 Elsewhere, team owners including Ross Perot Jr., who is using tax money to build an arena for his Dallas Mavericks basketball team, and George W. Bush, who saw the value of his stake in baseball's Texas Rangers rise to $15 million from $600,000 after the public financed a new stadium for the club, have figured in a debate that entwines the emotional threads of sports with the strands of politics.
"I think the public is at its limit," said Thomas M. Finneran, the Speaker of the Massachusetts House of Representatives, who led the fight to curb the amount his state would pay to keep the New England Patriots. The team is staying in Foxboro, Mass., with the help of $70 million in state road improvements, after backing out of a $375 million stadium deal with Connecticut.
"Our hearts are with the home team," Mr. Finneran said. "But more and more, people are saying enough of this kind of corporate welfare. And I think the sports owners asked for the backlash," by making exorbitant demands.
The new home of the Mariners, with its Internet kiosks, views of the Olympic Mountains and signature sculptures of baseball symbols, has been hailed by fans and design critics alike as a wondrous addition to Seattle. The 47,000-seat stadium -- which replaces the drab, 23-year-old Kingdome -- has a retractable roof, grass that can be automatically heated to bring it out of its dormancy in the spring and, hanging in a rotunda behind home plate, a chandelier of 1,000 translucent bats. Without the new stadium and the additional revenue that is expected as a result, it is unlikely that baseball could have remained in the city, said Bud Selig, the baseball commissioner.
But Safeco Field also has the distinction of being the first ball yard built with public money after voters said no to paying for it. It is a kind of dubious forerunner to stadiums that are scheduled to open in Milwaukee next year and in Pittsburgh in 2001, each built with tax dollars despite overwhelming, though nonbinding, votes against using taxes for them.
In Pennsylvania, what started as an effort to give one team, the Pittsburgh Pirates, a new stadium to keep it from leaving one of baseball's oldest venues ended up this year in the state's approval of public financing for a new home for each of four teams -- two in Pittsburgh, two in Philadelphia. The four stadiums will cost about $1 billion, at least two-thirds of which will be public money.
"Pennsylvania is a major league state, and we proved it today," Gov. Tom Ridge, a second-term Republican, said after guiding the stadium financing package through the Legislature.
But many others were outraged, particularly in the Philadelphia region, which had not been given a chance to vote on spending local tax dollars for new stadiums, and in Pittsburgh, which had been given the chance and rejected the idea.
"It boils down to politicians' giving more money to certain special interests that outweigh whatever voters may say," said Jake Haulk, director of the Allegheny Institute, a conservative public-policy organization in Pittsburgh. "They used to justify this on the grounds that these new stadiums were great economic generators, but they have abandoned that line. Now they just say, 'We need to be a world-class city, and taxpayers will have to pay for it.' "
At least 15 major sports complexes around the country are to open in the next three years, all but one, in San Francisco, financed by the public. Through the 1990's, nearly $11 billion in public money has been spent building and renovating sports centers.
In New York, both the Yankees and the Mets have asked the public to underwrite new baseball parks for them, although it appears that the Yankees will now most likely stay put in 76-year-old Yankee Stadium if $189 million in renovations are made in and around it.
Prompted by the runaway stadium plans of his home state, Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, has introduced a bill that would require Major League Baseball and the National Football League to pay at least 50 percent of the construction costs of new stadiums for their teams. For parks already being built, the owners are generally paying 10 to 30 percent, with the lone exception of San Francisco, where the Giants are privately financing the entire cost of $255 million Pacific Bell Park.
Senator Specter's bill has bipartisan support on the Senate Judiciary Committee but is strongly opposed by baseball and football owners, and other senators say it has only a slim chance of winning passage.
But a revolt of sorts is under way in a number of states. Gov. Jesse Ventura of Minnesota, for instance, has drawn a line against state financing of a new stadium for the Minnesota Twins despite ownership's repeated threats to move the team.
"No pushing things down people's throats," said Mr. Ventura, who last month set up a fund for Minnesotans who want to apply their state tax rebate toward construction of a new stadium. "This will be the state's contribution," the Governor said. "It's called put your money where your mouth is."
And in May, Arizona voters turned down a request by the owners of the Cardinals to finance a new football stadium. The vote followed by a year the opening of a $354 million stadium in Phoenix for baseball's Diamondbacks, a park financed largely by a sales tax increase.
The economics of major league sports, in which even mediocre players demand long-term contracts of $50 million or more, is largely behind the need for new stadiums and their revenue-enhancing features, like luxury boxes, corporate suites and innovative, interesting designs that can swell attendance.
"Could owners build and pay for their own stadiums?" said Allen Sanderson, a professor of economics at the University of Chicago who has written extensively about sports financing. "Yes, of course they could. But then they would make less money. So they go to the public instead."
In 1995, Seattle's voters narrowly turned down a proposal to raise the sales tax to build a new home for the Mariners. But later that year the team went on a magical run, coming from 13 games out of first place late in the season to win the division title and then beating the Yankees in the first round of the playoffs. A fan frenzy and the Mariners' demand for a new stadium prompted an emergency session of the Legislature, which gave the green light to a new taxing proposal. That proposal then went not to the voters but to the governing King County Council, which approved it.
The team's owners, a consortium of 16 members whose wealth is drawn largely from local high-technology enterprises and the Japanese-owned Nintendo Company, agreed to pay $45 million toward the new stadium -- most of which they raised by selling to the Safeco Corporation the right to name the park -- plus any cost overruns.
The owners say they have been losing more than $10 million a year, and with the prospect of $20 million in new annual revenue generated by Safeco Field, they ordered it rushed to completion. Then, just three weeks before it opened, they declared that tax dollars should be used to pay at least $60 million of the $100 million overrun. They are threatening suit for that amount against the Public Facilities District, the public agency that owns the stadium.
Political and business leaders who supported the team are furious. "I think all the unmitigated gall on the face of the earth right now resides at Mariner headquarters," said Cynthia Sullivan, a member of the King County Council.
Although they earlier promised to cover overruns, the team's owners say a close legal reading of the stadium financing contract supports their claim for additional public money. They have refused to respond in detail to questions about their position.
"I realize there are a lot of people who don't agree with us," said Howard Lincoln, a Mariner director who is chairman of Nintendo of America. "But even baseball owners are entitled to their day in court."
The baseball commissioner, Mr. Selig -- whose family, owner of the Milwaukee Brewers, is getting its own publicly financed stadium next year -- praised the Mariner owners, saying they were "heroes" who had lost $80 million since they bought the team seven years ago. "To me, they are the people that saved baseball in Seattle," Mr. Selig said. "Without them, there's no team here."
On Thursday night, protesters marched outside the Mariners' inaugural game at Safeco Field, holding signs reading, "No More Corporate Welfare" and "Keep Your Word."
Gov. Gary Locke offered advice to fans who feel conflicted. "It is not a contradiction," he said, "to say we love this stadium, and it's gorgeous and going to make people of the Pacific Northwest love baseball, but still insist that a contract is a contract, a deal is a deal."

Little Aid Seen in H.M.O. Bill

HEADLINE: In Iowa, Clinton Makes Case for School Spending

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER 

DATELINE: DES MOINES, July 16

 BODY:
President Clinton today pitched his $24.8 billion plan to modernize 6,000 schools, saying students could not do their best work in buildings "where kids walk up the steps and they see broken windows every day, where there are rooms, in some cases whole floors they can't even go on."
He also commiserated with Iowa's small farmers who have been hit hard by crop prices that have fallen below the cost of production in some cases. 
 Joking that he was the only noncandidate Iowans had seen in weeks, Mr. Clinton spoke in a newly refurbished, but sweltering, gymnasium at Amos Hiatt Middle School, a 74-year-old building where recent repairs were paid for through an $18 million Federal demonstration project. A line about how some schools do not even have working heating and air-conditioning systems got a huge laugh.
Mr. Clinton tied the need for school construction, through interest-free bonds, to the broader debate about how to spend the budget surplus.
"I believe before we pass a big tax cut we should save Social Security and Medicare and add a prescription drug benefit to Medicare," the President said.
But the outlook for Mr. Clinton's proposal in Congress is uncertain. It was defeated as an amendment to a tax bill this week in the House Ways and Means Committee.
"This is a time of confidence and pride," Mr. Clinton said of the current economic boom. "But the time to fix the roof is when the sun is shining, and that is literally true in the case of school construction."
These are not boom times in Iowa, though, and Mr. Clinton acknowledged that farmers were among those who have not shared the wealth.
Only a day earlier, he was criticized by George W. Bush, the Texas Governor and Republican Presidential contender, for ignoring the plight of farmers during his cross-country tour last week to highlight pockets of poverty.
Today, Mr. Clinton said, "The big problem on the farm is we've had four years in a row of worldwide record harvest for the first time in history, and an economic collapse in 1997 in Asia, so markets shrink, the products go, prices collapse."
At that point a woman in the crowd shouted, "Freedom to Farm!" referring to the Freedom to Farm Act, a 1996 law that phased out most direct crop subsidies and encouraged high production at a time when the Asian financial crisis had limited the buying power of overseas customers.
After the speech, Bill Sherman, a local lobbyist for the teachers union, said the farm crisis had, among other things, made it much harder to pass bond issues for school construction. "Until farmers can make a decent living, it will be very difficult to get decent facilities, especially in rural areas," Mr. Sherman said.
Later in the afternoon, Mr. Clinton had a closed meeting with a group of farmers who planned to talk to him about the importance of pushing for changes in the Freedom to Farm law, with the soft prices and bumper crops causing a repeat of the farm crisis in the 1980's, but with much less national attention.
Mr. Clinton was also to appear at two evening fund-raisers for Senator Tom Harkin, who said in an interview after his school speech that it was important for the President to come to Iowa to hear about the farm crisis firsthand. "This is the worst I've seen," he said. "It's worse now than in the mid-80's."
A recent report by the Agriculture Department projected the average prices for corn and soybean for this year at about half the prices of only a few seasons ago.
With commodity prices falling below production costs, Mr. Harkin said, an aid package for struggling grain farmers and livestock producers was desperately needed. "Every day we wait is going to cost us more," he said.
